HEADLINE: Market Place;
Round the World, Bond Profits Soar

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
FOR bondholders around the world, the summer of 1991 was a joyous time. With interest rates generally falling, their profits soared.
For American investors, the advantages of investing overseas have been enhanced even further by the dollar's recent weakness. After rising sharply early in the year, the dollar gave up some of its gains in the third quarter, and that served to accelerate profits from foreign markets. 
 In the third quarter, J. P. Morgan reported yesterday, government bonds in 9 of the 12 countries it monitored produced a total dollar return of at least 10 percent. The return, including coupon interest payments, capital appreciation and currency changes, ranged from 14.88 percent in Britain to 5.33 percent in the United States, where there was of course no benefit from the dollar's depreciation.
Over all, the global return in dollars for the J. P. Morgan Government Bond Index was 7.68 percent, the highest quarterly return since the fourth quarter of 1987, when interest rates fell around the world as central banks eased credit in the wake of the stock market crash. The gain then was 11.97 percent.
The gains in local currencies during the quarter were less impressive, ranging from 1.84 percent in the Netherlands to 7.18 percent in Canada, but they were still impressive, and related to the general slowness in world economies, which has dampened inflationary fears. While there has been much talk about economic revival in countries that fell into recessions, the evidence of such gains is still mixed at best. The three best bond markets in the quarter, on a local currency basis, were Canada, Britain and Australia, all of which have been in recessions.
J. P. Morgan calculated that on a global basis the average gain in local currencies was 4.91 percent, the best of the year but trailing behind the 5.47 percent in the fourth quarter of 1990.
The figures for this year's third quarter are through last Friday. Trading yesterday, the final session of the quarter, was generally quiet, and it was not expected to change the results significantly.
The profits in bond markets around the world helped to whet the appetite of American investors, who continued to pour cash into mutual funds that specialize in foreign bonds, even during the first part of 1991, when a strong dollar was making life painful for owners of such bonds.
During the first eight months of this year, global bond funds reported cash inflows of $6.4 billion, compared with $5.6 billion for all of 1990. The surge of cash into those funds began in August 1990, amid worry over American investments and declining short-term interest rates.
Much of that money has gone into short-term funds, which involve little interest-rate risk because they invest in the equivalent of Treasury bills around the world, seizing the higher interest rates available in many other markets. Those funds get the advantages of a depreciating dollar, but give up the potential of capital gains.
At the end of August, assets of such global bond funds had risen to $20.5 billion, well over twice the level of $8.6 billion that had prevailed a year earlier. Of that $20.5 billion, more than 40 percent was in short-term investments, according to figures released last week by the Investment Company Institute.
One fund manager who contends that emphasis on short maturities is a mistake is Leslie Nanberg of MFS Worldwide Governments Trust. He predicts interest rates will continue to fall, and that those who focus on short-term investments overseas are giving up opportunities to prosper.
The Morgan bond indexes are based on government bonds available for trading, and thus are not completely comparable between countries. For example, the United States and Britain have more bonds with decades to go until maturity, while some European countries have much shorter credit structures, making the possibility of capital gains, or losses, less likely.
For the first nine months of this year, the best bond markets, including currency gains, were those in Australia and Canada, both countries that have been mired in recession and have brought down interest rates without damaging their currencies. The third best market was Japan, where bond bullishness has grown rapidly in recent months, as the economy and monetary growth have slowed.

HEADLINE: In Search of Greener Showrooms

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Tony Salcido, who sells Toyotas in Puente Hills, Calif., is the kind of salesman who makes car companies both smile and cringe.
As the top salesman at his dealership, he helps move a lot of cars and keep Toyota's assembly lines humming. But Mr. Salcido's loyalty is to his paycheck, not his brand. 
 In the past, when sales of one type of car have cooled, he has never hesitated to change jobs and sell what is hot -- and profitable. Mr. Salcido, who began his current job two months ago, has changed dealers four times since February.
Auto makers worry increasingly that the people selling their products know too little about the features of the cars and do not sell them long enough to develop repeat customers or take advantage of referrals. Recently, manufacturers have trumpeted a host of new programs and incentives aimed at reducing turnover on the sales floor.
Just last week, the General Motors Corporation announced a deferred bonus program, which beginning next year will give salespeople a $50 bonus for every car they sell; G.M.'s Cadillac division will pay $75 a car. But these bonuses would be awarded only if the sales representative remained at the dealership until 1995.
The program, to be jointly financed by G.M. and the dealers, is voluntary. The company said it hoped as many as two-thirds of its dealers would participate. The Ford Motor Company is studying the G.M. idea, which is an adaptation of a program that Volkswagen is using in North America.
About 40 percent of people who stop selling cars for a dealer move to another field, according to one survey. But the majority are people who have been promoted off the showroom floor or moved on to another dealer. Besides deferred-bonus programs to retain good salespeople, other approaches include campaigns to instill a heightened sense of professionalism in the much disparaged car-sales business.
The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation have established certification programs within the last year that require sales staff to attend training sessions and pass exams on product knowledge. Certification also depends upon earning passing grades from customer surveys on how well the salespeople served their customers' needs. The National Automobile Dealers Association, meantime, plans to start the Society of Automotive Sales Professionals next year, complete with wall plaques and lapel pins for members who pass tests on product knowledge and salesmanship.
 
'Tremendous Heartburn'
 Industry surveys estimate that annual turnover runs between 35 and 50 percent, although it reaches more than 100 percent a year at some dealerships.
"Turnover causes us tremendous heartburn," said Robert Coletta, general sales and service manager for G.M.'s Buick division. Salespeople, he said, need about a year to fully understand a manufacturer's products and a dealer's procedures. And as cars grow more complex, he added, that learning period grows longer.
One of the earliest deferred bonus plans began two years at Volkswagen, which for every car sold pays the sales representative $150 -- in three installments, spread over two years. The bonus comes on top of whatever commission the dealer pays the sales staff. Volkswagen officials have no statistics on whether the program has reduced turnover, but they say dealers have told them it has helped.
Audi of America offers yearly bonuses of $6,000 to salespeople who sell 60 cars, and $12,000 and a trip to Germany to those who push 120 cars out the door. The wait is not as long as with Volkswagen's program but the idea is the same: to keep top producers in the fold, some of whom had left as sales drooped.
"If you lose a guy who's worth a hundred cars a year, it's like losing a whole dealer," said Joseph H. Tate, general sales manager of Audi of America.
Fritz Hitchcock, the owner of the Toyota dealership where Mr. Salcido works, calls the traditional commission system "very destructive." But Mr. Hitchcock, who has set up his own deferred-bonus program, doubts whether other alternatives -- some sort of guaranteed salary, say -- would be the answer. "It's hard to figure out if a guy is giving you his all if he's on a guarantee as opposed to a commission," Mr. Hitchcock said.
Mr. Salcido and other salesmen said that deferred bonus programs like the one offered by General Motors were a nice perk, but were not enough to make salespeople stick around after several slow months at a dealership. "It's an extra, but people want money now, said one Detroit-area car salesman who insisted that he not be identified. "My mortgage bill is now."
 
An Inherently Transient Business
 Salespeople and car dealers say they applaud any programs designed to reduce turnover and improve the image of salespeople. But many also believe the incentives or courses do not address the fundamental realities of selling cars that make it such a transient business: long hours, few benefits and unpredictable paychecks.
Mr. Salcido, the Toyota salesman, draws no salary at all. He earns 20 percent -- about $200 -- of the gross profit on each car he sells, plus bonuses for meeting volume goals. In addition, there is the deferred bonus program created by his boss, Mr. Hitchcock, which involves a six-month lag.
In pursuit of these emoluments, Mr. Salcido works about 65 hours a week and often comes in on his scheduled days off. He expects to make $50,000 this year, about twice the earnings of the average salesman in the current sluggish market.
"When you're running this type of system," he said, "you feel very insecure when you take a day off."
The new "sales professionals" society being set up by the National Automobile Dealers Association will require that members pass several training "modules," each containing six one-hour audio tapes, written homework, tests and training seminars. "The program hits hard on developing long-term customer loyalty, which is really what we're in business for," said Robert W. Nagel, a Casper, Wyo., G.M. and Jeep-Eagle dealer and chairman of the association's certification committee.
Mr. Nagel said the program was also designed to counter the negative self-image of many car sellers. "A lot of salespeople don't like to admit they sell autos," he said.
Many dealers have started hiring younger salespeople with no experience selling cars, in hopes that they will remain loyal to those who trained them.
"If I can get a fresh, energetic person who hasn't sold cars before and is willing to listen and accept training from us and the manufacturer, they can make a real good, loyal associate," said Ramsay Gillman, who owns several types of American and Japanese dealerships in Houston, San Antonio and Austin, Tex.
 
Nurturing the Customer
 The traditional high-volume, sales-commission approach is at odds with a shift in the industry to broaden salespeople's role to include more nurturing of customers current and past. Many of Nissan's Infiniti dealers, for exmple, now pay commissions based in part on how well each sales representative scores in customer-satisfaction surveys.
For all the innovations in the industry, though, many car dealers voice skepticism over how well the new programs will work. The best solution for high turnover in the sales ranks, they say, would be a stronger economy.
In the view of James B. Woulfe, owner of Shamrock Ford in Dublin, Calif., "The only thing that is going to solve the problem is when the market turns up."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls as Gold Rises On Soviet Reserves Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
But gold prices advanced. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $354 an ounce, up $4.90 from Friday. The Republic National Bank of New York said gold rose $4.75, to a late bid price of $353.75 an ounce.
Dealers said the dollar traded in a relatively narrow range throughout the session, while sentiment toward the currency remained bearish. 
 Investors are awaiting the Government's release on Friday of jobless data for September. "That is seen to be the next key factor that will influence Fed policy," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with IDEA, an investment advisory firm.
Economists expect the Federal Reserve will move to cut interest rates again to help stimulate the economy. At the same time, lower interest rates generally have a negative influence on the dollar because they make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors.
"Participants are not willing to take on any new positions," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. "The dollar is vulnerable to the downside, while the high-yielding currencies attracted a lot of buying interest," he said.
A sharp rise in the price of gold, attributable to reports that the Soviet Union's gold reserves were dwindling, also put pressure on the dollar, as money fund managers shifted into precious metals on the assumption that gold had greater upside potential than currencies.
The Soviets were thought to be selling gold to pay for imports and to make debt payments. But gold prices slid from their session highs in domestic dealings.
"People have to realize that those who bought gold can also become sellers," Mr. Chandler said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at a seven-month low of 132.95 yen, down 0.87 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 132.85 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 132.95 yen, down from 133.15 yen on Friday.
In London, the pound rose to $1.7525, from $1.7370 late on Friday. In New York, it cost $1.7500 to buy a pound, more expensive than $1.7435 on Friday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Southwest Air Makes Bid for Midway Assets

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The Southwest Airlines Company emerged as a second bidder today for Midway Airlines' assets. But unlike Northwest Airlines, Southwest said it had no interest in acquiring all of Midway, which is in bankruptcy.
Southwest's $30 million package exceeds by $10 million the deal offered last week by Northwest to help Midway out of bankruptcy. 
 But Midway officials were wary. David R. Hinson, the chairman, said the airline was reviewing Southwest's proposal "but, preliminarily, we are very skeptical about its feasibility."
Officials for the airlines were discussing the offer in Chicago, a Southwest spokesman, Ed Stewart, said.
"We are not interested in acquiring Midway," Mr. Stewart said. "This is basically an agreement to buy gates and lend money."
He said the offer was aimed at keeping Midway alive for the good of Midway Airport in Chicago. The carriers operate out of Midway, but neither flies out of Chicago's largest airport, O'Hare International.
Midway, which sought Federal bankruptcy court protection in March, still serves at least two dozen cities from Midway Airport.
Southwest, based in Dallas, said it had offered to buy 10 of Midway's 21 gates at Midway Airport for $10 million and sublease some of the gates back to the airline. The carrier also offered to lend Midway $20 million, repayable over five years and secured by a lien on Midway's additional assets at the airport.
Southwest, with 2.4 percent of the market, is the nation's 10th-largest airline. It uses a low-fare, single-class strategy that has helped bring it $47.1 million in profits last year, when most other carriers were being economically devastated.
Midway agreed on Sept. 23 to sell all of its gates at Midway Airport, as well as related operations, to Northwest for $20 million and to lease them back for a year.
Midway and Northwest also agreed last week to begin negotiations that could lead to Northwest acquiring the rest of Midway's assets.
Midway and Northwest signed a letter of intent, which is subject to approval by the Federal bankruptcy court. A hearing is set for Oct. 8.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Southwest's stock fell 37.5 cents, to $24.375, while Midway's rose 12.5 cents, to $2.

HEADLINE: Blackstone Unit to Buy Days Inns

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
A Blackstone Group subsidiary that owns the Ramada and Howard Johnson hotel chains agreed yesterday to pay $250 million for Days Inns of America Inc., the 1,214-unit franchise system burdened by some $750 million in debt.
If approved by the bankruptcy court, the transaction, which could be derailed if a better offer appeared -- would create one of the world's largest hotel franchisers. The three chains combined now operate 2,236 hotels with 284,000 rooms. 
 Days Inns also said it had filed for Chapter 11 reorganization on Friday in Wilmington, Del., shortly before three bondholders filed an involuntary bankruptcy petition that day in Manhattan.
 
Default on Interest Payments
 Those bondholders -- Northern Life Insurance, Northwestern National Life Insurance and High Income Advantage Trust -- said in their petition that Days Inns had defaulted on interest payments to them.
The buyer, Hospitality Franchise Systems, is a subsidiary of Blackstone Capital Partners, which is owned by the Blackstone Group, a leveraged buyout firm formed in 1985 by Peter G. Peterson and Stephen A. Schwarzman.
The transaction would also intensify Hospitality's spirited rivalry with Choice Hotels International, an affiliate of Manor Care Inc., a nursing home company in Silver Spring, Md. Choice's seven chains, including Comfort, Quality and Econo Lodge, have 2,245 hotels in operation with 210,000 rooms, plus an additional 514 hotels under construction.
 
Possible Bid by Rival Group
 Last year, Hospitality outbid Choice for Ramada and Howard Johnson, paying Prime Motor Inns Inc. $175 million. Choice, in turn, bought Econo Lodge, Friendship Inns and Rodeway for $75 million. Andrew R. Heyer, managing director of the Argosy Group, the financial adviser to Days Inns, said yesterday that Choice "expressed some interest on behalf of an investor group" in acquiring Days Inns, which Choice would then operate.
"If this acquisition is approved, it will give Hospitality a strong position in three segments of the market," said Dan Daniele, director of hospitality industry consulting for Ernst & Young in Chicago. Rates at Days Inns average $30 to $40 a day; at Howard Johnson's they average $40 to $50, and at the Ramada inns, $50 to $60.
While cautioning that the agreement is subject to approval, Henry R. Silverman, the chairman and chief executive of Hospitality, described it as a "classic strategic investment."
Reservations and advertising make up about 80 percent of a franchiser's costs, Mr. Silverman said, and with 1,214 additional units, Hospitality would be able to negotiate lower rates for its advertisements and for its toll-free reservations lines. That saving would translate into lower rates for the franchise operators, who contribute to a chain's advertising and reservations costs.
Mr. Silverman is no stranger to Days Inns. The Atlanta-based chain was a small operation when he joined Reliance Group Holdings Inc. in 1982, and the following year he formed the Reliance Capital Group, a leveraged-buyout firm. Reliance bought Days Inns in 1984, and Mr. Silverman, as chairman and chief executive of the chain, quickly expanded it to about 1,000 properties.
 
Sold for Profit 2 Years Ago
 Two years ago Mr. Silverman sold Days Inns to Tollman-Hundley Hotels, the largest Days Inns franchisee, for $765 million. The original investors, he said, made four to five times the $30 million they put up for the chain. Mr. Silverman joined Blackstone in January 1990.
If the economy had remained sound, Mr. Heyer said, the purchase would have been a good one. But the hotel industry fell into one of the deepest slumps in its history, with 60 percent of the hotels in the United States currently experiencing a net operating loss.
Mr. Heyer said the creditors are largely insurance companies, mutual funds and money managers, probably 30 or 40 of which are owed more than $1 million. The largest creditor, he said, is the First Executive Corporation, and others include CNA Financial and Allstate Insurance.
John D. Snodgrass, the president and chief operating officer of Days Inns, said the three bondholders who filed for involuntary bankruptcy "represent 6 percent of the debt."
Mr. Snodgrass added that the operating company -- the individual franchises -- "has done very well," generating more than enough cash to cover operating expenses.
 
Oversupply of Hotels
 Analysts say it will be at least two and possibly as many as five years before demand catches up with the oversupply of hotels, many of them built in the early 1980's to take advantage of easy financing and generous tax laws.
But the economy end of the hotel business -- or "limited service hotels," as Mr. Silverman said he preferred to call it -- is the fastest-growing segment of the industry. In the first six months of this year, while the average occupancy rate fell to 60 percent -- far below the average 65 percent break-even point -- the occupancy rate at economy hotels averaged 62.4 percent.
In addition, franchise operators have avoided many of the financial woes that have plagued other hotel operations.
"A franchiser gets a percentage of gross room sales, plus money for advertising and reservations," Mr. Daniele said. "And they are not saddled with all the real estate. The key is for them to get as many hotels in place in as many locations as possible, to make the advertising and marketing more economical. But to grow, a franchiser has to position itself as strong and attentive."
Under the agreement with Days Inns, Hospitality Franchise System is to pay $250 millon, of which at least $210 million -- cash and about 25 percent of Hospitality's equity -- is expected to be paid to Days Inns and its subsidiaries. Hospital's affiliate, the Days Inns Acquisition Corporation, which was formed specifically for this transaction, expects to commence a tender offer to purchase $40 million principal amount of Days Inns bonds for $40 million in cash.
If approved, the affiliate will acquire the Days Inns franchise system, including the Days Inns name, trademarks and support services.

HEADLINE: Another Strong Quarter for Wall St. Fees

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Despite the recession, American corporations maintained their strong appetite for cash from the stock and bond markets in the third quarter, bringing a healthy flow of fees to Wall Street investment houses.
The quarter also saw a significant change in the rankings of the top securities underwriters, as securities firms apparently dashed to capture market share lost by Salomon Brothers Inc., which has been shaken by the Treasury market scandal since August, and from Goldman, Sachs & Company. 
 But all of the firms had more business in the quarter than they had a year earlier. Rushing to take advantage of lower interest rates, which reduce borrowing costs, corporations raised $141.6 billion in the third quarter, up 94 percent from the $73 billion raised in the quarter last year, according to the Securities Data Company, a research firm in New York.
The good third-quarter results also brought a strong flow of fees to Wall Street investment houses for the second consecutive quarter. Fees nearly tripled, to $996.9 million, from $352.3 million in the third quarter of 1990.
Salomon also received higher fees, but its piece of the pie was much smaller than in the third quarter of last year. For the quarter, Salomon ranked sixth in fees, compared with second in the third quarter of 1990.
Over all, Salomon slid to sixth place in the rankings of underwriters, with 8.2 percent of the market, down from third place in the preceding quarter. The drop appeared to accentuate a fall that had already been under way at the firm, which was ranked third in the equivalent quarter of 1990 with 12 percent of the market.
The decline hits at a business that has been one of the most important for Salomon. The firm was a perennial leader in the underwriting business through most of the 1980's. It was overtaken by Merrill Lynch & Company in 1988.
Salomon executives attributed the decline partly to the firm's decision to be less aggressive in bidding for competitive deals, extending itself less in the aftermath of the Treasury scandal because of narrow profit margins.
The executives also said that the firm's performance was better than the data indicated because of flaws from improperly counted deals. The methodology of the underwriting rankings has long been attacked by the firms that ranked low, and praised by those with strong showings.
In the first nine months of 1991, corporations issued $408.3 billion in domestic securities, a 71 percent increase over the $238.2 billion raised in the equivalent period of 1990, according to Securities Data.
The growth in underwritings got its biggest push from the drop in interest rates in the third quarter, underwriters said. Many companies that had been holding out for lower rates finally found rates so attractive that they plunged into the marketplace.
"I was thinking the third quarter was going to be soft, but it turned out to be pretty active," said Dave Komansky, executive vice president of global equity markets at Merrill Lynch. "Our view of the fourth quarter looks as though it will continue to be surprisingly strong."
Added Jessica Palmer, managing director and head of capital markets at Salomon, "The rundown in rates we have seen over the last couple of months has brought a fair number of issuers out of the woodwork."
The quarter had the second-highest quarterly volume of stock and bond offerings in history, falling behind only the previous quarter, when a record $154.5 billion of securities were issued.
Merrill Lynch was the biggest underwriter in the third quarter, dealing $24.4 billion in domestic securities, or 17.3 percent of the market, according to Securities Data.
Lehman Brothers captured second place in the rankings, with 12.3 percent of the market, climbing over its fourth-place ranking at the end of the second quarter and its seventh-place spot in the third quarter of last year. Lehman Brothers underwrote $17.5 billion in the third quarter, compared with $4.8 billion in the comparable period of 1990.
The First Boston Corporation was third in the rankings, moving up from sixth place at the end of the second quarter. The firm underwrote $14.9 billion in securities, or 10.5 percent of the market, in the third quarter.
Goldman, Sachs, which had been ranked second in the second quarter, slipped to fourth, underwriting $14.5 billion, for a 10.2 percent share of the market.
Initial public offerings continued to be strong in the quarter, with $6.6 billion in new securities issued. That compares with the anemic $1.6 billion issued in the third quarter of 1990.

HEADLINE: Fall in Soviet Oil Exports Said to Force Sale of Gold

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Leonid A. Abalkin, a senior economic adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, said yesterday that the recent sharp decline in Soviet oil exports had forced the nation to sell off gold reserves to pay for imports and to make payments on foreign debt.
Although Mr. Abalkin said he did not have figures at hand, he generally confirmed disclosures in Moscow on Friday and yesterday that the central Government's gold reserves were well below Western estimates of how much gold was available to help meet foreign payments. 
 "The traditional understanding that the Soviet Union has large stocks of gold reserves is a mythical one," Mr. Abalkin said in a telephone interview from Duke University in Durham, N.C., where he visited the business school. Only half the gold mined in the Soviet Union, he said, goes into central bank reserves; the other half is for industrial use or jewelry.
 
Hedge Against Inflation
 "Given the existing level of Soviet inflation, we cannot get people to sell gold back to the state," Mr. Abalkin said. Gold, valued as it is in hard currency -- currently about $350 an ounce -- serves for Russians today as a hedge against the Soviet Union's high inflation rate, now more than 100 percent a year.
Western estimates of the Soviet Union's gold reserves, including estimates by the Central Intelligence Agency, put them at 500 to 1,000 metric tons. But Grigory A. Yavlinksky, another senior Soviet economist and the architect of a plan to move the nation toward a market economy, said on Soviet television on Friday that the reserves were only 240 metric tons, worth nearly $3 billion.
The Yavlinsky estimate was disputed yesterday by Aleksandr N. Doumnov, a deputy managing director of the Soviet State Bank. The Associated Press quoted him from Moscow as having said that the reserves were actually 374.5 metric tons, worth about $4.6 billion -- still well below Western estimates.
 
3 Possibilities Raised
 The disclosures raised three possibilities to two Western experts on the Soviet Union, David M. Kemme, an economist at Wichita State University, and Jacques Sapir of the School of Higher Studies in Social Sciences in Paris. One is that Mr. Gorbachev's advisers underreported gold reserves to strengthen their case for foreign assistance.
Another possibility is that the dwindling gold reserves would prevent the central Government from tying the ruble to a gold standard, to help control inflation. And finally, Mr. Sapir said, "the central Government might be understating reserves to avoid giving part of the stock to the Russian Republic."
Whatever the politics, oil apparently played a role. Mr. Abalkin said that the central Government had been forced to sell gold for hard currency because of a sharp drop in Soviet oil exports -- to just over two million barrels a day now from nearly four million in 1988. Oil and gas sales abroad account for roughly half the nation's export income.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Decline at Disney

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Sept. 30

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company continues to feel the effects of the recession, with attendance declines at its theme parks and resorts, said Michael D. Eisner, the chairman. He characterized the decline as "bigger than a bread basket." The chief financial officer, Richard D. Manula, said earnings for the fiscal year would be $4.75 to $4.80 a share, versus $6 a share in the 1990 year.

HEADLINE: Life Support for the Recovery

BYLINE: BY SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
With consumers cautious and service industries in the throes of cost-cutting, America's factories are likely to serve as the main life-support system for the weak recovery.
Manufacturing has been fitfully tugging the rest of the economy out of recession. Factory production has been climbing for five straight months and should continue to outpace sales of services in the coming months, economists and executives say. 
 By itself, the rebound in manufacturing has not been robust enough to propel a brisk economic recovery.
 
Disproportionate Impact
 But manufacturing's comeback is apt to aid the rest of the economy enough to keep the recovery alive. Even though factories employ just one in five American workers, they have provided nearly three-fourths of the meager gain of 110,000 jobs since the economy hit bottom in the spring. Manufacturers also get credit for more than a third of the rise in total private wage income since March.
Manufacturing's disproportionate impact on the economy is not all that surprising. While factory employment is down from around 30 percent of the work force in the mid-1960's, manufacturing's share of the gross national product, at 22 percent, is about the same now as it was then.
As factories churn out more goods, they buy more services and other goods from other businesses. They also fatten workers' paychecks, which in turn inspires greater consumer spending and larger tax collections.
That is exactly what's been happening at the General Motors plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., according to its manager, Gus Beirne. Although the auto industry in general remains weak, this factory, which makes mini-vans, has benefited from depleted dealer inventories and the manufacture of vans with more new features. Since last spring, the plant has recalled laid-off workers, assigned overtime and, more recently, added Saturday production. Its use of services, from recycling and waste-hauling to materials deliveries, is up sharply.
"There's no question that the G.M. plant has picked up and that's helped us," said D. Joseph Fleming, president of Falcon Transport in Youngstown, Ohio, which hauls truckloads of steel from U.S. Steel and LTV to G.M. Higher production is even helping the village government that sells the plant its water. North Tarrytown's Mayor, Frank Rey, reports that revenue from that source, though still depressed, is now going up. Local shops and restaurants, however, have yet to see their business improve much.
So far, in fact, the manufacturing recovery has been modest by past standards. Factory output and employment have not so far recouped more than a fraction of the ground lost during the recession. Computer makers and military contractors are in the midst of long-term restructuring. And though manufacturing output fell five times as much as overall G.N.P. during the recession, its decline was mild by past standards and suggests that the recovery will not be as robust either.
But barring an unexpected collapse in consumer or business sales, manufacturing is likely to continue expanding as companies replenish their inventories. Stocks of unsold goods in stores, warehouses and factories have been shrinking rapidly since last fall. But the latest readings show that inventory reductions, which shaved nearly two points off G.N.P. during the spring, may have started to ease in July. Now business is reordering freely. Factory order backlogs are rising. It is the classic pattern for a recovery.
The dynamic is clearest in cars and trucks, despite disappointing sales. Motor vehicle inventories have fallen from a 70-day supply in February to 50 days now. Production was a fifth higher in the summer than the spring, possibly adding as much as one percentage point to third-quarter G.N.P., according to Richard B. Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
Consumers, still worried by layoffs, could use more help from the factories. Factory wage income, about a fifth of total income, has recently advanced at a 6 percent annual rate, faster than after the 1981-2 recession. Partly that reflects a jump in pay: hourly compensation was up strongly in the spring, according to the latest available data. One reason is that manufacturers are relying on increases in overtime, with higher pay rates, to raise production.
Increasingly, however, wages are getting a lift from rising payroll employment. "The expansion in manufacturing is as healthy as in any recovery," said David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
Manufacturers expect to step up hiring this fall, according to a new survey by the Milwaukee-based Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary help concern. Among manufacturers, 21 percent say they anticipate more hiring this fall while just 10 percent of durables manufacturers and 13 percent of nondurables manufacturers see more cuts. These responses provide the second straight quarterly improvement in hiring plans, a good leading indicator of actual hiring.
 
Servicing Manufacturers
 Better times for manufacturers are brightening the picture for companies that sell business services. They added 23,000 new jobs in August. On average, manufacturers buy about one-sixth of what service companies sell, according to Inforum, a University of Maryland consulting enterprise that focuses on the links among industries.
That portion rose in the 1980's as more manufacturers contracted out all sorts of services, ranging from cafeteria management and cleaning crews to advertising, data processing and guard services. Every dollar of added auto production now generates about 50 cents for service businesses from car dealers and body shops to truckers.
One kind of business service, temporary help, is especially in demand among manufacturers right now. "When you have slimmed down the work force and you get some activity, you have to get some people," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of Manpower Inc. "Businesses don't want to get into hiring mode though, just after trimming."
Manpower's business has been on the mend since April, Mr. Fromstein said, with hours billed in August ahead of figures a year ago. The biggest gains, he said, reflect calls for assembly-line workers from companies in food processing, pharmaceuticals, electronics and packaging.
 
Cutbacks Could Be Harmful
 The factory revival faces several uncertainties. Since a third of all factory orders, for everything from paper plates to giant generators, come from service companies, overzealous cutbacks in retailing, finance and other services could harm the manufacturers. But that fear seems overblown, Mr. Fromstein said. Health-care companies are still hiring. Wall Street, which has been hacking away at payrolls for four years, is finally seeing healthier profits and adding a few new jobs.
As a result, private services employment, which performed more poorly in this recession than in most others, is already inching up. Moreover, the Manpower hiring survey indicates that except for government, service companies -- especially retailers and wholesalers -- plan to resume hiring this fall. Service companies also plan modest increases in purchases of equipment this fall.
The larger worry is that the factory revival will fizzle before consumer spending picks up again. "If consumers and businesses don't keep buying," said Jill Thompson, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, "manufacturers can't keep spending."
Right now, the prospects look better on the business side. Outlays on equipment, though weak, are not falling. Equipment orders, which bottomed out in May, surged in July and lost only part of that gain in August.
Exports also seem to be holding up better than expected. They will almost certainly slow from their astonishing pace last spring, when exports of goods other than agricultural products surged at a 22 percent annual rate. According to Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the business survey committee of the National Assocation of Purchasing Managers, export orders have leveled out, but not declined.
Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley, said, "The leadership in this recovery has been and will continue to be manufacturing."

HEADLINE: Nebraska Senator Enters the 1992 Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 30

 BODY:
To the strains of Bruce Springsteen's "Born to Run," Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska entered the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today and asserted that a short-sighted and cynical Federal Government was robbing young Americans of their birthright of good jobs, good educations and national greatness.
Mr. Kerrey, whose political odyssey began as a Navy Seal in Vietnam, where he won the Medal of Honor, accused the Republicans of a decade of "malignant neglect" that had left the nation adrift. 
 His speech was an echo, in spirit if not in langugage, of John F. Kennedy's 1960 appeal to "get the country moving again." Against the backdrop of the Nebraska Capitol, which Mr. Kerrey portrayed as a monument to prairie optimism in the depths of the Depression, the 48-year-old Senator said he hoped to touch off another era of national renewal.
"I want to lead America's fearless, restless voyage of generational progress," Mr. Kerrey said. "We have been led off course by a Federal Government whose engine has become inertia, whose direction is drift, and whose compass is cynicism."
Mr. Kerrey's speech reflected many of the traits that his allies say will serve him well in this late-starting race for the nomination. It was emotionally hot, an effort to provide the kind of inspirational leadership that many Democrats believe has been lacking in their party.
Mr. Kerrey's indictment was as much against a state of mind as against a party, asserting that continued inaction by the Federal Government had let the economy, the schools, the cities, the infrastructure of highways and bridges founder.
"Unless we do things differently now," he said, the nation in the year 2000 will be a grim place "where stagnant incomes will force them into more hours at work and less time with their children, where homeownership and college tuition and even adequate health care will be beyond the reach of all but the wealthiest."
It is time, he said, "for leadership that focuses its attention on posterity, rather than popularity, on the next generation, rather than the next election."
 
Unconventional Career
 Mr. Kerrey's announcement today capped a meteoric and unconventional political career that begin in 1982 when the young Nebraska restaurateur decided to run for office for the first time -- and defeated an incumbent Republican Governor. As the Springsteen title suggested, Mr. Kerrey's allies see him as a natural politician who seemed destined to take the step he took today, even though, for most of this year, he brushed aside the Presidential rumors that surrounded him.
As he took the stage in a downtown Lincoln park, under a brilliant autumn sky, surrounded by a euphoric crowd, that periodically broke into University of Nebraska fight cheers, Mr. Kerrey's eyes glistened and he seemed, for a moment, to be taking the full measure of what he was about to do. He looked out over the crowd, and an almost melancholic look crossed his face, then he turned to his speech and began.
Mr. Kerrey's attack on the Bush Administration did not have the personal tone used by his colleague and rival, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa. But Mr. Kerrey's language was unstinting.
He said the 1992 election "offers us a chance to break from a decade in which our leaders invited a season of cynicism." He went on: "They invoked morality but winked at greed. They crticized the public sector, but then robbed it blind. They spoke of balanced budgets but never submitted one.
"They railed against taxes but raised them on the middle class. They called for civil rights but practiced racial politics. They wrapped their cause in motherhood but then worked to deny motherhood of choice and meaningful opportunities."
But Mr. Kerrey asserted that Mr. Bush was not the enemy. "A more difficult enemy for us to defeat is our own pessimism," he said, "particularly in the Democratic Party."
Mr. Kerrey is the fourth major candidate to enter the race for the Democratic nomination, joining former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, Mr. Harkin of Iowa and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas is expected to announce his candidacy in Little Rock on Thursday; former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California is exploring a race, as is Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma. The Rev. Jesse Jackson is still considering his options.
Mr. Kerrey will have a impact on the campaign of Mr. Harkin. Athough Mr. Harkin's message of economic populism and old-time Democratic religion is quite different from Mr. Kerrey's, they draw from the same regional base. Mr. Kerrey will also probably cut across Mr. Clinton's potential support, since both offer themselves as young, exciting, change-oriented Democrats.
While his race is starting late, Mr. Kerrey's operation had a seasoned look to it, thanks, in part, to his quick collection of several campaign veterans, including some top strategists from the campaign of former Senator Gary Hart.
He was surrounded by a loyal audience of family and friends, including his former wife, Bev Higby. Mr. Kerrey, who was divorced in 1978, remains single.
Mr. Kerrey, who has often talked of his anger over the Vietnam War after he returned home, opened today's speech by thanking his community for helping a "bitter and lonely and altogether unpleasant young man." Mr. Kerry lost part of his leg in a raid that won him the Medal of Honor.
It is Mr. Kerrey's status as a Medal of Honor winner that, many Democrats assert, will protect him from Republican attacks, which often center on the charge that Democrats are weak on defense and out of touch with traditional patriotic values. But Republicans see vulnerabilities on this front: Mr. Kerrey voted against the resolution authorizing the use of force in the Persian Gulf.
There are also people in both parties who wonder whether Mr. Kerrey can live up to his billing. "It reminds me of John Glenn," said Charles Black, a top Republican strategist. "You remember, in 1983, Glenn announces -- astronaut, world hero, huge press coverage. Then he ran out of steam on the biography and had no message. And he got elbowed aside. Maybe Kerry has a message, but the jury's still out on that."

HEADLINE: Dublin Journal;
Will Haughey Get the Heave? It's an Irish Riddle

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The ancient Celts, fierce in battle though they were, had a nagging fear that if they angered the gods, the sky would fall on their heads. Their descendants, especially Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey, probably know the feeling.
In recent weeks, a wave of scandals involving public officials has combined with Ireland's worsening economy to shake Mr. Haughey's proven ability to rule this country of 3.6 million with a firm hand, taking backtalk from no one. 
 On Friday, four members of his party, Fianna Fail -- the Warriors of Destiny -- stirred the political world here by criticizing him publicly, possibly setting the stage for "a heave movement," as dumping a leader is known in Ireland.
To deprive his opponents of time to organize, the 66-year-old Mr. Haughey moved up by a week an important party conference, rescheduling it for Wednesday. The party could replace him as leader, which might lead to a battle with Government coalition partners over a new Prime Minister, or failing that, to a general election.
"Mr. Haughey has never had an easy ride," a spokesman remarked today. "Every three years he has had to prove his manhood."
Of the scandals and the political moves against the Prime Minister he said, "Hysteria -- everybody wants blood and they want it now."
Findings of investigations begun by the Government will be made public within six weeks, he said. As for the motives of the party dissidents, he said that they might honestly wish for better government, or possibly hope for promotions for themselves by a new leader.
For the better part of Mr. Haughey's tenure -- he has been Prime Minister in 9 of the last 13 years -- much of Ireland has seen relatively good times. Even his adversaries agree on that. As one of the smaller European Community members, just ahead of Portugal and Greece economically, the country enjoyed a mild boom from European subsidies and began to attract foreign companies to invest in plants and offices.
Although unemployment in some regions was high by European standards, it was eased by emigration. About 40,000 people a year left the country in the late 1980's for Britain, Canada and the United States, sending back millions to their families. But in the last year, mostly because of the American and European recessions, the Irish boom has collapsed.
Unemployment is now above 19 percent, and the Haughey Government is considering reneging on pay raises it negotiated with public employees -- whose leaders say the Government should instead catch the multimillionaire tax cheaters for the money it needs.
Were all this not bad enough, the scandals, most of them disclosed in The Irish Times and The Irish Independent, have given many people the impression that ranking Government officials have been filling their pockets at public expense -- "the cats among the pigeons," the editorial writers like to say.
 
Parrying With a Laugh
 Mr. Haughey, an accountant and lawyer, who instead of Prime Minister is called the Taoiseach, (pronounced TEE-shuck), the Irish word for chief or leader, has tried to brush it all off, smiling and quipping in the style he has used for handling the public since he was a star soccer player in college. Asked last week about the scandals, he said, "Look at London and New York -- there are scandals there daily which make anything that happens here seem in the half-penny place."
The most prominently reported of the scandals concerns a charge that officials of the Irish national sugar company used insider information to make a $10 million profit on shares of stock they acquired before the company was partly privatized last year. The officials also reportedly arranged millions in golden handshake pensions for themselves. Sugargate, the tabloids call it.
In addition, the chairman of Telecom Eireann, the state-run communications system, resigned, professing purity, after a company he partly owned sold a property to Telecom at a profit of $5 million.
Goodman International, a meat-processing and fertilizer company that controls much of the country's major meat exports, is under investigation by another commission on charges that it obtained unfairly advantageous loans from the Government, and sold the world cheap meat certified as top-grade.
In none of these has there been a suggestion that Mr. Haughey himself was tainted. But his ministers and friends in high office, where he put them, are being portrayed and perceived as naive, conniving or venal.
But one situation seems to get close to him, the sewer-pipe case. A public sewer line that local officials considered unnecessary was run under property that Mr. Haughey owns near his estate in the north Dublin suburb of Kinsealy. Members of Parliament from the principal opposition party, Fine Gael -- the Tribe of the Gaels -- said Mr. Haughey was in effect using public funds to improve the value of his property -- this even though the land is now a complex of modest cottages mostly without indoor plumbing.
 
Mom and a School Speech
 In interviews, some of the residents said Mr. Haughey was a good neighbor, and they thanked him for the sewerage. Others complained that their old mothers still had no bathtub in the house and had to go outside to the toilet. Mr. Haughey, who does not own the cottages, said he had no intention of selling the land for more luxurious housing.
The Prime Minister, a gifted speaker who refers convincingly to Virgil or to Gorbachev, has thrown no formal counterpunches. But the other night, The Irish Times reported, he noted at a school cememony that he had received two gifts that day, the same day that members of his party started the ouster process.
One was a bag of dirt from a place of religious importance, the garden of St. Colmcille in County Donegal, the other a sharp steel letter opener.
Having refused to comment directly on the ouster attempt, he dealt a simple Haughey parable: "I would like to assure everybody that that little bag of earth preserved me from disasters of any kind, and if the miracles do not work in this regard, I've got this little knife."

HEADLINE: First Report Card Issued on U.S. Education Goals

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Two years ago, President Bush and the nation's 50 governors, at a celebrated education summit conference, agreed to six national education goals to be achieved by the year 2000. It took them two years to decide how to measure progress toward the goals, but today they issued their first "report card" on that progress.
The report offered a baseline from which the nation will have to climb to reach the six goals -- and it will be a steep climb. 
 Although the report emphasized that the states must provide more reliable and more standardized data in order for more accurate reports to be written, it generally conceded that there were few areas where progress is clearly being made. The report said the nation was making progress in areas like educating the growing number of ethnically diverse students and in providing more of those students with minimum skills.
 
Some Good News
 The panel's report on the six national goals was one of three education studies released today. The other two were straightforward statistical reports on student achievement -- one on how well American students have performed in math, science, reading and writing over the past 20 years; the other was a report on students' math performances in 1990, measured against new national standards for 4th, 8th and 12th graders.
The report by the National Education Goals Panel, made up of six Governors, four members of the Bush Administration and four members of Congress, echoed recent studies that show American students failing to measure up academically. But it contained some good news as well: the percentage of students who earn a high school diploma or its equivalent is at an all-time high, although not significantly higher than it was 15 years ago. Also, drug use by students has declined, the report said.
"This report is not an action plan, it is a measurement instrument," said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat who is the outgoing chairman of the goals panel. "We now have a baseline, and we have a decade-long commitment by the President and 50 governors to move towards the goals."
The report is likely to renew arguments over the financing of Head Start, the Federal preschool program; to heighten debate over whether there should be national education tests and standards, and to provide political grist for both Democrats and Republicans over which party cares most about American education.
But over all, the report tells more about what the nation does not know about its educational status than how far it has progressed toward any single ideal. In many cases, the panel said it was unable to confidently measure progress toward its own goals because of a lack of reliable, standardized information from the states.
 
A Lack of Data
 National standards and national testing for American students are central elements in the education legislation presented to Congress by the Administration in April. Without adequate data to compare children, the Administration believes, it is impossible to know if progress is being made.
The report said there was no data, for example, on 3- to 5-year-olds that show how close the nation is to the first goal: having all children arrive in first grade ready to learn. It noted that there was "significant concern" that many children lack the necessary skills.
Such children are inhibited by factors like poor nutrition, poor health care, inadequate prenatal care for their mothers and other parental problems. Some educators and lawmakers, including Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, say the Administration could make great progress in preparing these children for school by fully financing Head Start. The Administration wants to spend $2.5 billion on Head Start in the 1992 fiscal year, enough to enroll 633,415 children, or 58 percent of the 4-year-olds it believes are eligible and interested.
On the second goal, a high school graduation rate of at least 90 percent, the panel relied on data from the National Center for Education Statistics, which showed that between 1975 and 1990 the number of 19- and 20-year-old students who have completed a high school degree or its equivalent rose to 83 percent from 81 percent. Among blacks, the rate rose to 78 percent from 66 percent over roughly the same period. But among Hispanic students, it declined to 60 percent from 63 percent.
 
Long Way to Go
 Goal three calls for American students, by the year 2000, to be able to leave school with demonstrated competence in English, mathematics, science, history and geography. Here the report incorporated data on national education trends reported today by the federally financed National Assessment for Education Progress.
Fewer than one in five students in 4th, 8th and 12th grades has reached competence in mathematics, the assessment found. But the number of Advanced Placement exams taken by high school juniors and seniors in English, mathematics, science and history has increased by 51 percent since 1986.
The fourth goal calls for American students to be first in the world in science and mathematics achievement. Here the report relied on earlier studies, which show students in the United States doing poorly in relation to others their age.
The fifth goal calls for every American to be literate and possess the skills to compete in a global economy. The panel reported that the vast majority of American adults are unable to carry out tasks like interpreting the main argument from a lengthy newspaper column or using a page from a shopping catalog to fill out an order form and calculate costs.
The sixth goal calls for every school to be free of drugs and violence and offer a disciplined environment for learning by the year 2000. Here again, the report card offered an incomplete picture. Marijuana use at school by 12th graders dropped from 21 percent of high school seniors in 1980 to 6 percent in 1990. At the same time, in a 1989 survey, about 30 percent of high school seniors reported that alcohol and marijuana were easy to obtain in their schools.
The report said violence remained a problem and found that black students were more likely to be the victims of violent crime than Hispanic or white students.
When the national goals were announced in the spring of 1990, educators expressed skepticism, noting that the goals had been set by politicians rather than experts in the field. And educators were quick to react critically to today's report.
"If President Bush truly wants to be the education President, he needs to use his influence to make 'better childhoods' a national priority," said Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association.
Some Democratic lawmakers recently accused the Bush Administration of using the issue of education, an arena where the Federal role has traditionally been small, to further Mr. Bush's as yet unannounced bid for re-election. Until the appointment of Lamar Alexander as Education Secretary earlier this year, there was little Federal momentum in the education arena.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Gets Polite Brushoff in Japan

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, churning through his first day of meetings in Japan, repeatedly told government officials here that Japan had to do more to open its markets to American investments and exports. But he was told repeatedly in return that Japan was doing all that it could.
Mr. Cuomo thus became the latest United States official to ask Japan to take steps to open its markets, only to hear that the problem of lagging American exports to Japan, the biggest source of mutual friction, was basically for the United States to solve. 
 "It's obvious that in many areas, you are simply intent on not allowing other people to compete," Mr. Cuomo told an executive at the Olympus Corporation, which makes cameras and other high-technology equipment. "You have a right to do that, but it's a problem."
It was a theme Mr. Cuomo repeated at meetings with the Foreign Minister, Taro Nakayama, and the Minister of International Trade and Industry, Eiichi Nakao. Those officials reportedly listened politely, then told Mr. Cuomo that Japan was doing as much as it could to meet American demands.
 
A Three-Part Theme
 "Cuomo is a very good salesman," said a Foreign Ministry official. But he said Mr. Nakayama told the Governor that "each country has its own way of solving these questions" and that the United States should first reduce the Federal budget deficit in an effort to improve the trade situation.
Mr. Cuomo, who is in Japan to promote exports of New York-made products to Japan, particularly those of small and medium-sized manufacturers, sounded a three-part theme during his first day: Japanese investment and involvement in the United States was welcome, the United States had to do more to solve its own economic problems and Japan had to do more to open its markets to American investments and products.
He said Americans were increasingly willing to blame Japan for America's economic woes, just as Americans were blaming politicians like himself, regardless of whether the blame was fair. If Japan failed to respond to United States efforts to improve the trade situtation, Mr. Cuomo said, "the political pressure is bound to create undesirable results."
While Mr. Cuomo agreed with his Japanese hosts that the United States was responsible for not addressing such problems as a declining educational system and the growing Federal deficit, he nonetheless asserted that Japan still had to do its share to reduce trade imbalances.
 
Little Interest in the Press
 Mr. Cuomo also repeated a familiar incantation to American journalists: "I am not running for President even though reporters don't believe me."
It was too early to tell how Mr. Cuomo was being received, but his visit seemed to stir little interest in the Japanese press. To them he seemed to be yet another in a string of about 30 governors who have come to Japan on economic missions in the last two years.
Mr. Cuomo also toured the Olympus Corporation, which has a joint venture with Symbol Technologies Inc. of Long Island to make high-technology instruments that are then sold in Japan.
He also performed double duty as a New York State commercial officer, pushing Japan to buy air reconnaisance planes built by the Grumman Corporation on Long Island to meet Japan's pledge to perform air surveillance over its surrounding sea lanes.
Mr. Nakayama, the Foreign Minister, said Japan would give "due consideration" to Mr. Cuomo's request, a spokesman said. But defense officials have said that a decision on what planes to buy would not be made for a year.
The Governor seemed to have the most fun meeting with one of Japan's most successful elected politicians, Gov. Sunichi Suzuki of the Tokyo metropolitan government, who recently won his fourth four-year term in a bruising political campaign.
Presented a key to the city, Mr. Cuomo thanked Mr. Suzuki but added, "What I'd really like is the key to your political success."

LENGTH: 844 words

HEADLINE: Legislators Seek Exoneration In House Bank Controversy

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Stung by criticism from constituents, more than two dozen lawmakers have asked officials of the House of Representatives to certify that they were not among the House members who had insufficient funds to cover checks drawn on the House bank last year, lawmakers and House officials said today.
A study issued this month by the General Accounting Office, an investigating arm of Congress, found that House members did not have sufficient funds to cover a total of 8,331 checks written last year. In none of these cases, the audit found, did the bank impose penalties. The accounting office reported that 24 House members wrote at least one uncovered check for $1,000 or more each month for the last six months of 1990. 
 Both the G.A.O. and House officials have refused to name the offenders, but it is understood that they include Democrats and Republicans, liberals and conservatives, rich and poor. Millionaires were among the worst offenders, House officials said, noting that many entrusted their checkbooks to aides.
The House bank has stopped the practice of honoring the uncovered checks. Members who wish to write checks on the House bank will now be required to belong to the House credit union, which will cover the checks and charge lawmakers the prevailing interest rates in the event of an overdraft, said Speaker Thomas S. Foley. Of the 435 House members, 300 belong to the credit union.
 
Questions From Voters
 Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat who asked for and received an exonerating letter from Jack Russ, the House's Sergeant at Arms, recalled his embarrassment when the accounting office report was published. He said his constituents asked how fiscal policy could be entrusted to lawmakers who could not handle their own finances, and resented the lawmakers' ability to obtain what amounted to interest-free loans.
"I had had a meeting with some constituents the day the news broke," Mr. Mazzoli said in an interview. "It was an issue raised by the constituents, and raised in a way that was very hurtful to me in that it reflected extremely unfavorably on the House as an institution.
"It's a minuscule amount of money, but it says that members of Congress are saying that the normal rules don't apply to them."
Representative David Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, requested a similar letter, only to learn that he had lacked sufficient funds to cover several relatively small checks he wrote during a 12-day period, said Jack Cole, the Congressman's press secretary. Mr. Obey made the admission to CongressDaily, a report on Capitol Hill activities published by the National Journal.
 
'A Private Matter'
 The letters of exoneration are being written even though Mr. Foley, a Washington Democrat, said last week that they should not be necessary. Asked on the House floor whether it would be proper for the Sergeant at Arms to "prepare a letter so as not to identify the transgressors but to free the innocent," the Speaker replied, "I think the member's word in this matter is trustworthy, and the members can say whatever they wish to the press."
Some lawmakers, including Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, were reluctant to discuss their check-writing practices. Mr. Solarz said he was unaware of having written any bad checks but believed that "one's tax returns and checking accounts are a private matter."
"I disclose everything I'm obligated to disclose," he said, "but one must try to preserve in this business some modicum of privacy."
The opposite view was expressed by Representative Scott L. Klug of Wisconsin, who is among a group of seven freshman Republicans who asked for a full disclosure of those who abused their checking privileges. "We can get John Sununu's travel records," Mr. Klug said in an interview from Madison, "but you can't get any information at all in the House. That's a double standard that I think makes the House look like it's hiding things."
 
'It Raises Questions'Check-Kiting Operation?
 "At some point, if the checks were substantial enough and on a frequent basis, it raises questions about whether it was a check-kiting operation," Mr. Klug added, referring to the practice of writing checks against insufficient funds to obtain credit.
Mr. Klug said he had also asked for a letter of exoneration, as a "pro forma" matter.
The lawmakers' check-writing privilege goes back 200 years, to the early days of the House bank, which is technically a disbursing office, House officials said. They said that over the years several presidents and senators who served their political apprenticeships in the House had been among those who wrote checks without sufficient funds to cover them.
Journalists and Congressional aides who used the House bank to cash their own checks often did not have enough money in their accounts to cover the checks, House officials said.
The officials said the House bank had never lost money on the uncovered checks. Most are uncovered for just one or two days, but some remain so for a month or two.
