HEADLINE: For Babies, an Ounce Can Alter Quality of Life

SERIES: Smallest Survivors: Dilemmas of Prematurity - Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
Cutler Dozier is a quick-witted, lively 4-year-old who gives not the slightest sign of how precariously his life began.
Born after only 26 weeks in the womb and weighing just 2 pounds 6 ounces, he spent the first two and a half months of his life on the precipice of medical calamity in the neonatal intensive care unit of Minneapolis Children's Hospital. He could not breathe on his own, he was severely jaundiced, his heart had a hole that prevented his blood from being properly oxygenated and he had to be fed through a tube directly into his small intestine. 
 But, as his mother, Phyllis Dozier of Eagen, Minn., put it, he was "a tough little tyke" who, despite his extreme prematurity, managed to leave the hospital more or less intact. Except for his small size and lung problems he has since overcome, he has no apparent physical or mental defects.
Cutler is a modern miracle, the beneficiary of extraordinary strides that have been made in the last two decades to support and nurture fetuses that leave the womb long before they can survive on their own.
Every year in the United States, 45,000 babies are born weighing less than three and a half pounds and more than two months premature. Today, 80 percent to 85 percent of these "very low birth-weight" babies live long enough to leave the hospital, four out of five of them without major physical or mental disabilities.
But Cutler belongs to the category of very premature infants who weigh more than 750 grams (1 pound 10 ounces) at birth. Infants born below this weight have a much higher chance of physical disability. And even with babies who weigh up to 3 pounds 10 ounces at birth, researchers are finding that many with apparently normal intelligence and sensory development turn out on reaching school age to have learning disorders and behavioral difficulties that can spell academic failure.
So far, Cutler seems fine. But Mrs.
Dozier said: "We don't know what will happen when he starts elementary school. We're still waiting for the other shoe to drop."
 
'Fetal Infants'
Saving More, At Higher Price
 In decades past, before the advent of sophisticated neonatal care, only an occasional extremely premature and very tiny baby weighing little more than a pound would survive and somehow grow up more or less normal. Today survival is commonplace even among the "fetal infants" who have spent little more than half the normal time in the womb and weigh only a pound or two.
Today the most pressing question is not survival, but the quality of that survival.
"Our ability to assess and report the outcome of surviving very-low-birth-weight infants has lagged behind our willingness to resuscitate them," Dr. Gabriel J. Escobar of the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Walnut Creek, Calif., and his co-authors wrote recently in an analysis of 111 studies that examined the fate of very-low-birth-weight babies
"We didn't know what we were getting into" when Cutler was in the hospital surmounting one medical crisis after another, Mrs. Dozier recalled. "No one could tell us what kind of child we would end up with, and we could only hope we would have the skills as parents to cope with whatever problems he would have."
Two infants who shared the neonatal intensive care unit with Cutler offer vivid examples of what can go wrong. Christopher Strommen of St. Louis Park, Minn., born at 1 pound 2 ounces after only 23 weeks' gestation, is blind and very delayed in his development. At 4 years of age, he still communicates with grunts and squeals. Emily Hanson of Bloomington, Minn., who was born after 27 weeks' gestation weighing 1 pound 11 ounces, has cerebral palsy and must use a walker or wheelchair. Her speech and other cognitive functions are also delayed, and she is still fed primarily through a tube in her stomach.
Both of these children were born to middle-class parents who were willing and able to devote time, money and educational and emotional resources to rearing children with serious disabilities and seeing to it that the children became well-integrated into the family and the community.
Even after they leave the hospital, babies like Christopher and Emily may need therapy that can cost of tens of thousands of dollars. Their parents may end up trapped in jobs they might otherwise leave, solely because the employer provides good medical insurance. Even then, the parents may spend thousands of dollars on care their policies do not cover.
The situation is even bleaker for the disproportionate number of premature babies born into families with limited economic and social resources. Many premature babies have unwed mothers, some barely out of childhood themselves. Others are born to women who abuse drugs or alcohol.
"Children born both very premature and into a low socioeconomic environment have a double whammy," said Dr. Maureen Hack, a neonatologist at Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital in Cleveland.
On the other hand, Christopher Strommen, the blind, nonverbal child who was 14 months old before he was able to leave the hospital, came home to parents who were dedicated to his well-being and willing to do whatever it took to foster his development. He now attends a preschool that has both normal children and some children with special needs. He receives regular physical, occupational and speech therapy and his mother, Judy Strommen, said he is making progress, however slowly.
"On the plus side," she said, "he's an extremely happy, good-natured little guy with strong attachments to everyone in the family."
Infants that are not so lucky may languish in hospital wards for years.
 
Lasting Legacies
Physical Problems Beyond Infancy
 While the majority of premature babies escape serious permanent harm, the legacy of desperate efforts to keep them alive can sometimes be severe visual damage, stunted growth and lungs too brittle to breathe without a respirator. During the first years of life, very premature babies tend to be highly susceptible to respiratory infections and many have problems eating, digesting food and absorbing nutrients.
Far more severe and irreversible complications can result from hemorrhages that occur in the brains of many of the tiniest babies. These "brain bleeds," as they are called, can, if severe, cause disabling movement disorders like cerebral palsy or serious intellectual deficits like mental retardation. Such a brain bleed was the cause of Emily Hanson's neurological damage. Less extensive hemorrhages may cause more subtle motor or cognitive problems.
"The smaller the baby the poorer the outcome is likely to be," Dr. Hack said. Over all, among those babies weighing less than 1,500 grams who survive, 16 percent to 18 percent will have "lasting neurological impairment" -- cerebral palsy or mental retardation, she said. For babies under 750 grams, 25 percent to 33 percent are so affected, and for those weighing from 500 to 600 grams at birth, 40 percent to 50 percent will be neurologically abnormal.
While these percentages of severely damaged babies may seem unacceptably high, those at greatest risk of serious consequences -- the "very low birth weight" babies that weigh less than 3 pounds 5 ounces, or 1,500 grams -- represent less than 1 percent of all live births. And fewer than two babies in a thousand weigh half that -- called "extremely low birth weight" -- and survive.
The vast majority of premature births occur after 32 of the normal 40 weeks of pregnancy and the babies weigh four and a half pounds or more. Nearly all of these larger infants leave the hospital neurologically normal and, if properly fed and nurtured, catch up in growth within a year or two.
But 5 percent to 10 percent of the very-low-birth-weight babies will have cerebral palsy involving the legs only or the legs and arms, and a similar percentage will be mentally retarded (with I.Q.s below 70). Other possible serious complications of extreme prematurity include seizure disorders, blindness or very poor vision and deafness, as well as milder forms of physical disability and mental slowness.
Researchers at McMaster University in Ontario who studied 129 extremely-low-birth-weight babies found that at 8 years of age the children had "as expected" more neurological impairments, general health problems and stunted physical growth than a comparable group of children who were not born prematurely.
But the researchers, led by Dr. Saroj Saigal, said they were encouraged by their finding that from two-thirds to three-fourths of the children "were performing in the normal range on most measures other than visual-motor integration and motor function."
In their report, published in May in The Journal of Pediatrics, the researchers emphasized that the greater needs these children have for special community and educational services "is not likely to pose a significant burden to society because the overall survivors number fewer than 0.2 percent of live births."
 
State of Mind
Learning Problems Surface Later
 But even premature babies who leave the hospital ostensibly neurologically normal do not always stay normal. In a study of 249 very-low-birth-weight children published last July by Dr. Hack and her colleagues, tests conducted at 8 years of age found that 25 percent had an I.Q. of less than 85 (slow normal) and 34 percent were doing poorly in a combined measure of academic skills.
At the University of New Mexico School of Medicine in Albuquerque, Dr. Jean Lowe, an educational psychologist, and Dr. LuAnn Papile, a neonatologist, showed that even children who tested neurodevelopmentally normal at 1 and 2 years of age often performed below normal on tests administered at ages 5 and 6. This decline in performance, which could impair learning, was more likely to be seen in children who had mild brain bleeds as premature infants.
Over all, said Dr. Marie C. McCormick of the Children's Hospital in Boston, several large and well-designed studies that took social class into account have shown that one-fourth to one-third of seemingly normal children who weighed less than 1,500 grams at birth are likely to have learning or behavioral problems once they enter elementary school. The most frequent learning disorder involves visual-motor skills -- the ability to translate what the eye sees into a proper physical response. For example, a child with visual-motor problems is likely to have difficulty copying figures or letters.
Another common problem is attention-deficit disorder, the inability to pay attention long enough to hear instructions or complete a task. Children with this problem often fail academically even though they may be bright. Many are also labeled hyperactive because they often disrupt classroom activities.
Dr. McCormick, who directs an infant follow-up program, said that even larger premature babies -- those who weigh less than five and a half pounds -- are more likely than full-term children to have behavioral problems like distractibility and difficulty focusing and concentrating, which can interfere with learning.
 
Early Intervention
Saving Children And Money, Too
 Hospitals that treat large numbers of premature babies in neonatal intensive care units typically follow the children for two years after they leave the hospital to monitor their physical and neurological development. Neonatologists are now beginning to realize that this is neither long enough nor comprehensive enough to assure the babies' maximum possible development.
Parents of premature babies need treatment too, Dr. Ruth T. Gross of Stanford University insists. A major study she directed showed that providing intensive help for both premature babies and their families in the first years after birth can greatly reduce the need for remedial education later on.
Even though the high-quality intervention she advocates is very expensive, costing $10,000 to $15,000 a year per child for two years, the later savings in educational costs -- $5,00 to $6,000 a year for 12 years -- would more than compensate. Over and above this, she said, society would save by fostering the development of an adult who is more likely to become a productive citizen.
The study, financed primarily by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, was conducted at eight university centers among 985 infants who were born before 37 weeks' gestation and weighed less than five and a half pounds.
The babies were randomly assigned to receive either regular pediatric follow-up care or regular care supplemented by intensive intervention by child development specialists. Home visits were made weekly the first year and biweekly the second. Parents were taught what to expect from their baby and how to respond appropriately to promote the child's development. Starting at the age of 1 the children attended specialized day care that fostered social, linguistic and motor skills.
The project's dramatic results, the first three years of which were published last year in The Journal of the American Medical Association, showed that those babies who received an educational boost and whose families received professional guidance on child development had significantly higher I.Q.s and many fewer behavioral problems.
Under grants from the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development and the Pew Charitable Trusts, the children are now being followed until they are 8 1/2 years old.. A participant in the ongoing study, Mimi Graham, an educational consultant at Florida State University Center for Prevention and Early Intervention, said that at age 6 only one-third as many children who received early intervention needed special education. She calculated that the resulting savings over a 20-year period would be $20,887 per child.
"Now what we need is a Madison Avenue approach to sell early intervention," she said. "The costs -- both monetary and societal -- of not preventing these problems in premature babies is just too high."
Dr. Michael Whitfield, a neonatologist, put it this way: "We're creating a new species of human being and don't yet know what their outcome will be. It's not enough just to wave goodbye and wish them well when they leave the nursery. We have an obligation to these children because we kept them alive."

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN: Battle Cry In Congress;
Lawmakers Brace For Fight on Arms

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
In his speech to the nation on Friday night, outlining major reductions in American nuclear armaments, President Bush warned against "unwise or unwarranted cuts in the defense budget" and said he was "counting on Congressional support" for his plans for the future.
On Sunday morning, his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said that by pushing ahead with plans for eliminating most tactical nuclear weapons Mr. Bush might win increased cooperation from the Democrats on Capitol Hill. The Democratic majority "will be more inclined to give the President what he needs for the defense of the country and less inclined to micro-manage," he said. 
 But early comments by influential Democratic lawmakers suggest that the White House may well have made a serious miscalculation.
With the precipitous decline in Soviet power and the crumbling of the Soviet economy, all of the political momentum is running against military spending. Worrying about their own economy, concerned about education and health care and other domestic issues, more and more Americans are concluding, according to the polls, that the time for pouring most of their tax dollars into the enormous military budget is nearing an end.
Making just that point, Senator John McCain, a conservative Republican from Arizona who sits on the Armed Services Committee, said he thought "the American people should be rewarded in some fashion for the fruits of their labors" -- preferably through tax cuts and deficit reduction.
Although he said Mr. Bush enhanced his standing by the boldness of his proposals, Thomas E. Mann of the Brookings Institution, a leading Washington research organization, also suggested that the President "probably legitimized the Democratic efforts to argue for a more rapid defense build-down."
The problem is this: To justify the abandonment of some American nuclear weapons and the removal of others from alert status, President Bush and his aides argued eloquently that there was no longer much prospect of war with the Soviet Union, which is what many of the weapons were built for. And that just whetted the Democrats' appetites for deeper cuts by giving them a ready-made philosophical justification for diverting more spending to domestic needs.
Mr. Bush himself said that the prospect of a Soviet invasion into western Europe was "no longer a realistic threat." Earlier that same day, Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had used stronger language in speaking to the Senate Armed Services Committee.
"We have seen our implacable enemy of 40 years vaporize before our eyes, a victim of its own contradictions, its imperial ambitions destroyed by the flame of freedom and by our willingness to meet the challenge that was put forward to us by the Soviet empire over the last 40 years," he declared.
Comments like those are hardly intended to build support for such projects as the B-2 bomber and the "Star Wars" missile defense program, which were in considerable trouble on Capitol Hill even before Mr. Bush spoke.
 
'Our Greatest Threat'
 Asked today if he thought the Administration's initiative would lead to further military cuts, the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, replied, "Yes, I think it will and should." In a preview of the approach Democratic candidates are likely to take in next year's campaign, he added: "Our greatest threat is here, in America. It comes from the steady erosion of our economy."
Others disagree. Representative G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery, an influential conservative Democrat from Mississippi, said he thought "we're cutting the military too much." He argued: "When you spend money for defense, you get two things, a good defense if you handle your money right and secondly you get people jobs. That's the name of the game out here, keeping people working."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said it was "disappointing" that having reduced tactical weapons, Mr. Bush "failed to apply the same compelling logic to pull the plug on the B-2 bomber and scale back 'Star Wars' from its gold-plated Cold War spending levels."
The B-2 and missile defense programs came under sharp attack in the Senate during last week's debate on the $291 billion military budget for next year. They survived, but Budget Committee officials predicted that Mr. Bush's speech would convince enough Senators that the Soviet menace was dead to hurt the two programs when conferees from the Senate and House of Representatives seek a compromise.
The House voted to halt B-2 production after completion of the 15 bombers already authorized, only one-fifth of the 75 envisaged in a scaled-down program approved by the Pentagon in April 1990 and four fewer than the White House had asked, and to cut Star Wars spending to $3.5 billion from $5.2 billion. The Senate voted for 19 bombers and $4.6 billion for the missile defense program.
Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, the staunchly pro-defense chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said Mr. Bush had undercut his negotiating position. He also called for savings of about $1 billion a year by mothballing the B-1 bomber fleet, which is now grounded for safety reasons. And he suggested that fewer aircraft carriers might be needed.
Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat who sits on the Armed Services Committee, said in an interview with Fox television, "The B-2 didn't pass in the House and barely passed in the Senate, so I would think as of this Monday morning the B-2 is in a lot more jeopardy."
Another potential target for cuts is the Seawolf attack submarine.
But Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, noted that "real budget impact requires changes in conventional forces," not merely decisions not to build "big-ticket" items. And Congress has yet to examine the planned 25 percent reduction in military forces or the base force to be left after those cuts take effect.

Mitchell, believes the Administration's initiative will lead to further military cuts. (Associated Press & Andrea Mohin)

HEADLINE: Money Scarce, Dinkins Warns; Labor Dismayed

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration has warned labor leaders that it is considering paring proposed property-tax increases, a decision that would deprive them of an important source of money for wage increases.
That warning, delivered by Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel in a speech to labor leaders over the weekend, represents the opening of a crucial phase in the city's negotiations with organized labor, which have been badly tangled since the city reached a controversial agreement with the teachers' union a year ago today. 
 Mr. Steisel's speech was intended to explicitly caution the unions not to expect that revenue from the proposed property-tax increase -- supplemented, perhaps, with money from a bond refinancing and additional state aid -- would be available for raises. Rather, scaling back on the increase could deepen projected deficits, which the Dinkins administration is counting on labor's cooperation to close.
 
The Threat of Layoffs
 In a bow to political and economic reality, the deputy mayor said the administration was backing away from the taxes because of their potential impact on New York City's stagnant economy and the probability that the City Council would reject them.
Mr. Steisel balanced a largely conciliatory speech in Atlantic City on Saturday to a meeting of the Municipal Labor Committee, a confederation of New York City public employee union leaders, with warnings that the unions's failure to grant concessions might make wage increases in any of the next four years politically untenable and would likely provoke further demands that some city services be turned over to private contractors.
Regardless, he said, a possible infusion from the Municipal Assistance Corporation and additional state Medicaid money "will not eliminate the need for significant downsizing -- accompanied in part by work force reductions."
The administration was hoping, though, that the possible re-emergence of those two financial contributions from others might revive stalled talks with unions over givebacks. Labor leaders were sending conflicting, but not necessarily mutually exclusive, signals in response.
Some were suggesting privately that they were prepared to devise their own broad austerity plan and one, Barry Feinstein of Teamsters Local 237, was threatening to bolt the concession talks and focus only on his contract, which expired yesterday.
Asked whether he found Mr. Steisel's remarks conciliatory, Mr. Feinstein said yesterday that he was awaiting the text because at the conference "I was too infuriated to listen."
Mr. Steisel acknowledged that "there have been misunderstandings and some contention on both sides of the table," and held out hope that the unions would share in efficiency savings -- like those he negotiated when he was sanitation commissioner. He hinted at another round of early retirement incentives and promised to rely on more attrition to avoid layoffs.
 
6,000 Workers Gone
 Since June, the city has laid off 3,000 employees in mayoral agencies and the Board of Education plus 3,000 others in places like the Health and Hospitals Corporation and libraries. The unions have maintained that attrition would make layoffs unnecessary, but the administration has demanded flexibility to reassign certain employees who survived and to get the most out of them so as not to gut municipal services.
Mr. Steisel said the administration's policy is to maintain a wage freeze through the fiscal year ending June 30, 1992. But other city officials said that if the unions want raises, the administration might give them in return for concessions: a 3 percent pay raise, one official suggested, could be justified with 4 percent worth of concessions. Each 1 percent pay increase for all 240,000 municipal employees costs the city about $140 million.
Without concessions, the Dinkins administration is prepared to freeze wages and threaten another round of layoffs when it outlines a revised financial plan to state monitors as early as next week.
Further complicating negotiations is the prospect that the state will begin relieving the city's Medicaid burden, as proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last week, and that the assistance corporation will generate hundreds of millions of dollars by refinancing its debt -- but only if labor contributes, too.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the assistance corporation chairman, warned yesterday that a failure to reach agreement on enduring savings by later this month would jeopardize the refinancing.
The administration has hinted before that it might seek ways to avoid raising the property tax by more than $1.5 billion over three years, as it had proposed. In June, the Council shaved the Mayor's property-tax request in half.
One year ago today, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a surprisingly generous 5.5 percent salary increase for the teachers' union. The settlement avoided a strike but triggered recriminations from other unions. This year, even the teachers' union is angry.
More than half the city's employees are working without a contract. The teachers' decision last week to join them -- only the second time in its three-decade history that the union has worked after its contract has expired -- reflects both its uncertainty about city finances and labor's increasingly contentious relationship with a Mayor whom many of the unions helped elect.
Sandra Feldman, the teachers' union president, yesterday echoed other labor leaders who hope their members will be spared layoffs through savings in other agencies or through attrition.
 
'There's Nothing to Negotiate'
 Ms. Feldman's reticence this year was in contrast to her threat to strike without a contract last year -- a threat that provoked a deep rift within the administration between those who insisted that the teachers deserved more than other unions and those who warned that the settlement would set a pattern that the city could not match in other contracts.
Ms. Feldman said yesterday that the city's financial situation is more precarious than it was a year ago, but that raises were still possible and were reasonable -- particularly because the union had deferred some benefits earlier this year to avoid layoffs.
After returning from the meeting of the Municipal Labor Committee, Stanley Hill, executive director of the largest municipal employees union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said yesterday, "There's nothing to negotiate."
And asked whether he found any cause for hope, James F. Hanley, the city's Director of Labor Relations, replied, "No."
Labor neogitations were further complicated this year by the dismissal of Mr. Hanley's predecessor, Eric J. Schmertz, after internal bickering finally erupted in public, and by Mr. Feinstein's preoccupation over the summer with the sudden death of his wife.
Mr. Hill's 15-month contract runs out in December. Bargaining is to resume today on a teachers' contract, which expired yesterday, as did the city's labor pact with Mr. Feinstein of the Teamsters. The police union, which entered binding arbitration with the city last month, has been working without a contract since June 30, 1990.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Peace Dividends

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
How swiftly and richly it has come -- the first great dividend of the disintegration of the centralized Soviet state.
Only a moment ago, the very idea of the collapse of Soviet central authority terrified the governments of Western Europe and the United States. They did what they could to shore up Mikhail Gorbachev in his struggle to keep the system working through maneuver, reform, tacking. 
 They failed. But the destruction of the Soviet internal empire was no sudden miracle. It came about through hard decades of the rot of built-in corruption, of bravery and suffering by its opponents at home, and the long wearing away of the Kremlin's strength by the commitment of Western military and economic power to containment.
But when the centralized power of the Communist Party and Moscow began to fall apart, Western politicians and theorists for the most part were filled with fear rather than rejoicing. They saw the dangers of conflict and disorder, which were and are real.
But they tended to pass over or minimize the benefits that the end of central rule could bring not only to Soviet citizens but to the world. They were paralyzed either by anxiety or by their own past political insistence on the critical importance of Mr. Gorbachev and the Soviet state.
The first dividend, of course, is the steps taken by President Bush to pull back nuclear forward forces -- including the destruction of short-range nuclear shells.
Fine -- but they do have one strange gap. Why no provision for mutual inspection once they are matched? Inspection is important not only for the U.S. but for the Soviet people, to make sure that no regional leader can squirrel away a shell or two. There's still time to patch up that hole.
Still, Mr. Bush's decisions were realistic, minimally risky now, and a step toward even more important stand-downs. That is plain and so should be this: they would have been impossible if Mr. Gorbachev had succeeded in maintaining the Soviet central structure in command.
The disintegration of central power allowed Mr. Bush to talk reciprocity not with a handful of top, never-elected apparatchiks who controlled Soviet military and political decisions but to representatives of the republics. They have everything to gain in getting rid of all or many nuclear bombs -- including the blessings of their voters.
So Mr. Bush said let's not spend years negotiating, let's act. He knew that Mr. Gorbachev could not negotiate right now, forget years to come and that only the republics act at all.
Yes, there's trouble ahead for many of those republics. Some of their leaders are dreary Communist hacks. Boris Yeltsin himself owes the world an explanation of precisely how he feels about Pamyat, a Russian Fascist group -- no more lackadaisical ambiguities. He knows how to make himself clear when he wants to.
Almost all the republics are still figuring out where to go, let alone how to get there. The West urges them to jump into total free market systems. But the people of the republics are shrewd enough to see that each and every Western government subsidizes producers, prices and social services of its particular choice.
Certainly, the ethnic hatreds that festered under Communism are breaking out. Be sure that Western politicians and specialists will again say, to see or deal with it we must protect, or resurrect, whatever is left of the Soviet central system.
The temptation for Western leaders will be to try to do that. Centralized authority always seems so much neater and easier to deal with.
Sometimes it is -- in a free society. But in imposed systems, whether Lenin's or Saddam Hussein's, centralization and despotism are twins. Their milk of life is war of aggression abroad or war of repression at home.
The U.S. cannot determine the exact mix of economic and state enterprise in the republics -- any more than it can India's, or Canada's. That is not our business.
But political freedom in the former Soviet Union -- from regional repressions or central dominance -- is our affair. Political freedom is the one best barrier to civil or international war. It is the garden that bears the dividends of peace and tending it should be very much our business.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Again, the Unemployed Need Public Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Fifty-six years ago, Walter Lippmann wrote a letter to John Maynard Keynes describing some exciting developments in Washington. The Franklin D. Roosevelt Administration was about to introduce a bill to help the unemployed. 
 Lippmann explained, "we shall set up a scheme of unemployment insurance more or less on the British model, but we shall supplement by providing that when an unemployed man has exhausted the 15 or 26 weeks benefit (the exact amount is not yet settled) to which he is entitled, he will then go off the insurance, but will acquire the right to a job on a public works project."
Lippmann was referring to the landmark Social Security bill, which included provisions for unemployment and old-age insurance. As originally conceived by the President's Committee on Economic Security, the unemployed person who exhausted unemployment benefits would be entitled to a job. The committee called it "employment assurance."
But the revised bill that President Roosevelt signed into law in August 1935 made no mention of employment assurance. That part of the proposal was torn away from Social Security and written into the Emergency Relief Act of 1935, which appropriated $4.8 billion for work relief. Roosevelt turned the money over to Harry Hopkins and his new Works Progress Administration, which provided 8.5 million public jobs to the unemployed over the next eight years.
Social Security has long outlived the W.P.A., and now Congress and the Administration are wrestling with extending unemployment benefits. Wouldn't it be a good time to reconsider the idea of providing public jobs for those who have exhausted their benefits? Looking out my window, I see plenty of public work that needs to be done.
 
DAVID A. MOSS
New Haven, Sept. 18, 1991

HEADLINE: No Danger in Airport Route During U.S. Open

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leonard L. Fleisig's conclusion (letter, Sept. 4) that "diversion" of some airplane traffic from Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens during the United States Open tennis tournament constitutes some unidentified safety problem is erroneous. Yet he uses it to support his general opposition to the proposed National Tennis Center expansion. 
 The Open is an international sports event that brings great recognition and economic activity to New York City and the borough of Queens. This is important when we are attempting to attract new business while retaining our tax base to avoid further tax increases. The tournament has been a fixture in the park for 10 years and will continue under the lease for at least the next 3.
Last year and this, Mayor David N. Dinkins and I requested the Federal Aviation Administration to use one of two standard runway procedures that minimize noise over the tournament during the hours of play. It is a safe and less complicated takeoff route than turning above the park and avoids a large, heavily populated portion of Queens. Last year, many constituents commented that use of this takeoff route during the Open permitted greater use of backyards and community parks.
Although I endorse in principle retaining the United States Open in Flushing Meadows, I am awaiting word on the terms the Dinkins administration is negotiating. I have advised the administration that Queens, its citizens and its flagship park must substantially benefit from retention of the tournament. Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, which generates more income for the city than any other park, has never received adequate attention or resources.
Finally, and most important, when it comes to the safety of our citizens, I have never waivered and will never compromise.
 
CLAIRE SHULMAN
Queens Borough President
Kew Gardens, Queens, Sept. 23, 1991

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Traders Bid Up Treasury Prices

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Traders in the United States Treasury market, bolstered by a belief that the Federal Reserve will ease credit again soon, bid up prices yesterday, sending bond yields to their lowest level in four and a half years.
Bonds prices rise when there are signs that interest rates are heading down, and traders appear to be growing more convinced that the Federal Reserve will ease credit again soon to keep the recovery on track. 
 The benchmark 30-year bond gained 5/32, or $1.56 for $1,000 face amount, to end at 103 22/32. The yield on the bond closed at 7.80 percent, the lowest since March 1987, and down from 7.81 percent on Friday. The yield was the lowest since March 27, 1987, when it fell to 7.64 percent.
"We're at some interesting levels, levels that haven't been seen for years," said Scott Winningham, chief market analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc.
 
Committee Meets Today
 The Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee meets in Washington today to discuss monetary policy, and some economists expect the Fed to force down interest rates as soon as Friday, after the influential unemployment report for September is issued.
The current target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other on short-term loans, is believed to be 5 1/4 percent, and many traders expect the Fed to move it to 5 percent if the unemployment numbers are weak. The rate last month was 6.8 percent.
"The only issue that needs to be resolved right now is the exact timing of the next Fed move," said Anthony Karydakis, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "I would be inclined to say they will probably hold out a little longer."
Douglas McAllister, a sales manager at Prudential Securities Inc., said, "Friday's employment number will give them the first opportunity to ease."
 
Higher Yields Sought
 The intermediate sector of the market, securities that mature in four to seven years, led the way as investors decided to extend maturities for a higher yield than can be obtained at the short end or in bank accounts.
"Intermediate-term investments are being favored by individuals aghast at the low yield in money market funds and bank deposits," one economist said.
Money-market accounts are currently yielding about 4.6 percent, while savings accounts yield about 5.35 percent. The four-year note ended with a 6.42 percent yield, while the seven-year yielded 7.25 percent.
The two-year note yield broke below the key 6 percent level, which traders said showed that another Fed easing was fully expected. The 6 1/8 percent two-year note ended at 100 8/ 32, up 2/32 to yield 5.99 percent.
Usually there is a spread of 100 basis points -- one full percentage point -- between the two-year note yield and the Federal funds rate target, which is now at 5 1/2 percent.
The 7 7/8 percent 10-year note ended at 102 29/32, up 7/32, to yield 7.45 percent. The three- and six-month bills both ended at 5.11 percent. The one-year bill was down two basis points at 5.12 percent.
Following are the results from yesterday's Treasury auctions:

HEADLINE: Lights, Cameras and a Sudden Surge in Action

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
During the hurly-burly of rush hour on a recent afternoon, a film crew had set up on West 58th Street in Manhattan. Horns honked, cabbies rubbernecked, pedestrians gawked and the New York-born director Paul Mazursky yelled "Action!" The New York-born actor Danny Aiello began speaking on cue in a movie about New York.
It was the first film crew the neighborhood had seen for a solid year.
"We're back, and it's about time, too," Mr. Mazursky said during a break from directing "The Pickle," a new Columbia Pictures film. "I think we were in real danger of losing New York as a film community." 
 He referred to the bitter stalemate between Hollywood producers and New York film unions that virtually shut down major-studio film making in New York City from last November to mid-May. The settlement, reached May 16, was viewed as a breakthrough that would bring producers substantial savings for night and weekend shooting in New York, work that had previously entailed considerable overtime penalties.
Until the agreement was reached, producers steered at least 10 films away from New York City, including "Frankie and Johnny" and "The Babe Ruth Story." The Hollywood decision-making amounted to a boycott of New York movie making except for independent productions.
 
Suddenly Short-Handed
 Because of the long lead time in film planning, it has taken since May for productions to reach New York in real numbers. But now they've definitely arrived. "A lot of people's phones started ringing a few weeks ago," said Brian Hamill, the unit photographer for "The Pickle." On one recent day, there were so many film productions in the city that one film union couldn't find enough grips -- the camera-moving crew members -- so some electricians were quickly drafted for camera duty.
In addition to Mr. Mazursky's film, shooting in the city are "Close to Eden," a Sidney Lumet movie about a detective, played by Melanie Griffith, who investigates a murder in the Hasidic community of Williamsburg; "By Any Means Necessary," Spike Lee's biography of Malcolm X starring Denzel Washington, and "Glengarry Glen Ross," an adaptation of the David Mamet play starring Al Pacino and Jack Lemmon.
The city has issued 29 feature-film permits for shooting until the end of the year, said Jaynne C. Keyes, director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. Among the productions scheduled to film here are "Boomerang," a Paramount comedy starring Eddie Murphy; "Mr. Saturday Night," a Castle Rock film directed by and starring Billy Crystal; "Night and the City," a 20th Century Fox film starring Robert De Niro and directed by Irwin Winkler, and Woody Allen's as yet untitled fall project, his first film for Tri-Star. Also working on films will be Al Pacino, John Turturro, Harvey Keitel and Elizabeth McGovern.
"We are having a great fall," Ms. Keyes said.
 
Spending Money in the City
 Nevertheless the losses, both artistic and economic, have been considerable. The film industry is estimated to generate $500 million to $2.3 billion in business as well as an abundance of ancillary jobs in New York City. Ms. Keyes estimates that more than $100 million was lost during the seven-month film hiatus.
Although activity has picked up, the film industry is a long way from full employment. "I think it'll take the movie industry here about six months to get back in gear," said Lieut. John D. Gasperin, head of the New York Police Department's Movie and Television Unit, which controls crowds and traffic at movie locations. "It's nothing like last year, which was one of our busiest years ever."
Frank Schulz, president of Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators, said: "During the boycott, we had better than 80 percent unemployment -- and the new contract is a 35 percent giveback." The 2,000-member union, under intense pressure from members of other film unions, voted to accept the new contract on May 16. Union leaders said members' annual salaries would be cut by one-third because of lost overtime from night and weekend shooting.
Michael Hyde, the teamster captain on "The Pickle," said he had been worried during the film drought last summer that he would lose his house. "And I know a couple of guys who actually did," said Mr. Hyde, whose crew of 24 moves equipment trucks, trailers and vans as the unit goes from location to location in midtown Manhattan, Greenwich Village and Brownsville, Brooklyn. "I've been on films here since 1967, and this year was the worst ever. I'd guess 90 percent of our people were out of work," he said of the 350 members of Local 817 of the teamsters.
Jan Foster, the film's location manager, who is covered by the Director's Guild, said: "Many people had to move to Los Angeles and Chicago to get work. I hope they all come back." She was out of work from March to July.
Producers, however, said they have benefited from the new union work rules. "It was like night and day, the difference between shooting in New York before versus now," said Roger Pugliese, co-producer of "Single White Female," a psychological thriller starring Jennifer Jason Leigh and Bridget Fonda that finished six days of shooting here on Friday.
"We saved money on night shooting, under the terms of the new contract," he said. "The attitude has changed, too. In the past they were rigid, and now they're bending over backwards to make things work. We definitely want to come back to New York, whereas in the past we were always a little bit hesitant."
"The Pickle" stars Mr. Aiello as a visiting film director who collides with New York before the screening of his latest opus, a teen-age science-fiction exploitation epic about a giant pickle-esque space ship.
Mr. Mazursky, who is not only the producer, director and writer of "The Pickle," but also plays a Hitchcockian bit part as a film projectionist, said, "I think the new rules will make New York more competitive." He said "The Pickle" would save money under the new rules. "At the last minute, the unions said they'd do a Sunday shoot at no extra cost. That wouldn't have happened before."
"There's no place like New York," said Mr. Mazursky, who will shoot four weeks of exteriors in New York before the company moves to Los Angeles to do interior scenes. "New York can actually change a shot."
While he was directing a scene on Central Park West, Mr. Mazursky said, he noticed a woman wandering by with a poodle and promptly asked if he could make the poodle and the woman the stars of a sequence involving Mr. Aiello. "You'd never have that happen in L.A.," he said. "First of all, no one would be walking. And secondly, if someone were walking a dog, it would be the maid."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mixed News On Dividends

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
LAST month, for the first time in nearly two years, more companies increased dividends than had done so a year earlier.
That fact, in figures released yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, was part of a somewhat contradictory report that shows that while there are signs of a revival in the fortunes of corporate America, there are also indications of increasing financial distress. 
 The offsetting indication came from the fact that 29 companies that had been paying dividends chose to stop paying them last month. That figure was the largest of any month in 1991.
Last month, 63 companies raised their payouts, compared with 56 in September 1990, when confidence in the economy was at a low after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the recession had begun.
Among those raising dividends last month were American Express, Union Pacific, Reader's Digest and Upjohn. While not all the companies on the list were large, most were. Of the 500 companies in the S.& P. 500, 12 announced increases, 2 decreases and none disclosed omissions.
By contrast, most of the 29 companies that omitted dividends last month were small ones, a number of them banks that had been forced to raise loan-loss reserves in the wake of real estate problems. The banks that halted payouts included the Bryn Mawr Bank Corporation in Pennsylvania, the Rochester Community Savings Bank in New York and the Bank of San Francisco.
But the list contained not only financial institutions. The Preston Corporation, a trucking company that had slashed its dividend in July, omitted it in September, saying it was more prudent to keep cash flow within the company.
Last month was the first year-over-year improvement in dividend increases since October 1989, when 139 companies raised dividends, up from 138 the year before. September's total was nonetheless a low number; it was the lowest level for a September, other than in 1990, since 1971, when only 24 companies raised dividends. That low figure came when Federal wage-and-price controls limited such increases.
Most companies make dividend decisions on a regular schedule, and fewer companies than normal generally make such decisions in September, reducing the impact of that month's figures.
Nonetheless, Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.& P.'s Outlook newsletter, said he was encouraged. "I would not be surprised if we had another month or two of negative readings, but I think we are probably around a turning point," he said yesterday. "It is no surprise that directors are not rushing out to boost dividends. They don't really see the end of the recession in their earnings numbers."
While the number of companies omitting dividends in September was unusually high and an indication that many companies are continuing to suffer, the number of companies reducing but not eliminating payouts was unsually low, at seven. That was down from 12 a year earlier, and the lowest figure for any month since January 1990.
For the entire third quarter, 217 companies raised payouts, down from 242 in the corresponding quarter of 1990. That 10.3 percent drop was the smallest for any quarter since the end of 1989.
The dividend picture in this recession has been clouded by the relatively low level of inflation, which has meant that even among companies where business has held steady, fewer have been able to impose price increases and obtain the funds to raise dividends. As a result, while it appears that there will be fewer dividend decreases and omissions this year than in 1982, the year of the last big recession, the number of increases is running well below the 1982 level and is likely to be the lowest since 1971.
When 1991 began, the companies in the S.& P. 500 were paying dividends at an annual rate of $12.25, based on the S.& P. stock index. That meant dividend yield of 3.71 percent, based on prices at the time.
But there were so many dividend cuts among the S.& P. 500 that by mid-August, the dividend figure was down to $12.13. It has since climbed back to $12.18. With the S.& P. 500 index up 17.9 percent this year, that means the dividend yield now is down to 3.13 percent, near the low end of its historic range.
To justify sharply higher stock prices, either investors will have to accept much lower dividend yields, or dividends will have to rise rapidly. In the 1980's, they grew at a compounded rate of 7 percent, but there is widespread doubt that a rate that high will be sustainable in the current decade.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Broadly; Gold Prices Edge Upward

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher in uneventful trading on world currency markets yesterday.
Gold prices were marginally higher after finishing mixed overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $354.20 a troy ounce, up 20 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold gained 25 cents an ounce for a late bid price of $354. 
 The dollar posted moderate gains in European trading, and the currency advanced in similar fashion when dealing shifted to domestic markets.
Traders said a report by the nation's purchasing managers that showed the manufacturing sector continued to advance in September helped underpin the dollar.
"The report gave the dollar a boost, but there wasn't that much follow-through," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Chicago-based Harris Trust and Savings Bank. He said the overall sentiment toward the dollar remained bearish.
Traders continue to mark time ahead of Friday's release of employment data for September. If the report is weak, as it is expected to be, market participants anticipate the Federal Reserve will nudge interest rates still lower. Lower interest rates are generally bearish for the dollar because they reduce the value of dollar-denominated securities.
Still, Mr. Johnson said many traders had already taken a rate cut into account, so the dollar might not be affected dramatically.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.23 yen, to a closing 133.18 yen. Later in London, it finished at 133.15 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 133.40 yen, up from 132.95 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7485, from $1.7525 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.7465 to buy one pound, less expensive than Monday's $1.7500.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.6685 German marks, up from 1.6650; 1.4550 Swiss francs, up from 1.4505; 5.6845 French francs, up from 5.6740; 1,247.75 Italian lire, up from 1,245.75, and 1.1314 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1318.

HEADLINE: Trying to Give Las Vegas a G Rating

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
Can this sleazy town that never sleeps transform itself into a Disneyland with slot machines, a family place where the kids ride bumper cars while Mom and Dad work the blackjack tables?
It is an unlikely notion, and one that would no doubt dismay the pioneering gangsters of Las Vegas like Benjamin (Bugsy) Siegel. It was he who built the first major hotel and casino here in 1947 and invited guests to "come as you are to America's Monte Carlo" -- before being summarily gunned down that year. 
 Now MGM Grand Inc., based in Los Angeles, is about to embark on a $1 billion gamble that one day family vacationers will talk about the town in the same breath with Orlando, Fla., home of Walt Disney World.
The company, which is 86 percent owned by the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian, will break ground next week on a singular resort combining the world's largest hotel (5,007 rooms), the world's largest casino, a sports arena bigger than Madison Square Garden and a theme park almost as large as the Walt Disney Company's in Anaheim, Calif. Among the attractions of this diversified gaming palace, a prospectus says, will be an elaborate child-care center.
Corporations like Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. and Mirage Resorts Inc. that own several casinos here have been trying for some time to promote the notion that they offer good clean fun for everyone. They have been helped by the fact that stiff controls on the granting of casino licenses have more or less eliminated organized crime, said Ron Asher, chief of the enforcement division of the Nevada Gaming Control Board.
But through its sheer scale and unique mingling of family attraction and casino, the MGM Grand Hotel and Theme Park is a radical departure in pursuit of what the company's chief executive, Robert R. Maxey, calls "the belief that we can turn this place from a gambling town into the great American vacation spot."
Las Vegas, America's fastest-growing metropolis, with 6,000 new arrivals a month, has already proved itself an adaptable place. The country's economic downturn has largely passed it by. Galvanized by two enormous new hotels and aided by the arrival of Asian high rollers playing for huge stakes, the town has "experienced no significant recession," said Harland Elges, the chief of administration for the state gaming agency.
Indeed, gambling revenue surged 13 percent in the last fiscal year. The hotel occupancy rate, at more than 85 percent, amounts to a remarkable anomaly at a time when the national occupancy rate has slumped to 60 percent. The Las Vegas rate eclipsed that in the Orlando area, where hotel occupancy was 79 percent last year.
The resilient growth of Las Vegas -- from 11.8 million visitors a year in 1981 to 20.3 million last year -- has been based in part on a successful broadening of the town's appeal. Still, it remains a casino town and the MGM project amounts to the boldest statement yet that gambling and children really can go together.
"We're making this investment because we believe that when you put a theme park in a place with 20 million visitors a year -- and that's never been done before -- you get something explosive," Mr. Maxey said. "Last year, only 5 percent of visitors to Las Vegas were children. That can go much, much higher."
The MGM executive is based in makeshift offices overlooking the vestiges of a golf course on a 112-acre site on the Las Vegas Strip. The basic cost of the complex, which is scheduled to open in 1994, is estimated at $875 million, but with financing charges from borrowing more than $500 million, MGM expects the tab to rise to more than $1 billion.
 
Some Skeptics, Some Believers
 Some are skeptical that the money will prove well spent. Stephen A. Wynn, the flamboyant chief executive of the rival Mirage Resorts, said: "A theme park is a whole new dimension for Las Vegas. Still, I wonder if kids' rides, gambling and a hotel are really compatible. Las Vegas is adult entertainment. Gamblers don't like to trip over children, you know."
But Richard J. Byrne, a vice president and gaming analyst at Merrill Lynch, argued that "the theme park amounts to a clever baby-sitting device." He added, "I think the concept will work and that in the gambling business you have to keep inventing new ways to appeal to the public."
Certainly the striking success of two innovative projects has done much to inspire the ambitious plans of MGM Grand, which has no financial ties to the troubled MGM/UA Communications Company.
Both the 4,032-room Excalibur Hotel, which cost Circus Circus $300 million, and Mirage Resorts' more luxurious 3,054-room Mirage Hotel, which cost $730 million, have defied the recession, with occupancy rates of around 90 percent and profit margins of more than 25 percent in their first year of operation.
 
Medieval Merrymaking
 The Excalibur, which opened in June 1990, is a sprawling monument to medieval merrymaking. Guests are greeted by costumed damsels peeking out from behind a turreted reception area. Telephone operators actually say, "Have a royal day!" and a guide to hotel services states: "Here ye! Here ye! His Majesty the King would like to welcome each of you to the land of Excalibur. He hopes you have a royal stay and would like to remind you that all Spectradyne in-room movies are $7.95 each."
For all its kitsch -- outlandish even by this town's standards -- the formula seems to work. The Excalibur, which offers rooms at a mere $39, had estimated operating profits of about $103 million on revenues of $316 million in its first year of operation. This money was made principally on the casino, whose high rate of return makes it possible to lure people by offering rooms relatively cheaply. Rooms at the MGM Grand resort will cost about $70.
Glenn Schaeffer, the president and chief financial officer of Circus Circus, Excalibur's owner said, "We're appealing to the baby boom generation who want to bring their children and to the elderly who, for the first time, have time, money and their health."
Blanca Serrato, for one, likes it. Steering her small son, Jonathan, through the maze of whirring slot machines that fill the Excalibur's lobby, she says that she and her husband have been to the hotel twice this year.
"We like gambling and this is a nice family place," she explained. "Sometimes we bring Grandma and Grandpa to take care of our boy."
Circus Circus, which also owns the Las Vegas hotel of that name, has almost doubled its revenue, to $692.1 million from $373.9 million, in the last five years. Now, it is about to announce another major project on the scale of Excalibur, to be built at the same time as the MGM project.
When it comes to boldness, few rival Mr. Wynn of Mirage resorts. He had a $13 million erupting volcano built outside his Mirage hotel and a 20,000-gallon aquarium of exotic fish placed inside it just to insure the place really looks like Polynesia in Nevada. The result in the first year of operation ended last November: operating profits of $187.6 million on revenues of $660.5 million.
"This hotel is the biggest success in the history of the world," said Mr. Wynn, who is not a man given to understatement.
 
Praise From Competitors
 Even the old family clans, like the Boyds, Binions and Gaughans, whose downtown "Glitter Culch" casinos have been hurt by the new projects, acknowledge Mr. Wynn's ingenuity.
"Wynn is the most creative guy in gambling today," said Michael Gaughan, the president of the Gold Coast and Barbary Coast casinos. "He has brought a whole new meaning to high rolling."
Jack Binion, the owner of the Horseshoe Casino, agreed that "Wynn's success lies in having created a hotel within a hotel for the super players from Asia."
Accommodated in special suites that have their own gardens, statuary swimming pools and putting greens, these gamblers -- mainly from Japan but also from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Thailand -- are capable of gambling as much as $12 million an hour on baccarat, according to several casino executives.
 
Ignoring the Recession
 This combination of high-roller gambling and a new family appeal has helped keep Las Vegas buoyant. Mr. Elges of the Nevada Gaming Board said gambling revenues in Clark County -- essentially Las Vegas -- rose 13 percent, to $4.035 billion, in the year ended June 30 after a 12.2 percent rise the previous year.
But the old downtown area saw its revenues decline slightly, to $657 million in the 1990-91 year from $662 million the previous year, while the Strip -- where Excalibur, Mirage and the planned MGM Grand resort are -- surged. "Downtown is not progressing, and it's a problem," said Mr. Binion, whose Horseshoe casino is in the midst of this more tawdry area.
Another potential problem for Las Vegas is the spread of legalized gambling in the United States, which could provide competition as well as new opportunities for Las-Vegas based gambling companies. With many Indian reservations now allowing gambling and a growing number of states legalizing it, there may be less incentive to come to Las Vegas.
Mr. Byrne of Merrill Lynch conceded that "as gambling proliferates there may be less reason to make the trip." But he argued that Las Vegas still has significant advantages over Atlantic City -- including 24-hour gambling, fewer regulations, visitors who generally stay several days rather than a few hours, and the population drift to the Southwest.
All these factors encourage the likes of MGM Grand and Circus Circus to plan their huge and ever more outlandish projects geared to families. "We're professional managers building one-of-a-kind, must-see entertainment mega-stores," said Mr. Schaeffer of Circus Circus. "That is what is going to turn Las Vegas into the next Orlando."
As for Mr. Maxey of MGM Grand, he reels off the figures for the theme-park-cum-casino: 3,500 slot machines, 165 gambling tables, a raft journey through a 1,600-foot watercourse, a 50-foot plunge on a log into the pond of a logging camp, a ghost coaster with a 35-foot drop.
"People want total fantasy, a release from everyday reality," he said, gesturing toward the vast and empty site. "They've shown us that. So we'd be fools not to provide it."

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Money Funds Fall Again

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to decline for the week that ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, the publication in North Palm Beach, Fla., that focuses on interest rates.
"Not only are the numbers falling quickly," said Robert K. Heady, The Monitor's publisher, "but savers should not expect any rate uptick by banks during the traditional October certificates-of-deposit roll-over period. Weak loan demand is keeping savings rates low, and certain institutions are purposely allowing their deposit bases to erode, thus reducing their cost of funds." 
 This, he says, offers an opportunity for banks' rivals to attract funds.
"Competitors such as mutual funds and brokerages will now aggressively pursue that roll-over money with yields higher than what the banks are paying," he said.
 
Falling Rates
 At New York area institutions, rates are being cut at a rapid pace, Mr. Heady said.
According to The Monitor, the largest change in New York area banks was made by Marine Midland, which lowered its six-month yield on a certificate of deposit by 27 basis points, to 4.86 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
First Nationwide cut the yield on its three-month certificate by 20 basis points, to 4.85 percent, the largest cut for that investment.
The New York branch of Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, reduced the yield on its money market account by 26 basis points, to 4.60 percent, the largest cut for such accounts among the area banks.
Among the commercial banks in New York, the average yield on money market accounts, has been cut to 4.72 percent, a decline of 6 basis points, and the average yield on three-month certificates was off by a basis point, to 5.01 percent.
 
S.& L. Yields Lower
 For depositors at savings institutions in the New York area, yields fell by an average of 4 basis points, to 5.02 percent, for money market accounts, and by an average of 3 points, to 5.19 percent, for three-month certificates.
Nationwide, according to The Monitor, the average yields of 20 leading banks outside the New York area have been cut by 4 basis points, to 4.98 percent, on money market accounts, and by 3 points, to 5.24 percent, on six-month certificates.
At the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday, the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 5.11, below the 5.18 percent rate the previous Monday, while that of the six-month bill averaged 5.14 percent, compared with 5.23 percent a week ago.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Continue Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices moved stubbornly higher yesterday despite a monthly survey showing that United States manufacturing expanded in September for the fourth consecutive month.
The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond, which fell 1/16 of a point in early trading, closed up 4/32, or $1.25 for $1,000 in face amount, to 103 26/32. Its yield was quoted at 7.79 percent, down from 7.80 percent late Monday. 
 The long bond's price has rallied 1 1/2 points in the last four sessions, buoyed by a growing conviction that the Federal Reserve is poised to ease interest rates to help stimulate the economy.
The Fed gave no clues about its near-term monetary course after a meeting yesterday of its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee. But many traders believe the Fed will move after Friday's unemployment report, which is expected to show continued weakness in the job sector.
"Most people sense if the data portray another shortfall in labor force activity, the Fed is apt to consider further relaxation in money market conditions," said William Sullivan, director of money market research for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
Interest-rate enthusiasm was temporarily dampened early in the session after a widely followed survey showed sustained growth at the nation's factories last month.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of business activity rose to 55 percent last month from August's 54.8 percent. When the index exceeds 50 percent, it generally indicates the manufacturing economy is expanding.
The report surprised economists, who had expected a decline, and sent bonds lower. However, underlying bullishness that the Fed will ease interest rates sent prices upward again.
Mr. Sullivan described the report as "too narrow to have any pronounced influence on Fed policy."
In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were unchanged to 1/16 point higher; intermediate maturities were up 1/8 point to 5/32 point, and long-term issues were up 1/32 point to 3/32 point.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, gained 0.63 to close at 1,220.09.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills issued at auction on Monday eased to 5.23 percent, as the discount rate fell 2 basis points, to 5.19 percent. Yields on six-month bills auctioned Monday fell to 5.33 percent, as the discount rate lost 2 basis points, to 5.12 percent. Yields on one-year bills held at 5.39 percent, as the discount rate stayed at 5.11 percent.
A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 5 5/16 percent, down from 5 1/2 percent late Monday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 94 29/32, up 5/ 32 point. The average yield to maturity was unchanged from late Monday's 6.89 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Hushing an Engine, Electronically

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Automotive researchers, who have long sought to develop a muffler that would suppress engine noise without creating a drag on horsepower and fuel efficiency, think they are finally nearing that goal.
An electronic muffler is under development by a joint venture between the Walker Manufacturing Company, the exhaust-system division of Tenneco Automotive, and Noise Cancellation Technologies Inc., which specializes in noise and vibration reduction. The joint venture is refining a microprocessor it developed to curb engine noise. The system is designed to generate a pattern of sound waves that in effect cancel out the engine's sound waves.
 
In Touch With Car Makers
 The joint venture, based in Grass Lake, Mich., has been keeping car makers informed of its progress and is working with a manufacturer of diesel truck engines on electronic mufflers for large trucks. Although a few other companies are at work on similar technologies, the participation of Walker -- the largest manufacturer of exhaust systems -- is thought to give the joint venture a marketing advantage.
A conventional muffler dampens the sound produced when the engine ignites fuel, using a series of baffles to redirect the sound of these explosions into an enclosed chamber where much of the sound dissipates. But this conventional muffler system tends to create a buildup of exhaust that causes back pressure on the engine, reducing power and efficiency.
The electronic muffler would have the same purpose as its conventional counterpart -- reducing noice -- but would not create the back pressure. As a result, the designers say, the electronic muffler would raise horsepower by as much as 7 percent and increase fuel efficiency.
"Tests have proven that the mufflers using this technology improve fuel efficiency by as much as 2 percent on the highway and about 5 percent in city driving," said Ronald J. Martoia, general manager of the joint venture.
Mr. Martoia also contends that the system would have no adverse effect on air quality, because pollution controls on modern cars are farther up the exhaust stream, at the catalytic converter or in the engine itself.
The acoustical theory behind the electronic muffler is straightforward. The system is based on the premise that undesirable sound can be neutralized by producing a wave pattern that is an exact opposite of the unwanted wave pattern produced by the engine. Thus, the crests of the first wave of sound are countered by the valleys of an opposing wave, creating a flattened sound wave. To the human ear, this translates into a significant reduction in noise -- only about one-third the sound of an unmuffled engine, officials say.
Applying the opposing-wave principle, Noise Cancellation Technologies, based in Stamford, Conn., is working on products to reduce vibration in car engines and devices to make household appliances quieter.
 
Prototypes Being Tested
 Mr. Martoia said that although the electronic muffler systems were still in the experimental stage, prototypes had been given to the three leading American automobile companies for testing. "We also have prototypes with just about every automobile maker in Europe," he said.
The venture hopes to make the electronic muffler available on an experimental basis on one or two car models within two years. "We can't try out new technology on cars until there are model changes," Mr. Martoia said. "The costs involved in retooling automobile models are high, and we have to wait until it becomes economically feasible for automobile companies to use this technology."
The system basically consists of a microprocessor-powered controller unit that analyzes the noise being produced by the engine and generates the opposing sound waves, and an amplified speaker that plays these sound waves at the tailpipe to cancel out the undesired sound. The microprocessor unit, which could be housed behind the dashboard or under a seat, is roughly 6 inches by 4 inches by 2 inches -- a bit smaller than a paperback novel. The speaker is about six inches in diameter.
A speaker must still be developed that is sufficiently small but also sturdy and powerful enough to keep piping out anti-noise for years through the rigors of daily driving. "We find that there is some trouble in getting the speaker to a size that will fit in the enclosure to allow it to be packaged to fit in the car," Mr. Martoia said. "We're working on developing a new speaker technology that will make it small enough to accommodate fitting under a vehicle."
 
Quick Response Is Required
 Another challenge facing the developers: making sure that their audio computer can respond quickly enough to engine changes. "We want to avoid having a system that does not respond fast enough to the changes in engine speeds," Mr. Martoia said. "The computer has to be able to detect changes in speed quickly enough so that it generates the proper frequencies of sound."
A microphone near the speaker at the tailpipe acts as an electronic ear, monitoring the sound. It sends its signal back to the computerized controller unit, which performs whatever adjustments are necessary to keep the ensemble in tune.
"The whole system produces the opposing wave faster than the ear can possibly detect," Mr. Martoia said. "It has to work at phenomenally fast increments of time."
The companies are testing the electronic muffler on several types of cars, but Mr. Martoia said the product would be "generic in the sense that it doesn't need to be tailored to any specific automobile model."
Walker Manufacturing and Noise Cancellation each started investigating electronic muffler technologies about three years ago. A year later they decided to collaborate, and the joint venture was formed.
 
Expanded to Trucks and Buses
 Under their agreement, the companies originally intended to test the system on passenger cars and light trucks. But the experimentation has been expanded to include electronic mufflers for heavy-duty trucks, farm equipment and buses; earlier this year, the joint venture entered into a development agreement with the Detroit Diesel Corporation, a leading maker of diesel engines, to work on systems for heavy-duty applications.
Mr. Martoia said that the joint venture hoped to price its electronic mufflers competitively with conventional offerings, although he added that the electronic models were likely to be somewhat more expensive. "We don't have the exact numbers yet, because we are still working on developing the electronics in a cost-effective way," Mr. Martoia said.
But the expected higher fuel efficiency and improved horsepower from the electronic mufflers "will more than compensate for the disadvantage of higher costs," he said. Compared with other recent technological advances in automobiles, like air bags and anti-lock braking systems, Mr. Martoia said, "the electronic muffler won't represent very much of a premium."
