HEADLINE: Facing Prison Time, Lawyer Vows to Pay His Victims Millions

 BODY:
A prominent Manhattan divorce lawyer who admitted bilking dozens of his friends, family members and fellow lawyers of millions of dollars has pledged to "mortgage the rest of his life" to repay his victims once he completes his prison sentence.
Alvin Ashley, a former partner at the firm of Colton, Hartnick, Yamin & Sheresky and past president of the New York chapter of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers, pleaded guilty on Sept. 24 to five counts of larceny. He faces a minimum of one to three years in prison, with a maximum term of three to nine years. No date has been set for the sentencing by Judge Herbert J. Adlerberg of New York Criminal Court. 
 The Manhattan District Attorney's office said Mr. Ashley enticed many people, including several of New York's most celebrated divorce lawyers, into giving him as much as $10 million of their money to invest. Mr. Ashley told them their money was going into his real-estate and fast food operations. In fact, no such enterprises ever existed; most of the money collected went to pay off prior investors, with the remainder spent on fine food, wine and clothing.
"I hope that even under the worst case scenario, I'll be able to get out of jail, make a new life for myself, and pay these peopIe back -- if not every penny, than at least to make a start," said Mr. Ashley, who is currently unemployed and who faces disbarment. "I grieve for everyone I've hurt," he said. "I stole money, but my heart is not a thief's heart."

HEADLINE: How Members of Senate Voted on Added Benefits

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Following is the 65-to-35 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to approve legislation providing extra coverage for people who have exhausted the regular 26 weeks of unemployment benefits. A yes vote was a vote to approve the bill. Voting yes were 57 Democrats and 8 Republicans. Voting no were 0 Democrats and 35 Republicans.

HEADLINE: Bernard McDonald, A Poverty Expert, 49

 BODY:
Bernard McDonald, Senior Fellow at the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development and a former official of the Ford Foundation, died on Sunday at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in Brooklyn.
He died of a heart attack, officials at the Pratt Institute said. 
 Mr. McDonald, an expert on antipoverty issues, worked in community development for more than 25 years.
He joined the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation in 1969 and worked there for nine years. The agency, founded in 1966, was the nation's first community-based development corporation.
Mr. McDonald joined the Ford Foundation in 1978 to help establish programs in community development, urban education and youth employment. He directed the foundation's urban poverty program from 1981 to 1987, and its Special Project on Community Development from 1987 to 1989.
He was named to his faculty post at Pratt Institute in October 1989 and directed the Ford Foundation-sponsored Community Development Corporation Oral History Project.
He was born in Brooklyn and graduated from Hunter College in 1964 with a degree in economics and from Brooklyn College with a master's in secondary education in 1968. He was a high school teacher in Brooklyn from 1964 to 1966 and taught at the Brooklyn Adult Training Center from 1966 to 1968.
He is survived by his wife, Clara, and his brother, Bobby.

HEADLINE: Helping Teen-Agers Avoid Pregnancy

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
A leading youth organization has shown that teen-age pregnancies can be greatly reduced by a simple but comprehensive program that arms teen-age girls with communication skills, information about sexuality and hope for a productive future, along with reproductive health services.
Participation in the program reduced by half the proportion of girls ages 12 to 14 who began having sexual intercourse and also cut in half the number of pregnancies among girls ages 15 to 17. 
 Unlike many other studies, this unusually comprehensive program was conducted under real-world circumstances, which make the results more generally applicable.
The study showed that such "high risk" characteristics as dependence on welfare, living in an inner city, residing in a fatherless household and having friends and mothers who became pregnant as teen-agers need not predestine girls to become teen-age mothers.
 
Social and Economic Problem
 The findings of the three-year study, conducted by Girls Inc. (formerly Girls Clubs of America), will be presented today at a news conference at the Capitol in Washington. The study was conducted among 750 girls from the ages of 12 to 17 at four Girls Inc. affiliates, in Dallas, Memphis, Omaha and Wilmington, Del., where members are at higher than average risk of becoming pregnant before finishing high school.
Corrian Spencer of Dallas, whose mother was a teen-age mother, said: "I would have been a different person" if not for the program. "I learned that I didn't have to go that way," she said. "I wanted to finish high school and have a different life for myself."
Miss Spencer, now 18 and a student at Dillard University in New Orleans, said she started a virgins' club among her high school friends.
Teen-age pregnancy is one of the nation's leading social and economic problems. According to the Center for Population Options, a Washington-based advocacy group on family planning issues, the United States spends $21 billion a year to support the families started by teen-age mothers.
 
More Than 'Just Say No'
 Each year more than one million teen-agers become pregnant, and half of those girls give birth. More than 80 percent of those births result from pregnancies that were unintended.
Joy G. Dryfoos, an independent family planning researcher, said the inexpensive grass-roots program devised by Girls Inc. could be applied by virtually all organizations that serve young girls, including Girls Scouts, Campfire Girls, Y.W.C.A.'s and 4-H programs.
Jane Quinn, a former project manager at Girls Inc., said in an interview, "Preventing teen pregnancies requires much more than a 'Just say no' approach." Mrs. Quinn, now with the Carnegie Foundation's Council on Adolescent Development in Washington, said that "young girls have to be taught how to say no without losing popularity."
"And the lessons have to start early, preferably by age 9," Mrs. Quinn said. "By ages 12 to 14, 25 percent of the participants in the study already had had sexual intercourse."
 
'Dosage Makes Difference'
 Dr. Heather Johnston Nicholson of Girls Inc. in Indianapolis, who directed the three-year project, said, "A significant support system is needed for teen-age girls who live in a society that continually bombards them with messages about how wonderful sex is."
The Girls Inc. study showed that attitudes and habits are not formulated in a four-hour program. "To teach skills effectively, you need to give it time," Dr. Nicholson said. "We showed that dosage makes a difference."
The research project included a control group of girls who did not participate. Although the girls were allowed to choose whether to participate or not, there was little difference between participants and nonparticipants with regard to characteristics associated with a high risk of early sexual activity.
 
Four-Part Program
 The project had four elements. Two of them, Growing Together and Will Power/Won't Power, were geared toward younger girls, all of whom had not yet become sexually active. The other two, Taking Care of Business and Health Bridge, were intended for older girls who may have been sexually active but had not yet become pregnant.
In Growing Together, five two-hour mother-daughter workshops were held to foster communication about sexuality and other sensitive issues. The participants were less than half as likely as nonparticipants to have sexual intercourse for the first time.
Will Power/Won't Power is an assertiveness training program designed by Mrs. Quinn to help younger teen-agers refuse to become sexually active without jeopardizing their friendships.
This program, delivered in six two-hour sessions, was most effective among those who participated in it for nearly its entirety. These girls were only half as likely as nonparticipants and less than one-third as likely as those who participated for a shorter time to become sexually active.
 
Looking to Future
 Taking Care of Business, held in nine two-hour sessions, sought to increase girls' desire to avoid pregnancy by fostering educational and career planning, helping them to set goals and teaching communication skills and responsible decision-making.
The idea is that girls who can see a future for themselves as educated adults or wage earners will be less likely to turn to motherhood for a sense of identity. Those who participated in nearly the entire program were about half as likely as nonparticipants to have sex without using birth control and one-third as likely as short-term participants to become pregnant.
 
Contraceptive Services
 The final component, Health Bridge, linked teachings about sexuality at the Girls Inc. centers with community-based health services that also provided contraceptive services.
Participants reported having sex without using birth control one-third as often as nonparticipants, and the participants were also less than half as likely to become pregnant.
Dr. Nicholson estimated that the full program could be offered for $116 a year per girl, whereas delaying a single pregnancy to beyond the teen-age years could save society $8,500.

HEADLINE: Memphis Campaign is Racially Divisive

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
Here in his hometown, Willie W. Herenton is a powerful symbol: a product of a broken home who was raised in poverty in the city's public housing projects, emerged from its segregated schools to earn a doctorate in education and became Memphis's first black Superintendent of Schools.
This year the 51-year-old Mr. Herenton seemed ready to add another chapter to that rags-to-riches story. He is running for mayor of this city of 610,000 people, one of the few large American cities with a black majority that has never had a black mayor. In the past, blacks never managed to unite behind a single candidate, but this spring several black organizations got together at what they called a People's Convention, excluding whites, to chose Mr. Herenton as their consensus candidate. 
 But as Mr. Herenton faces the conservative white incumbent, Richard C. Hackett, in the nonpartisan election on Thursday, the outcome is very much in doubt. The Herenton campaign is still dogged by divisions among black voters. To many voters, the issue is which candidate they will be most comfortable with; but some Herenton supporters say their candidate's struggle is a reflection of the sad racial history of this old Mississippi River city.
 
Fighting Anti-White Perception
 Mr. Herenton has been fighting a perception among many white voters that in his efforts to galvanize black voters, and because of the exclusion of whites from the People's Convention, his campaign has become anti-white. Consequently, he has attracted little visible white support, even in those white areas generally favorable to black candidates. And his opponent, who has been hard pressed to win black support in the past, has been getting some notable black support this time around, partly as a result of his appointment of blacks to jobs in his administration. .
"I wish some of my white friends would have publicly supported me, but that has not happened," Mr. Herenton said to a recent campaign gathering. "I had hoped, too, that blacks would have been unanimous in how they perceived what we needed, but regrettably that has not happened. I guess that is just Memphis."
 
Growing Out of Rural South
 Mr. Herenton's lament was a meditation of sorts on the city's tortured racial history, which many see being revisited and agonized over in the mayoral campaign. Memphis not only gained infamy as the city where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, but many of its black and white residents also say the city has been generally slow to embrace the model of the New South. There is a palpable impatience, and some embarrassment, among Memphis's blacks, who have seen other cities with black majorities, like Atlanta and Birmingham, as well as some with white majorities, like Denver, Seattle and Kansas City, Mo., have elect black Mayors.
Sidney Chism, head of the 2,000-member teamster local, and a Herenton supporter, said Memphis had only recently become more than a cotton and river town.
Although the city is now a fast-growing distribution center, Dr. Harry Moore, regional director of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, said its roots were in the poor rural life of the Mississippi Delta. At the same time, he said, its political life was shaped by nearly 45 years of domination by the political machine of Boss Ed Crump, who controlled the black vote through money and intimidation. All of this went a long way to stunting the growth of black political influence as well as prolonging the reliance of some whites on what Mr. Chism and Mr. Moore called "plantation politics."
But some political analysts outside Memphis suggest that the problem with Mr. Herenton's campaign is that it is relying too much on a sense of impatience among blacks and is not recognizing the need to find unifying factors.
Nationwide, there are 7,700 black elected officials, and black Mayors head five of the nation's 10 largest city's. As a result of those successes, Russell Owens, head of the Joint Center for Political Studies's National Policy Center, said, there might be understandable frustration among blacks here.
"I would be frustrated, too," Mr. Owens said, "but there are ways to build consensus without focusing exclusively on race as the unifying factor. And if there is a falloff in black participation because of this, it can be offset by the ability to attract white support."
 
Commercial Setbacks
 The election comes at a time when Memphis is still smarting from the loss of Holiday Inn's corporate headquarters to Atlanta and the bankruptcy of the management company that was to build the city's $52 million, pyramid-shaped sports arena into a major attraction. Mr. Herenton has tried to place the blame for these developments squarely at Mayor Hackett's feet.
The 42-year-old Mayor is a low-keyed man who cuts a workmanlike figure at City Hall and admits he is a bit "drab and dull." But in the last two years of his second term he has appointed a significant number of blacks, including the city's chief administrative officers.
Mr. Hackett, in an interview in his office, said he had stressed the "inclusiveness" of his administration in his campaign rather than attack Mr. Herenton or debate him. It is difficult to find him mentioning his opponent's name at all in his campaign. The nearest the Mayor comes to mentioning the city's racial makeup is in his campaign slogan, which touts him as "a steady hand for changing times."
 
A Liberal Corridor
 "The slogan is meant to suggest the racial change in the city, but also the economic changes and other changes," Mr. Hackett said. "And the inclusion we talk about is not only different skin colors but different opinions."
Mr. Hackett has never garnered many votes from the city's "Poplar Corridor," a white upper-middle-class swath that stretches across Memphis's midsection and draws its name from a major thoroughfare there. It is this area where a black candidate could usually expect to get a sizable white vote from among the comparatively liberal whites who have not joined the white flight to the suburbs,
"The Poplar Corridor has historically provided the majority of white votes that any black candidate got," said David Cocke, a resident of the area and former chairman of the city's Democratic Party organization. "But for whatever reason, this time around the Poplar Corridor will be voting for the white candidate in greater numbers than ever before."
Mr. Cocke and George Jones, who is black and is Mayor Hackett's campaign co-chairman, suggest that the reason is white anger over their exclusion from the People's Convention.
Mr. Herenton was named Superintendent of Schools in 1978 after a bitter, racially charged process and went on by most accounts to build a sound school system amid frequent fights with the school board over budgets. As with any urban school system, Memphis has its share of critics who lament declines in test scores, increases in dropout rates and ossified bureaucracies and budgets that inhibit experimentation and innovation.
In the 105,000-pupil system, which is 88 percent black, Mr. Herenton has won the trust and support of many black parents but has little or no constituency among whites, many of whom send their children to private schools.
The success of Mr. Herenton, who retired in June, could be measured by the fact that in the last three years he has been a top candidate for Superintendent of Schools in both Atlanta and New York City. His supporters acknowledge that there was one cloud over the later years of his tenure; He was involved in a sexual harassment suit, which was settled out of court in 1990 and the record was sealed.
Mr. Herenton said the local news media "blew it out of proportion and had a modern day crucifixion."

HEADLINE: Interior Panel to Study Logging Effect on Owl

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said today that he would convene a little-used Cabinet-level committee to determine whether logging in the Pacific Northwest should be allowed to continue despite its impact on a threatened species, the Northern spotted owl.
Mr. Lujan said he was reluctantly setting up the panel, but he added, "No solution to this problem could be found short of this action." He cited the economic impact of the ban on logging in the Northwest. 
 The Fish and Wildlife Service declared the owl a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act in June 1990. The service, an Interior Department agency, said excessive logging of ancient forests in the Northwest was a major cause of the decline in the population of the owl. An estimated 3,000 pairs of owls remain.
Last month, another Interior Department agency, the Bureau of Land Management, asked Mr. Lujan to convene the special panel to consider exempting some logging in Oregon from the Endangered Species Act.
Without the exemption, the bureau said, timber harvests on bureau land in Oregon would fall by 75 percent. Industry leaders fear that overall owl protection would cost tens of thousands of jobs in Oregon, Washington and California.
But critics said the move was the Bush Administration's latest attempt to undermine Federal environmental laws. "If they grant the exemption, they will be leading the spotted owl further down the road to extinction," said Kevin Kirchner of the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund.

HEADLINE: Boarding Schools Act To Win Back Students

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
A sharp decline in the number of students applying for boarding school admissions is forcing many schools, including the most prestigious, to adopt aggressive marketing strategies that would have sent shock waves through their sedate Gothic arches and leaded windows only a decade ago. But these new techniques seem to be starting to reverse the trend.
Lawrenceville School in New Jersey, one of the more prestigious East Coast boarding schools, whose alumni include Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut and Michael Eisner, chairman and chief executive officer of the Walt Disney Company, has installed a toll-free telephone number to encourage people to call the admissions office. 
 The school has also appointed Lawrence L. Hlavacek Jr., a lacrosse coach and former house master, as director of off-campus operations, a new position that dispatched the engaging Mr. Hlavacek through the back roads of America like an itinerant preacher to spread the good gospel of the boarding school.
 
Unheard- of Tactics
 These sort of marketing techniques "would have been unheard-of 10 years ago," said Anne Rosenfeld, president of Public Information Resources Inc., a marketing firm in Boston that specializes in independent schools.
"In the old days," said Heather Hoerle, associate director for boarding schools at the National Association of Independent Schools, "you just sat and waited for families to come to campus because you'd be filled by April anyway."
That is no longer true. Soaring tuition rates, a shrinking pool of teen-agers, and the current recession all have hit boarding schools hard. According to the independent schools' association, enrollment among their member boarding fell to 7,729 in 43 schools by 1989-90, from 10,166 in 46 schools in 1981 -- about the time the schools started seriously to consider new marketing strategies. By the following school year, enrollments had begun to inch back up.
To help make this happen, some boarding schools have quietly started to open their doors a little wider, recruiting students they might have spurned or admitted only reluctantly before: those with weaker grades, mild learning disabilities or minor emotional problems and even those from abroad with only a creaky knowledge of English.
Admissions directors from 12 boarding schools recently took a collaborative trip to Japan, Hong Kong, Thailand and South Korea especially for recruitment.
"Almost all boarding schools are becoming far less rigid about their entrance requirements," said Howard Greene, president of Howard Greene Associates, private education consultants in Connecticut and New York City.
So far, few have actually closed down. But at least two decided to become coeducational and three have changed from pure boarding to a mix of boarding and day students, where the demand for private education is still strong. Many are also working harder to generate more money for scholarship money.
The result is that boarding schools generally are becoming more accessible to a wider segment of the population, a change many of their administrators consider long overdue. Others argue that the shift toward a more diverse student body had been a goal for some time and the current crisis simply accelerated the process.
A major obstacle preventing people from choosing boarding school, of course, is the soaring tuition rates. These have been caused, administrators say, by rising costs of attracting and keeping good teachers, of buying advanced equipment like computers, and of keeping up the sports, library and arts programs needed to remain competitive.
 
School's Cost Rises to $17,800
 For instance, tuition, room and board at Kent Hills School in Readfield, Me., stands at $17,800 for the academic year 1991-92, compared with $9,900 in 1985 and $5,600 in 1981. This compares with a national median of $14,500 in 1990-91, more than double the $7,100 for 1981-82.
Many families can no longer shoulder such a financial burden, especially during a recession. That was a major reason why Kent Hills enrolled only 125 students in 1990-91, down almost 40 percent from the 200 students who attended four years ago.
The demographic trough has hit boarding schools particularly hard, admissions officers say, because the drop in the numbers of teen-agers has been particularly acute among the well-to-do families that traditionally patronized those institutions. Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass, for example, registered a 40 percent drop in the number of children of alumni eligible to apply from 1985 to 1990, as compared with the previous five years.
Some boarding schools have hired public relations and advertising firms to enhance their images. There have been the growing number of print, radio and television advertising campaigns, which many of these schools would have found horrifying only a few years ago. "Give your child the education you wish you had," urges one message attached to a snapshot of an introspective-looking preppie in wire-rimmed glasses, in an advertisement being run in a variety of national and regional magazines.
Most boarding schools are also stepping up their summer programs and turning to professional fund-raisers to build larger endowments and generate auxiliary income to increase scholarships and student aid. To retain students, Kent Hills, for example, now spends $425,000 a year on financial aid, or about $3,000 per student. This compares with $66,000 in 1980, or $500 per student.
On the national level, coeducation boarding schools spent an average of $5,994 per student in 1989-90, the latest year for which data are available, as compared with $3,748 in 1980-81.
But perhaps the most profound effect will come from international students, who are increasingly filling the breach. Statistics from the independent schools' association show that about 80 percent of the 1990-1991 rise in enrollment came from overseas students, in particular the nations of the Pacific Rim and Europe.
"Boarding schools now consider it part of their regular mission to educate future generations from many countries," said Ms. Hoerle, from the association. While it has been part of their long-term mission for some years, it has now also become a lifesaving strategy.

HEADLINE: Science and Math Get Most Support

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Major corporations that give money to support education in the United States are more interested in giving to mathematics and science projects, and are much less inclined to give money for programs to serve early childhood needs or to keep drugs out of schools.
These preferences emerged in a survey of leading companies' responses to the six national education goals set forth in 1989 by President Bush and the nation's governors. The survey was made by the Conference Board, a research and information organization based in New York City, which sent questionnaires to 1,600 companies and received 176 replies. 
 The country's major corporations have been urged by the Bush Administration to support the educational-improvement strategy coming from Washington. The business community has been the major supplier so far of money and leadership for the New American Schools Development Corporation, recently formed at the President's request to help create and finance new school models, from kindergarten to high schools.
Giving to projects at the elementary and secondary school level would be a radical shift from the traditional role of business as a supporter of colleges and universities. Corporations in 1990 contributed $5.9 billion for education, mainly to higher education. A slow but steady increase in assistance is now going to pre-college education, but it is proportionately small. American corporations last year gave $400 million in cash and equipment to schools covering kindergarten through 12th grade, according to the American Association of Fund Raising Counsel's publication, "Giving USA."
The widespread preference of business leaders, the survey showed, is to devote corporate dollars toward programs that help meet their work force needs and serve American companies well in global economic competition. This was reflected in the survey's showing a marked preference for the national goal that states, "By the year 2000, U.S. students will be the first in the world in mathematics and science." The survey also found a strong preference for supporting measurable academic achievement, such as achieving literacy.
By contrast, corporations reported that they were less enthusiastic about using their financial or technical help to attack social problems. Such investments often do not yield immediate benefits, or are not readily measured.
The survey showed that companies gave the lowest priority to the kindergarten-readiness goal, which states, "By the year 2000, all children will start school ready to learn." Next-lowest on the list of where they would choose to put their money and technical assistance was the goal that "by the year 2000 every school will be free of drugs and violence and offer a disciplined environment."
Ronald E. Berenbeim, a senior research associate of the Conference Board, who directed the survey, said: "Early childhood education comes at the bottom of the list, because it takes 10 or 12 years to measure results, and also businessmen find it is not easy to relate small children to the company's definition of self-interest."
 
A 'Government Problem'?
 Drug abuse and the needs of children are regarded as a "government problem" by many companies, Mr. Berenbeim said. "And yet when we ask people who work at the operating level in companies and have first-hand exposure to communities what they would do to improve education, they all say the same thing: start earlier."
The preference for math and science projects is understandable since they relate to many company operations, particularly in manufacturing, said Dr. Leonard Lund, program director of business education research at the Conference Board. "Science and math have a constituency among corporate leaders, because so many of them have been trained in engineering," he said. "The problems of disadvantaged children are of concern, but only remotely so."

HEADLINE: HELP FOR JOBLESS CLEARS LAWMAKERS BUT MAY BE VETOED

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Both houses of Congress voted today to spend $6.4 billion on extended unemployment benefits for about three million Americans who have been out of work at least half a year, but the margin in the Senate was too narrow to override the veto President Bush has threatened.
Republicans accused the Democrats of fiscal irresponsibility and of pursuing a political issue rather than offering real help for the unemployed. Democrats said the Senate majority on the bill giving workers up to 20 additional weeks of benefits fell two votes short of being veto-proof because of White House pressure. The Democrats said the pressure showed that the Administration cared little for Americans in distress. 
 Five Republican Senators who had backed an earlier version of the bill voted against it today, saying that the language adopted Thursday by House-Senate negotiators undermined last year's budget agreement.
In the end, 8 Senate Republicans and all 57 Democrats voted for the bill, while the 35 other Republicans voted against it, leaving the tally at 65 to 35, two votes short of the two-thirds majority needed to override a veto.
 
Waiting for Jobless FiguresFriday
 The 300-to-118 House vote was easily enough to override a veto. Fifty-five Republicans joined 244 Democrats and one Independent in voting for the bill. Eleven Democrats and 107 Republicans opposed it, and 15 members did not vote. [Senate and House roll-calls, page D20.]
Democrats refused to concede thebill's ultimate defeat. They said they hoped Mr. Bush would change his mind and sign it. Or, they said, possible bad news in unemployment figures due out Friday and pressure from constituents, which they hope to organize, might lead two Republican senators to change their votes.
 
Republican Alternative
 In particular, the Democrats were zeroing in on Senators John Seymour of California and Christopher Bond of Missouri, who are up for election next year. The other three Republicans who switched their votes to oppose the bill today were Senators Conrad Burns of Montana, John C. Danforth of Missouri and David Durenberger of Minnesota.
But Republicans said they hoped thatonce the bill was vetoed and the veto sustained, Democrats would support a $1.9 billion measure sponsored by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader. That measure provides up to 10 additional weeks of benefits. In most states, the unemployed are now eligible for benefits for up to 26 weeks.
Republicans said the Dole bill would be more fiscally responsible than the Democratic measure, which would add to the budget deficit over five years. The Dole bill, while bringing no money into the Treasury in 1992, would eventually pay for itself from proceeds of auctions of unused radio frequencies and by continuing current tax laws allowing unpaid student loans to be taken out of tax refunds by the Internal Revenue Service.
 
Partisan and Angry
 The exchanges among lawmakers in both houses were partisan and angry. Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who heads his party's Senate campaign committee, said the Democratic bill was a "political sham," because proponents "are not willing to pay for it by taking the money from something else."
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who is head of the Joint Economic Committee, said that under current law, in only one state, Rhode Island, are workers eligible to receive money from a $7.7 billion trust fund for extended benefits. That, he said, "is the political scam, to have employers paying these monies into the trust fund for the purpose of extended benefits and not to use the money."
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who sponsored the measure, attacked the Dole bill for making it harder for veterans to collect uenmployment benefits if they have "finished their tour of duty with Desert Shield and Desert Storm and then honorably discharged and find themselves without a job." The Democratic bill makes more benefits available to veterans than current law allows; the Dole bill would reduce them by making veterans whose enlistments are up ineligible for jobless benefits.
In the House, which took up the bill after the Senate vote, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said that if the Democrats would accept the reality of the veto situation and pass the Dole bill, "the unemployed would get real checks; they wouldn't just get press releases."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, renewed a major Democratic theme, that Mr. Bush is prepared to declare emergencies to permit extra deficit spending for foreigners like Kurds or Bangladeshis and get around last year's budget act, but is unwilling to see emergencies at home. "Working Americans have no place in the President's New World Order," he said.
Last year's budget act, and the roles of the President and Congress, figured heavily in today's argument. In August, at Senate insistence, Congress passed a two-step measure. Under it, Mr. Bush signed the bill, saying he wanted to show sympathy for the jobless, but then refused to issue a separate declaration of emergency that would have allowed checks to go out, saying he did not want to "bust the budget."
That provision, requiring separate Presidential and Congressional decisions that an emergency existed, was scrapped in conference. If Mr. Bush signs this bill, or it is passed over his veto, it will take effect without any additional step -- in effect declaring the emergency for him.
Senator Danforth cited this change, made in the House-Senate conference, as his reason for switching to opposition of the bill. "The budget agreement of last year requires that we make choices among worthy programs," he said. "The deal last year was that we begin to live within a budget. I believe the conrols on Federal spending must be maintained."
The bill adopted today would be in effect until next July and temporarily replace the existing extended-benefits system. That system provides extended benefits up to 13 weeks after a worker has exhausted regular unemployment benefits, which average $167 per week. The current program is paid for equally from state and Federal funds.
Extended benefits are now paid when joblessness among a state's workers who are covered by unemployment insurance reaches 6 percent, or when the rate reaches 5 percent if the level of jobless covered by insurance exceeds by one-fifth the average level in that state over the last two years. But even though the national unemployment rate was 6.8 percent for August, workers in only one state, Rhode Island, and in Puerto Rico are now eligible.
Under the bill passed today, the standard would be total unemployment. Democrats argue that total unemployment is the better gauge, because when there is widespread joblessness of any sort in a state, it is harder to find a job. Only about half of all workers are covered by insurance.
Under the bill approved today, all benefits would be paid from Federal funds. In states with 8 percent unemployment, averaged over the last six months, up to 20 weeks of additional benefits could be paid. Workers in Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi and West Virginia would be added to those in Rhode Island and Puerto Rico as eligible.
In states with 7 percent unemployment, 13 additional weeks of benefits could be paid. California and New York, the nation's two most populous states, are in that group. In all other states, seven weeks of additional benefits could be paid.
Two of the eight Republican senators who voted for the bill, William S. Cohen of Maine and John J. Chafee of Rhode Island, represent states whose workers would be eligible for 20 additional weeks. Three of them, Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and James J. Jeffords of Vermont, represent workers who would be eligible for 13 additional weeks. The other three, Mark O. Hatfield and Bob Packwood of Oregon and Bob Kasten of Wisconsin, represent workers who would be eligible for an extra seven weeks. Mr. D'Amato, Mr. Packwood, Mr. Specter and Mr. Kasten are up for election next year.
The bill's reach would be temporary, extending only until next July, except for a provision affecting people who leave the armed services. A permanent change would make them eligible for 26 weeks of benefits, instead of the current 13 weeks. They would be able to start collecting after one week of being out of work, instead of the current four. Both changes would put them under the same rules as people who leave civilian jobs.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Saroyan's 'Time of Your Life,' at Arena Stage

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
In these rough economic times, one might expect Arena Stage, the premier resident theater in the nation's capital, to use its art to prod politicians into action. But Arena is instead opening its new season with William Saroyan's San Francisco barroom reverie of 1939, "The Time of Your Life," surely the most comforting American play to emerge from the Depression, and will soon follow it with a musical adaptation of Frank Capra's "It's a Wonderful Life," another work that champions the power of fundamentally decent Americans to vanquish any misfortune single-handedly. Far from challenging Washington's conventional wisdom, Arena's 41st season -- the first under the artistic direction of Douglas C. Wager, Zelda Fichandler's successor -- seems eager to chime in with its own program for a thousand points of light.
The wattage will have to be a lot higher than it is in Liviu Ciulei's staging of "The Time of Your Life" if Arena is to convince anyone that the country is as full of good Samaritans as its chosen scripts would have audiences believe. Mr. Ciulei, a Romanian-born director and designer capable of startling visions of classics, would seem to have a special fondness for Saroyan's play; though he has now been working in the United States for nearly two decades, it is the first American play he has chosen to direct here. 
 Yet, with the exception of one major performance, by Casey Biggs as Joe, and a few minor ones, this production is sloppily acted as well as flaccidly paced, running three hours despite textual trims. Mr. Ciulei's approach to the work is pure stock -- even his saloon set looks as pre-fab as a Pizzeria Uno franchise -- and his only bold directorial gesture is to change the play's favored jukebox tune from "The Missouri Waltz" to "You Go to My Head."
It would be easy, but wrong, to blame the evening's failings on Saroyan. The standard line on this writer, who died a decade ago, has long been that he is a sentimentalist whose literary string ran out when World War II rendered his sunny world view obsolete. But he has never lacked for critical defenders -- Edmund Wilson, Mary McCarthy and Harold Clurman have been among them -- and in truth "The Time of Your Life" seems less dated than many other touchstone American plays of the same period.
Unburdened by ideology, the work has none of the antiquated preachiness of Odets; bereft of structure, it is free of the creaking plot mechanics of Kaufman and Hart. Yes, the play's characters, from the philosophical longshoreman to the lovable cop to the whore with a heart of gold, are too good to be true, but they have their own poetic reality. Saroyan's off-center vignettes about his ethnic cross-section of drifters and his shaggy, unforced sense of humor make his play, initially titled "The Light Fantastic," as brightly colored and animated as the pinball machine at center stage.
For the show to fly, each character's turn has to be supercharged with theatrical personality, not naturalistic acting, like succeeding comic acts in a vaudeville bill or a circus. Though "The Time of Your Life" was written in the same year that O'Neill wrote "The Iceman Cometh," the denizens of its bar dream attainable dreams, not pipe dreams, and the play upholds magical illusions rather than spreading disillusionment.
In an Arena cast exceeding two dozen, the light fantastic is tripped only by Joey McKneely, who brings a Dead End Kid's tattered innocence and a hoofer's grace to the role of an erstwhile "natural born dancer and comedian" originally played on Broadway by Gene Kelly, and, to a more incidental degree, by Jeffery V. Thompson as the bartender, Nick, and Teagle F. Bougere as an itinerant honky-tonk pianist.
Among the more central and damaging performances are those of Pamela Nyberg, who acts Kitty, the sweet and distraught prostitute, as if she were a cross young suburban matron, and Kevin James Kelly, who goofily and sexlessly caricatures the young man smitten by her. In a class apart is Richard Bauer, outfitted in long whiskers and full Buffalo Bill regalia as a mock frontiersman who calls himself Kit Carson. A mountain of mannerisms -- odd crouches, vocal twangs, stomach pattings, whisky-eyed winks -- he pays attention to the other actors only if they threaten to upstage him. During his longest soliloquy, the cast surrounds him in worshipful, open-mouthed poses (a prostrate posture of adulation mimicked by a minority of the audience) while Mr. Ciulei spins the revolving stage to show off his prize specimen of ham from every angle.
As Joe, the mysteriously wealthy, Champagne-sipping philanthropist who functions as the play's unofficial stage manager, Mr. Biggs is a most elegant antidote to such shenanigans. This is a very, very fine performance in an impossible role: the wry, distanced Joe could seem bland next to the barflies around him, and he often seems to be Saroyan's stand-in for God. An urbane figure in a gray suit, Mr. Biggs wears his halo lightly. He is serene without being unctuous, a martini-dry rather than syrupy-sweet humanitarian. He sounds the dark notes in the play -- the European drums of war, most notably -- without being portentous, gently nudging the audience to recognize that Saroyan had more on his mind than the wonderfulness of little people. In the compassionate, troubled undertow of Mr. Biggs's Joe, which recalls the world-weary tone of the wartime Hollywood performances of Claude Rains, one feels the brunt of the play's principal refrain, recited by an unnamed Arab: "No foundation all the way down the line."
One does not want to make too much of Saroyan's seriousness even so. "In the time of your life, live" is the play's main, and lightweight, message, and it is as a fantasy, an entertainment, that the play must live, not as any kind of exercise in social realism. From its first production, there have been arguments over how best to realize the piece -- Saroyan drove away the original, fabulist-inclined director, Robert Lewis, and designer, Boris Aronson, during the New Haven tryout -- and one can see why. If "The Time of Your Life" never had much to add to political debates, it remains a fertile ground for esthetic debate and experimentation in the theater. But the play's dream world of 1939 is no more present at Arena Stage than the real world of 1991. Milking Saroyan merely for his hokiest jokes and cheap nostalgia, Mr. Ciulei has reduced an artist's genuine feat of escapism to a truly irrelevant, and synthetic, heap of corn.
 
The Time of Your Life
 
By William Saroyan; directed and designed by Liviu Ciulei; costumes, Marjorie Slaiman; lighting, Nancy Schertler; choreography, Joey McKneely; sound, Susan R. White; dramaturg, Laurence Maslon; technical director, James Glendinning; stage manager, Maxine Krasowski Bertone. Presented by Arena Stage, Douglas C. HEADLINE: Guggenheim's Orbit May Take In Spain

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Officials of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, which in the past several years has been hatching plans to expand from SoHo to Salzburg, Austria, are meeting in Manhattan this week with representatives of Bilbao, the fourth largest city in Spain, to work out the final details on yet another branch: the Guggenheim Museum/Bilbao.
A design for the new museum -- a sprawling, riverside structure of sand-blasted steel and concrete by the American architect Frank Gehry -- has already been approved. 
 Juan Ignacio Vidarte, the director of finance for the region of Biscay, which includes Bilbao, said in a telephone interview the other day that the project was expected to cost $100 million, and was part of a redevelopment plan for the city that calls for an investment of more than a billion dollars over the next 25 years.
Thomas Krens, the director of the Guggenheim Museum, was not willing to discuss current negotiations, but said that his museum would provide "exhibitions, our collection, expertise and administration, but none of the costs."
"There will be no drain on the Guggenheim Foundation in terms of capital or costs of operation," he continued. "You can be sure that the 28 members of our board will want to be satisfied on that before we go forward."
Meanwhile, the peripatetic Mr. Krens is overseeing the $24 million renovation and expansion of the spiral museum designed by Frank Lloyd Wright at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street; supervising the creation of a $5.5 million branch museum in SoHo; presiding over temporary offices in midtown Manhattan; directing the Peggy Guggenheim Museum in Venice; lobbying for the last-minute reprieve of Massachusetts state seed money for the proposed $87.5 million Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art (known as Mass Moca) in North Adams, Mass., which the Guggenheim has offered to operate, and concluding a deal with the city of Salzburg for the construction of a $90 million Guggenheim Museum in that city.
How is he managing all of this when the country is still in the grip of a major recession?
"It comes to having faith in the art, faith in the architects, faith in the cities and faith in the internationalization of the art world," said Mr. Krens in an interview last week at the gutted building at 575 Broadway, at Prince Street, that is soon to house the Guggenheim SoHo Museum.
He paused, and added with a subtle narrowing of his large eyes, "Maybe there's also a modest act of defiance here."
It was the Salzburg project, which has received wide publicity in Europe since it was announced in 1989, Mr. Krens said, that attracted the proposal from Bilbao.
What made him take the proposal seriously was learning that Bilbao, an old steel town on the Bay of Biscay, plans over the next 25 years to transform itself into a modern financial center.
So one day last April, Mr. Krens found himself circling Bilbao in a helicopter scouting a possible location for the new musuem. He chose one on the banks of the Nervion River, which bisects the city.
Mr. Gehry, speaking from his office in Los Angeles, said, "The space has enormous sculptural appeal, in a river valley with surrounding hills and the city." The museum is to open in September 1995.
Even before the Bilbao museum was announced, Mr. Krens was criticized for stretching himself, his staff and resources too thin. "The Metropolitan Museum does $80 million a year in their merchandise operation and nobody says that distracts them," he said when the criticism was mentioned. "It all depends on whether you're running a holding action or looking forward."
As for wear and tear on the collection that is intended to rotate from one Guggenheim museum to another, Mr. Krens said that in the past about 97 percent of it had to be kept in storage. "The art is only effective if it can be seen," he said. "We want to balance access with security, care and conservation, and we can do all of that most effectively with multiple sites under the supervision of a single staff."

HEADLINE: U.S. Suspends Assistance to Haiti And Refuses to Recognize Junta

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
The United States today suspended economic assistance to Haiti, said it would not recognize the military junta that ousted the democratically elected government there and joined with other Latin American and Caribbean nations in organizing a pressure campaign to restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
President Aristide, who was bundled off to Venezuela early today by the coup leaders after the American ambassador negotiated for his life, defiantly declared at a news conference in Caracas that the rebels were "power mad" and that he would do all he could to reinstate his seven-month-old government -- the first to be elected by a democratic vote in Haitian history. 
 American officials said President Aristide was planning to fly to Washington to take part in an emergency meeting of the Organization of American States Wednesday to decide on a collective response to the Haiti coup.
 
Sanctions to Be Sought
 The officials said President Aristide will ask for sanctions and possibly even some form of international intervention to reverse the coup, which Administration officials are describing as the first real test to the new democratic order that has emerged in the Carribean and Latin America over the last 15 years. Except for Cuba, virtually every government in the region is now democratically chosen.
Haiti's representative at the United Nations expressed disappointment today over the failure of the Security Council to discuss the coup. The Haitian official, Fritz E. Longchamp, told a news conference he was disturbed by the Security Council's reaction, which he described as "unfair and a denial of Haitian rights." The president of the Security Council had informed him that a majority of the delegations felt there should not be a meeting on what was seen as "an internal matter."
The elections that brought President Aristide to power, said Bernard Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American affairs, "were held under unprecedented international supervision. The O.A.S. and the United Nations both oversaw them. Therefore, they have a legitimacy not just in Haiti but internationally. So it is very important in our point of view that they be defended."
Secondly, added Mr. Aronson, "every time democracy is threatened by the military in this hemisphere it sends off potential shockwaves and we want to make clear that this kind of behaivor has a terrible price. We are going to isolate them, and we hope that the hemisphere is going to isolate them until democracy is restrored."
For now, though, Washington and its allies appear to be confining themselves to diplomatic and economic pressures to reverse the coup, and it remains unclear whether military action may be considered. The O.A.S. members have traditionally spurned interventionist actions.
 
100 Deaths Reported
 The Reuters news agency reported from Haiti's capital, Port-au-Prince, that troops loyal to the military Government were patrolling the streets on foot in and cars, spraying crowds with random machine gun and rifle fire, according to witnesses. It quoted the Caribbean Human Rights Network, based in Barbados, as saying preliminary counts indicated more than 100 people have been killed since the coup began late Sunday. By late today, though, the American Embassy in Port-au-Prince, said the streets were "tense but calm," as the military imposed a 6 P.M.-to-6 A.M. curfew.
The three-man-junta led by the army's commander, Brig. Gen. Raoul Cedras, was trying to consolidate its hold on power. General Cedras broadcasst a statement on the Government television station tonight saying the coup was necessary to halt human rights abuses and violations of the Constitution by President Aristide's Government, The Associated Press reported. In his statement, General Cedras called President Aristide an "apprentice dictator."
 It is still not clear exactly who is involved in the coup or what ideological positions they represent.
 "There is a general who is trying to rob the people of democratic power and I am sure that with the support of the international community we can overthrow him," said President Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest, at his news conference at the palace of President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela in Caracas. "The democratic process which we have been experiencing in Haiti cannot be stopped by this coup d'etat."
The United States had appropriated $84 million in economic and food aid for Haiti, and $1.5 million in military aid, for the 1991 fiscal year. State Department officials, however, could not say how much of this had already been paid out and how much would be affected by today's suspension in aid. The 1991 fiscal year ended Monday.
Besides suspending this year's economic assistance to Haiti, the State Department is also going to hold up its request to Congress for $88.6 million in economic aid and $2.2 million in military aid for the 1992 fiscal year. For a country as poor as Haiti, even these relatively small amounts of aid could have an impact on the junta, particularly when they are combined with aid cutoffs from other donors.
In addition to freezing assistance to Haiti, Washington joined other members of the O.A.S. in calling an emergency foreign ministers meeting to organize collective diplomatic pressure to restore constitutional rule in Haiti.
The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, speaking of the coup, said "this outrageous action by elements of the Haitian armed forces is an attack on the democratic aspirations of the Haitian people. Yesterday, the United States joined the member nations of the Organization of American States in condemning this action and in demanding, 'respect for the Government legitimately established through the free expression of the popular will of that country.' The United States government does not recognize this junta."
Bush Administration officials are anxious to quickly demonstrate that the coup cannot work and should not inspire military coups elsewhere.
"Right now virtually every nation in this hemisphere is freely elected, and every democratically elected president in this hemisphere has a stake in making sure that that the military in Haiti fail," said Robert A. Pastor, an Emory University expert on Latin America and one of the observers at last December's Haitian elections. "The real question is whether they have the courage to act with enough collecitve punch to put Aristide back in the National Palace."
At the last O.A.S. foreign ministers meeting, held in Santiago, Chile, in June, the organization agreed to a new method for preserving democratic Governments from military coups. It decided that whenever democracy was disrupted in any member state, O.A.S. foreign ministers would be authorized to adopt "any measures" deemed appropriate to restore constitutional rule.
France and Canada also responded to the coup by suspending all their aid programs and refusing to recognize the junta. French aid amounted to about $36 million and Canada's assistance to $8.8 million. It was also expected that aid programs instituted after Haiti's democratic elections by the Organization of American States, the European Community and the World Bank -- which last July raised $350 million in pledges for Haiti at a meeting in Paris -- would be suspended.
Haiti's international airport has been closed since Monday afternoon, when the coup plotters seized Father Aristide at the National Palace. Venezuelan, French and United States diplomats negotiated with the coup plotters for the President's life, and the American Ambassador, Alvin Adams, escorted Father Aristide to the airport. The Haitian President had been planning to visit Washington later this week for a meeting with President Bush.

HEADLINE: CALLS TO REVIEW BUDGET PACT RISE

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, today joined a growing chorus of leading Democrats seeking to reopen last year's budget agreement after President Bush's announcement that he would destroy thousands of nuclear weapons.
Mr. Foley, a Washington Democrat, said the President's action and changes in relations with the Soviet Union brought on by the failed coup in August should be reflected by a shift in the way Congress views the Pentagon budget. 
 The budget agreement set limits on three categories of spending -- military, foreign and domestic -- and barred shifting money among them. At the time, political leaders did not foresee large changes in any category. Now that the possibility of a larger-than-expected military budget cut is being discussed, Mr. Foley and other Democrats are frustrated that the budget agreement dictates that any savings go to reduce the budget deficit and not to supplement domestic spending.
 
'Conditions Have Changed'

 "The budget agreement was undertaken last year in good faith by all of the parties," Mr. Foley told reporters. "The President's initiative last week is a dramatic example of how conditions have changed within the last year."
He said Mr. Bush's arms initiative "would have been considered totally irresponsible a year ago" when the five-year budget agreement was reached, and added, "Under those circumstances, it is difficult for me to believe the budget shouldn't be open to some review."
Mr. Foley and other Congressional leaders were briefed on details of the President's Pentagon plan today at a White House meeting with Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
If Mr. Bush opposed setting aside the budget agreement, it would take a majority of both houses to alter it. But in calling for a review of the agreement, Mr. Foley stopped well short of a call for legislative action.
Mr. Bush's initiative has become a factor in talks between House and Senate negotiators who today resumed their efforts to reconcile differences on the $291 billion military budget for the fiscal year that began today. Members of both parties said the initiative strengthened the Democrats' view that even deeper cuts could be made in military spending.
Echoing comments made Sunday by Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the committee, said the Bush plan had "weakened" his bargaining position to preserve funding for the B-2 bomber and the anti-missile defense system known as "Star Wars." The House rejected the B-2 altogether and financed "Star Wars" at lower levels than the Senate.
"At this moment, we're seeing what we can do to reconstruct the Senate position, and hold on as tenaciously as we can to B-2 and 'Star Wars,' " Mr. Warner said.
 
Who Gets the Money?

 Mr. Foley's remarks about the budget agreement reflected a partisan tinge that was elaborated on by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, who also attended the White House session today.
"The President would like to keep the money in Washington," Mr. Gephardt said in an interview. "We would like to see if we can return some of the money to the American people. We're looking at a change in priorities."
Congressional Democrats have tried to steer the White House into a debate over domestic priorities that will help them mount a credible Presidential challenge in 1992. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, had first urged that the budget agreement be reopened early last month when the Senate returned from its August recess.
Today's statements appeared to be the latest salvo in that battle.
Mr. Foley emphasized that Mr. Bush's plan on military spending had bipartisan support and that there was a tentative understanding that the budget agreement would remain in force at least for the 1992 fiscal year. He said Mr. Bush used the meeting today to issue a "plea" that Congress stay within the confines of his Pentagon spending plan for at least this fiscal year.
Some lawmakers, including Representative Willis D. Gradison Jr. of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, said Mr. Bush was unlikely to agree to any change in the agreement before the 1992 election.
 
Debate on Agreement
 The agreement that Mr. Bush and Congress struck last fall resulted in the first comprehensive deficit-reduction plan in American history. Politicians and economists still disagree over whether the deal was, on balance, good or bad, but nearly all agree that if the agreement is adhered to the deficit will be nearly $500 billion lower by 1996 than it would otherwise be.
Both sides paid a large price. Mr. Bush was forced to renege on his no-new-taxes pledge and found himself portrayed by Democrats as paying more attention to the rich than to ordinary citizens. Democrats gave up for several years what may have been their strongest political suit: the argument that the Government needs to spend more money for health, education and other popular domestic causes and less on the military.
The agreement caps military spending at $291 billion, representing about a 1 percent decline from 1991.
The Senate and the House have several options for altering the budget agreement. In the House, members could try to eliminate the spending caps among categories by shifting priorities within an appropriations bill. Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, tried that last week by suggesting that defense spending be cut by 3 percent and the money diverted to foreign aid and domestic programs. The effort failed in committee.
In the Senate, lawmakers would have to agree to a formal resolution to waive the budget agreement before acting on a bill that contained domestic or Pentagon spending. Senator Tom Harkin, a Democratic Presidential candidate from Iowa, tried that approach last month by proposing to divert $3.1 billion in Pentagon spending to education and health programs contained in an appropriations bill. That too failed.
Democratic conferees on the military spending bill could barely contain their glee today at the sudden turn of events.
"The House is feeling much more empowered on their position of no more B-2's," said Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado.
But other lawmakers and their aides voiced a cautionary note that Congress would not be able to muster the will or the energy to tackle such drastic reductions this year.
"I don't think the impact on the conference will be as great as it will be the longer term," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr., Democrat of South Carolina.

HEADLINE: How to Avoid Another Bank Bailout

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Don't Deform Bank Reform" (editorial, Sept. 23) cites my core bank proposal as useful, but labels three aspects of it as overreaching:
(1) You criticize the proposal's effort to limit the exposure of the bank insurance fund by limiting coverage to core banks.
Many of the problems plaguing this country's banks have the same root cause as the savings and loan institution crisis -- unlimited access to federally insured "free money." Preventing a repeat of the savings and loan crisis should be the sine qua non of this year's banking bill.
(2) You fault the proposed cap on individual loans because it will not make core banks completely safe.
Of course not. But is that reason to forgo efforts to make them much safer through loan caps and floating interest-rate ceilings? Core banks could still affiliate with uninsured institutions that would be less restricted, provided they raised such funds in the markets and did not use insured Federal dollars.
(3) You express concern that core banks would be vulnerable in the event of a market crisis.
In my proposal, regulators would have the authority (and in practice would exercise it) to waive rate ceilings temporarily in the event of interest rate spikes, regional downturns or other economic crises.
The core bank proposal would compel banks to become healthy and strong by forcing them to go to the markets to raise more of their funds. By contrast, the Administration's insistence on continuing to insure all deposits will only push banks further down the road to another taxpayer bailout.
 
CHARLES E. SCHUMER
Member of Congress, 10th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Sept. 26, 1991

HEADLINE: Report Card on Educational Goals: At This Rate, the Nation Is Flunking

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Monday's report card assessing progress toward meeting educational goals for the year 2000 points to an inescapable conclusion: the nation cannot reach these goals at the rate it is now moving.
What to do about that, and whether enough is being done now, are important questions that remain unanswered. The report of the National Education Goals Panel, made public on Monday, offered the first chance to grade three sets of people on their actions so far to improve education -- the President, the governors and the American public. Although the report did not directly evaluate their efforts, the fact that the goals still appear so far out of reach was damning indeed. 
 The education goals, drawn up by President Bush and the nation's governors, include making American children the best in the world in mathematics and science achievement, raising the high school graduation rate to 90 percent, insuring that all children start school healthy enough and intellectually stimulated enough to be "ready to learn," equipping every American adult with work, citizenship and literacy skills, and keeping schools free of drugs and violence.
One reason America's educational woes are so hard to fix is that they are entangled with a number of other enduring problems that the report hinted at, but did not fully address -- family disintegration, racial polarization, poverty and public complacency about educational achievement.
 
Quick Response From Critics
 The report was hardly out before critics rushed to complain of misleading or incomplete data and of a failure to evaluate whether current efforts to reach the goals were sufficient.
Many critics were Democrats eager to challenge Mr. Bush on domestic policy and confident that he is vulnerable on his pledge to be the "education President."
But some educators contend that the compilation of the report is in itself a sign of progress and a ray of hope. The panel's report is different from other gloomy pronouncements, they say, because it offers for the first time a clear set of statistics that will enable the public to track progress toward achieving these goals and may force Americans to confront the dimensions of the problem.
For those looking for guidance on what to do now, Education Secretary Lamar Alexander said the report made it clear that a "quantum leap" is necessary if the goals are to be reached.
"We've got to transform the way our schools are organized and what they're doing, what they're teaching, how teachers are trained, what schools look like and how they're staffed," he said. "We've got to transform the schools and the way we do things outside the schools."
Mr. Bush has offered his answer in the "America 2000" education strategy made public last spring, which calls for national standards, national tests, new kinds of schools and a commitment by every American community to draw up a plan to change schools. But several educators argue that the Bush plan fails to address severe underlying social and racial problems.
"There is no goal that calls for equal education for rich and poor children," said Jonathan Kozol, author of "Savage Inequalities," a recently published book that condemns public schools as segregated and contrasts impoverished city schools with those in affluent suburbs. "No goal breathes a whisper of the abiding American embarrassment of racial segregation. I can't understand why these two matters aren't on the agenda."
Partisan debates are already being joined on how to transform schools and what the Federal Government's role should be. A long section of the report offered one of the most complete breakdowns to date on how much money the Federal Government is spending on efforts to meet the goals. The report offers a total of $59 billion, up by 13 percent after inflation since the President and the governors agreed to set national education goals in 1989.
But several Democrats, including the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said the panel had improperly counted programs like airplane flight training in the Defense Department to artificially swell the total. And a Senate Democratic aide said that the Administration was taking credit for money that had actually been appropriated by Congress.
"The money is going up," the aide said, "but the Administration has no business claiming that it is going up because of them."
One example is Head Start, the preschool program for poor children, which has a demonstrated record of success and bipartisan support since its inception in Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society.
Mr. Bush has pledged to fully finance the program, which now serves only 28 percent of those eligible, according to Congressional estimates. Congress has consistently appropriated more money than the President requested, the Senate aide said, and will do so again this year. Mr. Bush has requested a $100 million increase, to $2.05 billion, and Congress will probably allocate about $2.2 billion.
Several other educators also criticized the report, saying it evaded difficult issues raised by the first national goal -- insuring that children are ready to learn. The report said there was no direct way to measure that, although in supplementary data at the end it pointed to some disturbing statistics about low-birth-weight babies and widespread lack of prenatal care for pregnant women.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, accused the panel of ignoring several concrete recommendations made by its own task force on the first goal, school readiness.
Samuel B. Husk, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, a group representing the major cities' school systems, said: "I think the fact they ducked the first goal is the most telling thing about the report. The most critical data, including low birth weight, is in the back of the book. It's an indication that we have a health system in trouble, and we're not paying attention to that."
Mr. Husk said the nation's major cities spend an additional $205 million a year for special education, teaching children with preventable disabilities.
 
Need for 'Populist Uprising'
 But other educators and business leaders said more money was not the answer. Spending on education has increased by more than one-third after inflation in the past decade, they say, without dramatic progress. Public attitudes, students' study and television-watching habits, and the stakes of school success must change first, they say. This is why the President's education strategy calls for national standards and national tests that would prod students to meet those standards.
"We need a purposeful populist uprising, in the sense that people buy into behavior changes that range from what schools do to what employers do to how people spend their evenings at home," said Chester E. Finn Jr., an architect of the President's education strategy. "
There is ample evidence that Americans so far have failed to grasp that their schools and their children are the ones in trouble. A Harris Poll released the other day by the National Education Goals Panel and the Business Roundtable, a group of corporate leaders, found that parents and students think they are doing fine, but employers and college and vocational-school educators think they are not.
"I don't think we're there yet in terms of a national political will to do the things we need to do to reach these goals," said William H. Kolberg, president of the National Alliance of Business, a business consortium.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 3, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Education page yesterday about national education goals omitted the identity of a sponsor of a poll about the gap between employers' and students' perceptions of how well students are educated. It is the Committee on Economic Development.
