HEADLINE: Forget the Dress, the Flowers, Mendelssohn. Just Run Away!

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
SHORTLY after her engagement last year, Letechia Shevik was overwhelmed by a feeling familiar to many brides-to-be.
Terror.
"I just couldn't handle it," said Mrs. Shevik, who is 29 years old, lives near Chicago in Buffalo Grove, Ill., and works as an administrative assistant at Clairol Inc. "All that stress, the planning, the walking up the aisle, turning around and seeing everyone looking at me. 
 "People I know who got married usually say that if they could do it over again, they would have eloped. So, that's what we did."
To many Americans, the notion of eloping may sound anachronistic if not mythical, a vestige of a romantic time when impetuous Romeos climbed ladders to bedroom windows and stealthily swept away their beloveds for impromptu private weddings, sometimes in another state. Never mind that the deed was probably inspired by a premature pregnancy, parental disapproval or an under-age bride.
Nowadays, thanks to a rising number of older brides and grooms, a spate of second marriages, a steady stream of immigration-related "green card" weddings and the new 1990's cheap-is-chic ethos, elopements of one sort or another are almost as common as the traditional ceremonies in churches and banquet halls. Indeed, for many contemporary couples, one of the first lines they might hear at their wedding service would come not from a minister ("Dearly beloved, we are gathered here. . . .") but from a city clerk ("Next in line, please. Hablas Ingles?")
Even Martha Stewart, the high priestess of home entertaining whose many life-style bibles include "Martha Stewart: Weddings" (Potter, 1987) has noticed the trend away from giving a $50,000 celebration, which is how much an average ceremony and reception for 200 costs in Manhattan. "Instead of paying runaway prices," she said, "people are running away."
Of course, nuptial purists may quibble about the word "elopement," which is derived from the word "lope," as in loping away. They would never use the word for small civil ceremonies or jaunts to exotic locales that are designed merely to merge the wedding into the honeymoon. To elope, they argue, the service must be shrouded in secrecy and scandal. "I can't recall the last time I heard someone say 'elope,' " said Cele Lalli, the editor in chief of Modern Bride magazine.
Others believe that it is only the term, not the activity, that has fallen out of favor. "I don't think people call it eloping anymore, but what else would you call it when someone pulls up and gets married in the back seat of their limousine, or someone flies in from Los Angeles and then turns around and flies back?" said Charlotte Richards, a minister who owns four Las Vegas wedding chapels, including the famous Little White Chapel, which features a drive-in window.
"Just yesterday I had 20 people who came in and said they came to Las Vegas to get married and didn't want the big wedding," added Ms. Richards, who is often referred to as the Wedding Queen of the West because, she says, she has performed more than 500,000 weddings in the last 30 years. "I'd call that eloping."
Statistics on the subject are as elusive as the perfect spouse. Figures from the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsviile, Md., however, suggest that a growing number of couples are abandoning the concept of formal weddings in favor of what, loosely speaking, would be considered an elopement.
For example, from 1973 to 1988, the number of weddings held in states where neither the bride nor the groom resided increased by 4 percent in the 41 states from which the center obtains such records. Moreover, in the same period the mean age of bridegrooms has risen to 31.3 years from 28.8 years, and for brides to 28.2 years from 25.5. This, in all likelihood, raises the chances that the parents of the bride will decline to pick up the wedding tab. For couples still struggling with their finances, the specter of paying for their own wedding can be an amazing incentive for an elopement.
If more proof were needed, there are roughly 2.4 million marriages performed each year in the United States and in 1988, 46 percent involved either the bride or the groom remarrying; in 1973, the figure was 35 percent. According to the National Center for Health Statistics, anyone remarrying is much more likely to have a civil rather than a religious ceremony. Indeed, the percentage of civil ceremonies rose to 31 percent in 1988 from 26 percent in 1973.
Sociologists like Andrew Cherlin at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore say that a decline in religious ceremonies among people who are remarrying might be attributed to the bride and groom having less in common with each other than they would if they were marrying for the first time. "A lower percentage have the same religion, education or are the same ages," he said.
Ms. Lalli said that the growing diversity in American culture probably increased the pressure to elope, especially when people from different ethnic groups or economic classes were marrying. "When you try to put a symbolic rite of passage together and you can't because the backgrounds are so dissimilar, one of the solutions is to have a private, simple ceremony," she said.
A no-wait, no-witness, one-minute wonder performed by a civil servant seldom matches the extravaganzas of the blessed affairs depicted in newspaper society pages or in bridal magazines. Sometimes the brides approach the altar in business suits, blouses or blue jeans instead of gowns, and sometimes the grooms wear ancient blue blazers, leather jackets or sweatshirts instead of morning coats. Sometimes, the couple doesn't even verbalize a vow of love and commitment. In some quickie states, like Maine, saying "I do" or "I will" isn't required, making the ceremony even less interactive than registering to vote, which at least demands that one hand be raised.
And for those who are eloping to satisfy immigration officials, the ceremony can be even less romantic. The marriage clerk at the New York City marriage chapel in the Municipal Building, Laurence A. Israel, estimated that 30 to 50 percent of the ceremonies performed there (60,700 in 1980, 71,000 in 1990) are designed solely to obtain a green card.
How can he tell? "They don't have a ring; they don't kiss; sometimes they don't even speak the same language," Mr. Israel said, noting that he can perform a ceremony in 16 languages.
Mr. Israel said that the resurgence in elopements is obvious in his chapel, where the ceremony costs $25, in addition to the $30 fee for a marriage license. "A lot more are coming in not just for the license but the ceremony, too," he said. "They're coming in and after the ceremony saying, 'Now, don't you tell anyone.' "
Of course, not all the weddings performed in city clerks' offices are conducted to appease the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Tight budgets are another popular reason. "If I had the money for a big wedding, I wouldn't be here," said Luis Ramos, 33, an unemployed postal worker from Staten Island who last week married Lourdes LeBron, 23, in a ceremony performed by Mr. Israel. "But we're planning on having a big party sometime later on."
Denise Shaw, a graphics artist from Manhattan, said she married Espen Fjermeros, a computer salesman from Norway, in New York's marriage chapel because she had been married previously. She also was turned-off by the "money-making aspect" of a large ceremony, saying, "I prefer not to have a big wedding."
Then there are couples like Ms. Shevik and her husband, Gary, who eloped last December to Cancun, Mexico, not only because of stress over the ceremony but because of the bride's aversion to her hometown. "I've lived in a lot of neat places -- San Francisco, Atlanta, Greenwich, Connecticut," she said. "I don't want to get married in Rockford, Illinois. Why get married in a boring little town?"
The Sheviks even found a service, Far Away Weddings of Dallas (800-882-9337), that arranges elopements. "My clients want a memorable and romantic wedding experience without the complications involved in planning a traditional wedding," said the director of the four-year-old company, Pamela Robinson. "Mexico, the Caribbean and Hawaii are popular, as are places in Europe."
Elopements do raise a new set of questions about etiquette. What about presents? (Couples should still expect them, along with gracious notes of congratulation, said Letitia Baldrige, the author of "Letitia Baldrige's Complete Guide to the New Manners of the 90's," published by Rawson) Announcements? (Ms. Baldrige suggests handwritten letters to family and friends.) Are apologies ever called for? (Yes, if the couple elopes after either family has been preparing for a large wedding.) Who gives the party afterward? (Preferably, the family and friends of the couple, but the bride and groom may do it themselves.)
For engaged couples considering elopement, Ms. Lalli added a cautionary note. She said that one of the most requested ceremonies these days is the reaffirmation, whereby married couples spend a great deal of time and money giving a highly ritualized mock wedding, replete with bells, gowns and lavish receptions. A sizable percentage of those couples, she said, eloped the first time around.
"They say that they wished they hadn't," Ms. Lalli said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene: No-Fault Rises From the Ashes

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE high price of auto insurance got you down? Join the throng. Premiums rose at three times the rate of inflation in the 1980's. And in many states -- most recently, New Jersey -- politicians and voters have declared war on insurers, demanding that they charge less than the market will bear.
 Squeezing the insurers might work, argues Jeffrey O'Connell, a University of Virginia law professor and an early champion of "no fault" insurance. But not for long. The right point of attack on insurance inflation, Professor O'Connell says, is its bloated underbelly -- the 13 cents of every insurance dollar spent fighting over legal liability in accidents, along with the 23 cents awarded a tiny minority of victims for pain and suffering. 
His latest fix is a variation on no-fault insurance, which has generated disappointingly modest savings in the past. But the O'Connell plan offers a distinction with a big difference -- one that could cut average premiums by a whopping 30 percent, yet preserve the rights of those determined to have their day in court.
 The prime reason auto insurance is expensive is that accidents are expensive. "Cars cost a lot of money to repair," Professor O'Connell points out, "and so do humans."
 Fiercer regulation might force the most torpid insurers to trim costs and the most efficient to settle for smaller profits. But there simply is not enough fat in auto insurance, he says, to pacify long-suffering policyholders: According to a 1990 study by McKinsey & Company in San Francisco, increases in insurers' administrative costs and insurers' earnings have actually trailed inflation. The practical alternative, Professor O'Connell argues, is to allow drivers to protect their incomes and property without relying on the hit-and-miss justice of the tort liability system.
 That is what no-fault has always been about: accident victims are compensated for tangible losses without regard to fault, and can go to court for more only if they pass a threshold of severe injury. But Professor O'Connell notes that no-fault has not fully delivered on its promise to save money because the barriers to suits can still be breached by determined plaintiffs. And once breached, the rewards of going to court can be very, very large.
 Under the system proposed by Professor O'Connell, drivers would have the choice of sticking with liability insurance-as-usual. But they could opt for much cheaper no-fault policies. These would guarantee compensation for economic losses up to the limits of the coverage, while eliminating the biggest bonbon in the trial lawyers' candy box, the right to collect for pain and suffering.
 In any accident that involved at least one driver with old-style insurance, the old liability rules would apply. Where both parties carried no-fault, however, they would make claims against their own insurance carriers for medical bills, damaged property and lost wages. Victims would still be able to sue for economic losses -- but only losses beyond the limits of their own policies.
 If, as Professor O'Connell expects, 90 percent of drivers choose the no-fault option, the savings on bare-bones coverage would range from an estimated 56 percent in Arizona to a spectacular 70 percent in Chicago. Even drivers who choose to sheath themselves in hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of no-fault protection could expect to save 30 percent.
 Who could object to a reform that simply gave drivers the chance to waive their rights to sue for intangible losses? Start with trial lawyers. Some no-fault cases would still get to court, as victims sought compensation beyond their coverage limits. But with pain and suffering out of the picture, multimillion-dollar paydays would be only a memory for the trial bar.
 Then there are consumer lobbies. Some consumer groups do support no-fault -- in California, they stand behind a tough no-fault reform initiative. But Ralph Nader, the godfather of consumerism, wants no part of any change giving drivers a financial incentive to limit their rights in court.
 The one state effort to get voters to approve an O'Connell-style no-fault system went down in flames last year in Arizona. Professor O'Connell says the best hope for giving drivers a choice lies in Washington, where trial lawyers have less influence and politicians are searching for ways to please Joe and Josie Sixpack without raising their taxes.
 Conservatives are leery of Federal legislation requiring states to do anything in particular about auto insurance. But a law that merely insisted that drivers be given a choice ought to be more palatable -- and would certainly mesh with the Bush Administration's drive to streamline liability laws.

HEADLINE: Aid to Poor Lands Up

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Aid to developing countries from major industrial nations rose by $7.4 billion last year. But as a share of economic output, the level of assistance was no higher than in the late 1970's, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. Aid rose to $54.1 billion, from $46.7 billion in 1989. The United States regained its position as the largest single donor, with $11.37 billion, followed by France and Japan.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Tucson Electric Seeks Lower Rate

 BODY:
The Tucson Electric Power Company, one of Arizona's primary utilities, has hired Bear, Stearns & Company to advise it on ways to lower the high interest rate on $117.5 million of Pima County industrial-development revenue bonds.
Called periodic auction reset securities, the bonds are repriced through Dutch auctions every 28 to 35 days. The bonds now carry an interest rate of 12.58 percent. 
 The bonds bear triple-A ratings from Moody's and Standard & Poor's because they are backed by a surety bond granted by Financial Security Assurance, a unit of U S West Inc., the telephone company.
"The recent auctions have failed, unfortunately, despite the good credit rating and the surety bond backing the bonds," Joseph S. Fichera, a managing director of Bear, Stearns, said on Tuesday. He said the auctions have failed since mid-1990, before which the bonds traded to yield about 8 percent.
Interest is current and being paid by the guarantor. But the high rates have reflected the troubles of Tucson Electric, which faces an involuntary bankruptcy petition.
Under rules of Dutch auctions, the rate is automatically set at a high level as a result of a failed auction. The failure of the auctions has meant that some owners of the bonds who wished to sell them at face value were unable to do so.
The advice that Bear, Stearns might give, according to Tucson Electric, could include converting the interest rate on the bonds from a floating to a fixed rate and then remarketing them. Mr. Fichera said he expected the new rate to be substantially below 12.5 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Quiet Trading; Gold Advances Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined in quiet dealings on world currency markets yesterday.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $355.60 a troy ounce, up $1.40. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $1 an ounce, to a late bid price of $355. 
 The dollar sold off in foreign markets overnight and opened on a soft note in domestic trading. But a Government report showed new-home sales jumped 6.7 percent in August and the larger-than-expected rise set off a technical rally.
"It caused a few people to hold back from selling the dollar further," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. The market had been anticipating a gain of about 1 percent in home sales, he noted.
Still, the dollar settled lower for the day. Trading was quiet over all as it has been all week as dealers await the Labor Department's report tomorrow on employment in September.
"People think this may be the straw that breaks the camel's back in terms of the Federal Reserve having to ease monetary policy," Mr. Donney said. Many market watchers believe weak employment data will prompt the Fed, which trimmed interest rates as recently as Sept. 13, in a bid to stimulate the economy, to lower them further, a move generally bearish for the dollar.
Until the report is released, however, most investors are expected to remain on the sidelines, Mr. Donney said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.07 yen, to a closing 133.11 Japanese yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 132.55 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 132.60 yen, down from 133.40 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7519, from $1.7485 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.7497 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.7465.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6660 German marks, down from 1.6685; 1.4565 Swiss francs, up from 1.4550; 5.6765 French francs, down from 5.6845; 1,246.00 Italian lire, down from 1,247.75, and 1.1308 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1314.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Free Fund Yields Up; Taxables Down

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields of tax-free and taxable money market funds continued to move in opposite directions for the week ended yesterday, with tax-free yields moving up and the yields on taxables heading down.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues the Money Fund Report, said that "the prices of tax exempts are coming down and yields are going up." 
 "There is a shift of money from the short-term money funds into longer- term municipal bond funds," he said, "and the effect has been to drive down prices of the short end of the tax-exempt market and to strengthen prices of longer-term municipal funds."
 
Tax-Exempt Yield: 4.49%
 Mr. Frank said total assets of tax-exempt funds dropped again, by a more substantial amount this time, down by $779 million following a drop the previous week of $308 million. Total assets now are $86.3 billion, and portfolio holdings of the funds averaged 59 days, compared with 60 days a week earlier.
The seven-day compounded average yield for the tax exempts rose to 4.49 percent, up from 4.43 percent a week ago, while the simple yield rose to 4.39 percent from 4.33 percent. Both increases were 6 basis points; a basis point is one hundredth of 1 percent.
Yields for the 30-day period were also up 6 basis points: to 4.34 percent, from 4.28 percent for the compound yield, and to 4.25 percent, from 4.19 percent for the simple yield.
The highest-yielding fund among those with assets over $100 million continued to be the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a 7-day compound yield of 5.37 percent, up from 5.32 percent.
 
State Fund Leaders
 Among funds investing in individual states, in New York State the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market fund continued to head the list, with a 7-day compound yield of 5.05 percent, up from 4.98 percent.
In Connecticut, the Prudential Connecticut Municipal Money Market Series again led with a 5.32 yield, up from 4.76 percent in terms of the 7-day compound yield -- an increase of 44 basis points, largely because of capital gains.
In New Jersey, the leader again was Calvert N.J. Tax-Free Reserves, reporting a 7-day compound yield of 5.16 percent, up from 5.00 percent a week earlier.
 
Taxable Yield Dips to 5.29%
 Among the taxable funds, Mr. Frank said, the average 7-day compound yield dropped to 5.29 percent from 5.31 percent, and the simple yield was 5.16 percent, down from 5.18 percent.
The 30-day compound yield dropped to 5.35 for taxable funds, down from 5.38 percent, and the 30-day simple yield was down to 5.21 percent from 5.24 percent.
Assets of taxable funds declined by $4.1 billion, a much larger drop than the $900 million last week. Assets now total $452.0 billion. Institutional investors accounted for $1.3 billion of the decline, which Mr. Frank described as "an accelerated continuation of the swing from money funds to bond funds."
Average maturities of portfolio holdings of the taxable funds moved up by a day to 61.
The taxable fund with the best return was the Value Line Cash Fund, with a 7-day compound yield of 6.49 percent, helped by a year-end distribution.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped from 5.06 percent to 5.02 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Drop

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell in a quiet session yesterday, weighed down by a Government report showing a surprising jump in home sales in August, an indication that the real estate sector is picking up.
But the downward move was tempered by anxiety about the key unemployment report due tomorrow, which will provide the first official look at the economy's performance in September. Economists have said that if the jobs report is especially weak, the Federal Reserve could be prompted to cut interest rates to spur the recovery. The August unemployment rate was 6.8 percent.
 
Waiting for Numbers
 "Everybody is waiting for the jobs numbers Friday, which may or may not give the Fed an excuse to ease," said Jay Goldinger, a fixed-income specialist at Capital Insight, a Beverly Hills, Calif., investment firm. 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 12/32, or $3.75 for $1,000 face amount, to 103 14/32, raising the yield to 7.82 percent, from 7.79 percent Tuesday.
In the corporate sector, new-issue activity picked up as corporate treasurers scrambled to lock in low rates before tomorrow's employment numbers.
There were five major new deals for a total of $950 million from good- quality debtors. The new-issue activity was led by the triple-A-rated Pfizer Inc., which set a $250 million five-year senior note deal at a yield of 7.18 percent.
The Treasury market began the day on a weak note after the Commerce Department reported new-home sales shot up an unexpected 6.7 percent in August -- the strongest sales pace in more than a year. Economists said lower mortgage rates spurred home-buying interest.
Most credit-market participatns had expected a small decline. But economists said that the housing industry was one of the two strongest sectors of an economy struggling to recover after a yearlong recession. Manufacturing is the other.
 
Report on Greenspan Views
 The market was also weighed down by a report late Tuesday by a Washington consulting firm, Johnson Smick International, which said that Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, was cautious about easing interest rates.
The report said Mr. Greenspan's stance contrasted with other Fed policy makers, who favored a more aggressive effort to force down rates.
Recent Government reports have shown the economy to be on an uneven rebound, hampered by consumer caution in spending because of worry about the job outlook.
The most recent survey of consumer views, a private report by the University of Michigan, showed consumers grew slightly more optimistic about the state of the economy in September.
The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index rose to 83 in September from 82 in August, market sources who saw the report said yesterday. The figure compares with a base of 100 in 1966.
But Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting center at Georgia State University, said: "I think the consumer is very nervous right now. They're not sure the economy's improving."
That appeared to be the prevailing view in the bond market, where traders were optimistic about further price gains and lower interest rates ahead.
"The market retains the view that the economy remains weak and further easing in monetary policy is likely," said Henry Engler, an economist at the Chemical Bank.
Traders said that the Treasury's announcement of a $9.25 billion seven-year note auction, for next Wednesday, helped encourage switching out of the 8 1/4 percent note outstanding. That note closed down 6/ 32 lower at 105 6/32, yielding 7.27 percent.
Among other issues, the three-month Treasury bill ended at 5.09 percent, and the six-month bill at 5.15 percent. The two-year note yielded 6.01 percent and the 10-year note fell 8/32, to 102 24/32, yielding 7.48 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New-Home Sales Rise A Sharp 6.7%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
New-home sales surged 6.7 percent in August to their highest level in a year, according to a Government report today that showed the housing recovery apparently back on track after a brief retreat.
Most analysts said home buyers took advantage of falling mortgage rates to re-enter the market. The renewed sales, the analysts contended, should create more housing starts and permit the industry to continue its traditional role of helping to lead the economy out of recession. 
 All regions increased sales except for the West, where home sales were flat. Sales in the Northeast, which had jumped in July, slowed, while sales in the Midwest, which had plunged in July, rebounded strongly and more than made up their loss.
 
July Rate Revised
 Nationally, sales of new single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 540,000, up from a revised 506,000 rate a month earlier, according to the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development. The August increase was larger than many analysts had expected.
The department originally estimated July sales to have fallen 8.5 percent but changed that to a 2.7 percent drop in today's report. At the same time, they lowered June's initial 4 percent advance to a 2.6 percent gain.
The July decline was the first since sales fell to a 414,000 rate last January, the trough of the housing recession. The August rebound raised the rate to the highest level since a 541,000 sales pace in July 1990.
"Quite clearly, mortgage rates continued to decline in August and that brought buyers off the sidelines and back into the market," said Mark Obrinsky, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association.
Interest on 30-year, fixed-rate conventional mortgages has continued to fall, averaging 8.92 percent during the week ended last Friday. That was the lowest level in 14 years, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
But despite the favorable mortgage rates, most analysts agreed the housing recovery would remain moderate.
Thomas Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said sales would be restrained by "sluggish economic growth and thus sluggish employment growth, and problems with consumer confidence."
David F. Seiders, economist at the National Association of Home Builders, agreed. He is forecasting new-home sales to total just 500,000 this year, down from 534,000 last year and the lowest since 412,000 in the recession year of 1982.
The sales pace for the first eight months of 1991 was 10.1 percent below that of the corresponding period last year.
The Government report said a seasonally adjusted 290,000 new homes were on the market at the end of August, representing a supply of 6.6 months at the current sales rate. That was down from 9.3-month supply in January and the lowest since a similar supply in November 1989.
 
Expecting New Construction
 Analysts said the lean inventory should spur new construction -- if builders obtain financing in a market dominated by restrictive lending practices.
If not, Mr. Seiders warned, inventories will be drawn down even more, resulting in "strong increases" in prices. The median price of a new home was $122,000, up from $120,200 in July. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less.
Regionally, sales soared 24.7 percent in the Midwest, to a 101,000 annual rate, and wiped out the 15.6 percent drop a month earlier. Mr. Holloway said the July decline was a "statistical anomaly that was washed out" in the August report.
In the South, sales rose 5.7 percent, to a 221,000 rate, after falling 1.4 percent in July. Mr. Seiders said the pace was led by sales in the Southwest.
The Northeast posted a 3 percent gain, to a 69,000 rate, slowing from a 13.6 percent advance the previous month. It is another sign "the market there has truly bottomed out," Mr. Seiders said.
But sales were unchanged at a 149,000 rate in the West after falling 2 percent in July. Mr. Seiders said the region was the "last part of the country to weaken" during the slump and "still has a bit of healing to do."

HEADLINE: American Express Sets Reserve for Card Losses

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
With many of its once-affluent customers driven into bankruptcy by the recession, the American Express Company yesterday took its most striking action to date to protect its business from a ballooning number of defaults on its credit cards.
The company said it was setting aside $265 million for the expected defaults and to pay for a reorganization of its flagship charge-card business, including the loss of 1,700 jobs. 
 The move principally reflects major problems with the company's four-year-old Optima credit-card program, which has encountered an unexpectedly large number of delinquencies among its well-to-do clientele. Unlike the company's core business in charge cards, whose balances must be paid monthly, the Optima card, like Visa and Mastercard, extends credit in exchange for a fee and a finance charge.
 
Travel Unit's First Loss Ever
 The $265 million in expenses and expected defaults will yield the first loss ever for the company's Travel Related Services division, which has long been the money machine for the entire company. American Express estimated that the division would post a third-quarter loss of $50 million to $75 million, but made no estimate on the company's overall earnings.
The pressures on American Express, long a dominant force in the financial services industry, stem from a tide of consumer defaults on personal credit lines and underscores the harsh impact the recession has had on the white-collar workers who make up the backbone of the company's credit-card business.
Company officials said the troubles also reflect the frustration of dealing in the credit business in an era when racking up unpayable debts has become increasingly common.
"Societal factors are now making bankruptcy more acceptable, with some raising bankruptcy to a fine art," said Harvey Golub, the company's vice chairman.
But American Express officials also conceded that their strategy for the credit-card business was flawed. "We haven't very successfully run a revolving-credit business," said James D. Robinson 3d, chairman and chief executive.
With credit tight throughout the economy, American Express said it would shift its strategy in the business by increasing its requirements needed to qualify for credit. The company also plans to provide incentives to reward borrowers who consistently repay their debts.
By tightening its credit standards, American Express is signaling its bearish outlook on the economy. "We are not very optimistic about the likelihood of an economic recovery in the near future," Mr. Golub said.
Analysts said the problems at American Express stem in part from its own rapid growth. "This has been a very well-run company, but the entropy has finally caught up with them," said John Keefe, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Securities. "The company got to be too big to avoid economic cycles, and now they are in the soup with the rest of us."
But analysts also praised the reorganization plan, saying it would help strengthen the company's primary business. Indeed, American Express said it expected to save $100 million a year from the reorganization and that it planned to plow that money back into the Travel Related Services division, with programs to ease relations with merchants and entice customers into using the charge card more.
 
Costs Relatively Low
 Even with the waves of defaults, analysts say that Optima, which was introduced in 1987, has still been a net money winner for the company. "Their costs of operation were relatively low," Mr. Keefe of Lipper said. "This has actually been a fairly economical investment for them."
American Express hoped to make money from the Optima card from the combination of fees and monthly charges for credit balances. But the plan became too much of a good thing for consumers, as the balances grew and delinquencies rose, eroding the company's profits.
The ailments in the Optima card operation have not spread significantly to the company's charge card lines -- its green American Express card or its Gold or Platinum cards. Those card holders are a much more diversified group than the Optima holders, who are concentrated on the East and West Coasts, where the recession has hit particularly hard.
To put itself on a stronger financial footing, American Express is cutting the costs of its entire card and travel business, by shutting down some operations and trimming its work force. About 1,700 of American Express's employees, or 3 percent of the work force, will lose their jobs, with about 1,500 of those in the New York area.
The shutdowns, severance for the layoffs and expenses for other aspects of the reorganization will cost American Express $110 million.
American Express said that losses from bad credit, most of which was extended through the Optima card, will cost it $155 million more than it had anticipated. Also included in that amount is $24 million of write-offs from defaults by customers that were not properly reported by American Express for three quarters because of accounting problems.
The accounting errors resulted in some incorrect documents being filed with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by the company's Centurion Bank, which issues the card. The company has contacted Government officials to inform them that corrected records will be submitted.
 
Signs of Troubles
 After decades of growth, the first sign of the severe troubles at American Express came in the first quarter of this year, when the company set aside $50 million to cover bad loans through the Optima card and other credit programs.
Those losses came as American Express was challenged in its bread-and-butter charge-card business by upstart rivals including A.T.& T. and Sears, Roebuck & Company, as well as traditional competitors like banks.
Even as it began to hurt from the increasing competition, the company's pursuit of a wealthier clientele was proving to be a problem, as the recession produced more and more layoffs among well-paid white-collar workers.
With troubles in its credit business, American Express plans to refocus its business around its premier product, the charge card.
The results of the restructuring will include the abandonment of some of its roots. For example, the company will close a regional operating center in New York City, which was the first major charge-card operations center of American Express.
In a memorandum to employees yesterday, Mr. Golub said the company decided to close the center because the cost of upgrading it was much larger than shifting business to other, larger offices.
 
Closing Merchandise Center
 The company will also close a merchandise center in Great Neck, L.I. The center is used for operations connected to the American Express card in which customers can order merchandise through the company.
About 240 employees in the New York area will be transferred to other posts in New York. Those not transferred will be relocated or given severance payments and help in finding another job, Mr. Golub said in the memo.
American Express said the the $100 million it expects to save from the reorganization will be used for several programs related to its card business, like enhancing the relationships between American Express and service establishments, like restaurants. Those relationships have been badly strained over the last year as a number of restaurants protested the comparatively high fee the company charges them for accepting the card.
American Express has already introduced some programs for the benefit of clients like restaurants, partly in response to the protests. In one program, American Express will give fee discounts to merchants who use electronic data systems for charge cards. Such systems send information about a transaction to American Express electronically, eliminating the need for paper slips.
American Express said it would also use the money saved in the reorganization to increase the number of services provided to card members, and to focus more resources on frequent travelers.

HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS;
Excerpts From Senate Hearing on Nomination of C.I.A. Chief

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence's hearing on the nomination of Robert M. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence, as transcribed by the Federal Information Systems Corporation, a private transcription service. Among the Senators on the panel were David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma; Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire; John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island; John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, and Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona. Among the witnesses were Jennifer L. Glaudemans, former Central Intelligence Agency analyst, and Douglas MacEachin, Chief of the Arms Control Intelligence Staff for the C.I.A., who both gave opening statements today, and  Harold P. Ford, a former member of National Intelligence Council who is now a C.I.A. contract employee, and Melvin A. Goodman, a former C.I.A analyst, who both gave opening statements on Tuesday. 
 
COMMENTS BY SENATOR BOREN
 The American people, in many ways, are getting their first real glimpse into the intelligence community through these hearings. They're seeing, perhaps in a more detailed way, how the intelligence community really operates than they've ever seen before. They've learned about the fact that, in many ways, the C.I.A. is not one agency, but two -- that there's a very distinct difference between the operations side of the agency and the intelligence analysis side of the agency. 
 They've learned that even within the analysis side of the agency, there are various bodies that form -- come together to form intelligence analysis, that come to the decision makers.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
STATEMENT BY MS. GLAUDEMANS
 . . . I take no satisfaction in sharing with you the basis of my conviction that Mr. Gates politicized intelligence analysis and is responsible for an overall degradation of the analytical process. During the period when American policy makers deserved and demanded unbiased, objective analysis about Soviet foreign policy in the third world, I believe that they instead at times received distorted studies. Tragically, these slanted studies became the foundation upon which the executive and legislative branches of our Government deliberated momentous foreign policy decisions.
Unfortunately for the C.I.A., another result has been the continued exodus of many good Sovietologists and the loss of an esprit de corps that can only exist in an atmosphere and a culture devoted to the highest standards of excellence.
Let me be clear. I am here today at your request. As you may know, I walked away from this mess nearly two years ago. I find the re-examination of old scars and the publicity surrounding this hearing personally difficult. Until several weeks ago, I had expected that someone else would be testifying in this seat instead of myself . . . I did not wish to bad-mouth the agency in general. There are still too many people working there whom I respect. In fact, I take great comfort in the offers of support I have received from a number of analysts, young and some not so young, still working in the C.I.A. who did not feel that they are at liberty to come before you to speak publicly but did not welcome the prospect of Mr. Gates returning to the C.I.A.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Much of what I describe . . . resulted as much from careless and perhaps deliberate inattention to the maintenance of a culture devoted to truth as it did from a calculated effort to advance the views known to be consistent with the preconceptions of senior policy makers. . . . One cannot be seen as any less troubling than the other. Together, they continue to contribute to the culture of fear and cynicism among frontline analysts. Solving one without the other solves nothing.
There was, and apparently still is, an atmosphere of intimidation within the Office of Soviet Analysis. Many, including myself, hold the view that Mr. Gates had certain people removed because of their consistent unwillingness to comply with his analytical line. Even today, I am aware of a perception in SOVA that managers could risk their positions if they are not sufficiently pliant. There were times when insufficient evidence was irrelevant as long as the judgment was consistent with what Mr. Gates wanted . . .
In the analyst training courses, the C.I.A. taught me that my responsibilities were to be independent. I was taught that there's a tremendous responsibility in weighing evidence and that I had a duty to have a very good working relationship with my collective counterparts so that I could inform them of my intelligence gaps and seek to get what I needed. I also was taught that I had a duty to state that I didn't know certain things in my research. I was taught that intelligence scenarios were meant to explain inconsistencies in evidence or uncertainties because of a gap of evidence.
We were first told in late May 1987, after Mr. Goodman was removed from his office, that the way we did analysis was going to have to change, that the way we packaged and presented our message had to change. We were also subsequently told in a formal memorandum to the Third World Division in May of 1986 that the way we presented our analysis had to change. I was specifically told -- and it also came out in conversations and discussions -- that we were supposed to just describe evidence, that we were not to come to a conclusion, that we were to leave our analysis open-ended so that readers could come to a conclusion themselves.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I heard terms such as "soft on the Soviets" and "Soviet apologist" thrown in certain people's direction. And in the environment such as the C.I.A.'s, where employees must pass a polygraph question about their loyalty to the United States, that can be an extremely inhibiting managerial tool . . .
Because he was so public in his views, I believe Mr. Gates had a special obligation to uphold and protect the independence of C.I.A.'s analysis. His objectivity never came through. Moreover, I believe he had an obligation to clearly distinguish what were his personal views from what were C.I.A. or intelligence community views . . .
When I resigned I told my branch chief, my division chief, my group chief and the deputy office director of SOVA why I was leaving. The only answer I have heard to this perception problem was from Mr. Gates himself a few days ago to this committee. He said that when he was a junior analyst, and his views were not accepted, that he too thought this was politicization.
Senators, I think that answer is the most smug, condescending, and callous answer to such a sensitive question I could possibly imagine. And I believe it offers an insight into Mr. Gates's managerial style. I shudder to think what he might do if he is confirmed as D.C.I. and he gets his hands on those SOVA MAG [Management Advisory Group] reports that you now possess.
I know that as a former employee of the C.I.A., who left at the GS-13 level, I am irrelevant. To the C.I.A. and to its future. But on behalf of those analysts with views that are reflected in the MAG reports you now have, and whose views are reflected in the Memorandums for the Record that your committee staff has compiled, I ask you not to give them the back of your hand. Even if you conclude that the basis for their perceptions -- that analysis has been politicization -- are unfounded, please take care to see that this perception is alleviated in a manner that also sends a clear, loud, and strong signal as to what the analysts' mission really is.
I believe those people deserve a better answer than the one they have been given by Mr. Gates thus far.
 
STATEMENT BY MR. MacEACHIN
 This is very awkward appearance for me. I've tried to be a little light here to start off, but I have to tell you that this is, without question, the worst day or the worst couple days in a 26-year career, for reasons I'll describe. It's also very awkward for me to be here today. I am absolutely, clearly in a no-win position. If Mr. Gates is confirmed he will be my direct supervisor . . . Anything I say in his favor will be viewed by some as statements of a bureaucrat taking care of his career. Anything I might say which is not viewed as favorable will be seen by others as taking care of my career in yet another way.
All I have to hold on to, Mr. Chairman, and I hope at least to have some of it left, is -- after this hearing -- is the credibility I think I've demonstrated over some 26 years as being willing to challenge the conventional view and take whatever flak comes with it. I've made many mistakes in this process: mistakes of substance, mistakes of process. And I paid my share of the bureaucratic penalties for doing so . . .
And I sincerely hope, Mr. Chairman, that the committee does probe into the specific evidence behind all of the assertions that have been made here. Because listening to these proceedings I've been struck by how much they reflect the same approaches and contests and clashes of egos that I have listened to for now more than 26 years. The same characteristics are all there: an emphasis on pieces of evidence that support one case; I think rather careless sourcing; position advocacy rather than balanced assessments. It's going to be left to the committee to sort this out and be the honest brokers.

 	 	 		. . .	 	It is a simple fact that should not have to be recorded that for a large part of the major intelligence issues, the information from which the judgments must be drawn does not permit unambiguous conclusion. Far more often than we'd like, the evidence is quite legitimately subject to different interpretations. . . .
A second fundamental point I'd like to emphasize -- and one that I think should be equally obvious, but I find myself continually repeating it, including in testimony before this committee earlier -- is that the audience for the intelligence product is a very, very tough audience.
It includes senior officials of the executive department and members of Congress and outside experts. And if an intelligence product offers a judgment contrary to a particular policy view, whether a policy which is currently in effect or a policy which is being advocated by someone, it will be challenged, and it will be challenged by people of consequence, who have access to a wide spectrum of views and expertise. . . .
Mr. Chairman, I am going to digress and give you an example. Last Friday, at a meeting one of my staff was attending, at a policy agency . . . agency meeting, a paper which had been published about a week earlier, a paper with which, frankly, I had problems, not because of the bottom line, I had problems with the paper because I thought it didn't offer anything new and didn't really get at the question that was asked, nonetheless, this paper was pointed out to my colleague as being "unhelpful right now," it's unhelpful while we are trying to persuade so-and-so -- I had better not go any further than that. And all we could think of that night is, isn't anybody paying attention to what's going on? . . .
One thing I have a hard time figuring out, Mr. Chairman, is why there are people who find it remarkable that when you go to your boss with a judgment that contradicts the boss's view or which gets your boss crossways with his boss, that you really have to have your act together. It just doesn't surprise me . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	But the charge of politicization -- as I said, my original studies were in economics and literature, so if I resort to literary examples, excuse me -- but it's right straight out of Franz Kafka, because once you are accused, the Inspector General will never come back and say, "You're absolved." You'll never be definitively acquitted. They will never say, "No, that is not the case," they will say, "We found no evidence to substantiate it."

 	 	 		. . .	 	And I'd like to end this with the note I started on, that what we need here is a professional ethic. And I think that the people asking "What will Bob Gates do?" in the very trying times we have ahead for ourselves, major changes in a major new world, I would put that one right very much at the top of the list, and I think he will, too.
 
QUESTIONS FOR PANEL OF WITNESSES
 MR. BOREN: You've now reached a conclusion that Mr. Gates should not be confirmed. . . . What is it that caused you to change your view? . . .
MR. FORD: Why did I change my mind? One, because I began to do some research, looking at the record. My attention was called to the 1985 Iran estimate. I re-read that. I read the subsequent ones. . . . Over the years all kinds of people, largely from the D.D.I., whose abilities and character I respect, had given me all kinds of stories of very unprofessional conduct and of rather dreary consequences.
I purposely pursued this latter kind of thing in the intervening time. Some have had a big effect upon me . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	Also in the intervening time, more of my colleagues have come to me, not at my initiative, but at theirs, and it's a combination of these things that have led me with, as I said, great pain to come down on the side that I feel he should not be confirmed. I was guilty of a great intelligence error myself, speaking personally. I did not think he would be renominated. I was wrong on that . . ..
SENATOR RUDMAN: Mr. Goodman, you accused Gates of suppressing analysts with whom he disagreed on whether or not the Soviets would send MIG aircraft to Nicaragua. And you quoted that "lead with the chin" quote . . . I think it is unhelpful -- unhelpfully leading with our chin to make a prediction when we really don't have anything to go on. . . .
. . . To use that memo about leading with our chin in that closed session -- and, again, I might point out that your testimony in closed session is at variance with your testimony in open session, and I suggest the committee read both, because let me point out: we went in Thursday night never knowing there would be a public session. The whole case might have rested on that closed session, were it not for the insistence of a number of members, mainly the chairman, that this be taken public.
But the fact is you cited that as an example of politicization. Don't you think that's stretching it a bit?
MR. GOODMAN: No, I don't, because I think when analysts are told not to lead with their chin, and the message comes down very strongly, it does have an inhibiting, if not an intimidating, effect on the kind of analysis you do. I don't think what's appreciated here is the courage it takes to come up against the conventional wisdom on all of these issues.

 	 	 		. . .	 	SENATOR HOLLINGS: . . . I've got a lot of confidence in what each of the witnesses have said. I don't have to cross-examine them, like the press is trying to write, "you don't know how to cross-examine." If we had time we could cross-examine and break down, in a sense. But I want honest reaction as to the agency out there and the politicization.

 	 	 		. . .	 	What would you do if you were given Gates's job -- to correct all of this situation? Is it correctable by Mr. Gates?
MR. FORD: Yes, it is correctable. But I don't think it is correctable, sir, by Mr. Gates. Who, as I said earlier, I think is part of the problem and not part of the solution.
There wouldn't have been all these investigations carried on by the C.I.A. itself -- and there have been several -- if there weren't some smoke in the room. The detailed facts is another thing.
But I think it is quite correctable. And what is needed, in my personal view, is a director of national stature. And there are many such people in American life.

 	 	 		. . .	 	. . . Under Mr. Casey and Mr. Gates, I think there's been a retreat from . . . listening to everyone and faithfully recording their views, recording what is fact and -- and what is -- what is not, recording what is hard evidence and what is -- what might be, and we've had, I think, too much in recent years of a few people making big decisions, especially in the D.D.I., so that everyone's views were not listened to.
Now, the details and who's got whom I'm not familiar at the present tense, but the fact that such a malaise -- malaise exists, I think there's no question about it . . .
SENATOR HOLLINGS: . . . Would any other witnesses want to comment very briefly on the morale or the malaise or anything else further than what's been attested to?
You do, Mr. Goodman?
MR. GOODMAN: Yes, Senator, I feel compelled to do so.

 	 	 		. . .	 	When I arrived at the agency in 1966, we had three separate institutions that dealt with analysis . . .
They were three separate entities. They all looked at problems from three separate viewpoints. They had three separate hierarchies. They argued, they debated . . .
And I think there needs to be some re-examination of the way we used to do business in the C.I.A. and the way it was done under Bob Gates when he was allowed to head all political analysis. No political analysis could get out of the C.I.A. from 1982 until 1986 without going through one filter. Now, whoever that man is -- I don't know how wise he can be, how busy he can be, how courageous he can be -- it's too much. We need three institutions, three hierarchies, three leaders, and we need multiple levels of advocacy. . . .
SENATOR CHAFEE: . . . I was curious who these individuals are that you give such weight to, other than -- in other words, going beyond that of Admiral Inman [Bobby Ray Inman, former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence].
MR. FORD: I appreciated when I came to the committee in closed session that I was up against tough competition. These are senior, respected people who have testified on behalf of the Director -- on behalf of Mr. Gates. I will say it's much easier for someone to testify in favor of someone because they don't have to make their case. They can make a general statement, and everyone leaves them alone. If you've got criticism, then you have to be put in the penalty box, and I think that that's the way we're being treated today, sir. . . .
But to return to your question. . . .
I could give the committee -- I'd rather not give them in . . .
SENATOR CHAFEE: O.K. Mr. Goodman, in answer to one of the agency's in-house studies on the papal assassination, you stated under oath last week, quote, "It concluded the analysts were manipulated by Bob Gates." You said that's what the study showed.

 	 	 		. . .	 	MR. GOODMAN: Oh, I'd be very glad to help you with that one, Senator. You want to go to the -- remember, there were two in-house studies, Cowey and Hibbits. If you go to the Cowey inside -- in-house study, and go toward the back of that study, you will see reflected in there the perception in the building that the analysts were manipulated by the seventh floor.
Now, when I read a message like that -- now --
SENATOR CHAFEE: The seventh floor, we've got to remember, is -- not all Mr. Gates.
MR. GOODMAN: . . . except when a . . . when a D.I. analyst talks about the seventh floor -- believe me, Senator, I worked in that building for 24 years -- when a D.I. analyst talks about the 7th Floor, he is talking about the D.D.I. No in-house study is ever going to name the D.D.I. No I.G. study is going to be very sensitive -- is going to reveal very sensitive messages about upper management.

 	 	 		. . .	 	SENATOR DeCONCINI: When the committee did interview Mary Desjeans, one of the authors of the 1985 report [papal assessment], she said she was told not to talk about it with anybody or tell anybody what I was working on. So, Mr. MacEachin, is that normal, by any means?
MR. MacEACHIN: Oh, no, sir.
SENATOR DeCONCINI: No, sir. And do you know who might have issued that order not to talk to anybody and tell her what she was working on? Did you issue that order?
MR. MacEACHIN: The -- I certainly did, because that was the order that was given to me.
SENATOR DeCONCINI: And who gave you that order?
MR. MacEACHIN: That paper -- that was by Mr. Gates.
SENATOR DeCONCINI: Mr. Gates --
MR. MacEACHIN: Sure.
SENATOR DeCONCINI: -- gave you that order. Thank you.
MR. MacEACHIN: Senator, that is not unusual for a sensitive subject --
MR. GOODMAN: I . . . that is not true.
MR. MacEACHIN: That's -- that's --
MR. GOODMAN: I was in the building for 24 years, and --
SENATOR BOREN: [Sounds gavel.] I'm going to have to ask -- I'm going to have to ask . . .
MR. GOODMAN: . . . that was very unusual.

 	 	 		. . .	 	SEN. DECONCINI: What was your position under Mr. MacEachin?
MR. GOODMAN: At that time I had been removed by Bob Gates as the Chief for Soviet Third World Division --
SEN. DECONCINI: So actually, when --
MR. GOODMAN: And to be fair to Doug, Doug said that Gates wanted me out of the D.I. And Doug --
SEN. DECONCINI: So there was good reason for him not to --
MR. GOODMAN: No, Doug --
SEN. DECONCINI: -- not to tell you, then, because you had been --
MR. GOODMAN: No, he made me the senior analyst in the office, and that's important.
SEN. DECONCINI: Okay, let me get this right. At the time that Mr. Gates went to Mr. MacEachin and said, "Do this secretly" or "limitedly," whatever you want --
MR. GOODMAN: March 1985.
SEN. DECONCINI: At that time, March 1985, were you his chief analyst, or had you been removed?
MR. GOODMAN: I was the chief of the Soviet Third World Division until March 15, 1985. On that day I became --
SEN. DECONCINI: So you were not his chief analyst then?
MR. GOODMAN: On that date I became his chief analyst. And I think if I were the chief of that office I would have wanted my chief analyst, who he respected -- and he's already on record and I thank him for that -- to show it to him. Because I do think that Doug respects my judgment, just as I respect Doug's.

 	 	 		. . .	 	SENATOR WARNER: . . . To Mr. MacEachin, and I ask it in a very concise and pointed way, did Bob Gates ever, to you, slant intelligence?
MR. MacEACHIN: No, sir.
SENATOR WARNER: Did he ever, in any way, try and suppress facts that were essential to an intelligence report?
MR. MacEACHIN: Suppress facts, no, sir. He, as has been discussed, sometimes killed a paper from publication, but that was the opinion or the judgment . . . All the D.D.I.'s do that.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jennifer L. Glaudemans, former C.I.A. analyst, during her testimony yesterday at the Senate Intelligence Committee hearing. Other witnesses were, at rear from the left, Douglas J. MacEachin, Graham E. Fuller, Lawrence Gershwin and Melvin A. Goodman. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Decoding the C.I.A."
 A glossary of terminology used at the Gates confirmation hearings.
 
D.C.I.: Director of Central Intelligence, the head of the C.I.A. and overseer of the bureaucracy that includes the C.I.A. and other espionage agencies.
 
D.D.C.I.: Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.
 
D.D.I.: Deputy director for intelligence, head of the C.I.A.'s analysis division.
 
D.I.: Directorate of Intelligence, the C.I.A.'s analysis division.
 
D.I.A.: Defense Intelligence Agency.
 
National Intelligence Estimates (N.I.E.'s): The most important and best-read of intelligence analyses, written to reflect the consensus of experts in all the major intelligence agencies. Special National Intelligence Estimates are a more hastily prepared version and are often issued to predict or respond to sudden changes in world events. The estimates are issued by the National intelligence Council.
 
N.I.C. (National Intelligence Council): A group of senior intelligence analysts who advise the Director of Central Intelligence and coordinate the writing or analyses with experts throughtout the intelligence establishment.
 
N.I.O.: National Intelligence Officer, a senior analyst and intelligence specialist who sits on the National Intelligence Council.
 
N.S.C.: National Security Council, the White House agency that advises the President on foreign policy.
 
O.G.I.: Office of Global Issues, a C.I.A. analytical shop created in 1981 by the former Director of Central Intelligence William J. Casey to focus on third world issues and other problems that cross geographic boundaries or academic disciplines.
 
Presidents Daily Brief (P.D.B.): The six-days-a-week publication prepared by C.I.A. analysts to inform the President and other senior officials about world developments.
 
SOVA: The C.I.A.'s Office of Soviet Analysis, its collection of analysts on Soviet issues.

HEADLINE: Senators Yield to Bush on the Israeli Aid Request

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
In an expected yet unusual setback for Israel and its advocates on Capitol Hill, Senators today formally acceded to President Bush's request for a 120-day postponement in considering Israeli loan guarantees.
While an overwhelming majority of 70 Senators sponsored the proposal to offer the $10 billion in guarantees to help resettle Soviet Jews, Senators Bob Kasten and Daniel K. Inouye declared that they would not force an embarrassing showdown with the White House. The number of sponsors would have been enough to override a veto threatened by President Bush. 
 "It is clear to us that our colleagues do not wish a confrontation over the issue of delay," Mr. Kasten, a Wisconsin Republican, asserted on the Senate floor. He added that "the President and other high officials of the Administration have been, by and large, positive on the substance of absorption guarantees."
Mr. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, said, "We believe that the President recognizes the urgency of resettlement."
In a statement pledging support for Israel, House and Senate Democratic leaders said they would give "careful consideration" to the matter when Congress convenes early next year.
 
The President's Argument
 Yet the lawmakers' decision not to challenge Mr. Bush could mean that he would get his way in imposing economic conditions on the loan guarantees. The President had pressed for the delay in weighing the guarantees, arguing that a debate over them would hinder the Administration's plans for a Middle East peace conference next month.
Mr. Bush pointedly accused lawmakers opposed to the delay of trying to please their Jewish constituents, while his critics said he was retaliating for Israel's continued expansion of settlements in the occupied territories.
Margaret Tutwiler, a State Department spokeswoman, said the delay by Congress was "a welcome affirmation of the President's judgment that a pause" would be "in the best interests of the historic opportunity for peace that lies before us." The Administration, she said, would support the guarantees next year, "provided terms and conditions acceptable to the Administration are worked out."
Groups that lobby on behalf of Israel today emphasized the widepread support for the gurantees in the Senate rather than the lawmakers' decision to agree to the delay.
The American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the most potent pro-Israel lobby, which usually tries to keep a low public profile, took the unusual step of issuing a statement praising today's developments. "We're extremely pleased with the overwhelming bipartisan support in the Congress for securing the refugee guarantees," said Toby Derschowitz, a spokeswoman for the group.
Alfred H. Moses, president of the American Jewish Committee, disputed in an interview that the delay was a significant setback.
 
Avoiding a Confrontation
 "The Jewish community is not looking for a confrontation with the Administration," he said. "That would be a lose-lose situation. What we're hoping for is that the Administration in January will support the loan guarantees."
While groups and lawmakers that champion Israel often wield significant political influence, they said they backed down from taking on the President this time because they were subjected to White House pressure more intense than many had ever experienced before.
"It's in no one's interest to have a shootout at O.K. Corral," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a New York Republican who had pressed for immediate consideration of the guarantees. "One has to recognize the pragmatic side of what a losing effort might bring about."
Sponsoring the Kasten-Inouye measure was a relatively risk-free move by Senators because pivotal lawmakers made it clear several days ago that they would not force a vote on the matter.

HEADLINE: BUSH VOWS TO VETO NEW JOBLESS BILL

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Vowing to veto a new bill extending jobless benefits, President Bush said today that he was "a little annoyed at the constant political pressure" about unemployment, civil rights and other issues, telling everyone that he still had not formally announced for re-election.
As he left the White House today on a three-state day trip mixing political fund raising with official events intended to promote his domestic policies in preparation for the 1992 campaign, Mr. Bush seemed irritated that he was being increasingly treated as a candidate by the Democrats and in news reports, even though he has not declared himself in the race. 
 "We want to help the unemployed, put forward a sound crime package and all of a sudden, everyone says it's political," Mr. Bush said. "Now I assume that's just because we're getting close to 1992."
Mr. Bush later criticized the unemployment bill in a similar way, saying: "The Democratic leaders, I think they sense a political issue they can use next year against all of us. They were determined to pass and ram down my throat a budget-busting bill. Every taxpayer in the country will be burdened by their approach. I will veto the bill."
 
Air of a Campaign
 In recent weeks, Mr. Bush's domestic trips have increasingly taken on the air of a campaign. But his advisers say he remains reluctant to announce his candidacy and has even delayed forming the financial committee that he said he would put together in September, because he would prefer to avoid the disadvantages of being a candidate for as long as possible.
Once he declares, Mr. Bush will be under greater pressure to respond to the Democrats seeking their party's nomination and will be more subject to accusations of using Presidential travel to campaign.
"Yes, I expect people to say it's political, but that's just the time of year -- that's just the season" Mr. Bush said on the White House lawn before leaving Washington. He added: "So I'm not going to be worried about it, nor am I going to be deterred by it. Nor am I going to let a handful of Democrats announce -- and I'm not announced -- set the agenda for this country. They weren't elected to do something. I was, and I'm going to keep on trying to do it."
Today, he went to Pittsburgh for a fund-raising event for Dick Thornburgh, the former Attorney General who is running for the Senate in Pennsylvania and then traveled to Louisville, Ky., for a conference of citizens who try to help the police catch criminals, known as Crime Watchers. He also attended a fund-raising event for Representative Larry J. Hopkins's campaign for governor before flying to Nashville for the annual awards of the Country Music Association.
 
Criticism of Rights Bill
 Along the way, he blasted the Democrats on the debate over a civil rights bill that is pending before Congress. "I want to sign a civil rights bill, but I want to sign a good bill," he said, referring to his criticism of a Democratic civil rights bill as establishing employment quotas.
He also joined Republicans who accused the Democrats in Congress of using the unemployment issue for political gain.
"They know very well I can't sign it," Mr. Bush said of the new unemployment measure. "If they want to help the unemployed and those who have no benefits, they ought to work cooperatively with this Administration."
Although the Senate vote on Tuesday for the unemployment bill, 63 to 35, was two votes short of the two-thirds majority that would be needed in the Senate to put the bill into law over Mr. Bush's objections, the President seemed clearly irked today to be challenged again by a Congress with which he has been fighting a duel of legislation and vetoes since he took office. The House vote earlier on the same $6.4 billion bill was more than enough to override a veto.
Mr. Bush said that the bill would break last year's agreement on reducing the budget deficit and that Congress should consider a $1.9 billion bill sponsored by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader.
The Democratic bill would add to the budget deficit, while the Dole bill would eventually pay for itself.
Mr. Bush said: "What I want is a bill that doesn't bust this budget. I've made that very clear from Day 1. We're prepared to extend unemployment benefits. In fact, I'd like to see it done, but I'm not going to go out and put the burden on all the rest of the people in this country."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush and Dick Thornburgh, Republican candidate for the Senate from Pennsylvania, at a fund-raiser in Pittsburgh. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS;
Battle Over World View

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The internal intelligence feuds over Nicaragua, Iran and papal assassination laid bare in Congress this week were but skirmishes in a struggle during the 1980's to shape the lens through which American intelligence viewed the Soviet Union: as an implacably evil force or an empire in retreat and flux.
For the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, the central question is whether Robert M. Gates, the hard-line Soviet expert who now seeks to become Director of Central Intelligence, played an intellectually honest role in that struggle, or was driven purely by ambition and political loyalty.
 
How to Promote C.I.A.
 The battleground was the Central Intelligence Agency's analytical division, the Directorate of Intelligence, which Mr. Gates and his boss, William J. Casey, thoroughly shook up from the first days of their arrival in 1981. The two men were the avowed leaders in a crusade to restore American intelligence, and especially the C.I.A., to a front-line post in the cold war and a first-tier seat in the councils of the White House. 
 But scores of analysts in the Intelligence Directorate, and especially in its Soviet section, took a far more benign view of the Soviet threat and were uneasy with the ideological fervor and pessimism of Mr. Casey and Mr. Gates, said current and former intelligence officials and Administration policymakers.
The result was a clash not just of philosophies, but of fundamental world views, in the C.I.A. department that produced some of the Government's most sensitive and important analyses of foreign issues.
Some combatants in this struggle turned up this week before the Senate Intelligence Committee, bringing accusations that Mr. Gates and Mr. Casey perverted their judgments on Soviet affairs into a gloomier, more threatening picture of Moscow's intentions and abilities. Mr. Gates has cast himself as a champion of hard-headed, but independent analysis, and has previously denied ever shading any intelligence analysis for political gain.
The foremost casualty may have been a more accurate picture of the true Soviet Union in the early to mid-1980's, a time when both the intelligence agency and the White House depicted Moscow as a dangerously expansionist power with a slowing but still powerful economy, and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, after he assumed power in 1985, as a historical fluke who was unlikely to have a lasting impact on his country.
An internal C.I.A. review released by the committee this week concluded that at least one controversial analysis was affected by the pervasive belief that the agency's top officials held strong views on the subject, and that some analysts had been "apprehensive about whether their views would be well-received up the line" since 1981.
"I know many people felt that the direction of the line under Casey made it more difficult to stay there and remain true to their version of the facts," one Bush Administration official, a Soviet expert who witnessed some of the debates, said today. "There was a definite feeling that the leadership was actively promoting a harder line and that the way to get ahead was to follow it."
Within the agency's Soviet division, the hot spot of analysis and the prestige job in the Directorate of Intelligence, at least a half-dozen ranking analysts left their jobs in the early and mid-1980's, the official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. There is little doubt that morale was low among the agency's Soviet hands and that Mr. Gates, who headed the directorate from 1982 to 1986, shares responsibility for that. Mr. Gates carried out an overhaul of the entire analysis division that split the Soviet office from its Eastern Europe counterparts and threw together experts on an array of subjects, sparking turf fights and some confusion.
As memorandums made public this week also show, he could be a pitiless critic of subordinates, lecturing them on Soviet history and belittling them for what he saw as a naive view of Moscow's intentions.
But intellectual brawls are nothing new within the C.I.A.'s analytical division, and, in fact, are officially encouraged as a way to weed out weak ideas and sloppy thinking. The agency teaches analysts to argue their views in special courses and runs a working group on ethics and intelligence analysis to encourage analysts to resist political pressure to alter their views.
The bitter feuding revealed this week in the Senate, "independent of the political context, is probably the norm at the C.I.A. and probably something to be hoped for," said Allan Goodman, a senior aide to President Jimmy Carter's Director of Central Intelligence, Stansfield Turner. "When I was at the agency, my stuff was reviewed more closely than any academic publication I ever submitted," Mr. Goodman said. "That's what they're paying people to do."
It is also true that some intelligence experts who are less passionate than Mr. Gates about the Soviet Union believe that Mr. Casey may have had a point. The C.I.A.'s Soviet office in the early 1980's harbored the most optimistic view of Moscow's intentions of any intelligence agency in the Government, they say. Their judgments sometimes were sought out by Administration policy makers seeking to thwart policies they believed wrongheadedly anti-Soviet.
The question clouding Mr. Gates's nomination to head the agency is whether he acted as an honest reformer at the C.I.A., seeking to raise fresh questions in a group of experts whom he believed had become too orthodox, or whether he simply acceded to demands of superiors to produce intelligence that would support the Administration's anti-Communist crusade.
"You have to realize that the moment the analyst gets wind of the fact that only a certain view is politically correct, then you don't have to make that point more than once, and then the whole process is skewed," said Mr. Goodman, now dean of Georgetown University's graduate school of foreign service. "If they think it had a chilling effect, something was wrong. If they thought there was an atmosphere of politicization, then something is wrong."
The internal C.I.A. documents released this week reinforce that view. Because Mr. Casey was so publicly anti-Soviet, and other officials like Mr. Gates shared his ideology, one paper suggested there may have been a perception that intelligence had to be slanted, whether in fact that demand existed.
 
Wrangling Over Embargo
 Some officials believe that those strong views at the top only made analysts more determined to resist pressure. The Bush Administration official recalled today, for example, that Mr. Casey pressed vigorously for evidence to support the Reagan Administration's decision, in the early 1980's, to call for an embargo of Western goods and technology to a Soviet gas pipeline then being built. But the C.I.A.'s own views on the embargo -- that it would not work -- appear not to have been swayed, he said.
David Whipple, a retired C.I.A. officer who was Mr. Casey's chief terrorism analyst from 1983 to 1985, today recalled attending Congressional briefings with his boss and hearing Mr. Casey attribute many of the world's bombings and assassinations to the Soviet K.G.B.
"Then he'd have to be excused to go back to work, and the committees would ask me to stay on for the afternoon session,' he said. "And I would, as tactfully as possible, try to leave the committee with the right impression -- that you can't prove Soviet involvement, that it's likely the Sovs weren't involved.
Mr. Whipple, now head of an association of former intelligence officers, said that several times he consulted Mr. Gates for advice on how to deal with the situation, and was told by Mr. Gates, "Stick to your guns."
