HEADLINE: Vietnam Agrees to Forced Return Of Its Citizens From Asian Camps

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Vietnam has tentatively agreed to accept the forced return of tens of thousands of Vietnamese refugees now held in camps throughout Southeast Asia, diplomats and refugee workers said today.
The decision, a major policy reversal for Vietnam, would allow nations housing Vietnamese refugees to send them home by force if they are determined to have fled their country for economic reasons, rather than out of a well-founded fear of persecution. 
 "The first of them may be forced onto planes or boats and sent home by the end of the year," a Western diplomat said. "The saga of the Vietnamese boat people would be all but over. It could be a rather ugly ending."
The Vietnamese offer reported today had been sought by Britain, and would doubtless be welcomed by several Southeast Asian nations that are now sheltering boat people and have sought for years to send them back to Vietnam. But the United States brought a halt to a similar Vietnamese plan two years ago, and may try to derail that proposal.
[In Washington, a spokesman for the State Department said American officials had not yet received details of the proposal but noted that the United States has long been opposed to forcible repatriation of the boat people.
["Our position on involuntary repatriation is well known," said Joseph Snyder, the spokesman. Mr. Snyder said that American diplomats had been in contact with the British and United Nations officials responsible for the new proposal but as yet have not received all the details.]
More than 100,000 Vietnamese refugees are living in refugee camps in Southeast Asia -- about half of them in the British colony of Hong Kong and the rest mainly in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines.
Until now, Vietnam has opposed mandatory repatriation of the refugees, in part because it lacks the money and other resources needed to resettle them.
More than 6,000 boat people have gone home to Vietnam under a two-year-old voluntary repatriation program in which they are given living allowances drawn from an international fund for refugees and are monitored by representatives of the United Nations to be certain they are not persecuted.
Diplomats said the Vietnamese offer to accept forced repatriation of the boat people had been made in discussions over the last two weeks with British and United Nations officials.
 
Ending U.S. Embargo
 But the offer has not been formally announced in Hanoi, and diplomats warned today that it might be quickly withdrawn if there were strong objections from the United States, which the Vietnamese Government is reluctant to offend.
Vietnam has sought to restore diplomatic relations with the United States and to end a punishing American economic embargo on this impoverished nation.
The United States expressed outrage when, in December 1989, the authorities in Hong Kong forced 51 Vietnamese refugees, many of them kicking and screaming, onto a plane in the middle of the night and flew them to Vietnam. There have been no forced repatriations since.
The exodus of Vietnamese began shortly after the end of the Vietnam War in 1975. Vietnamese, some seeking to flee political persecution, many others trying simply to escape the wretched poverty of their homeland, took to rickety boats, and tens of thousands died in the treacherous journey across the Gulf of Tonkin and the South China Sea.
 
'Economic Migrants'
 Under a 1989 international agreement intended to end the exodus, Vietnamese refugees who cannot demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution are labeled as "economic migrants" and must be returned to Vietnam.
More than 80 percent of the Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong and elsewhere in Southeast Asia are estimated to fall into that category, refugee workers say.
But since the Governments of Vietnam and the United States object to forced repatrition, it is not being carried out, even as hundreds of new refrugees flee from Vietnam each month.
The authorities in Hong Kong, where the crisis is most severe, maintain that most of the Vietnamese in its camps are illegal aliens and should be sent home without delay.
 
'Trying to Escape Poverty'
 "The international community is returning to forced repatriation because it has to," said a diplomat who is sympathetic to Hong Kong's situation.
"The boat people who are leaving Vietnam today are not searching for political freedom so much as they are trying to escape poverty," he said. "At some point, we have to ask ourselves why the Vietnamese should receive privileges that we do not extend to others who are also trying to escape poverty."

HEADLINE: CROATIAN APPEALS FOR A CEASE-FIRE

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Croatia's president appealed to the federal army today for a new cease-fire in the Yugoslav civil war, offering to lift the blockade of federal army barracks in Croatia if the army will call off an offensive against the breakaway republic that began Tuesday.
The appeal by Franjo Tudjman came as Yugoslav army and Serbian irregulars kept up a steady artillery barrage from positions extending from Vukovar, on the eastern panhandle near the border between Croatia and Serbia, down to the medieval city of Dubrovnik on the southern Adriatic. 
 There was no direct response from the Yugoslav army to the appeal by Mr. Tudjman, but federal army officers in Belgrade earlier appeared to reject any new initiative. "The time for talking is definitely finished," the army commanders said in a statement issued before Mr. Tudjman's appeal. "We no longer believe in words."
 
Letter to Bush
 Mr. Tudjman also sent a letter today to President Bush pleading for aid for Croatia and calling on Washington to send military observers to monitor the fighting there.
"The Yugoslav army is preparing its final attack on cities in the Republic of Croatia," Mr. Tudjman said in his letter, adding that the army's actions have endangered Croatian cultural monuments.
The best known of those monuments is the walled limestone city of Dubrovnik, a major tourist attraction whose alleys, terraces and plazas echo Venetian and Byzantine influences. Dubrovnik has been under seige by Serbian forces and the Yugoslav navy since last weekend.
Recent reports say that no major damage has been done to the historic section of the city, but that hotels on the perimenter have been hit by shells and a fire is raging in a forest south of the town. Electricity, water and telephone service has been cut off to the city and jet fighters today reportedly knocked out television and radio transmitters.
The latest cease-fire appeal came following a meeting in Rome between Mr. Tudjman and Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti and Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis of Italy.
Mr. Tudjman traveled to Italy to lobby for diplomatic recognition for Croatia, economic sanctions against both Serbia and Yugoslavia's federal government and for a peacekeeping force to be sent to Croatia.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has No Plan to Ask for Direct Aid for Soviets

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The Administration has no plans to ask Congress for any direct assistance to the Soviet Union other than humanitarian aid and technical advice over the next year, a State Department official said today.
Remarks by Robert B. Zoellick, the Under Secretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs, before the House subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East appeared to indicate that the United States would not support such ventures as a special fund to make the ruble freely convertible into other currencies. Echoing President Bush, Mr. Zoellick added, "On the humanitarian side, we will be there as necessary." 
 Mr. Zoellick declined to specify what if any additional help the United States would provide if the Soviet Union adopted the policy changes urged by the United States, like a move toward a freer economy.
Without a separate request to Congress for additional direct assistance, the Administration must seek money from existing programs that already have their own spending plans, Mr. Zoellick said.
 
Report on Soviet Changes
 In a report on the Administration's views of changes in the Soviet Union, Mr. Zoellick also made these observations in his testimony:
*There was a danger that just as the Soviet Union had broken apart into many republics, the republics themselves might fragment into smaller areas, "if the new leaders fail to establish legitimacy through democracy with respect for minority rights."
*The International Monetary Fund will likely sign a document in Moscow this weekend giving special associate status to the Soviet Union. I.M.F. officials said privately that the fund's Managing Director, Michel Camdessus, was likely to go to Moscow but that no final agreement had been reached on the special status, which would allow the Soviet Union to receive technical advice but not large loans from the fund.
*While the Soviet Union is easily able to service its $60-$65 billion foreign debt over the long run, it faces a temporary cash shortage and the Group of Seven major industrial nations is studying ways to provide short-term help with the debt.
*A recent estimate that the Soviet Union's remaining gold reserves are worth only $3 billion appears credible.
*Although widespread famine is unlikely in the Soviet Union this winter, food shortages will cause hardships, especially for old people, young people and republics like Armenia that are farthest from places where surplus food is grown or imported. The United States is considering shipments of baby food and milk directly to the republics to insure that the neediest families receive it.
*The United States is likely to expand its program of humanitarian medical aid, which has sent $11 million to the Soviet Union since December.
Also today, John D. Macomber, the president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, said that the Federal agency now requires that any projects it may finance in Russia or the Ukraine be guaranteed by the governments of these republics and not just by the central Soviet government.
The bank is also prepared to begin financing energy projects in the Soviet Union, Mr. Macomber said.
In a separate announcement the bank said that it had used up its entire budget authorization of $10.6 billion in insurance and loan guarantees, the first time it had done so since a limit was set on these categories in 1981.

HEADLINE: THE O.A.S. AGREES TO ISOLATE CHIEFS OF HAITIAN JUNTA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The Organization of American States agreed late tonight on a campaign of diplomatic pressure to isolate the new military junta in Haiti and restore the elected Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
O.A.S. officials said they had agreed on a resolution calling for a suspension of all economic, commercial, diplomatic and military assistance to the coup leaders. They also agreed that if these steps did not lead to a restoration of democracy, they would consider other measures, which they declined to specify at this time. 
 The officials said they had agreed to send a delegation to Port-au-Prince, possibly as early as Thursday, to make it clear to the new leadership how isolated they are and how economically deprived their Government will be if it does not immediately restore President Aristide to power.
 
Opening Address
 Father Aristide, a 38-year-old leftist Roman Catholic priest who was inaugurated in February, opened a special meeting at the Western Hemisphere organization's headquarters here.
In a passionate speech, he appealed to the 34-nation group to immediately send a delegation to Port-au-Prince to try to explain to "the criminals who have taken power" what economic price they will pay and what other measures "have been taken and could be taken" if they do not step aside.
Bush Administration officials said they were determined to reverse the coup in Haiti, having spent a great deal of time and energy over the years trying to produce a democratic government in Port-au-Prince, but President Bush said he was not inclined to use American military force.
 
Prefers Not to Use Arms
 Mr. Bush left open the possibility that Washington might support the dispatch of a multinational force organized by the O.A.S. or the United Nations, but not including American combat troops. Officials seemed to hope that diplomatic and economic pressure would be sufficient to persuade the new military leaders to step aside.
The situation in Port-au-Prince, where more than 100 people have been reported killed in fighting since the coup began Sunday night, was reported to be calm but confused. The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said that "scattered firing has died down," but that "there does not appear to be any central government in control."
The airport in Port-au-Prince remained closed.
The Associated Press reported from Port-au-Prince that the leader of the junta, Brig. Gen. Raoul Cedras, said today that the military would give decision-making power to the elected National Assembly, but did not indicate that executive authority would also be handed over.
General Cedras told a news conference that the military uprising began among the rank and file, not senior officers, and that he and other army commanders had intervened to save Father Aristide's life. "I personally protected the President," the general was quoted as saying.
He added that the mutiny was a reaction to flagrant abuses of power by President Aristide, adding that the last straw was the formation of a presidential guard under Father Aristide's direct command.
General Cedras further asserted that Father Aristide had not been toppled, but had resigned, The A.P. reported. When pressed for details of the resignation, General Cedras dismissed this as a "stupid" line of questioning. He also dismissed suggestions that he step aside. "I personally do not believe it's a good idea for Aristide to return," he said.
Father Aristide flew to Washington from Caracas, where he fled early Tuesday aboard a Venezuelan Government aircraft hours after being toppled.
 
Emigres Turn Out

Today, while he spoke, hundreds of Haitians gathered outside the O.A.S. building, beating drums, ringing cymbals and waving signs saying: "We Want Aristide Back in Power."
The ousted President began his speech by telling the foreign ministers how the coup evolved, saying that rumors of an impending mutiny started to reach him on Saturday. He said he confronted General Cedras and was repeatedly told that there was nothing to the rumors. Two days later, though, as the mutiny spread throughout the army, Father Aristide said General Cedras confronted him at the National Palace and said, "Now I am President."
Father Aristide said the general then turned to a group of Haitian soliders and asked what they wanted to do with him. Some said to kill him, others said he should be spared so as not to have trouble with Western powers. Eventually, Father Aristide said, it was decided to let him flee the country with the help of the French, American and Venezuelan envoys.
Father Aristide called on all Haitians to "stay mobilized" against the coup, but to use only nonviolent means. The O.A.S. ministers gave him a standing ovation
The organization, at its meeting in Santiago, Chile, in June, agreed for the first time that since every member was now more or less a democracy, its foreign ministers would be authorized to "adopt any measures deemed appropriate" to restore constitutional rule if democratic processes in any member country are overturned.
As the foreign ministers worked out their response to the coup, Pentagon officials said a contingent of 300 to 400 marines had been dispatched from Camp Lejeune, N.C., to the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station in Cuba to prepare for a possible evacuation of the roughly 8,000 Americans living in Haiti -- if the Administration determines that their security is in danger.
Officials said they would go into Haiti with planes or heavy-lift helicopters to bring out Americans if the order was given.
But President Bush made clear that the United States was not inclined to intervene on its own in an attempt to restore the Aristide Government.
"I am disinclined to use American force," he said. "We've got a big history of American force in this hemisphere, and so we've got to be very careful about that. But I will see how others feel at the O.A.S. There might be some talk over there now about a multinational force of some sort, so we'll have to wait and see."
Mr. Bush also said he was not inclined to impose economic sanctions, like a trade boycott, to reverse the coup because "the problem with that one is you start hurting the Haitian people."
The State Department suspended all economic aid to Haiti on Tuesday and refused to extend diplomatic recognition to the coup plotters.
Haiti, the hemisphere's poorest country, was scheduled to receive $84 million in American economic help and $1.5 million in noncombat military aid this fiscal year, which ended Monday. About $66 million still has not been allocated to the hemisphere's poorest country. In the new fiscal year, it is supposed to receive $88.6 million in economic and food aid and $2.2 million in military assistance.
Some experts questioned whether the aid cutoff, an action that has also been taken by the European Community, France and Canada, would be able to reverse the coup.
Robert A. Pastor, an Emory University expert on Latin America and a member of the international commission that observed the Haitian elections this year, said:
"Unless the O.A.S. goes further, they may be repeating the mistakes made in Nicaragua and Panama -- of sending a delegation to negotiate with a military dictator without sufficient leverage to assure the desired outcome. My view is that you really need to put together a package of sequenced sanctions and get them all publicly accepted at the beginning to send a clear message to the military of the consquences of its failure to step down."
American officials said that while they cannot simply let the Haitian coup stand, they should not get ahead of the O.A.S., which has repeatedly denounced American military interventions in the hemisphere.
The question of intervention has bedeviled and paralyzed the organization for the 40 years of its existence. It has been caught between its support for representative democracy and its adherence to the principle of nonintervention in the internal affairs of members.
When the O.A.S. was dominated by dictatorships, the principle of nonintervention held sway. Now, with the rise of new democratic leaders in the hemisphere, American officials question whether the organization will take a more active approach in the coming weeks.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in his address to the group, declared: "It is imperative that we agree for the sake of Haitian democracy and the cause of democracy throughout this hemisphere, to act collectively to defend the legitimate government of President Aristide. Words alone are not going to suffice. This is a time for collective action."
He added that until President Aristide's government is restored, "this junta will be treated as a pariah throughout this hemisphere, without assistance, without friends, and without any future."
If diplomatic and economic efforts to isolate the Haitian junta "do not succeed," the Secretary of State said, "then we must consider additional steps," but he did not elaborate.

HEADLINE: Doctor Acts to Heal Romania's Wound Of Baby Trafficking

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Dr. Alexandra Zugravescu has spent most of her life in Bucharest hospitals, tending to the health of Romanian children. Now, this 66-year-old pediatrician is tending to the well-being of her country, trying to cure one of its most publicized scandals: the selling of babies for adoption. Her task, as she explains it, is to wipe out "the dirty business of baby trafficking."
Efforts by Dr. Zugravescu and the new Government agency that she heads, the Romanian Committee for Adoptions, will affect a great many families in the United States. In the last year, Romania, which has a large population of abandoned and orphaned children as a legacy of the Communist dictatorship that was deposed in 1989, has overtaken South Korea as the leading source for foreign adoptions by Americans. 
 A ban on abortion and contraception under the old regime and grinding poverty that left many people unable to support a family turned children into a commodity that was sometimes sold on the streets.
As a first step in carrying out a new law to control adoptions, Romania has temporarily halted adoptions by foreigners. Those adoptions will not resume again until January, at the earliest, Dr. Zugravescu said here last week.
Dr. Zugravescu completed a 10-day visit to Washington, during which she met with Government officials and child-welfare experts, just as her country was thrown once again into political turmoil. The Prime Minister resigned last Thursday after violent protests against the Government in the streets of Bucharests led by miners upset over economic hardships.
Officials at the State Department and the Romanian Embassy said that despite the sudden political uncertainty, they did not expect the new adoption law, which went into effect in July, to be affected.
According to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 2,287 Romanian children were adopted by Americans from Oct. 1, 1990 to Sept. 4, 1991. In that period, Americans adopted 1,534 Korean children; until a few years ago, South Korea provided more than half of all foreign babies adopted by American families. But that country, while the No. 2 provider of children for adoption in the United States, has drastically reduced the number of babies released for overseas adoption.
"It is a tremendous turnaround," said William L. Pierce, president of the National Committee for Adoption, an advocacy group. "In two short years, Romania has eclipsed the world's most active country in terms of adoption."
Dr. Zugravescu said the purpose of her country's new adoption law was twofold: to eliminate private adoptions and to give priority to Romanian families to encourage domestic adoptions. In effect, Romania is trying to establish an organized, Government-controlled system patterned after those of other major sources for international adoptions, as in South Korea and Colombia.
When international adoptions resume in Romania, foreigners will be required to go through agencies in their own countries that have been selected to work with Romania's adoption committee. The adoption committee is now reviewing applications of licensed agencies in the United States, Canada and many European countries. No agencies have been selected yet. Dr. Zugravescu said Romanian courts would not consider any case that did not originate with an accredited agency.
The new law also requires a six-month waiting period before an international adoption can occur. During that time, efforts will be made to find a Romanian home for an abandoned or orphaned child. Romanian families seeking to adopt a child will not be subject to the waiting period.
Dr. Zugravescu said several dozen foreigners in Romania had ignored warnings of the impending change in the adoption law and were now caught in a legal nightmare. They have custody of children, but the courts have not approved the adoptions because they presented their papers on July 17, the day the law changed. As a result, they cannot leave Romania with the children.
Dr. Zugravescu said at least 7 American families and nearly 50 from Canada and Europe were in that situation "in a hotel in Bucharest with the children." She said she could not predict what would happen because her committee had no authority in those cases. "Only the courts can decide," she said.
Some people smuggled babies out of Romania and completed adoptions in neighboring countries, Dr. Zugravescu said.
The penalty for breaking the new law is one to five years in prison. United States immigration officials have issued an advisory warning Americans that they may be subject to criminal prosecution if they try to evade the Romanian law by trying to take children out of the country.
Romania's adoption industry sprang up after the overthrow of the regime of Nicolae Ceausescu in December 1989, when the plight of tens of thousands of children in squalid public institutions received widespread publicity.
Americans, Europeans and Canadians flocked to Romania in search of children to adopt. Unwanted children were suddenly a valuable commodity, and entrepreneurs sold babies to raise hard currency.
There will be fewer Romanian babies available for adoption in the future, Dr. Zugravescu said. The birth rate has decreased sharply with the legalization of abortion and contraception.
Nonetheless, more children may become available for adoption from other Eastern European countries, said Dr. Pierce of the National Committee for Adoption. Stories about orphans "in desperate straits" in Albania are starting to circulate, he said.
Information on the status of Romanian adoptions can be obtained from the State Department, which provides a recorded telephone message. The phone number is (202) 647-3444.
Even now, Dr. Zugravescu said, she finds it hard to believe that her country has made a name for itself as a baby bazaar.
"It pains me that this could happen," she said. "There were such abuses. Who could have imagined such a thing?"

HEADLINE: SENATE PASSES BILL SETTING UP LEAVES FOR FAMILY NEEDS

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to require many employers to grant up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for workers to attend to family emergencies like the sickness of an elderly parent or the care of a newborn or newly adopted child.
The 65-to-32 margin indicated that the Senate could apparently vote to override the veto that President Bush has threatened. 
 Adding to the bill's prospects was the fact that among the senators who did not vote were two of the bill's Democratic co-sponsors, Senators Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Tom Harkin of Iowa, who were making Presidential campaign appearances. Democratic leaders also said Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who was the third member who did not vote, would have supported the bill if he had been on the floor and would vote to override a veto. [Roll-call vote, page A20.]
 
Second Challenge to Bush
 But Congressional officials said it was doubtful that the House, which is expected to vote on the measure as early as next week, could pass the legislation by the same two-thirds majority.
It was the second Congressional challenge in two days to the President, who has also said he will veto a bill to provide extended unemployment benefits to those who have been out of work for six months. Both houses passed that bill on Tuesday.
Republican opponents of the family leave bill accused Democrats of catering only to those who can afford to take time off from work. Democrats said they were trying to make family life more secure and grant American workers a benefit similar to those already enjoyed in Japan, Germany and other industrialized countries.
After the vote, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who has sponsored family-leave legislation for five years, said: "I'm very interested in working with the Administration to work out a compromise the President can live with. The door is open and the phone lines are free.
 
Slight Change From Vetoed Bill
 The bill, which has been vigorously opposed by business lobbyists, is slightly different from one passed by Congress last year and vetoed by Mr. Bush. Democratic sponsors forged a compromise with Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, to exempt essential employees, who are the highest paid 10 percent of the work force, and part-time workers who worked fewer than 1,250 hours the previous year.
Despite the revisions, President Bush this week repeated his intention to veto the bill, suggesting that it would impede economic recovery and inappropriately extend the power of Government over the workplace.
The bill passed today would potentially cover 46 million employees -- those who work for companies that employ more than 50 workers. It requires employers to provide up to three months unpaid leave per year for the adoption or birth of a child or a serious illness suffered by an employee or a member of the immediate family and to guarantee the worker a job after the leave. It requires employees to provide medical certification of the illness to the employer.
Conservative groups devoted to family issues have criticized the proposal as "a yuppie bill" that would benefit upper-middle-class careerists but do nothing for traditional mothers who stay at home with their children. Business groups have charged that the bill would reduce the flexibility employers need to tailor benefits for employees.
Senator Wendell H. Ford, Democrat of Kentucky, said the bill would "insure that workers will not have to choose job over family in times of emergency." He noted that 11 million children have mothers who work full time whom they depend on when illness strikes.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, said he approved of the benefits outlined in the bill, but added that they should be voluntarily granted by business, not mandated by Government. "It's easy to create mandates," he said, "but it's very difficult to stop mandating once you start." He also suggested that the bill would make the United States less competitive on world markets.
Mr. Hatch proposed a substitute measure supported by business that would provide up to six years of unpaid leave for parents "to bond" with their newborn children and up to two years to care for seriously ill family members. Employers would be obliged to rehire the worker only if his job or a similar job was open, but would also be required to notify the employee when another position opened. Mr. Hatch's amendment was defeated 65-32.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
U.S.O.C. Seeks Funds Using State Lotteries

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Ever eager to find new ways to support athletes, the United States Olympic Committee is turning to an unlikely source for revenue: state lotteries. In effect, the committee is using the five Olympic rings, once a symbol of amateur idealism, to help sell a game of chance.
A test program in at least 15 states, scheduled next year around the Winter Olympics in Albertville, France, and the Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain, could raise as much as $2 million, Olympic Committee officials say. And that could lead to subsequent programs that officials expect could generate as much as $25 million by the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. 
 "Any number of national Olympic committees fund a very substantial part of their Olympic activities with a national lottery," said John Krimsky, the U.S.O.C.'s deputy secretary general and chief marketing strategist. "This gives the opportunity to use a device to supplement our income that, quite frankly, has not been available to us before."
 
Scratch Off and Win
 Until now, the bulk of the committee's revenues, feeding a four-year budget of $300 million, has been produced through corporate-sponsored programs and the sale of television rights. The only direct public program, an income-tax checkoff in nine states, has generated only $3 million since 1986.
Scientific Games Inc. of Atlanta, the country's largest producer of instant lottery tickets and the U.S.O.C.'s partner in the new deal, has already signed 15 states, which have agreed to buy a total of 378 million tickets with instant-win scratch-off games bearing the Olympic design.
Massachusetts alone has agreed to buy 100 million, California and Illinois 60 million each. The other states taking part in the program are Delaware, Maine, Iowa, Arizona, South Dakota, Missouri, New Hampshire, Vermont, Washington, Idaho, Ohio and Indiana.
Scientific Games is tailoring the game to the state, using a theme of "Winning Spirit" for the Albertville Games and "Golden Glory" for Barcelona, each with an Olympic logo.
The company has not completed the prize structures, but in general, buyers will be able to win anything from $1 or a free ticket to as much as $5,000, $10,000 or $50,000, depending upon the size of the state and ticket sales.
Discussions are under way for distribution in at least five other states -- New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Florida and Minnesota -- and that would give the U.S.O.C. exposure in more than half of the 34 lotteries in the United States. If sales next year are encouraging, the Olympic committee plans to expand the program in time for the 1994 Winter Games in Lillehammer, Norway, with more states participating.
Under its contract with the U.S.O.C., the states pay the Olympic committee through Scientific Games, a flat rate of about $3.50 for each 1,000 tickets sold to the states, Krimsky said. In each state where the tickets are sold, the money would be counted toward the fund-raising projections for the year made by national and state Olympic officials and that money, in turn, would be funneled back to support programs for athletes in training. The U.S.O.C. will receive none of the income from the sale of lottery tickets by vendors to the public nor will it have anything to do with the payouts.
"The U.S.O.C. does not do anything to disrupt education, wild life, parks programs or anything else state lotteries support," Krimsky said. "We get our money from the other end."
 
A Tax Safeguard
 While state lotteries are viewed in some circles as exploitive for attracting buyers with limited disposable income, the games have nontheless proved to be popular with buyers and invaluable as sources of financing for a vast assortment of projects and safeguards against tax increases.
Duane Burke, the publisher of Public Gaming International, a monthly magazine, said that the lotteries in 33 states and the District of Columbia would produce $19 billion in revenues for the 1991 fiscal year, a 5 percent decline from the year before, which he attributed to the current recession.
But citing the two previous recessions, after which eight states each time instituted lotteries, he predicted that as many as 10 more states would have lotteries by 1994.
"Lotteries are producing as much as 5 percent of a state's budget," he said in an interview. "I don't think any governor in his right mind is going to give up hundreds of millions of dollars."
"The key thing for us is the money we can raise for the athletes," Krimsky said. "It gives the U.S.O.C. the opportunity to advertise itself and gives the American public a chance to support Olympic athletes."

HEADLINE: A Standoff Won't Help the Jobless

 BODY:
The distress of America's long-term unemployed offers a strong argument for reworking last year's Federal budget pact. But unless the Democrats are prepared to brace the overall budget issue head on, their $6.4 billion bill to extend unemployment benefits won't fly.
President Bush and Congress agreed in good faith to abide by specific caps on defense and non-defense spending, and not to increase either category without offsetting cuts or new revenues. Nor may they rob one category to fatten the other. 
 With Communism's collapse, defense savings could be applied to domestic needs without worsening the deficit. But absent a renegotiation that the Democrats seem reluctant to broach, the budget agreement still holds: If you want more domestic spending, find the money to pay for it.
The Democratic unemployment insurance bill approved by Congress provides up to 20 weeks of additional coverage beyond the basic 26, and expires next July. The proper way to pay for it would be to raise the tax employers already pay for the basic program. The President favors fewer additional weeks, and other funding. But the Democrats' bill skirts the issue by declaring an emergency, not subject to pay-as-you-go.
The Democrats tried a similar device in an earlier bill, extending benefits if the President declared an emergency; Mr. Bush refused to take the bait. With the emergency declaration now built in, he says he will veto the new bill.
House support for this bill was easily enough to override the veto, but the Senate's majority was two votes short. It remains to be seen whether Republicans who voted against the measure can be persuaded to switch. The September unemployment report, due Friday, could affect the vote.
The larger issue -- renegotiating the budget pact in the light of fundamentally changed circumstances -- will take time to resolve, when and if it is joined. The immediate issue is to provide for the unemployed within the existing rules. The worst of the recession may be past, but with new layoffs coming every day, the outlook for workers laid off months ago remains bleak. If the President's veto sticks, they will still need help.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Courage and Vision

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
Watching President Bush announce those sweeping nuclear weapons reductions and restraints last week -- some of which seemed beyond hope a year ago -- I had mixed but largely jubilant feelings.
To one of my generation -- whose memories of the Cuban missile and Berlin crises are clear and traumatic -- these changes seemed at least as remarkable as those that have engulfed the Soviet Union. My generation had, after all, lived our adult lives in the constant awareness not only of the cold war but of the mushroom cloud. Now the one seems as remote as Guadalcanal, the other a lesser threat than global warming. 
 There also was a certain satisfaction in hearing at last, in a President's words, propositions that Americans once were derided and denounced for advancing -- such as the withdrawal of tactical nuclear weapons from Europe.
Mr. Bush said that changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe mean that an invasion of Western Europe is no longer a realistic prospect. In view of long-evident Soviet economic weakness, the predictable unreliability of Warsaw Pact military forces, obvious Western defense advantages and the Soviet-American power equation overall, that might have been said years ago -- and was, by some Americans -- and the withdrawal ordered much earlier.
To those who had opposed the MX missile from the day President Carter proposed converting Nevada into one vast warren of launchers and silos to house the hydra-headed monster, andeven after President Reagan had ludicrously renamed it "the Peacekeeper," Mr. Bush's announcement of its demise promised one of the "few good funerals" the world so badly needs.
Nuclear cruise missiles also are to be taken off Navy ships -- a once-unthinkable step that those who understood the difficulty of establishing adequate controls on these weapons have long advocated.
Most of all, as Mr. Bush spoke, it seemed that in regard to the horror of nuclear weapons, the world might be moving at last toward quasi-disarmament. From John Foster Dulles, who argued that the U.S. should make no distinction between nuclear and conventional weapons, to Ronald Reagan, who said that a nuclear war "could not be won and must never be fought," an arduous struggle has been waged between those who believed more terrible weapons would keep an uneasy peace and those who feared these arms threatened inevitable holocaust.
Now George Bush had promised, in addition to the significant actions he announced, more attention to the ominous problem of nuclear proliferation; Moscow seemed likely to be forthcoming in response (and now has promised to be); and President Mitterrand of France is proposing a five-power summit to talk about the future of nuclear weapons. If the terrible genie can't be put back in the bottle, perhaps it can be more stringently safeguarded and made an international pariah.
The millennium has not arrived. Mr. Bush did not mention intercontinental missiles, save to make the welcome proposal that they should carry only one warhead. He wants American submarines to retain multi-warhead missiles, and thus an existing advantage. He did not propose to halt nuclear testing. He called -- incongruously and illogically -- for greater investment in the B-2 bomber, Star Wars, ground-based anti-missile systems and renegotiation of an ABM treaty that, not "broke," doesn't need fixing.
The President warned against converting reduced military spending into greater non-military spending. Such a restriction would perpetuate perhaps the single greatest cause -- inflated military budgets -- of the nation's decline in standard of living and international economic position. Democrats in Congress, fortunately, don't seem inclined to heed Mr. Bush.
All that said, and granted that he seized on some Soviet initiatives previously spurned (such as the elimination of tactical nukes), hoped in part to head off Congressional and allied pressures for even greater arms reductions, and no doubt will profit politically by the measures he announced -- still, Mr. Bush abandoned some of the sacred texts of 40 years of cold war, was willing to reverse several of his own stands and risked the disapproval of his party's powerful right wing.
That took courage, as well as the vision that George Bush is often accused of lacking. He could hardly have chosen a subject of greater importance for his demonstration of both.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: How C.I.A. Invented Soviet Military Monster

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A Sept. 26 front-page article reports the accusation before the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence by Melvin Goodman, former Central Intelligence Agency analyst, that Robert M. Gates, the nominee for Director of Central Intelligence, suppressed dissent within the agency and slanted intelligence conclusions to support Administration policies. 
 Professor Goodman's revelations come as no surprise to me; indeed, they suggest an answer to puzzles raised over the last 15 years in my studies of C.I.A. estimates of Soviet military spending.
The C.I.A. estimates have been, in my opinion, continually slanted upward to make Soviet military spending appear larger than careful analysis of the data suggests, thereby supporting the Reagan-Bush-Pentagon military buildup policies.
It was clear to me that the decisions to slant the conclusions were made at the highest levels because the techniques used were so unacceptable on scholarly grounds. In my work on military spending, I have come to know many of the C.I.A. analysts who prepare these estimates, and I believe that, had they been free of political pressure, the estimates would not have been distorted. Let me offer a few examples.
* The accepted method of comparing United States-Soviet gross national product and any of its components is to take an average of comparisons in ruble prices and in dollar prices. For example, C.I.A. analysts summarized a comparison of United States-Soviet consumption levels thus: "In 1976, per capita consumption in the Soviet Union was 34.4 percent of that in the United States: this value is the geometric mean" -- average -- "of comparisons in rubles (27.6 percent) and in dollars (42.8 percent)."
Note that the dollar comparison exaggerates Soviet consumption, the ruble comparison exaggerates United States consumption. This is always the case and is why the C.I.A. almost always makes the two comparisons and uses their average. The major exception is the military spending comparison with the result that, as estimated by the C.I.A., Soviet military spending has always been grossly exaggerated compared with that of the United States.
* In 1979 the C.I.A. raised its estimate of the percentage of Soviet military spending in G.N.P. from 12 percent to 13 percent. The reason given was that since 1976, military spending had been increasing annually 4 percent to 5 percent, whereas the increase in G.N.P. had declined to 2 percent. In 1983, the C.I.A. admitted that military spending had been growing since 1975 at only 2 percent a year. Yet it did not make the appropriate reduction in the ratio of military spending to G.N.P. from 13 percent to 12 percent. Consider also that it took the agency eight years to admit it had been substantially exaggerating the annual growth of Soviet military spending.
* The Soviets introduced a price reform in 1982, the first in 15 years. In 1986, the C.I.A. switched its estimates of Soviet military spending and G.N.P. to the new 1982 prices. The percent of military spending in G.N.P. took a 3 percent jump upward because, according to the C.I.A., prices of weapons had increased much faster than prices of civilian goods. This was a lie or guesswork.
In November 1987, a year and a half later, the C.I.A. published "A Guide to Monetary Measures of Soviet Defense Activities," a pamphlet that stated: "Recently the C.I.A. shifted its base year to 1982, the year of a major price revision. It is not yet known in the West if or how the Soviets adjusted the prices of their weapons systems in that year." Further substantiation that military prices were unavailable is found in the answer of Jerome Weinstein of the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency to Senator William Proxmire's query in 1988 on the inflation in military prices: "Sir, that's a very soft figure. There is no hard evidence on what the inflation actually is."
Basic responsibility for the crude distortions could not be attributed to the competent analysts who develop C.I.A. estimates. Top officials like Mr. Gates undoubtedly call the tune on these matters. Whoever was responsible did this nation a disservice by contributing to our enormous and excessive military buildup over the last 15 years.
 
FRANKLYN D. HOLZMAN
Medford, Mass., Oct. 2, 1991
 
The writer is professor of economics, Tufts U., and research fellow, Harvard Russian Research Center.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 6; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: How C.I.A. Invented Soviet Military Monster;
Record of Failure

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The search for a smoking gun in the Robert M. Gates confirmation hearings for Director of Central Intelligence is pointless. It is clear that, if Mr. Gates did not know about the Iran-contra affair, the reason was he deliberately kept himself ignorant. 
 However, lying is no longer considered a serious transgression in American public life. President Bush said that Clarence Thomas was the best qualified person in the United States for elevation to the Supreme Court, and Judge Thomas himself said that he had no opinion about abortion and Roe v. Wade. No one believes these statements, but neither speaker will be penalized. Why do we care whether Mr. Gates is lying or not?
The real issue is what kind of intelligence service the United States needs in the coming years. If we think we want the same kind of Central Intelligence Agency we have had, then Mr. Gates is the best possible candidate; if we think we need something different, he is the worst.
On most of the issues that count -- those related to the broad political, social and economic currents of the times -- the C.I.A. has had a spectacular record of failure. On Cuba, Iran, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, the C.I.A. has always been wrong. (On Saddam Hussein, where a little old-fashioned spying might have done the trick, the C.I.A. also missed the boat.) It is likely to continue to be wrong if it is staffed with ideologues whose favorite activity is hatching secret plots, and if it is overseen by a Congressional committee that also likes that sort of thing.
We can safely relegate both traditional spookery and high-tech reconnaissance to tasks such as exposing double agents and tracking military placements. If, on the other hand, we hope to predict world movements truly important to the security of the United States, that can only be done entirely in the open by politicians, diplomats and scholars of all kinds, including economists, political scientists, sociologists and physical scientists. In other words, it will take the same kind of effort that we would apply to any difficult interdisciplinary problem.
Much of this should take place at the State Department, at universities and think tanks, and it should involve studies, meetings, publications and extensive international visits. Perhaps if we devote enough effort to this task, we shall be somewhat less surprised at the next cataclysm in world affairs.
 
WILLIAM F. SCHREIBER
Cambridge, Mass., Sept. 23, 1991

HEADLINE: Income Figures Show No Gains by Blacks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The affirmative action debate associated with Judge Clarence Thomas's nomination hearings confuses person with population. Both conservative and liberal presentations of personal portrayals miss picturing the condition of populations. The position of African-Americans relative to whites has eroded since 1975. 
 Look at the percent change in the ratio of black-to-white median family income from 1975 to 1989. In 1975, the ratio was 62 percent. In 1982, it was 55 percent. For 1989 it was 56 percent, down from 57 percent in 1988. Gains and losses over those 15 years show black median family income dropped 6 percent relative to whites. In the same period, cumulative gross national product increased 19 percent.
If African-Americans are successful and have been taking opportunities from whites, their incomes relative to whites should increase, but they have not.
 
COURT SMITH
Professor of Anthropology
Oregon State University
Corvallis, Ore., Sept. 21, 1991

HEADLINE: Lloyd K. Garrison, Lawyer, Dies; Leader in Social Causes Was 92

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
Lloyd K. Garrison, a lawyer from a distinguished family who built an extraordinary record of individual achievement and public service, died at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.
He died of heart failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Garrison was the great-grandson of William Lloyd Garrison, the abolitionist, and the grandson of Wendell Phillips Garrison, the literary editor of The Nation. His father, Lloyd McKim Garrison, a lawyer, and his mother, Alice Kirkham Garrison, were pillars of New York society.
Mr. Garrison was schooled at St. Paul's and at Harvard and Harvard Law School, where his brilliance and social connections brought an offer from the law firm of Elihu Root, one of the leading figures of the country's elite establishment.
 
Leading Social Causes
 But Mr. Garrison's interests, seemingly indefatigable energy and commitment to progressive social causes took him far beyond the life of the Wall Street lawyer.
Mr. Garrison, a partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, was a very successful Wall Street lawyer. But he was also at various times a law school dean, a crusading and innovative Federal investigator and administrator, a civil rights and civil liberties advocate, a close adviser to a Democratic Party standard-bearer, and a political reformer who took on and bested the Democratic Party machine in New York City.
Mr. Garrison was a friend of some of the most powerful establishment figures in 20th century America -- Root, Judges Augustus and Learned Hand, Adlai Stevenson. He was called to government service several times by Presidents Franklin Delano Roosevelt and his successor, Harry S. Truman. He served on numerous Federal agencies and commissions.
Yet Mr. Garrison was a stalwart champion of expanding economic opportunity and increasing citizen participation in political life. He was influential in an early and landmark National Labor Relations Board ruling that required employers in collective-bargaining negotiations to bargain exclusively with the representatives selected by a majority of employees. The ruling was later made part of the National Labor Relations Act of 1935.
In the early 1950's, Mr. Garrison, as a member of the Democratic Reform Movement in New York City, played a significant role in ousting Carmine DeSapio as the county Democratic leader. In national politics he was a stalwart supporter of the Presidential candidacy of Mr. Stevenson, a longtime friend.
Mr. Garrison joined the National Urban League in 1924, which he said opened his eyes to the realities of racial discrimination in America, and was its president from 1947 to 1952.
That commitment remained through the decades.
In 1968 after the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Garrison wrote a letter to The New York Times in which he stated that Dr. King "in the last years of his life" realized that "civil rights legislation and court decisions were not enough to wipe out discrimination and inequality; that the ravages of poverty had to be dealt with on a massive scale; (and) that the cleansing and transformation of the our inner cities was the first order of business and the establishment of peace was indissolubly linked with these objectives."
In the early 1950's, Mr. Garrison, a longtime member of the American Civil Liberties Union, defended the poet Langston Hughes and the playwright Arthur Miller when they were summoned by Senator Joseph McCarthy before the House un-American Acitivities Committee. And he defended J. Robert Oppenheimer when the Atomic Energy Commission -- for whom Mr. Garrison had been a special consultant in the 1940's -- sought to remove Mr. Oppenheimer's security clearance.
Mr. Garrison lived a super-charged life. But his friends invariably described him as a somewhat shy man with a self-effacing manner.
"I've never planned my life," he said in the early 1960's. "I've taken things as they've come along. For me life has been a series of accidents."
"I like to be of use," he went on, "but I don't consciously go out to serve."
Others recognized what Mr. Garrison, in his modesty, would not acknowledge, and he was constantly called upon to be "of use:" " as a partner of Paul, Weiss, which he joined in 1946, and in a broad array of volunteer activities.
The calls began early in his career. After college, interrupted for service in the Navy, law school and his settling on Wall Street, Mr. Garrison was asked by the City Bar Association in New York to investigate incidents of "ambulance chasing" and bankruptcy fraud by lawyers.
 
Bankruptcy-Fraud Inquiry
 His work gained such prominence that President Herbert Hoover appointed him to a special Federal commission investigating bankruptcy-fraud across the country.
That began a career of Federal service in the 1930's -- including helping start the National Labor Relations Board. Mr. Garrison at the time was actually employed outside the Government, as dean of the University of Wisconsin Law School, where his efforts at improving the school's standing drew widespread praise.
Among his many activities over the years, Mr. Garrison was a member of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University, and a trustee of Sarah Lawrence College, and Howard University, and a member of the Council of Foreign Relations and the City Bar Association.
He is survived by his wife, Ellen; two daughters, Clarinda Garrison and Ellen Shaw Kean, and a son, Lloyd McKim Garrison, all of Manhattan, and 11 grandchildren.
A memorial service will be held on Monday at 12:30 P.M. at All Souls Unitarian Church, at 80th Street and Lexington Avenue in Manhattan.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 4, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Lloyd K. Garrison, a New York civic leader and lawyer, misstated his age. He was 93.

HEADLINE: Rhode Island Banker Held

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I. Oct. 3

 BODY:
A bank vice president was arrested today on charges of helping doctor the books of his small institution months before its collapse touched off Rhode Island's banking crisis.
Prosecutors said Peter J. Iannuccilli, vice president and a director of the Heritage Loan and Investment Bank, altered bank computer records to make it appear that more than $1 million in payments had been made on 12 loans now suspected of being fraudulent. 
 The arrest was the first of a high-ranking banking executive since a private deposit insurer's failure forced 45 banks and credit unions in Rhode Island to close Jan. 1.
Heritage's president, Joseph Mollicone Jr., has been missing since November 1990, when state officials discovered Heritage was teetering on collapse. He has been charged with embezzling $13 million from the bank and a Federal fugitive warrant has been issued for his arrest.
Mr. Iannuccilli was charged with one count of fraud. He was arrested at his Cranston home today and led into the Attorney General's office in handcuffs. After a hearing, he was released on $50,000 personal recognizance.
Prosecutors charge that he altered bank records to show that Mr. Mollicone had validly obtained the loans and made payments on July 13, 1990. But there was no collateral or other standard documentation to support the loans.
When Heritage failed, its private deposit insurance fund had to pump millions of dollars into it to cover guaranteed deposits. That subsequently caused the collapse of the insurer, the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
How Much to Cut Arms Spending?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WHAT will be the economic consequences of President Bush's unilateral decision to eliminate all tactical nuclear weapons on land and at sea in Europe and Asia?
The near-term effect on military spending and the Federal budget will be slight. Mr. Bush, announcing his initiative last Friday, immediately sought to spike expectations of a "peace dividend" -- dollars saved from the military budget that could be used to meet domestic needs. "Some will say these initiatives call for a budget windfall for domestic programs," he said. "But the peace dividend I seek is not measured in dollars but in greater security." 
 Indeed, in the near term, he added, some of the steps he was proposing "may even cost money." And, given the "ambitious" plan he had already proposed to Congress for cutting military spending by 25 percent over the next five years, he said, "We cannot afford to make any unwise or unwarranted cuts in the defense budget."
Military analysts estimate that the President's decision to give up short-range nuclear weapons will, in itself, facilitate modest savings over the next five years. Before his new initiative, the President's plan called for reducing budget authority for tactical nuclear weapons to $1.5 billion in 1996 from $2.4 billion in 1990. That would have scaled back tactical nuclear deployments to 2,500 warheads from 4,600, and brought down total military budget authority by a scant one-third of 1 percent.
Assuming that such deployment will be cut to fewer than 500 warheads from 1993 on and that all the costs of removing the tactical nuclear missiles are absorbed in the 1992 operating budget, analysts see estimated savings of $1.2 billion a year, or $6 billion over the five-year planning period. With the additional costs of decommissioning and safe disposal of the warhead material, net savings might be closer to $5 billion in constant 1992 dollars.
The tactical nuclear weapons are the main components affected by the President's initiative. One budget expert said he did not think the taking of long-range bombers off ready alert would save any money, although, he said, it would mean "happier families." But significantly bigger savings will result if Moscow accepts the President's proposal to negotiate sharp reductions in intercontinental ballistic missiles.
The crucial issue on which Mr. Bush's initiative has now opened the door goes far beyond the potential savings on tactical or strategic nuclear weapons. For, in stating the logic for his elimination of tactical nuclear weapons as the opportunity created by the end of the cold war and the turn of the Soviet peoples "to democracy and freedom," the President has kicked off what is likely to be a continuing debate in Congress and in the coming election campaign on how much the total military budget can be cut -- and what should be done with the savings.
This will be a complicated issue for both Democrats and Republicans, for the chance to cut military spending comes when the American economy is still in purgatory, between recession and recovery, and unemployment appears likely to hang on through the election year. Mr. Bush has sharpened the issue by threatening to veto the Democrats' bill to extend unemployment compensation for 20 weeks, saying that he had to think of taxpayers and not just the unemployed.
No one can know how long the economy will have to endure the pain for its sins of excess during the 1980's; meanwhile, however, the military budget is regarded, by members of both political parties and their local constituencies, as a barrier against worse unemployment. Economists may stress the economic benefits of reducing military spending, whether the proceeds are used for deficit reduction or domestic programs, till the cows come home, but voters focus on the loss of jobs immediately linked to closing bases and plants.
According to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney's five-year plan for trimming the military budget, active forces would be gradually brought down to 1,653,000 troops in 1995 from 2,070,000 in 1990. Military reserves would be cut to 906,000 from 1,128,000, and civilians employed directly or indirectly by the Department of Defense would be reduced to 940,000 in 1995 from 1,068,000 in 1990. In all, this means eliminating 22 percent of active military personnel, reserves and civilian workers.
It may require a much more vibrant economy to persuade a majority of Congress to press for steeper cuts in the military. And the President is likely to continue to fight for his present military plans, including the B-2 bomber, the Strategic Defense Initiative, new attack submarines, two new aircraft carriers and much else, whether to repel military or political-economic threats.

HEADLINE: Orders to Factories Fell 1.9% in August, After a July Surge

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Orders for manufactured goods, unable to sustain their biggest increase in 21 years, fell 1.9 percent in August, the Government said today.
Some analysts question whether the industrial sector can continue to lead the recovery without stronger participation by consumers, who represent two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. 
 "Saying the manufacturing sector will turn the economy around is like saying the tail is going to shake the dog," said Paul Getman, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa.
Orders for durable and nondurable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $243.3 billion, down from $248.1 billion in July, the Commerce Department said.
The drop was the largest since a 2.9 percent decline in March. It followed a slightly revised 6.1 percent jump in July, the biggest since a 6.6 percent advance in December 1970. The July increase had originally been estimated at 6.2 percent.
Most analysts had expected the industrial sector, representing one-fourth of the nation's economic activity, to give back part of the July gain.
Still, Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, noted that even with the drop, orders were 4.1 percent above the June level. "We're looking at an ongoing industrial recovery," he contended.
In another report today, the Labor Department said the number of people filing initial claims for unemployment benefits dropped to 430,000 in the third week of September, down 10,000 from the previous week.
But the decline was not considered large enough to indicate any meaningful improvement in hiring practices and was not enough to offset the surge of 37,000 new claims a week earlier. And the average number of new applications for the four weeks ended Sept. 21, was 423,250, the highest since the four weeks ended July 20, when the average was 403,000. Many economists consider the four-week average to be more significant than the weekly data.
The Commerce Department report showed that factory orders for durable goods fell 3.9 percent in August, to $125.7 billion. The decline had been estimated at 3.8 percent.
 
A Big Gain Is Reversed
 Durable orders had soared 11.7 percent in July, the largest increase since the department began keeping records in 1958. Durable goods are relatively expensive items, like computers and cars, that are expected to last more than three years.
The drop more than offset a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in nondurable goods, to $117.6 billion; that category had risen six-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Inventories continued to fall, down three-tenths of 1 percent, the eighth decline in nine months. The declines could mean increased production and jobs if demand increases.
Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, suggested that some inventory rebuilding may already be under way.
He noted that inventories of finished goods -- as opposed to raw materials and goods in the process of manufacture -- rose three-tenths of 1 percent. At the same time, he said shipments rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, their fifth consecutive gain.
Unfilled orders, often a barometer of how busy industry will be in coming months, also rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the second consecutive increase.
Transportation orders contributed the most to the drop in durable-goods bookings. They fell 8.8 percent as a large decrease in aircraft more than offset increases elsewhere. The overall category had jumped 27.1 percent the previous month.
Excluding this sector, orders were still off seven-tenths of 1 percent in August as all major categories posted declines.
The often-volatile military category posted a 15.8 percent gain, exceeding the 13.3 percent increase in July. Excluding the military sector, orders were down 2.6 percent.
Nonmilitary capital-goods orders excluding aircraft -- a barometer of industry's plans to expand and modernize -- fell 2.5 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Alcoa and Kobe Steel To Form 2 Ventures

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The Aluminum Company of America and Kobe Steel Ltd. of Japan said today that they had agreed to form two joint ventures to make aluminum for cars and light trucks and other uses in the transportation industry.
The ventures, one in Japan and one in the United States, are meant to capitalize on auto makers' efforts to make lighter, more fuel-efficient cars by using more aluminum parts. 
 The new joint venture in the United States, to be operating by 1994, will be the first American-Japanese joint venture to manufacture, market and sell automotive aluminum products in North America. It will serve American and Japanese auto makers in the United States, the companies said.
The joint venture in Japan, to be established in January, will research, manufacture, market and sell sheet aluminum. It will also research the production of shaped aluminum parts, such as those made through casting.
Kobe and Alcoa formed an alliance in September 1990 to pursue worldwide business opportunities in aluminum. The first venture was KSL Alcoa Aluminum Company Ltd., a 50-50 joint venture formed in Japan in January to make and market aluminum can stock.
The amount of aluminum in the average American car has almost doubled in the last decade, to nearly 159 pounds, or 5.4 percent, of the car's weight in 1990, according to the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. Steel represented 54 percent of the weight, and plastic about 7.6 percent, the trade group said.
About 1,000 pounds of aluminum auto parts could be combined in one car, making the vehicle about 24 percent lighter than the average car today and increasing fuel economy by 20 percent, according to the Aluminum Association, another trade group.

HEADLINE: 10-Day Vehicle Sales Up

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Strong sales of 1992 models to fleet buyers and sizable rebates on leftover 1991 models helped increase sales of American-made cars and light trucks by 5.8 percent in late September over the comparable period a year earlier, according to figures released by the auto makers today.
Analysts said the figures overstated actual consumer demand, which remains sluggish but is showing signs of gradual improvement. 
 On a seasonally adjusted basis, domestic cars were selling at a 7.2 million rate for the Sept. 21-30 period, compared with an 8.2 million rate at this time last year. Car sales were 226,602, compared with 236,375 last year, a drop of 4.1 percent. Light-truck sales posted a strong gain to 150,213, an increase of 25.3 percent.
Analysts said the final 10-day sales period in September was not a reliable indicator of the auto industry's health because rebates on last year's models and fleet sales tend to skew the numbers from year to year.
 
Gradual Improvement in '91
 But Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, noted that the annual selling rate in 1991 has shown a gradual improvement from quarter to quarter, and should therefore calm fears that the auto industry was heading into a prolonged slump after a strong showing this summer. "That's consistent with the gradual recovery thesis," he added.
Another economic report today also proved moderately encouraging to analysts. The Government said August factory orders fell 1.9 percent, but that was still higher than the June level and analysts had expected the industrial sector to give back part of a big July gain. [Page D4.]
Of the auto makers' figures, Mr. Heinbach said the annual rate was 6 million cars in the first quarter and has increased steadily each quarter since to 6.4 million units. The seasonally adjusted annual rate last month was 6.3 million cars, about the same as in August.
The sizable increases in domestic truck sales were attributed to heavy marketing pushes by the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation in competing for the title of America's best-selling pickup. Ford proclaimed itself the winner today, due in part to sales of its F-Series pickups, which jumped to 38,601 units in late September, from 14,574 in the period last year.
Herbert Abramson, owner of Silver Lake Dodge in Wellesley Hill, Mass., hopes that new incentives announced today by the Chrysler Corporation, which extended rebates on leftover models and slapped them on selected 1992 models, will draw buyers to showrooms. The rebates are "unbelievably heavy" for new models, Mr. Abramson said. "They're really stepping out ahead of the market on these."
The number of domestic vehicles sold by the Big Three was up 6.1 percent in late September, and the number sold by Japanese "transplants" was 3.7 percent higher. Thus, the Big Three's share of sales resulting from domestic production rose to 87 percent percent, from 86.8 percent in the 1990 period.
In car sales, General Motors sold 93,449 American-built units in the late September period, down 9.2 percent from a year earlier; Ford Motor sold 61,584, down 10.8 percent, and the Chrysler Corporation sold 31,422, up 15.2 percent, based on estimates by Ward's.
 
Gains by Honda
 Of the Japanese auto makers with American plants, the Honda Motor Company sold 17,612 cars, an increase of 22.5 percent; the Toyota Motor Company sold 9,585 cars, a drop of 10.1 percent, and the Nissan Motor Corporation sold 5,733 cars, a drop of 18.5 percent.
In light-truck sales, G.M. sold 55,677, an increase of 18.2 percent; Ford sold 65,326, a jump of 66.6 percent; Chrysler sold 20,515, a drop of 13 percent.
For the entire month of September, sales of all cars and trucks, imported and domestic, fell 7.2 percent, to 1.03 million, from 1.11 million in September 1990. Car sales were down 13.1 percent, to 662,951, and truck sales rose 5.6 percent, to 371,016.
The Big Three's total vehicle sales in September, including imported models, fell 8.7 percent; the Big Three captured 70 percent of the market, compared with 71.2 percent a year earlier. Sales by Japanese car makers, including vehicles built in the United States, rose six-tenths of 1 percent, and captured 24.4 percent of the market in September, compared with 22.5 percent a year earlier. Vehicle sales by importers outside Japan fell 18.4 percent; the market share of these non-Japanese importers was down seven-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier.
 
U.S. Manufacturers Slip
 G.M. sold 222,416 American-built cars in September, a drop of 18.7 percent from a year earlier; Ford sold 129,501, a decrease of 18.1 percent, and Chrysler sold 57,222, down 15.8 percent.
G.M.'s total market share for cars in September was 35.8 percent, compared with 38.1 percent in September 1990. Ford had 20.6 percent, compared with 21.7 percent a year earlier. Chrysler's total market share was 9.3 percent, compared with 9.4 percent. Toyota's market share was 7.3 percent, compared with 6.3 percent, and Honda's market share 10.7 percent, compared with 8.3 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
RJR Plans To Reduce Debt Load

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
RJR Nabisco Inc. announced plans yesterday for large offerings of common and preferred stock that would help the company retire some of the debt it incurred in 1988 when Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company bought the company in a deal worth $25 billion.
Because the financing will add more than 300 million shares to the 1.1 billion common ones that already exist, RJR's stock fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $11 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange after the announcement. 
 The proposed issue of preferred stock, which is convertible into common, would be the second public offering by RJR this year. In April, the company sold 100 million shares at $11.25 each.
 
More Freedom Seen
 But over the long term, analysts said, the move will benefit RJR Nabisco by allowing it to renegotiate its bank loans so it has more freedom to make investments and acquisitions.
"Changes in the bank-loan agreements are very important to RJR's plans to become a more aggressive competitor in overseas markets," said Jennifer Coury, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. She noted that tobacco sales were growing faster overseas than in the United States, and that RJR, like other tobacco companies, was planning to make investments and acquistions in foreign markets.
By getting its debt below $15 billion and increasing its equity, or shareholders' capital, to about $8 billion, RJR expects that it bank loans will no longer be labeled a "highly leveraged transaction" by banking regulators.
 
Shedding a 'Straitjacket'
 Karl von der Heyden, RJR's chief financial officer, said yesterday that even though the company's credit quality had improved since the Kohlberg, Kravis takeover, the "highly leveraged" label was a roadblock to a new agreement "because the banks are unwilling to amend the agreement or to lend more money" to companies with that label. They have been responding to regulators and investors who see a high potential for loss from such borrowers.
"Under the existing agreement, our excess cash goes to reduce the bank loans, and we are in effect unable to make acquisitions or major investments without getting the approval of the banks," Mr. von der Heyden said. "With a new agreement, we would not be in such a financial straitjacket."
In the new agreement, Mr. von der Heyden said the company was hoping to reduce the interest rate on its loans to 75-hundredths of a percentage point above the offered rate for interbank deposits in London, down from the current 2.75 percentage points.
 
Getting Money Cheaper
 He added that a new agreement might allow RJR Nabisco to borrow low-cost money from banks to retire or refinance debentures that carry interest rates as high as 17 3/8 percent. The company might also used its new bank credit line to pay cash interest on some debentures, known as pay-in-kind securities, which pay interest in the form of additional debentures.
Several rating agencies said the proposed cut in RJR Nabisco's debt could cause them to lift their ratings on the company's senior debt out of the high-risk junk bond category and into the bottom of the lower-risk investment grade category.
The debt reduction will result from an exchange offer of common stock for $1.8 billion in preferred stock to be handled by Goldman, Sachs & Company. A companion offering of 160 million shares of a relatively new kind of security called Preferred Equity Redemption Cumulative Stock, or Percs, will be handled by Morgan Stanley & Company, which developed the security earlier this year.
The Percs offering is expected to raise about $1.9 billion.
