Chart: "Decoding the C.I.A."
 
A glossary of terminology used at theGates nomination hearings.
 
D.C.I. Director of Central Intelligence, the head of the C.I.A. and overseer of the bureaucracy that includes the C.I.A. and other espionage agencies.
 
D.D.C.I. Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.
 
D.D.I. Deputy director for intelligence, head of the C.I.A.'s analysis division.
 
D.I. Directorate of Intelligence, the C.I.A.'s analysis division.
 
D.I.A. Defense Intelligence Agency
 
D.O. Directorate of Operations. C.I.AS. division that manages agents overseas and handles the clandestine collection of inteligence information as well as runs covert operations.
 
D.D.O. Deputy Director for Operations, head of the C.I.A.'s operations division.
 
I.N.R. State Department Bureau of Intelligence and Research, which handles intelligence analysis for the State Department.
 
N.F.I.B.: The National Foreign Intelligence Board. A group composed largely of senior intelligence and military officials, it advised the director of central intelligence on major issues and receives all major intelligence analyses.
 
Inspector General Reports reports prepared by the Inspector General of the C.I.A.
 
N.I.C. (National Intelligence Council) A group of senior intelligence analysts who advise the Director of Central Intelligence and coordinate the writing of analyses with experts throught the intelligence establishment.
 
National Intelligence Estimates (N.I.E.'s) The most important and best-read of intelligence analyses, written to reflect the consensus of experts in all the major intelligence agencies. Special National Intelligence Estimates are more hastily prepared version and are often issued to predict or respond to sudden changes in world events. The estimates are issued by the National Intelligence Council.
 
N.I.O. National Inteligence Officer, a senior analyst and intelligence specialist who sits on the National Intelligence Council.
 
N.S.C. National Security Council, the White House agency that advises the President on foreign policy.
 
N.S.A. National Security Agency, one of the government's largest intelligence agencies. It is responsible for cracking codes used by foreign governments and intercepting communications by foreign governments.
 
O.G.I. Office ofGlobal Issues, a C.I.A. analytical shop created in 1981 by the former Director of Central Intelligence William J. Casey to focus on third world issues and other problems that cross geographic coundaries or academic disciplines.
 
Presidents Daily Brief (P.D.B.) The six-days-a-week publication prepared by C.I.A. analysts to inform the President and other senior officials about world developments.
 
President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board: It is a presidentially appointed body of outside experts with free rein to investigate and advise the White House on almost any intelligence topic of its choice.

PUB-DATE: October 4, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Arkansas' Clinton Enters The '92 Race for President

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 3

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas entered the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today with an unstinting indictment of a decade of Republican domestic policies and a promise to restore the American dream for "the forgotten middle class."
The 45-year-old Governor offered himself as someone who could "reinvent government," infuse it with the values that Americans hold dear, and use it to address the problems that plague this nation, from crime to economic decline. 
 He promised an administration that would broaden opportunity for Americans through better schools, more college scholarship programs, tax breaks for the middle class and a healthier economy. But Mr. Clinton also said his style of government would expect more from Americans -- from welfare recipients who would be expected to seek work, to corporate executives who would face an irate President if they engaged in the excesses of the 1980's.
 
Reclaim the Middle Class
 Mr. Clinton, who has argued in recent years that the Democratic Party must refashion its message if it hopes to reclaim the middle class, tried to make the case for a more active, problem-solving Federal Government -- but not the stereotypical Democratic administration that the Republicans delight in running against. "A Clinton Administration won't spend your money on programs that don't solve problems and a government that doesn't work," he said.
Mr. Clinton is the fifth major candidate to enter the race for the Democratic nomination. His declaration today follows a month when the Democratic field suddenly came to life, after a summer when one leading Democrat after another backed away from a challenge to Mr. Bush. The new class of candidates, in contrast, scents opportunity even amid the towering Bush approval ratings.
Mr. Clinton presented his case against the Republicans today with smooth confidence and a trace of disdain. He asserted that the Republicans "have washed their hands of responsibility for the economy, for education, for health care and for social policy." Rather than leadership and vision, Mr. Clinton asserted, they had offered only "neglect and selfishness and division."
Mr. Clinton was particularly impassioned about the Republicans' record on race. The setting was appropriate, one of those historical ironies that so often crop up in modern Southern politics: He stood on the steps of the Old State House, the site of two conventions in 1861 that led to the state's secession from the union.
 
'Race Against Race'
 "For 12 years, the Republicans have tried to to divide us, race against race" Mr Clinton said. "Here in the shadow of this great building, all of us, we know all about race-baiting. They've used that old tool on us for decades now. And I want to tell you one thing: I understand that tactic, and I will not let them get away with it in 1992." His audience roared its approval.
Mr. Clinton, a fifth-generation Arkansan, seemed euphoric today as he finally said the words that he was expected to say for so long, "I am proudly announcing my candidacy for President of the United States of America." He was 32 years old when he was first elected governor here, a New South Governor with humble roots and an educational background that included Georgetown University, Yale Law and Oxford University, where he was a Rhodes Scholar.
He lost his first re-election campaign, but came back to win the governorship in 1982, and has held it ever since. He has, by necessity, built his Presidential campaign on his domestic expertise, presenting Arkansas as a laboratory for policy innovations, from teacher testing to welfare reform.
Mr. Clinton said little on foreign policy today, praising Mr. Bush's recent arms control initiatives and generally promising "to keep America strong and safe from foreign dangers and to promote democracy around the world." But Mr. Clinton argued that America's strength must begin at home, with the core American dream of education, home ownership and decent jobs. There, he asserted, is where the nation is now imperiled.
"Middle class people are spending more time on the job, less time with their children and bringing home less money to pay more for health care and housing and education," he said. "The poverty rates are up, the streets are meaner, and even more children are growing up in broken families. Our country is headed in the wrong direction, fast. It's falling behind, it's losing its way."
Mr. Clinton's lack of foreign policy expertise is just one of the hurdles he faces; he is also from a small state, and like most of his colleagues begins the race with little name recognition. He has also, in recent months, been forced to deal with a rumor campaign pressed by political opponents here an Arkansas.
Mr. Clinton was, until recently, the chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group formed in 1985 to push the party toward what it considers the political center. Much of his speech today and his campaigning of recent weeks have come from themes he articulated while chairman of that group, including the emphasis on values. At the same time, Mr. Clinton has tried to broaden his appeal in recent months.
Today, he defined his cause as "preserving the American Dream, restoring the hopes of the forgotten middle class and reclaiming the future for our children."
Mr. Clinton has also acquired a strong populist tone. "I'm not out to soak the rich," he said today. "I wouldn't mind being rich myself. But I do believe that rich people should pay their fair share of taxes. For 12 years, while middle class incomes went down, the Republicans raised taxes on middle class people. And while the incomes of our wealthiest people went up, their taxes were lowered. That's wrong, and the middle class needs a break."
Like many of his colleagues, Mr. Clinton tries to resist ideological labels. "The change I seek, and the change that we must all seek, isn't liberal or conservative. It's different and it's both." Mr. Clinton asserted that most Americans care little about such distinctions and simply want policies that work.
 
Generational Appeal
 In his resistance to labels, Mr. Clinton is like another Democrat who entered the race this week, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. Like Mr. Kerrey earlier this week, Mr. Clinton made a generational appeal, asserting, "I refuse to stand by and let our children become part of the first generation of Americans to do worse than their parents."
So far, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kerrey seem to be positioning themselves as future-oriented, fresh-thinking Democrats who are willing to challenge the orthodoxy, the kind of position Gary Hart sought in 1984.
The voice of unabashed Democratic liberalism in the race is Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, while Governor L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia offers himself as a blend of fiscal responsibility and compassion. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts runs as a pro-business liberal. The other candidates considering a race include former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma. The Rev. Jesse Jackson is still considering his options.
Mr. Clinton's speech today was relentlessly focused on the strains of the middle class, but he closed with a poignant plea to remember the poor. He talked of his own childhood, which he described as poor but hopeful, shadowed by the death of his father before he was born but rich with grandparents and great-grandparents.
"It's a long way from that," he said gently, "to the children in the streets of our cities who have to worry about being shot going to and from school, who do bullet drills at school, and go home and worry about their parents' drug abuse." Mr. Clinton, speaking almost softly, beneath the old white pillars of the antebellum South, added, "I tell you, by making common cause with those children, we give new life to the American dream."

HEADLINE: Jaquelin Hume, 86, Dried Food Producer And Philanthropist

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Jaquelin Holliday Hume, a pioneer in the dehydrated food business, a philanthropist and a major political donor to Ronald Reagan, died Tuesday in San Francisco.
Mr. Hume, known as Jack, was 86 years old and a resident of San Francisco. He died of complications of cancer and a stroke, his family said. 
 In 1933, Mr. Hume and his brother, William, founded the Basic Vegetable Products Company. It became the world's largest producer of dried onion and garlic, and after the merger of competitors now ranks second. Two decades later, he started the American Potato Company, the world's largest processor of dehydrated potatoes.
Mr. Hume created the Foundation for Teaching Economics to promote that subject in elementary and high schools.
He also headed the boards of the Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and was vice chairman of the Asian Art Foundation.
A longtime contributor to conservative Republicans, he was major supporter of Mr. Reagan for Governor of California and President. Mr. Hume founded Citizens for America to promote Mr. Reagan's views and was on the board of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation.
Born in Harbor Point, Mich., Mr. Hume grew up in Indianapolis. He received a is bachelor's degree from Princeton and master's degree from the Harvard Business School.
He is survived by his wife, Caroline; four children, Patricia Highberg of Woodstock, Vt., Carol Tolan of New York City, and William J. and George H. Hume of San Francisco, and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: New York Shifts on Welfare: Education Stressed Over Jobs

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
In a little-noticed but pivotal shift in New York City's welfare-to-work program, the Dinkins administration has changed a strategy of quickly placing welfare mothers in mostly low-paying jobs in favor of a more expensive -- and as yet unproven -- investment in education and training.
The city's Human Resources Administrator, Barbara J. Sabol, is betting that teaching thousands of women on welfare reading and a variety of skills will eventually lead them out of poverty into higher-paying jobs, improving their chances of staying off the welfare rolls and thus saving taxpayers money in the long run. 
 In sharp contrast, her predecessor, William J. Grinker, had begun requiring able-bodied women on welfare to look for a job or lose part of their welfare checks. He cited national research showing that low-cost job-search workshops placed enough women in jobs to reduce welfare expenses and modestly improve women's incomes.
 
Philosophical Opposites
 Mrs. Sabol and Mr. Grinker are on opposite sides in the welfare-reform debate. Like most other welfare administrators across the nation, Mrs. Sabol believes that society must nurture welfare recipients with education and training so that they can compete in a tough job market.
Her policy, experts say, is based more on hope than on hard evidence. Rigorous studies of intensive programs like those she favors are under way but have not been completed.
But if her approach works, it may help the more unskilled who are unable to find work through a job search, said Judith Gueron, president of the Manpower Demostration Research Corporation, a New York nonprofit organization that has become the nation's leading evaluator of welfare-reform programs.
Mr. Grinker maintains that welfare mothers are often able to help themselves, just as the working poor do, if required to look for a job, even if it pays badly.
Under Mr. Grinker, Mary Thornton, a mother of three who has lived on welfare for a decade, would have been required to attend a monthlong "job club." Staff members coach women in writing resumes and interviewing for jobs. The women are then required to hunt for jobs through classified advertisements in newspapers and the Yellow Pages.
Instead, under Mrs. Sabol's program, Ms. Thornton was invited to an H.R.A. office in the Bronx recently. In a brief interview with a caseworker, Nellie Vega, Ms. Thornton said her dream was to be a nurse.
"We have two programs suitable for you," Ms. Vega replied. One would combine study for a high school equivalency diploma with unpaid work in a hospital. The second would place Ms. Thornton in two years of nursing school after she got her diploma. Her tuition would be paid for with government funds.
Ms. Thornton seized the second choice. "That's my goal," she said with certainty. "I'm all for it."
 
The Long View
 City welfare records show that a monthlong job search is more likely than education to lead directly to employment, but the jobs themselves are often low-paying.
Mrs. Sabol acknowledges that 15 percent of the women assigned to job clubs generally find immediate employment, compared with about 5 percent of the women assigned to work/study or other education and training programs.
"Even granted that difference," she said, "we have to look over the long term and see what happens with clients who learn to speak English and get their G.E.D.'s" -- the General Educational Development certificates that are the equivalent of diplomas.
Mr. Grinker said he believes that more women will remain unemployed under Mrs. Sabol's new policy and simply move from training program to training program.
"A low-wage job is a hell of a lot better than welfare," Mr. Grinker said. "It's the first rung on the ladder that gives people opportunity. It teaches people how to come to work on time and what it is to be productive."
At a time when almost 1 million New Yorkers, about one-eighth of the city's population, are on public assistance -- the highest level since 1976 -- the city's latest experiment in welfare reform faces the challenge of breaking a deeply rooted pattern of welfare dependency in the midst of a prolonged recession.
"It's mind-boggling," said Catherine Zall, Deputy Commissioner of the city's Office of Employment Services, which runs the welfare-reform program. "Think of large geographical areas of the city where the predominant way of life is welfare."
New York City's welfare-reform efforts have gone through many incarnations over the last decade. In 1985, the city began what was then described as the nation's most extensive mandatory program to get women off welfare.
Under the program, women who did not volunteer for education or training were required to work part time in government agencies for no pay while they continued to get their welfare checks. At any given time, about 5,000 women were dispatched to work as janitors or clerks or in other low-skilled positions.
To get their work assignments, women on welfare from all five boroughs were summoned to one huge office in Manhattan. They were offered virtually no counseling and little choice about what work they preferred, Ms. Zall said.
"Work experience was a very blunt instrument," she said. "It was like an assembly line." The program cost $54 per welfare recipient and placed only 4 percent of them in permanent paying jobs, she said.
 
Choice vs. No Choice
 Mr. Grinker, who founded the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, took over the city's Human Resources Administration in December 1986 at the request of Mayor Edward I. Koch, bringing with him great ambitions to revamp the city's welfare efforts.
But it was not until April 1989 that Mr. Grinker began to carry out a new policy of requiring women on welfare to look for jobs. Mr. Grinker said he was distracted from welfare reform by crises in child welfare and homelessness. "It was a priority that had to take a back burner, much to my chagrin," he said in an interview recently.
A year later, in April 1990, Mayor David N. Dinkins appointed Mrs. Sabol to run the city's vast social-services apparatus. Six months later, she jettisoned Mr. Grinker's mandatory job search for her own program emphasizing individual choice.
Her more expensive, intensive program actually serves fewer than half as many welfare mothers as the workfare program of the mid-1980's -- 2,100 at a time, compared to 5,000 then.
 
New Federal Rules, Too
 Despite the smaller numbers, the city is able to meet the requirements of a new Federal welfare reform, which took effect last November and requires that a growing proportion of able-bodied welfare recipients with children 3 years old and above be placed in education, training or job programs.
In this, the first year covered by the Federal rules, at least 7 percent of the 106,000 eligible welfare recipients in New York City will have to enter a program or lose a portion of their welfare benefits. By 1995, 20 percent will have to participate.
Under Mrs. Sabol, the number of local offices for the city's welfare-reform program, called "Begin," has grown from 1 in Manhattan to 2 in Manhattan and 2 in the Bronx. The city plans to open 4 more offices in Brooklyn and Queens by January.
In the last year, the city has mailed out thousands of call-in letters for Begin. The letter starts with encouragement: "You have an opportunity to change your life. You've probably dreamed about leaving welfare; now you can make it happen." But it leads to a warning a few paragraphs further, in underlined capital letters: "YOUR PUBLIC ASSISTANCE GRANT MAY BE REDUCED IF YOU DO NOT KEEP THE APPOINTMENT."
 
Results Are Not In
 Mrs. Sabol softened the mandatory-participation requirement by giving women choices. What is not known is whether welfare mothers will succeed in school or job training or, if they finish the programs, whether they will get decent jobs.
To begin to answer those questions, Mr. Grinker's Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation is conducting the first large-scale study women who receive intensive education and job training do better in the work force.
The research organization has studied programs in Arkansas, San Diego, Virginia and Maryland and has found that job clubs, Mr. Grinker's favored route, have done well in finding employment for women and, as a consequence, have cut welfare costs and lightened the load on taxpayers. But they also found the strategy did not help the most disadvantaged welfare recipients.
Under Mrs. Sabol's program, about a third of the women participating in Begin are choosing immediate job searches while 40 percent are picking work/study or career-planning classes and about 25 percent are enrolling in classes to learn English as a second language.
Under Mr. Grinker, all but the non-English speakers would have been sent first to job clubs. Only those who did not find jobs would have been referred to education and training programs.
After receiving a recent call-in letter, Alicia Hall, who has been on welfare for 10 years, picked a job club, which requires her to make 25 telephone calls to potential employers every day. One afternoon, she scoured the Yellow Pages for potential employers and neatly noted on a pad each of her calls. She said she hoped to find an office job, perhaps as a receptionist.
"If it wasn't for job club, I wouldn't have pushed myself," she said. "I don't want to kid you. But I am ready to work. My youngest is 6, and this girl ain't having no more children."

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
New York Fails to Advance in Cup Bid

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
The organizers for the 1994 World Cup named 19 communities yesterday as the leading contenders to stage games in the monthlong soccer tournament. New York, the country's most populous city, was not among them.
In reducing a list of 26 bidders, the organizing committee placed New York on a "nonpriority" list of sites now virtually assured of no chance of holding games. The metropolitan area was not shut out, however. A New Jersey bid for Giants Stadium in East Rutherford and Rutgers Stadium in Piscataway, and the Yale Bowl in New Haven were among the "priority" sites that representatives of soccer's international federation will inspect over 10 days, starting Oct. 29. 
 Early next year, the contenders will be reduced to 12, after which consultations between the world body, the Federation Internationale de Football Association, and the organizing committee will determine the 8 to 12 sites and stadiums in which 5 rounds of 52 games will be played.
"These were extremely difficult decisions," Alan Rothenberg, the president of the organizing committee and the United States Soccer Federation, said during a telephone conference call, reflecting on the selection process so far. "We will try our level best to bring the World Cup to as many regions as possible."
 
Stadiums Hurt Bid
 In general, organizers took several criteria into consideration in developing the priority list. Included were the size and nature of the stadium, public and private support, population and the area's past and projected future commitment to soccer.
New York fared well in all but the stadium category, as organizers thought the arrangements necessary to play games in Yankee Stadium or Aqueduct race track -- the only sites under consideration in the formal bid -- would have been too onerous. The size of the field and sight lines were the problems with Yankee Stadium; constructing a field over a parking lot was the concern at the race track.
Don Smith, the president of the New York City Sports Commission, said that organizers were informed that Shea Stadium was also available but the formal bid documents included no reference to it as a potential site, only to sites "to be determined."
The New Jersey bid also posed problems but, apparently, not insurmountable ones. Giants Stadium would require construction of a platform, on which a grass field would be placed to meet the FIFA requirement that all surfaces must be natural. At Rutgers, discussions are under way to increase the stadium seating capacity.
Rothenberg did not necessarily view New York's fate as a loss for the city, never mind the economic impact staging games might have meant. "Our view is the New York metropolitan market as one massive, vitally important market," he said.
 
An Off-the-Field Role
 New York has already been assured at least some participation in the World Cup, having won the right to stage the Dec. 8 qualifying draw, a process in which 132 countries will be grouped for two years of continental and regional playoffs, producing the 22 countries to make the final rounds in 1994. As the host nation, the United States automatically qualifies, as does Germany, the defending champion.
Rothenberg also said that New York is in contention as host for the final draw, the FIFA Congress, which is a series of meetings, and to be the international media center.
These are the other areas still under consideration: Atlanta; Boston-Foxboro, Mass.; Chicago; Columbus, Ohio; Dallas; Denver (for a proposed stadium and Mile High Stadium), Detroit-Pontiac, Mich.; Kansas City, Mo.; Los Angeles-Pasadena, Calif.; Miami (for Joe Robbie Stadium and the Orange Bowl); New Orleans; Orlando-Kissimmee-St. Cloud, Fla.; Philadelphia; San Francisco Bay (for Candlestick Park and Stanford Stadium); Seattle, Tampa, Fla., and Washington.
Along with New York, the other demoted bids were from Charlotte, N.C., Honolulu, Houston, Knoxville, Phoenix and Portland-Corvallis, Ore.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
The Deal Is Already Done For Gorbachev's Coup Book

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
First came the coup of the Kremlin; now comes the coup between hard covers: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has sold his account of the August uprising to HarperCollins for what some in the industry say is $500,000.
Giving new heft and meaning to the ever-growing field of quickie books, HarperCollins says it plans to translate the 74-page typed manuscript, print it, bind it and ship it to stores before the end of this month. 
 In a nation where Nikita S. Khrushchev, after his own overthrow, was forced to write his memoirs in secret and smuggle them out of the country, many Kremlin denizens are now tell-all graphomaniacs. Mr. Gorbachev; Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, and a raft of other Government figures are competing to publish their versions of the coup that failed.
And even though the Soviet Union is at one of the most critical junctures in its history, struggling to redesign its economy and Government, several of these leaders have already found time to write their accounts of the August events.
"We, without a doubt, have the publishing coup," said William M. Shinker, senior vice president and publisher of the adult trade division at HarperCollins. "After the coup, every publisher in New York was trying to resuscitate Soviet books on their back lists. But this clearly is the book to have."
He would not comment on widespread industry reports regarding the size of Mr. Gorbachev's advance. But people in the publishing industry, who insisted on anonymity, said colleagues in the Murdoch organization had told them that the $500,000 figure coincided with figures mentioned to them when they expressed interest in the book.
Publishers are also furiously trying to secure the rights to a coup memoir by Mr. Yeltsin, whose resistance to the plotters is credited with defeating the attempt to oust the Gorbachev Government. An aide in Moscow said Mr. Yeltsin was currently writing a book at a Government country house in Sochi, on the Black Sea.
Newsweek magazine has acquired first serial rights to the book, but the rights to its publication are to be auctioned at the Frankfurt Book Fair next week.
 
Murdoch Is Summoned
 HarperCollins received a telephone call from the Soviet Embassy in Washington last week, asking that Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, the publisher's parent company, fly to Moscow to meet with Mr. Gorbachev about publishing his book, Mr. Shinker said.
Mr. Murdoch had personally acquired the memoirs of Mr. Gorbachev's wife, Raisa, titled "I Hope," during a trip to Moscow last July, but he was not able to make this latest trip. Instead, Eddie Bell, HarperCollins's chief executive in Britain, went to Moscow on Friday and returned with the manuscript of "The August Coup."
The book, which will be published in the Soviet Union by Novosti, is said to be an analysis of the events that brought on the coup, and the consequences of its failure. HarperCollins executives said the book would describe in detail the Gorbachevs' three days of incarceration in their Crimean dacha.
Mr. Gorbachev said after the coup, however, that he would never disclose everything about the events. Many people, including Soviet officials and leading cultural figures, say they expect few revelations in the book and describe it as Mr. Gorbachev's attempt to stamp his interpretation on the events. Mr. Gorbachev has been circumspect about his personal life and thoughts in all his interviews and published writings, including "Perestroika," the best seller published by HarperCollins in 1987.
"It will be an attempt to say everything but what we want to know," said Tatyana Tolstaya, a popular Russian writer, who is teaching this year at Goucher College in Baltimore.
Mr. Yeltsin's book can be expected to be more personal and explicit. His earlier book "Against the Grain," which was published by Summit Books and became an underground best seller in Moscow, broke many taboos about Kremlin politics and etiquette.
 
A Journalist in Demand
 Random House has commissioned a quickie book on the coup from Vladimir Pozner, a Soviet television journalist whose flawless English has already earned him a best seller ("Parting With Illusions," published last year by Atlantic Monthly Press) and regular appearances on Phil Donahue's television talk show.
Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Foreign Minister who quit his post last December after issuing warnings of an encroaching dictatorship, tacked a coup epilogue to his book, "The Future Belongs to Freedom," published this month by the Free Press.
Even before the coup, leading and even middling lights of Soviet politics, culture and history seemed to have been caught up in a wave of literary confession. Yegor K. Ligachev, Mr. Gorbachev's longtime conservative nemesis on the Politburo, has pressed Western correspondents in Moscow for the names of literary agents in New York who could help sell a book he wrote.
And the obsession with writing has swept up some of the people arrested for plotting and carrying out the coup. Anatoly Lukyanov, the former chairman of the Soviet Parliament and a law school friend of Mr. Gorbachev who is in jail on charges he masterminded the overthrow, told a Soviet journalist that he has been writing love poems in his cell.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
On 20th Anniversary, Fans of the Islanders May Want a Divorce

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
The Islanders have little to celebrate as they begin their 20th season tomorrow night in Boston. Their milestone is burdened with millstones. They have more problems than some expansion teams -- and less optimism.
For sale since last winter, they have no buyer yet. Their best player, Pat LaFontaine, has demanded a trade and the team has tried, so far without success, to move him; meanwhile, he did not come to camp. The captain, Brent Sutter, has said he wouldn't mind a change of scene, although he did finally come to camp. The top goalie, Mark Fitzpatrick, still has a blood disorder that threatens his career; he is working out with minor league teams but his status is uncertain. 
 The team's spiffy new practice complex, which was supposed to open last season in Suffolk County, is unfinished because of financial problems. The team's new radio network is anchored by a New Jersey station that can't be heard at night inside many Long Island homes. Some gaps will be partly filled by smaller stations with limited range.
Perhaps, if fans are stuck in traffic on the Long Island Expressway and they can't tune in the play-by-play, they can get on their car phones and CB radios and pass the word:
The 20th-anniversary edition of the Islanders might be every bit as good as the team back in Year One, which won 12 games in a 78-game schedule.
This is not to say that every player is worthless. LaFontaine is a scoring whiz who thrives even without a supporting cast. His trade could bring one or more good players. Sutter combines discipline, intelligence, talent and effort. Patrick Flatley scraps on the boards and in the corners. David Volek has advanced play-making skills. David Czyzowski has a major league shot. Randy Wood cuts and drives to the net as well as anyone. On defense, Rich Pilon is a rugged checker whose comeback from a career-threatening eye injury helps him see the bright side of hockey life.
"There are a lot of people in this world worse off than me," Pilon said after a recent workout. "People in wheelchairs. People out of work. I'm in the National Hockey League. It's a business and I'm here to do a job.
"Let's face facts: We're not an overly talented team. And Paddy's not here. But we can win with hard work in the corners and good checking. We can win those games, 2-1 and 3-2."
 
Defense Might Be Good
 If they do, a major factor might be Pilon and his associates on the blue line, the strength of the team. Joe Reekie keeps the puck away from his net and toward the other end. Gary Nylund, recovering from a knee injury, can be physically dominating. Dean Chynoweth is young and big and strong and tough. Jeff Norton can rush the puck from one end to the other.
Ken Baumgartner is a team leader in the locker room and a brazen intimidator on ice. Two newcomers, Tom Kurvers and Randy Hillier, should add stability, experience and depth.
The main man in goal is Glen Healy, who played in 53 games last season. He said that the lack of turnover on the roster could have a positive aspect because "we know the system, we know what's expected."
"Of course, we would like to have a player like Steve Yzerman, but we don't, so it's no surprise we don't score," Healy said. "So we have to play as a tight-knit group of 20. Heart and hard work can go a long way."
The locker room has a new coat of paint and a new trophy case, but the stagnation on the roster brings apathy from the fans. A radio commercial for season tickets avoids mentioning any players.
 
Impact of Uncertainty
 Bill Torrey, the general manager, said during training camp that the possible sale made him reluctant to shuffle the "assets."
"In the past," Torrey said, "when I wanted to make a deal, I made a deal. Anytime anybody is in limbo, it just makes it another element involved, a factor in the team's life. You can't ignore it."
Don Maloney, the former Ranger star, is the new assistant general manager, replacing Gerry Ehman, who remains in a reduced role. Ken Morrow, a star defenseman from the Stanley Cup years, is a new assistant coach to Al Arbour.
Arbour has coached the team since 1973, except for the Terry Simpson era, which lasted less than two seasons in the late 1980's. He and Torrey still enjoy exalted reputations for their earlier success. But the impending change of ownership casts them now, at best, as Long Island lame ducks.
Perhaps symbolic of the franchise's uncertainty is the practice headquarters in Happauge. It is three-quarters finished, according to Timothy Mattimore, a lawyer and investor.
"The Islanders indicated they would be very happy if we would get it built yesterday," Mattimore said. "They are saying, 'Are you ever going to finish this project?' "
For the time being, the team continues to practice at Cantiague Park in Hicksville. The players dress in the women's locker room. On the way to the ice, they walk by a sign that reads "Caution: Plaster Falling."
 
Why Buy the Cable?
 This season, the new flagship of the four-station radio network is WPAT (930 AM), in Paterson, N.J. Also on the network is WGBB (1240 AM) in Babylon, L.I., WRHD (1570 AM) in Riverhead, L.I., and WFAS (1230 AM) in White Plains.
Fans out of radio range can always pay for SportsChannel, the pay-cable TV service that will carry most of the games.
But why buy cable with so many good tickets available? During a recent exhibition at the Coliseum, as the team skated through a listless 2-1 loss to the Devils, the organist tried to rouse the small gathering with "Glory Days," one of the Springsteen anthems from the early 1980's, back when the Isles were good.
The song is about youthful optimism and sports triumphs of the past and how fast that all slips away. A few fans clapped to the beat but most sat still as the music bounced hollowly about the building. Soon, the puck was dropped, the music stopped and play, such as it was, resumed.

HEADLINE: Trump Officials Return Fee

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Two of Donald J. Trump's top executives have returned $1.4 million they received as a consulting fee from one of his financially troubled casinos, after bondholders objected to the payment.
The Press of Atlantic City reported in today's issue that Stephen Bollenbach, the Trump Organization's chief financial officer, and Nick Ribis, head of Trump's Atlantic City holdings, set up a corporation to advise on restructuring the bonds of Trump's Castle Casino Resort. 
 Trump made a $1.4 million payment on July 31 to the corporation, the Financial Advisors Capital Corporation, as the first installment on a $2.7 million fee. Mr. Bollenbach told the newspaper that he and Mr. Ribis ended the contract and returned the money on Aug. 17 after bondholders objected to the fee arrangement and threatened to kill the restructuring deal. The proposed deal would give the bondholders half the equity in the casino, in return for their acceptance of lower interest rates on their bonds.
The New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement said it would probably have filed a complaint if the money had not been returned.

THE ECONOMY
Sales of U.S.-made cars and light trucks rose 5.8 percent in late September, helped by strong sales of 1992 models to fleet buyers and sizable rebates on leftover 1991 models. [Page D1.] 
 Orders for manufactured goods, unable to sustain their biggest increase in 21 years, fell 1.9 percent in August. [D4.]

RJR Nabisco announced plans for large offerings of common and preferred stock that would help the company retire some debt. The financing will add more than 300 million common shares. [D1.]

Columbia Pictures has a new president who says he hopes the studio will make more films that are 'socially relevant.' [D1.]

MARKETS

Soybean futures prices sagged more than 10 cents a bushel amid reports that the harvest had been better than expected. [D13.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Short-Term Treasuries Post Gains

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Treasury bill prices rose yesterday on hopes that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates soon to stimulate the faltering economic recovery.
But while the short-term market benefited from the prospect of an expected rate cut, the long-term market languished; the 30-year Treasury bond closed slightly lower. 
 The 8 1/8 percent 30-year Treasury bond closed down 3/32, or 94 cents for $1,000 face amount, at 103 11/32. It yielded 7.83 percent, up from 7.82 percent on Wednesday.
The three-month bill rose, sending its yield down 8 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to close at 5.01 percent. The six-month bill gained to cut its yield 7 basis points, to 5.08 percent.
 
Employment Data
 Traders are betting that the Fed will cut interest rates as early as today, if the September employment report scheduled for this morning proves especially weak. The figures will provide the first official look at the economy's performance last month, and economists are projecting a slight rise in the unemployment rate to 6.9 percent for September from 6.8 percent in August.
The focus of any Fed interest rate cut would likely be the Federal funds rate, the amount banks charge one another for short-term loans. The target rate is now believed to be 5 1/4 percent, and it could be cut to a target of 5 percent -- the lowest since 1977.
The prospects of a Fed easing were bolstered by the weak money supply figures released yesterday, which showed that M-2 money supply in the week ended Sept. 23 fell by $3 billion.
M-2 is a broad measure of money in circulation, including cash, traveler's checks, checking accounts, bank deposits and Eurodollars. A decline in the money supply tends to show a slowing economy.
"The money supply is one of the main factors that has influenced Fed policy making in the last couple of months," said Jim Winder, an economist at Merrill Lynch. "The latest numbers are weaker than most people were looking for."
Adding to the sense of a sluggish recovery, the Labor Department reported yesterday on initial jobless claims in late September, and economists said they were at recessionary levels.
Factory orders fell 1.9 percent in August after a big July surge, the Government reported yesterday.
The White House has also voiced increasing concern about the health of the economy, adding another element of pressure on the Fed for easier rates, economists said.
Corporate bonds were aided by the RJR Nabisco Holdings decision to retire $1.8 billion of high-interest preferred stock with a new issue of common stock.
The move will leave the company with less than $15 billion in debt, lowering its overall borrowing costs. In response to the plan, all the big rating agencies said they might upgrade RJR's debt to an investment grade from its present junk bond status.
In intermediate maturities, the 6 1/8 percent two-year Treasury note ended 3/32 higher at 100 10/32, yielding 5.96 percent. The 10-ear 7 7/8 percent note was 1/32 higher at 102 25/32, yielding 7.47 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Lower in U.S.; Yen Posts a Broad Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar sank to a seven-month low against the Japanese yen yesterday and finished lower against most currencies in domestic trading after turning in a mixed performance in Europe.
Gold prices rose. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid for an ounce of gold at $357.25, up $2.25 from Wednesday's late bid. 
 The yen was the center of attention in the currency markets, appreciating against most other currencies after some recent weakness.
Dealers in Japan said the yen surged after news reports there that an unidentified Foreign Ministry official had said Japanese companies would remain competitive if the dollar fell below 130 yen. That suggested to some traders that Japanese and United States authorities had agreed to stand aside as the yen rose.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 131.15 yen, from 133.11 on Wednesday. That was its lowest close there since it finished at 130.95 yen on Feb. 22.
The dollar sank further in Europe and the United States. In London, the dollar was quoted at 130.83 yen late in the day and it dropped to 130.60 yen in New York from 132.60 yen late Wednesday.
Michael Guarino, senior manager for foreign exchange at ABN-Amro Bank in New York, said the yen might have been helped by the announcement that the Japanese Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, would resign in the wake of the Japanese financial scandals. He said the resignation could signal that an embarrassing series of scandals are being "put to rest."
"This also could be the correction that a lot of market participants have been looking for in the yen," he said.
The pace of dollar trading was tempered by anticipation of today's release of United States employment figures for September.
If the figures show more economic wekaness, many traders expect the Federal Reserve will take steps to encourage lower interest rates, a development that could depress foreign demand for the dollar. German markets were closed for a national holiday and that also depressed the level of trading in Europe.
Mr. Guarino said the dollar did not fall as sharply against other currencies because the German mark, Swiss franc and the British pound were being sold primarily against the yen.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Good Year For Money Managers

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
AS a group, the nation's money managers are outperforming the market so far this year, buoyed in large part by a favorable climate for small and medium-sized stocks, estimates released yesterday by CDA Investment Technologies show.
CDA, which based its calculations on quarterly filings made by 525 money managers with the Securities and Exchange Commission, found that the portfolios of those in the reporting group had increased an average of 25.4 percent in the first nine months of the year. That is 5.1 percentage points better than the rise in the Standard & Poor's 500. 
 The top performer was Target Investors Inc. of Wilton, Conn., whose gain CDA put at 79.3 percent. Robert Zuccaro, Target's president, said CDA's estimate was in line with actual performance.
Though he invests in a range of health-care, financial and technology stocks, he attributed his standout performance to the one thing that all his picks have in common: they tend to be small to medium-sized stocks.
"That's our style," Mr. Zuccaro said. "We never deviate from it. Like any style, it comes into favor and goes out of favor and right now it's very much in favor."
One of his best performers was Score Board, a seller of baseball cards and memorabilia that is traded over the counter. He bought it in the low teens. It closed yesterday at $27.25.
Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., last place in the rankings and the only money manager that showed any loss for the period, was down 3.9 percent for the year. A Dean Witter spokeswoman said she would look into CDA's figures but had not called back by late yesterday.
While CDA's numbers have proved a decent indicator over time, the methodology has shortcomings. For instance, CDA assumes that money managers finish the quarter with the same stocks they began it with, and that they were fully invested. Those assumptions distort the stated performance of any manager who traded actively in the quarter or had assets sitting in cash.
CDA also does not track foreign equities, small holdings, stocks of bankrupt companies whose value is negligible and short positions. Short-sellers sell borrowed stock, hoping to profit by replacing it with shares bought later for less.
Another shortcoming is that managers who hold only a few stocks or who keep to one or two industries dominate the top and the bottom of the rankings, since their holdings tend to be more volatile than a well-diversified portfolio.
Two of the three worst performers did not quibble with their estimated returns, but rather they explained that CDA's methodology punished them for being specialists.
W. H. Reaves & Company of Jersey City, which placed third from the bottom, with a 7.4 percent gain for the nine-month period, noted that it concentrated almost exclusively in utilities and other defensive stocks that have had trouble vying for investors' attention since the end of the Persian Gulf war.
Kenneth J. Gerbino & Company of Beverly Hills, Calif., which landed second from the bottom with a gain of 2.1 percent, had the misfortune of having invested heavily in another out-of-favor sector: gold-mining stocks.
Mr. Gerbino, the president, said CDA was underestimating his performance since it gave him no credit for the money he was making on the short side or for two winners in Canada. One was a large position he had amassed in Continental Gold, which was bought out by Placer Dome last year, pushing the stock up nearly sevenfold. More recently, he scored big with his stake in Taseko Mines, the owner of a huge copper find whose stock has roughly doubled this year amid speculation that it might be bought out.
"CDA leaves out a lot," Mr. Gerbino said. That said, he was still less than thrilled at being featured so prominently near the bottom of the heap. "Don't worry about spelling my name wrong," he said.
On the other end of the spectrum, managers who had concentrated their bets in biotechnology and recession-resistant sectors were handsomely rewarded, especially after strong results by two biotech companies, Amgen and Chiron.
"One of the better eggs I've laid was selling Chiron after it acquired Genentech and the earnings were going to be negative for six quarters," said Louis Navellier, president of Navellier & Associates Inc. in Incline Village, Nev., which nonetheless placed second from the top. "It went up 20 points after I sold it."
He and Mr. Zuccaro both cited ECI Telecommunications, a supplier of digitized equipment that enables telephone companies to transmit data much faster than before, as one of their smarter picks. The stock has more than doubled since Feburary.
Mr. Zuccaro, whose computers keep tabs on 21,000 stocks, which are then subjected to rigorous screening before he will buy them, is also fond of Smithfield Foods, which sells premium-priced smoked hams and deli meats. In his view, the company's widening profit margins make the stock attractive even though it has about doubled this year. "It's a well-run business," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 9, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
The Market Place column in Business Day on Friday quoted an executive who misidentified the company that is merging with the Chiron Corporation. It is the Cetus Corporation, not Genentech.
