HEADLINE: A-Plant's Closing Brings Shrugs as Well as Doubt

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROWE, Mass., Oct. 2

 BODY:
After Federal regulators recommended that the Yankee Rowe nuclear plant be closed indefinitely for safety reasons, workers here this week portrayed the shutdown as a bureaucratic mix-up and said they were proceeding as if it were a routine maintenance interruption.
"There are always problems and always solutions," Gregory Maret, the plant's technical director, said on Wednesday, the day after the shutdown. "We'll continue to operate as normal except the plant will be in a cool condition and we won't be generating electricity. Other than that, it's just another day in the wonderful hills of New England." 
 Workers reduced temperatures in the nuclear reactor from 520 to 180 degrees and were keeping busy with routine maintenance chores like cleaning the plant's main electricity generator, inspecting pumps and recalibrating monitors, Mr. Maret said.
He said the halt was similar to one in June, when lightning hit a transformer and forced the plant to close for a week. Yankee Rowe, the nation's oldest nuclear plant, has been shut down 38 times in its 31 years of operation, he said.
 
Defending Plant's Safety
 The managers coming and going from the plant's gate insisted Yankee Rowe was as safe as it was in June when the Nuclear Regulatory Commission rejected arguments that the plant's aging reactor vessel had become so brittle that it might crack and release radiation during an accident.
But the commission's staff reversed itself on Tuesday based on new safety calculations, and the plant operator, Yankee Atomic Energy Company, a consortium of New England utilities, voluntarily shut the reactors. It was the first time in nearly five years that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had recommended closing a plant for safety reasons.
Norm St. Laurent, the plant supervisor, said company officials now hoped to persuade the N.R.C. to allow them to restart the plant within the next few weeks.
"I would have shut the plant down if I thought it wasn't safe," said Mr. St. Laurent. Asked whether any of the plant's 260 workers might be laid off, he said: "I can't tell you anything about that."
 
'Bombshell' to Workers
 The N.R.C.'s recommendation to shut the plant came as a "bombshell" to plant workers, said Jim Lynch, a security supervisor who has been at Yankee Rowe for 16 years. "If there was a real problem here the way some people think there is, I can't imagine why anyone would work here on a daily basis," he added.
The 350 residents of this tiny northwestern Massachusetts town near the Vermont border have benefited greatly from tax revenue from Yankee Rowe and many of them have defended it against out-of-town protesters. Now, some are saying they are eager to know the results of extensive safety tests that are scheduled in the future.
"It gives you doubts," said Heidi Lehr, owner of Rowe's only grocery store. "I think they should shut it down now to test it." But she said she still distrusts the motives of plant opponents who had appealed to the N.R.C. to shut the plant before next spring.
"They're going to keep pushing," she said. "They're trying to shut it forever."
 
Doubts on License Renewal
 A Yankee Rowe opponent who runs a Unitarian retreat here said he believed the N.R.C.'s action meant it was unlikely the plant would be able to renew its operating license when it expires in the year 2000. "I would sleep easier if it was closed down for good," said the opponent, Doug Wilson, a director of the Rowe Conference Center.
Other residents say they are concerned about layoffs at the plant in a recession that has already given Massachusetts one of the country's highest unemployment rates, 9.2 percent.
But in the meantime, the troubles at the plant have been a boon for the Rowe Country Store. Ms. Lehr reported a run on disposable cameras Tuesday when tourists flocked here to watch protesters celebrate the shutdown.

HEADLINE: Japanese Premier Forced to Give Up Bid for New Term

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu was forced today to abandon his effort to win a second term in office after his most powerful party benefactors abruptly withdrew their support.
The sudden withdrawal by Mr. Kaifu cleared the way for a chaotic scramble to succeed him among several leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed Japan uninterrupted for 36 years. He is to remain in office until his term expires on Oct. 30. 
 Politicians and analysts agreed that the contest would be one of the most bitter in many years, but that no major policy matters would be at stake. All the leading candidates hold the same basically conservative view of economic issues coupled with strong support of the United States, and policies in Japan are forged by consensus among political leaders and bureaucrats who will continue to wield power.
 
Slow Process of Consensus
 It appeared that the Kaifu ouster was also a product of consensus, a slow process, often maddening to the United States when it wants quick action, but revered by the Japanese. People in Tokyo almost seemed to take pleasure today in being reminded that politics at its highest level in this country consists of behind-the-scenes maneuvering, like a grand form of bunraku, or Japanese puppet theater.
This Prime Minister was brought into office and then removed because he was needed at a time of scandal to provide a "clean" facade for the powerful party barons, who run the party's multibillion dollar patronage machines, and then finally no longer served their purposes.
In the last two years, these barons settled policies among themselves and dictated them to Mr. Kaifu, sometimes forcing him to shift abruptly. The Prime Minister never objected. Indeed, he performed cheerfully and was popular because the public felt he was doing his best in tricky circumstances.
 
Takeshita Among Candidates
 Among the leading candidates to succeed the 62-year-old Mr. Kaifu are former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita; Kiichi Miyazawa, a former Deputy Prime Minister; Tsutomu Hata, a former Agriculture Minister; Ichiro Ozawa, a former secretary general of the governing party, and Michio Watanabe, a former Minister of Trade and Industry.
The collapse of Mr. Kaifu's power base came early today when it became clear that his main supporter, Mr. Takeshita, withdrew his backing out of irritation with what was deemed to be the Prime Minister's impetuousness and equivocation on the issue of political reform.
This action came after a long period of rising dissatisfaction among party elders over Mr. Kaifu's general performance on the Persian Gulf war, the Soviet Union and the handling of the recent stock market scandals.
 
No Public Comment by Kaifu
 Looking ashen-faced and shaken, Mr. Kaifu made no public comments about his decision to withdraw, which was announced by an aide.
Mr. Kaifu took office in August 1989 at a time of public furor over bribery and sex scandals in the Government and the earlier imposition of an unpopular sales tax, all of which resulted in a sharp setback for the Liberal Democrats in parliamentary elections that summer.
When he took office, Mr. Kaifu was a former Education Minister with little experience in foreign policy or economic affairs and little independent political strength. But in his first statement after being selected for the post, he pledged to pursue "step-by-step efforts for political reforms." Six months later, he led his party to an election victory, largely because of his image as a clean politician.
But Mr. Kaifu never banished the perception that he was plucked from relative obscurity and beholden to the powerful party barons who put him in office. Party professionals saw him as reactive, weak and indecisive.
He was widely regarded as having been too slow to condemn the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last year and the hard-line coup attempt in the Soviet Union in August. He refused concessions on Japan's ban of rice imports, dashing American hopes for a breakthrough on trade negotiations.
 
Most of His Bills Fail
 Most of the Prime Minister's legislative package failed, although a proposal to permit Japanese troops to join United Nations peacekeeping forces may be approved this year or next.
Paradoxically, the issue that led to his downfall was the one that put him in power in the first place -- his dogged espousal of legislation to cleanse Japanese politics of the overwhelming influence of big money contributions from businesses and individuals.
Mr. Kaifu's ethics package would have imposed new limits on fund-raising, provided for Government subsidies for campaigns and carried out a sweeping redistricting plan that would have cut the power of rural areas and left most districts represented by only one lawmaker, instead of three or four under the current system.
The legislation was opposed for various reasons, not least because it would have transferred electoral power to urban areas and thoroughly disrupted everyone's re-election plans. It was long expected to fail, in fact, but not quite so spectacularly as it did on Monday.
Even Mr. Kaifu was startled when most his own party members moved to kill the legislation, hoping that this would humiliate the Prime Minister. But what apparently doomed Mr. Kaifu was his response to the defeat, a reaction that was interpreted as an unseemly mixture of stubbornness and equivocation.
 
Party Leaders Infuriated
 He infuriated party leaders by threatening, if only indirectly, to dissolve Parliament, and then backing down when it was clear that party leaders opposed such a move. Then on Thursday he again hinted that he would dissolve Parliament.
"The party leaders have been supporting Mr. Kaifu with a certain amount of exasperation and frustration and maybe resentment," a Government official said. "But when he indicated he might dissolve the Parliament and then withdrew it, there was an outcry: 'What kind of leader is he?' "
Even before the events of this week, three of the governing party's four main factions were fielding candidates to oppose Mr. Kaifu's re-election. The election is to take place Oct. 27 among the 394 Liberal Democratic Party members in Parliament.
The three factions already opposed to Mr. Kaifu control a majority of the Liberal Democratic votes. But Mr. Kaifu has always counted on the backing of the fourth and largest faction, which has 108 members and is headed by Mr. Takeshita, who is widely considered the most powerful politician in Japan because of his grip on patronage and fund-raising.
Until this week, politicians assumed that Mr. Takeshita would find it useful to stick by Mr. Kaifu and entice one or two of the other factions to join him by offering jobs and patronage in a new Kaifu government. The first signal that something was amiss came Thursday when a Takeshita ally criticized Mr. Kaifu for his threat to dissolve Parliament.
Some may see Mr. Kaifu as a martyr for his cause of political reform, but Japanese leaders seem to regard him as merely an instrument for advancing an idea for reform that failed to achieve consensus. It thus seemed that his idle threats and stumbling remarks were being punished almost on esthetic grounds.
Mr. Kaifu, in other words, was out of sync with his patrons, and the consensus behind him vanished as quickly and mysteriously as it had appeared.

HEADLINE: Pact Bans Oil Exploration in Antarctic

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Climaxing a long campaign by environmental groups to turn the Antarctic into a "world park," 24 countries, including the United States, signed an agreement today to ban mineral and oil exploration in the continent for at least 50 years.
The agreement, which was hailed as historic by governments and environmental groups alike, also includes new regulations for wildlife protection, waste disposal, marine pollution and continued monitoring of the Antarctic, which covers nearly one-tenth of the world's land surface. 
 'It's the first time that the international community has formally recognized the finite nature of this planet," said Steve Sawyer, executive director of Greenpeace International. "This is as close to a permanent ban as can be obtained," added James N. Barnes of the Washington-based Friends of the Earth.
 
'Last Great Wilderness'
 Governments seemed equally satisfied. "This is the protection of the last great wilderness," said Michael Heseltine, Britain's Environment Minister. "It's a case for celebration. I'm delighted to be making history."
Tucker Scully, the chief American delegate, said, "I think it is a very good agreement and it's important we move quickly to implement it."
The agreement takes the form of a protocol to the 1959 Antarctic Treaty, which banned nuclear and military activity in the area, suspended competing territorial claims by seven Southern Hemisphere nations and established rules for scientific research.
Although there is no firm evidence that Antarctica contains oil or minerals in commercial quantities, many governments, led by France and Australia, rejected a 1988 convention regulating mining activities on the continent as inadequate and began campaigning for an outright ban.
 
U.S. Held Up Accord
 But today's accord, which will go into effect after ratification by the signing governments, almost came unstuck in Madrid last June when the United States refused to endorse a draft agreement accepted by all other governments on the grounds that a 50-year moratorium was effectively a permanent ban.
Last June's draft said the ban could be lifted after 50 years only with the unanimous approval of all 26 full members of the Antarctic Treaty, while the United States insisted that future economic and environmental circumstances could justify greater flexibility. Since the Antarctic Treaty nations always work through consensus, Washington could hold up the accord.
But a new formula requiring only a two-thirds majority to end the moratorium proved acceptable to the United States and in July President Bush announced that Washington would sign the protocol.
The agreement, which emerged from four negotiating sessions over the past year, was signed at a ceremony at the Spanish Foreign Ministry today by 24 members of the Antarctic Treaty, including the Soviet Union, China, Germany, Canada, Britain and France as well as the United States. Japan and South Korea said they would sign after completing domestic legal procedures.
 
14 Other Nations Involved
 The negotiations also included 14 other signatories of the Antarctic Treaty -- countries with environmental interest but no scientific bases in the continent. Of these, seven signed today and all others are expected to do so during the year in which the protocol will be open for signature.
"Not only has the Antarctic become an international park for peace, but it has been considerably promoted for developing scientific research for the benefit of all humanity," Spain's Foreign Minister, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez, said at today's signing.
But, while heartened by the protocol, environmental groups said they would continue to be vigilant in the Antarctic because, in Mr. Sawyer's words, "it is still not safe from continuing human activities."
He said some 25 national scientific bases in the Antarctic have proven to be "environmentally disastrous" -- some bases have been abandoned without being dismantled -- while an increasing demand for Antarctic fish and growing numbers of tourists represent new threats.

HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS;
Excerpts From Senate Hearings on Nominee to Be Director of Intelligence

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from today's hearings by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on the nomination of Robert M. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence, as transcribed by Reuters and the Federal Information Systems Corporation, a private transcription service.
 
Statement
By Senator David L. Boren
Democrat of Oklahoma
 After hearing Senator Hollings last night, I felt that in a way I had not been fully fair to the nominee because I have not shared in open session and before these hearings close, I think I should share in open session some of my own insights into actions by this nominee that I think should be considered by this committee. 
 They're not determinative, I would say to you Mr. Gates, and I would say to you as I sit here this morning I have not fully determined in my own mind how we'll vote on this nomination. There are many factors to be considered. . . .
I want to weigh the benefits of your experience that you would bring to this job against the disadvantages that in some way that experience also presents itself. There are two sides to the argument. There are those that say experience is critical for the next director to make the changes that need to be made.
There's another point of view presented by some of our witnesses and even though some of it was not based upon direct experience with you, it is an important perspective that says we need someone who can make a fresh start to make all the changes in the agency. So there are many, many factors that have to be weighed before I make a final decision myself.
But there is one other factor, and perhaps I am in some ways the best witness on this element, that should also be before the members of the committee. It is not determinative of how someone should vote or how I will vote, but it is evidence, in a sense, our experience that should be weighed in the balance with the other factors as we make a decision about how to proceed.
 
. . .
 . . . [F]or the past five years I have made it the focus of my own personal legislative agenda and my own work as chairman of this committee, to strengthen the Congressional oversight process over intelligence. Because I became convinced that if we had true, credible, effective, efficient oversight, that could probably do as much as anything to prevent that kind of thing from happening in the future. . . .
So we tried to change the oversight process and make it efficient, and make it effective, and make it tough, and let people in the agency know that someone was watching, and watching more effectively than had been the case before.
RELATIONSHIP OF TRUST The other thing I was determined we should try to do is build some relationship of trust between the executive and legislative branches, and between the two parties and the operation of this system, so that we wouldn't have to sit here as members of this committee and try to figure out the right question to ask in exactly the right way to get the information that the elected representatives of people deserve to have.
And that had been the atmosphere before, and, quite frankly, that was the atmosphere during the Casey tenure, and that I think was his personal attitude because he came from a culture in the intelligence community that existed before oversight was ever heard of or thought of. And so he had a different attitude.
And we wanted to change it. And we wanted to build that trust.
 
. . .
 And I would tell members of this committee, there was no single person in the intelligence community, without exception, that supported the efforts of this committee to get access to information and to have truthful reporting to this committee than the nominee that's before us this morning, Mr. Gates. Every time we had a problem of not having people give us information or talk straight to us as we were trying to have our quarterly reviews of covert action, he responded.
We then struggled to set up an independent audit unit for the first time, since the General Accounting audit units cannot go out and audit secret programs. This committee and the committee in the House for years have been dependent upon the C.I.A. itself to tell us how they were spending their money and how they were operating their secret bank accounts. . . .
So we set up an independent audit unit. . . .
I can tell you from my personal experience that the person who was most forceful in all of the intelligence community and the executive branch in advocating full cooperation and full access to the new audit unit of this committee of any information we ever wanted was the nominee, Mr. Gates. . . .
 
. . .
 And then when we got into negotiations with the executive branch about whether or not there should be a statutory independent inspector-general confirmed by this committee and answerable to it, with an obligation to report any differences of opinion in terms of the conduct of investigations that they might have with the Director of Central Intelligence -- so it couldn't be swept under the rug -- they had to report any difference of opinion to us within a certain number of days. . . .
And I want the members of this committee to know who it was, because I had those conversations and I was in the room when some of those debates occurred with some of the other advisers to the President. It was this nominee, Mr. Gates, who most forcefully argued and used his influence to urge the President of the United States to approve and not to veto the independent statutory inspector-general.
'FORCEFUL ADVOCATE' And over almost six years now, we have negotiated with the executive branch for major reforms in the oversight process and in the finding process for covert actions; first, with the Reagan Administration and then with the Bush Administration. And, as you know, through two attempted enactments, one of them vetoed by the President, to get the lessens learned from the Iran-Contra matter written into the law so we could never again have retroactive findings and verbal findings and some of the things that we found wrong with the process during the Iran-Contra years. . . .
And I know, again, who was the most forceful advocate for this committee and for the oversight process in trying to explain, even to the President of the United States who was D.C.I. when the oversight process was not in place, why it's important and why it is appropriate, is this nominee, Mr. Gates.
 
. . .
 So I just put that into the record and I want my colleagues to know that.
And in listening to Senator Hollings last night I realized that he was thinking about this nomination without the benefit of what I know.
 
. . .
 . . . [T]hat is not in any way for me to say that's the sole factor on which we should judge this nominee. There are many, many factors. We have to consider lots of things before we judge this nominee. There are many factors that I'm going to weigh.
I would say, Mr. Gates, as I said in the beginning, I haven't made a decision about how I'm going to vote on your nomination. And I'm going to carefully look at the record.
 
. . .

 
 
Questions
From Senator Sam Nunn
Democrat of Georgia
 You state to the analysts and the managers who were gathered, quoting you, "While our list of successes is impressive, the list of our shortcomings, the events where we fell short, is in some ways even more impressive. We failed adequately to predict the scope of Soviet strategic deployments during the late 1960's and early 1970's. We failed to anticipate technological breakthroughs such as those that led to the deployment of the Alpha class submarine.
We missed the revolution in Iran. We failed to predict the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan until they actually began their military preparations. We failed over a number of years to identify for our policy makers the magnitude of Soviet efforts to acquire Western technology, and the nature of those efforts.
We failed to anticipate the Egyptian decision to launch a war against Israel in 1973. We significantly misjudged the percentage of Soviet G.N.P. allocated to defense.
We have repeatedly misread Cuba. We ignored Soviet interest in terrorism. We have been far behind events in devoting resources to examining instability and insurgency, and that is not an exhaustive list."
Mr. Gates, that sweeps from the late 1960's all the way up to the early 1980's with an astounding number of what you perceived to be and told your community intelligence failures.
Could you tell us what your view is on the intelligence failures, shortcomings, of the 1980's up to the present time, and also, any notable successes? . . .
A. I think that among the failures would be most recently the failure to anticipate Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. It would be the Soviet recognition that they could no longer sustain the level of defense spending that they had with the economic troubles that they had.
I think that we did not anticipate -- I'm stretching here -- I think we did not anticipate the Israeli incursion into Lebanon in 1982.
SOME SUCCESSES I think some of our successes, I think that the record on Eastern Europe is good. There was an estimate done in 1984 that anticipated, that predicted major crises in Eastern Europe by 1990. A 1987 estimate that predicted that Czechoslovakia and Hungary would be in crisis within two or three years.
I think we did a pretty good of tracking Gorbachev's reform measures, and the problems in those reform measures. We did a better job than I remembered yesterday, I was going to deal with this with Senator Bradley, in looking at some of the alternative futures for the Soviet Union, the event of major problems.
I think they did a good job of predicting a crisis this year in the Soviet Union. There is a very good memo from April.
I think another success -- there are some shortcomings clearly in performance on the Iraq war, but I think that there was a very good success in the respect that they had -- the intelligence community had a good fix on the technological capabilities of Iraqi weapons. I think intelligence did a remarkable job in tracking the effectiveness of the sanctions and in providing a basis for some 800 diplomatic demarches.
So just off the top of my head, those are some successes and failures that I can think of.
Q. Well, let me just read you a couple of quotes from Secretary Shultz in his Iran-contra testimony.
 
. . .
 . . . [T]here were two things that I objected to, and I'm quoting him. One was the intelligence analysis that was stated in it, because I thought that they were not reading the Iran situation right. And the other was the suggestion that basically flowed from the intelligence estimate that it was desirable to change our policy on arms sales, so the two things were connected, end quote.
Now let me read you another Shultz quote.
. . . "I developed a very clear opinion that the President was not being given accurate information. I was very alarmed about it. It became the preoccupying thing that I was working on during this period, and I felt it was tremendously important for the President to get accurate information so he could see and make a judgment."
 
. ..
 Here you had a Secretary of State, one of the principal customers of intelligence, that basically was having to fight against what he believed to be the Central Intelligence Agency or the intelligence product going to the President.
Now, you in that period of time, either head of D.D.I. or deputy, and yet you say that you don't believe the President was being misled. And yet the Iran-contra committee found that the President was being misled. And people that worked for you believed that the President was being misled. . . .
A. Senator, two points.
First of all, there is no -- no secret that Mr. Casey and Secretary Shultz disliked each other intensely. In fact, I think during that fall period of 1986, that Mr. Casey even tried to get the Secretary of State fired.
Second, it's also, I think, no secret that Mr. Casey did not draw as bright a line as he should have in terms of his own role between providing intelligence and trying to influence the policies.
Q. On that one, Mr. Gates, did you ever go and tell the President that: Watch out for Mr. Casey because -- you said yesterday, we have to pull him back all the time.
A. No, sir, and I don't think either one of my predecessors did either.
Q. Well should you, looking back on it, have gone to President Reagan in this time frame and told him that he had better be cautious?
A. What I felt was important was insuring that the President's daily brief that went to the President every day, and that the intelligence that was published by the community and by C.I.A. that went to the National Security Council staff, to Admiral Poindexter, to Secretary Shultz, presented as honest and forthright an account of what was actually going on as we possibly could.
And I think that record stands up well. . .
 
. . .
 Q. Did you ever express concern to Mr. Casey himself that he should be careful about what he was saying on this subject?
A. I talked to Mr. Casey on several occasions about insuring that the views of the analysts get represented when he would go do his briefings at National Security Council meetings.
 
Remarks
By Senator Warren B. Rudman
Republican of New Hampshire
 Well, I would just like to point out to Senator Nunn, a very interesting line of questions, that all of Secretary Shultz's comments, if you go back and look at the record, were not relating at all to national intelligence estimates out of the C.I.A.
They were all related -- and I'll give the Senator the cite -- to National Security Council Directives, N.S.D.D.'s. And the committee found that there was atrocious misrepresentation to the President of the United States of what the real facts were by the National Security Council headed by then Admiral Poindexter.
 
Questions
From Senator Dennis DeConcini
Democrat of Arizona
 I just want to discuss the now famous speech of '86, "War by Another Name." Senator Bradley raised this with you yesterday and I believe you told Senator Bradley that you tried to make it very clear when you delivered this speech that this was your own opinion. Is that a fair statement to Senator Bradley?
A. The passage that he read, yes, sir.
Q. When you made that speech, you were introduced as the Deputy Director of the C.I.A. Was there any qualification or caveat that this was your own statement and not to be considered the statement of Bob Gates the Deputy Director of the C.I.A. or just Bob Gates, Mr. Citizen who wants to express a view here personally?
A. I don't recall that there was any caveat. Sometimes I would introduce speeches by saying that what I was about to offer was my own view. I don't recall whether I did in this case.
Q. In this speech you made some very interesting statements that have been rehashed here that within the Soviet Union's global strategy, its targets include, among other things, the Panama Canal, the mineral resources of South Africa, the oil fields of the Middle East, and I believe you admitted to Senator Bradley that this amazing analysis was based on no evidence.
A. That's correct. I was my analysis.
Q. So my question is, if you are to make these kinds of speeches and you are confirmed, number one, I gather that maybe you're not going to make them but if you do, don't you think it's very important that you clarify that this is your own personal view, particularly when you are the director of the C.I.A.? . . .
A. . . . I not only agree that it's important to differentiate whether I am offering what is in essence a summary of what intelligence has concluded at a given time on a subject like proliferation or whatever and where it's a personal view. But frankly, going back to the discussion of yesterday and two weeks ago, as I had indicated on the first day of the hearings, and quite honestly, before I was nominated for this job, having where you stand sometimes depending on where you sit, from my job as deputy national security adviser, it seemed to me inappropriate for the director to give speeches that could be interpreted as policy advocacy.
Q. And certainly you agree that that one could be?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. And I take it that's not going to be your practice if you're confirmed.
A. You can bank on it.
 
Questions From
Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum
Democrat of Ohio
 Mr. Gates, I've thought a little bit the last 24 hours about your 20 points, and I kept coming back to the 33 non-recollects that you gave this committee, and the 40 don't-knows, and I'm having some difficulty with it, and I'm wondering whether you would like to address yourself as to the reason that you told this committee . . . that you couldn't recollect the answer to 33 questions, and you didn't know the answer to 40 others, when it's quite obvious that you had the resources -- the whole C.I.A. was ready to help you, the whole White House ready to help you -- to get any information that you needed, to go back and dig out the facts. Why didn't you give this committee more full answers than you did?
A. Senator Metzenbaum, I gave this committee in those interrogatories the most honest answers that I could. Some of those questions concerned conversations between other people. Some of them involved Mr. North's diaries, which I had nothing to do with, and hadn't looked at.
Q. Why didn't you go to look at them at that point?
A. . . . First of all, when I prepared those 20 points, I went back to C.I.A., I went through the allegations that had been made before this committee last week, and I listed all of those allegations. . . . And I asked them to pull together the documents for me that were related to those questions.
. . . [A]ll I'm trying to tell you is that -- and I guess that I am responding with some passion because I'm a little annoyed at this notion of selective memory or selective amnesia, to take the other side of it.
And the fact of the matter is that I don't, I don't think it is unreasonable that somebody is not going to remember the details of a conversation that took place five or six years ago, or even five or six weeks ago, if there is no written record made of it, and if it falls in the middle of a variety of other things that are going on.
 
. . .
 Q. What bothered me from the inception, bothers me now, is whether you were leveling with us, whether you were trying to sort of "gild the lily" a little bit, by saying, "I didn't read the North notes." But you could have gone and read them when you got the interrogatories, and you could have then answered our question. But you didn't do that. I had difficulty with it.
A. Well, Senator, at times those questions were asking me what I thought Mr. North had been referring to when he would write something or other, and that's where I would answer that I didn't know. Because I, I -- far from me to know what was in his mind when he --
Q. Somebody said you didn't know what was in the notes.
A. I was trying to be very careful, Mr. Chairman, in responding to those questions. I obviously had read the entries that were being asked about, but I did not -- I had not taken the time to read all of Colonel North's diaries, or to know the context, or to even know that the entries reflected things that had actually happened.
 
Closing Statement
By Mr. Gates
 . . . [J]ust as I would worry that inadequate coordination and sharing of information might cause C.I.A. to miss an important development abroad, I believe we need further safeguards when it comes to recognizing and acting upon intelligence information raising the suspicion or possibility of illegal activities outside of C.I.A. This is related to the concerns expressed by both Senator Nunn and Senator DeConcini.
While by statute C.I.A. is not a law-enforcement agency, I think we have to act conscientiously when information of concern comes to us.
 
. . .
 The D.C.I. is the President's senior intelligence officer and as such, he is expected to have a personal view. But it is his first responsibility to insure that the views of the institution -- the analysts -- are accurately and faithfully reported together with dissents and alternatives.
The problems of perceived politicization and self-censorship must be addressed urgently. . . .
Finally, on a personal note, this confirmation process, while long -- after all, the whole Soviet empire has fallen apart in the course of these things -- has been fair, thorough and professional. And for that, I thank the committee and its staff. I will close by again thanking the President for nominating me, and I will say that I hope that this committee and the full Senate will see fit to return me once again to the agency I love and to which I dedicated my life a long time ago.
Thank you.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert M. Gates testifying yesterday. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
From His Position of Power, Bush Swings Into a Defense

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Maintaining an oddly defensive posture as he prepares to enter the 1992 campaign, President Bush called a news conference today to tell the country that he really does care about domestic problems.
Stung by Democratic assaults on high unemployment, civil rights and parental leaves, facing the gloomy prospect of an election year with the economy in recession, and battling polls that show American voters think he spends too much time on foreign affairs, Mr. Bush insisted that he was as concerned about problems at home as about the global crises that have consumed much of his 31 months in office. 
 "So I will keep plodding along here, and making clear what our domestic priorities are, and I will not neglect my responsibilities to keep the American people informed on national security matters," Mr. Bush said.
That the President of the United States felt compelled to make this argument was a measure of the challenge facing Mr. Bush, even though he is a heavy favorite for re-election: His undeniable electoral strength is based on his handling of foreign policy, but the concerns of American voters are increasingly turning to pocketbook issues.
Today, he tried to use the forum of a hastily called news conference in the White House press room to turn the pressure on Congress.
Mr. Bush accused the Democratic leaders of passing legislation that they know he will veto simply to score political points against what even Republican advisers concede is his weakest flank: economic and social issues. Mr. Bush insisted that he, in turn, is not playing politics when he uses his Presidential pulpit and the trappings of his enormous traveling entourage to promote his programs.
As he did on Wednesday in a three-state political swing, the President insisted once again that he is not yet a candidate for re-election and suggested it was not fair to treat him as one.
So intent was Mr. Bush on countering the impression that he is almost exclusively focused on foreign affairs that he turned one question on European affairs into a discussion of the domestic political struggle.
Asked if he was willing to attend a four-power summit conference on arms control, as suggested by France, Mr. Bush said: "Well, I've got to watch foreign travel. I don't want to have it leveled agianst me that I'm interested in only one area here."
And the President kept what he called "a score sheet" on his lecturn of the number of domestic and foreign-policy questions he was asked by reporters, with the apparent aim of backing his argument that he is forced to address foreign policy more often than domestic issues by nature of his job.
 
Facing Embarrassing Vetoes
 Frustrating his effort to seem engaged in domestic policy are ineluctable political realities: Mr. Bush has no extra money to address social ills. He is fighting a Democratic Congress that is presenting him with several politically embarrassing vetoes on bills regarding parental leave, abortion and other hot issues. And he has been forced to deal with an astonishing series of complex international crises.
These have naturally taken up much of his attention. But Mr. Bush is, by his own admission, more at home at the United Nations than on Main Street and in the end, he is likely in the 1992 campaign to try to change the subject from domestic to foreign affairs.
For now, Mr. Bush is trying to do just the opposite. But he has been doing it a reactive way. Mr. Bush has been so vexed by recent Democratic charges that he lacks a program on domestic policy that he has often resorted to voicing the criticisms himself simply so he can then rebut them.
He has done this as he hiked through the Grand Canyon, visited dozens of schools, clinics and crime-prevention centers, addressed schoolchildren twice on satellite television links and flown from coast to coast raising money for Republican candidates.
Today, Mr. Bush began his news conference by saying a drop in the unemployment rate for the month was a sign that "the economy is strenghtening." And he renewed his attack on Congress over a $6.4 billion bill extending payments for the unemployed beyond the normal cutoff period, which he has said he would veto.
 
Backing Smaller Benefits
 "I am deeply concerned about those who are out of work," Mr. Bush said. "Unemployment benefits are important. Congress should provide a responsible extension of such benefits. The bill that we've been for for some time, the Dole bill, does just exactly that. And I'll sign a bill that helps people and also protects the overall economy."
Mr. Bush was referring to a $1.9 billion measure sponsored by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, that would also extend unemployment benefits but would pay for itself, while the Democratic bill would cost the Government money, which Mr. Bush said would break the 1990 agreement on reducing the Federal budget deficit.
Asked his advice for those who are unemployed and facing a loss of benefits, Mr. Bush said, "What they ought to do is demand of their Congressmen: 'Let's not just try to get it your way up there. Do something that the President can sign that will help us with unemployment benefits but will also protect the other taxpayers.' "
But he conceded that his promise at the 1988 Republican National Convention to create 30 million jobs in eight years was too ambitious. "Whether I live up to 30 in eight years, I don't know, but if I can get through these first four years is what I'm focusing on right now," he said. "I've learned just to avoid all the predictions now, including 30 million in eight years."
Renewing his proposal to cut the tax rate on profits from investments, or capital gains, Mr. Bush asserted that such a reduction would "stimulate the economy immediately."
"It doesn't have to take effect, it just has to get the confidence that a reduction in capital gains would give it, because it would create jobs and people would see it and people would invest more," Mr. Bush said.
 
Keeping Score
 Pressed to explain what he meant, Mr. Bush said: "I mean confidence in the economy," he said. "You see, what I think is that what the economy needs is a shot of confidence."
Mr. Bush argued that the criticism of his focus on foreign affairs was unfair, asserting: "The point is, a President has to deal with these things. You can have every Congressman and every group can deal much more openly and be much more engaged on the domestic side, but on foreign policy, there's a disproportionate responsibility for national security, whatever it is"
Mr. Bush suggested that news coverage of his Presidency also left the impression that he was not engaged on economics and social issues. "You all ask a lot of international questions and I answer them," he said.
Picking up a sheet of paper, Mr. Bush said: "I'm thinking of this press conference. I kept a little score sheet here."
He never reported the results of his tally. If he had, it would have shown that Mr. Bush was asked 26 questions, 16 of them on domestic issues.

HEADLINE: Manhattan Boat People: Lo Rnt, Riv Vu

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
Riverside Park was not meant to be a housing project, but over the years two groups of people have made it home. One formed a small shantytown of homeless men and women. The other established yachting's version of a trailer park on Manhattan's Upper West Side, living year-round on 120 boats and floating homes in the city's 79th Street Boat Basin.
The homeless people were called squatters, and the boat owners were called a community, but to some critics there was not much difference: Both groups had turned public waterfront into private housing at unbeatable prices. For $300 a month -- less than it costs to park in nearby commercial garages -- boat basin residents can not only park their cars in a city garage, they get a berth big enough to moor a three-story home. 
 This year, though, when city officials moved to reclaim the park for public recreation, a clear difference between the two groups emerged. The city evicted the homeless people in the summer. It is letting the boat dwellers remain, even though most of them have been on rent strike for more than a year, and it is spending more than $2 million over the next year to fix up their home.
In some cities it might seem odd for a government confronting a budget crisis to be subsidizing the owners of yachts and houseboats, but in New York the boat owners and some local politicians consider it customary and just. And that may be the most remarkable thing about the story of New York's brand of boat people: It is a typical example of how the housing system often works in the city.
It is a traditional New York saga of tenants who complain about intolerable conditions but refuse to leave and make a profit with clandestine sublets; of landlords who spend more energy on legal battles than than on maintenance; and of public policies that provide cheap rents to long-ensconced residents -- who tend to be middle class or affluent -- while leaving indigent newcomers to fend for themselves on the open market.
 
'Squatters on Public Land'
 The result of all this is a dilapidated public facility that is sealed from the public by chain-link fence and razor-ribbon wire. Its docks are rotting and its waters have so much silt that they are unnavigable most of the day -- not that navigability is a major concern. Ninety percent of the boats in the marina never leave the dock, and consequently there is rarely any room for outside boaters to come in.
"The people in the boat basin are squatters on public land," said Peter Wright, chairman of the Riverside Park Fund, a private group that raises money for the park. "We should have a spiffy public recreational facility that generates revenue for the Parks Department. Instead we have an eyesore that's like a private co-op, and the city is subsidizing it. Why? These are not poor people. Why do they get to live in a park?"
New York's four other municipal marinas, which forbid boaters to take up residence there, generate revenue for the city. The city is guaranteed at least $150,000 annually, for instance, from the concessionaire at the 330-slip World's Fair Marina in Flushing, Queens. The concessionaire operates it and pays for maintenance as well as capital improvements, an arrangement common at municipal marinas in other cities.
The Parks Department, however, is currently unable to find any concessionarie to run the 79th Street Marina because of its decrepit condition and its residents' reputation for rent strikes.
The residents began living there year-round in the mid-1960's, according to Gene Greenspun, who has the most seniority among the roughly 150 "live-aboards" there today. He got a berth at the marina in 1955 and began living year-round in 1969.
"It's a romantic way of life," Mr. Greenspun, a chemist and engineer, said while sitting on his upstairs balcony recently watching the orange evening sky over the Palisades. "When I moved here it was strictly for love of the water. Today you have people here because it's cheap."
Mr. Greenspun's 2,000-square-foot home, named the Fountainhead, is a three-level, brown-shingled house with carpeting, a dishwasher, a den, a bar, a two-story living room, an organ and synthesizer, a washer and dryer, and cable television. His rent is $262.50 a month; two of his neighbors with taller, roomier houses pay a little less.
The average rent at the boat basin is $233 a month -- roughly what other residents of the Upper West Side pay in property taxes alone. The average monthly tax bills in the neighborhood are $170 a month for a rental apartment; $203 for a co-op; $420 for a condominium; $541 for a house.
Live-aboards get running water included in their rent, but they pay for their own electricity and provide their own oil or coal heating. They pay $60 monthly to park in a city garage next to the marina. At nearby commercial garages it costs between $300 and $415 monthly to park, and the city parking tax alone comes to more than $30 a month.
The city hopes to raise the dockage fees by 40 percent, which would still be a little less than the rate at some local private marinas. The increase will not provide any revenue for the city, because the new fees would just cover the budgeted operating and maintenance expenses, assuming the fees are paid. For now, with two-thirds of the live-aboards on a rent strike for the past year, the city is losing more than $200,000 a year running the marina.
 
Charges of Negligence
 In addition, the city is currently spending $2.2 million in capital funds to renovate the marina, and there are future plans to spend another $3.4 million on dredging and other capital improvements. The city is also contemplating spending $800,000 for a sewage-pumping station for the waste from the boats' toilets, which is currently released directly into the river.
Why, when other marinas in the area are turning a profit for private owners and concessionaires, should the city be subsidizing the boat basin? The live-aboards, who have formed a group called the Hudson Harbor Preservation Association, argue that the city should repair the marina because the city let it deteriorate when it was being run by concessionaires.
"These people have suffered through tremendous personal and economic costs," said Lonn Berney, the association's lawyer. "Yes, the city's putting in funds now, but it was the city's negligence that let the marina fall into disrepair."
The live-aboards have long argued that the marina's decrepit conditions have justified their low rents. But these conditions rarely caused tenants to leave. The waiting list for berths grew to 400 names over the past decade as nearly all the live-aboard renewed their leases, often quietly profiting by subletting their homes.
Over the years they have used rent strikes to press for repairs, successfully resisted an attempt by the city in 1980 to shut down the marina as a fire hazard, enlisted support from politicians like Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, and inspired sympathetic media coverage of their fight to keep their homes.
"How are you ever going to get a guy out of here who's been here 15 years?" asked Mr. Greenspun. "The city can't do that. When you've got 120 boats, you can spend $100 each to hire a lawyer to keep fighting the city forever. And why shouldn't we get to live here? You can say that it's cheap living down here, but what about people up the hill living in rent-controlled apartments for $99 a month? Where's the rationale for that?"
That is a good question, according to critics who refer to the marina as floating rent control. They see its decay as a classic example of what happens when public policy keeps rents so low that tenants never want to move, landlords never want to make repairs, and lawyers never stop arguing.
Robert S. Bernstein, the president of Nichols Yacht Yards, which operated the boat basin from 1977 to 1982, said that his firm spent $250,000 in legal fees battling the city and tenants on the rent strike. "It's the crummiest marina I have ever seen in my entire life," he said, blaming its deterioration on the city's refusal to raise rents to pay for improvements.
"There was an entrenched, combative tenant group," he said, "that got politicians and the press on their side with their story of people living on the brave new frontier on the water fighting the evil landlords. But they're nothing but rent-control squatters."
 
Plans by the City
 No private operators have responded to the city's requests for bids to renovate or operate the marina, which is why the Parks Deparment has taken it over. Charles McKinney, the city Parks Department's director of Riverside Park, has been negotiating with the live-aboards' association on a plan for the city to rebuild the marina in return for higher dockage fees, an end to the rent strike, and a gradual change in the marina's character.
Mr. McKinney said he would like to open a pier for strollers and perhaps for commercial sightseeing boats or ferries. He has met resistance from the live-aboards' association, particularly in his proposal for allocating any slips that are voluntarily vacated by live-aboards. He wants to set them aside for short-term stays by visiting boaters.
"I'm willing to accommodate the people living there now," Mr. McKinney said, "but I don't want to perpetuate the situation indefinitely after they leave. They want to be able to pass their slips along to other live-aboards, and they want the community to stay as large it is. My position is that the park should be used for recreation for everyone, not housing for a few people."
Mr. McKinney said the marina's residential character has forced the city to allocate most of the current capital spending on an extra electric line to protect the live-aboards against a power failure and the city against resulting lawsuits for endangering the safety of residents. Mr. McKinney said the extra line, which is costing $1.8 milllion, would not be essential if the marina were not being used for housing.
Mr. McKinney said that most other capital improvements at the marina should ultimately benefit the public, and that he hopes the rebuilt marina will eventually generate revenue for the city. But it is still unclear whether the public will get access to the marina, or whether the city will ever recoup its investment.
The fate of the marina did not hold much interest for a group of homeless men and women sleeping a few yards away one recent night in the park's rotunda, just above the marina's parking garage. They expressed some resentment at the new policy forbidding them from leaving shanties or other permanent structures in the park, and said they wished they could find a single-room-occupancy hotel with rents as low as the marina's.
But they showed little reaction when told that the city's contribution to the the boat basin this year amounted to $15,000 for each of the homes there.
"It ain't fair," Ernest Davis, a 42-year-old native of Harlem, said with a shrug. "Nothing we can do about it. They got money and authority, and we don't. Money talks in politics. If you got a dollar and I don't, they're going to take care of you."

HEADLINE: New York Drops Painters to Hire Inmates, Union Says

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration is laying off unionized painters and replacing them with welfare recipients, jail inmates in work-release programs and ex-offenders, union leaders say -- a practice, they contend, that violates the law and further strains the administration's contentious relations with organized labor.
But supporters of the use of welfare recipients and others in city painting jobs say the goal is simply to educate these people and help them find jobs, not to displace union workers. 
 The city's Human Resources Administration, which oversees social-service programs, has discharged eight union painters since June and nine more are scheduled to be let go.
The agency says it is eliminating the civil-service jobs to help resolve the city's budget problems, but it has also extended and expanded a longstanding job-training contract with a nonprofit agency that hires welfare recipients, jail inmates on work release and former inmates to do the same work as the union painters.
The union, Local 1969 of the civil service painters, sued the city early last month, accusing the Human Resources Administration of violating state law by replacing civil servants with welfare trainees. The local demands that the union painters be returned to their jobs.
Officials of the Human Resources Administration would not comment on the dispute because it is now in court, said Sheila Jack, an agency spokeswoman. The city is to respond to the union's lawsuit in court next Wednesday.
Because of paperwork delays, the layoff of nine painters, originally planned for yesterday, was postponed, union officials said. The employees will be discharged any day, bringing to 17 the number of painters laid off, or 40 percent of the 42 civil-service painters employed by the city agency last spring.
Labor leaders have occasionally chafed at the use of trainees in jobs that could be filled by civil-service workers. But those concerns were muted during the 1980's, as the city's economy boomed and thousands of additional municipal workers were hired each year.
But as the city's fiscal condition deteriorated in the last year causing the layoff of about 5,000 city workers, union leaders have become alarmed at the possibility that welfare trainees could be used to replace civil servants.
The Wildcat Service Corporation, the private, nonprofit agency that runs the job-training program for the city, said initially, in response to questions, that its trainees do not do painting that is ordinarily assigned to union painters. The point of the program, they said, is educational, to teach basic painting and broader "life skills" like punctuality and how to search for a job.
"It's just a training program," Amalia V. Betanzos, the corporation's president, said early this week. "It's not union work. It's not work that the people who are being laid off ordinarily do."
Mrs. Betanzos said the painting done by the trainees is work that the city would ordinarily contract out to private companies. The program is in its fifth year, she said.
But labor leaders insisted that people in the job-training program are assigned to do exactly the same work in city shelters as civil-service painters. Sometimes, union and nonunion crews have worked simultaneously at the same site, but most of the time they are kept apart, union officials said.
When Mrs. Betanzos was asked again, on Thursday, how the trainees' work was different from the union painters', she referred the question to her agency's vice president of operations, Richard Harris.
Mr. Harris said the trainees used to do only basic painting, while the union painters also performed more sophisticated tasks like reconstructive plastering. But he said that, in response to complaints from the union, an agreement was reached last year expanding the scope of the trainees' work and making it the same as that of the union painters.
Union officials said they had made no such settlement, and that it had been imposed, over their objections, by the city.
"It appears to us that the city is using Wildcat workers to get similar service at lower cost," said Albert M. Carrozza, the president of Local 1969.
 
Another Program
 State law allows municipal social-service agencies to create on-the-job training programs with private employers for people receiving home relief, the form of welfare for able-bodied adults with no children.
In a separate welfare program for women with children -- the largest one of its kind in New York -- the city has recently shifted its strategy away from putting these mothers in low-paying menial jobs and toward educating and training them in programs like Wildcat's.
But the social-service law also says that welfare recipients cannot be used to replace regular government employees, or to do the work they ordinarily do, said Adam Ira Klein, the lawyer representing the union.
The union argues that that is precisely what has happened at the Human Resources Administration.
"It's really just cheap labor, taking family people and replacing them with low-paid workers," said John Alfarone, the special trustee in charge of District Council 9 of the International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades, the local's parent body. "The city values cheap labor."
 
Minimum Wage
 The union painters earn an average of $21 an hour, based on prevailing labor rates set by the city, Mr. Carrozza said. Each must have three years' experience as an apprentice and five years as a full-time journeyman painter to be hired by the city, he said.
The welfare recipients and ex-offenders are paid the minimum wage, $4.25 an hour, Mrs. Betanzos said.
The city paid $664,500 to Wildcat for the painting program during the fiscal year that ended June 30, Ms. Jack said. It has budgeted $398,000 -- an increase of 20 percent -- for the first six months of the fiscal year that began on July 1.
Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said the welfare recipients in the Human Resources Adminstration's painting program "are effectively being used as union busters."
"We shouldn't allow it," he said, "because the union movement is being destroyed by people who are supposed to be supportive of it."
The civil-service workers paint the interiors of 34 homeless shelters operated by the city, as well as administrative offices of the Human Resources Administration. Members of their local also paint in about a dozen other municipal agencies. Job trainees employed by Wildcat paint in the Police and General Services Departments, said Mr. Carrozza, the local's president. He said he did not know whether union workers had lost their jobs and been replaced by trainees in those departments.
The labor leaders said they had tolerated the city's use of welfare trainees for a long time, because they support such programs. "We are not against the programs that Wildcat has," Mr. Carrozza said. "Wildcat's aims are worthy ones."
But the union officials said they drew the line when civil-service workers began to be laid off and in effect were being replaced by people in the training programs.
Union officials said the trainees are exposed to all kinds of hazards -- from lead and asbestos at work sites to the use of ladders and scaffolding -- for which they are ill prepared. The labor leaders also contended that they were not motivated by racial concerns: Most of the unionized painters are members of minorities, Mr. Carrozza said, as are many of the people in the training program.
Mr. Carrozza and other union leaders noted that Mayor David N. Dinkins was elected two years ago with broad support from organized labor. But the city's labor relations have deteriorated badly over the last year, as the administration has laid off workers and demanded union concessions.

HEADLINE: S. L. Brown Weds Jean MacGregor

 BODY:
Jean Agnes MacGregor, the host of "Rhode Island Weekly," a public affairs program on Times-Mirror Cable Television of Rhode Island in Providence, was married yesterday to Stephen Lee Brown, the associate publisher of The Phoenix's NewPaper in Providence. The Rev. John Edmunds, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the bridegroom's home in Jamestown, R.I., assisted by the bride's brother, Ronald MacGregor, a brother of the Episcopal Order of St. Gregory.
The bride, a graduate of Emerson College, is the daughter of Greg MacGregor of Pompano Beach, Fla., who retired as a public relations officer for the New York Blood Center, and of Eileen Palmer McMorrow of Baldwin, L.I., a retired radio actress who used her maiden name, Eileen Palmer. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce. 
 Mr. Brown, a graduate of the University of Vermont, has an M.A. in public administration from Harvard University. He is a son of Kenneth G. Brown of Southern Pines, N.C., and Elizabeth Woods Ryan of Chappaqua, N.Y. The bridegroom's father is a freelance economist and energy consultant.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.;
Convention Center Project

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST

 BODY:
THE State of Rhode Island is the prime mover and investor in a $290 million convention center project now under construction in downtown Providence. The state is not only financing the project but it will be the owner of a new hotel and of the landmark Biltmore Hotel, which it is buying from The Providence Journal Company.
Managed by the quasi-public Convention Center Authority, the project is being financed with tax-free revenue bonds. The authority, arguing that the recession had made it impossible to find a private hotel developer able to finance construction of a needed new hotel, got permission from the General Assembly this year to include the two hotels in the project. 
 The cost of construction of the new hotel and the purchase and partial renovation of the Biltmore is estimated at $90 million.
At the June groundbreaking, Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun compared the convention center to the "pump-priming" projects of President Franklin D. Roosevelt in the Depression. Construction is expected to generate about 1,500 jobs and, once the project is completed late in 1993, about 3,500 permanent jobs. Rhode Island has a 9.1 percent unemployment rate.
The project is expected to run a $9.3 million annual deficit, at least in the first few years, but the authority argues that the state will realize a net economic gain. Figures prepared by the Dallas office of Coopers & Lybrand, accountants, predict $50 million in tax revenue over the next 10 years and $600 million in tax revenue to both the state and Providence over the next 30 years.
The Providence Convention and Visitors Bureau, charged with marketing the convention center, has found interest in it to be "very favorable," said Terry Dale, the bureau's president. The primary reason, he said, is that hotel rates in Providence are as much as 40 percent below rates on other nearby metropolitan areas.
"Many groups have wanted to come to New England for some time," Mr. Dale said, "but have found rates in Boston prohibitive."
The convention center, developed by the local Metro Partners Inc., will include a 100,000-square-foot exhibit hall, 20,000-square-foot ballroom, 15,000 square feet of meeting space and parking for about 2,400 cars.
The new hotel will have 260 rooms and be connected to the convention center. The authority will own both it and the 290-room Biltmore, but they will be managed by TCC, a Miami company. The authority has voted to negotiate a franchise agreement with Westin Hotels & Resorts of Seattle.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rendering of the convention center planned in Providence, R.I. (Metro Partners Inc.)

HEADLINE: Casing In The Bomb;
Disarmament Plan Quickens Calls for A Peace Dividend

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN most respects, the budget deal President Bush and Congress struck last October was as pleasant for the politicians involved as a skinned knee. The President was forced to renege on his no-new-taxes pledge. Democrats had to concede that there would be no growth in social programs for years. But the agreement did have one fundamental political attraction: it was supposed to put off further argument about spending and taxes until after the 1992 elections.
Now, that has gone by the boards. When the President startled the nation a week ago Friday by announcing that he planned to scrap a significant portion of the nuclear arsenal, it was guaranteed that the size of the military budget will once more come under intense political scrutiny. And that will throw open the door to fresh debate on the basic budget issues that have divided politicians for years: how high taxes should be, how large the deficit should be and how much the country can afford to spend on health, highways and the myriad other Government programs voters demand. 
 Lawmakers from both parties agree that changed circumstances mean that the military budget should be re-examined. If, as the President said -- even before yesterday's announcement of plans for sweeping cuts in the Soviet nuclear arsenal -- war with the Soviet Union is "no longer a realistic threat," then why, they ask, is it necessary to keep active a dozen aircraft carriers at an annual cost of about $600 million apiece? Why should the nation spend billions for the Star Wars missile defense system, the B-2 Stealth bomber, a new attack submarine or other astronomically expensive state-of-the-art weapons? Why should tens of thousands of troops be maintained in Germany, South Korea and elsewhere around the world?
Those questions were raised not only by liberal Pentagon critics but by such staunch conservative supporters of the military as Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, and Senator John McCain, a conservative Republican and former career naval officer who was a prisoner of war in Vietnam.
On Friday, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin, suggested that he foresaw deep new cuts in the Pentagon budget, which, at close to $300 billion a year, now accounts for about one-quarter of total Federal spending. Mr. Aspin, a Wisconsin Democrat, announced that he was beginning an investigation to "determine what real defenses we need at the spending levels we can justify by the real threats we face."
 
Things Fall Apart>
 After days of similar speech-making and news conferences, it was clear by the end of last week throughout the Capitol, downtown at the White House and across the Potomac at the Pentagon that the budget arrangement was coming apart and would have to be renegotiated next year, before the election.
"It's getting very frayed around the edges," said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Budget Committee and was one of the main authors of the budget agreement. "An unraveling is imminent."
The cornerstone of the deal between the President and Congress was that tax rates, the military budget and domestic spending were locked in concrete for years. Any proposal to reduce taxes was required to have an offsetting spending cut. And money could not be shifted between the military and domestic sides of the ledger.
The issue now is not whether the annual spending levels for the Defense Department enacted last year will be reduced in the years ahead. That is almost a certainty. What must be decided is how much will be cut and what the money will then be used for.
 
'Reasonable' Cuts
 Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were concentrating last week on getting their budget through Congress for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 and insisting, at least publicly, that cutbacks in the years to come would be unwise.
While some saving might result eventually from the President's new moves to reduce nuclear weapons, they said, initially the Government will face the added expense of destroying some nuclear weapons and shipping others home.
But a senior adviser to the President said he was sure that if Mr. Bush had not already instructed Mr. Cheney to begin preparing a new, less expensive long-term plan for the military, he would soon tell the Defense Secretary to do so. "What the President insists on," said the aide, who talks with the President often, "is that the defense reductions be reasonable and prudent and not done in haste."
How much is reasonable and prudent is, of course, open to question. Two authorities on the subject, William W. Kaufmann, professor emeritus of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and John D. Steinbruner, director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution, argued in a paper prepared before the failed coup in the Soviet Union and published late last month that the budget now planned for the Pentagon could safely be cut over the next 10 years by nearly 50 percent at a saving of $316 billion.
"The future ability of the United States to maintain the conditions of its security will depend as much on its moral authority, diplomatic skills and economic assets as on its military capabilities," the study asserted.
The Pentagon and the White House surely will not agree to cuts that deep, and Congress might not either. But a reduction of 25 percent or so in the military budget has already been scheduled over the next five years, and further reductions of tens if not hundreds of billions of dollars are not out of the question.
That money could be used in three basic ways: to reduce the budget deficit, to cut taxes or to expand domestic programs.
Many Democrats in Congress would like to spend the money on new social programs, particularly in the area of medical care. But the Bush Administration is dead set against that.
"One of the big problems in opening up the defense budget for debate again is that the money can be used as an offset for anybody's favorite spending program," said one of the President's senior assistants. In the same vein, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in an interview last week that the Administration vigorously opposed "an income-transfer policy, which we know in the Great Society was tried for a long period of time and which economists have thrown over as a way of life."
Republicans in Congress generally favor a proposal by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas that would divide Pentagon savings between a tax cut and deficit reduction. "The American people should be rewarded in some fashion for the fruits of their labors," said Senator McCain.
Meantime, discussion has begun within the Administration about taking some money out of the Pentagon budget to provide short-term economic assistance to the Soviet Union. Secretary Brady said he thought such talk was premature, and whether the President himself has been involved in such discussions is not clear.
The best bet -- no surprise in these times of divided Government -- is for a negotiated settlement: a little money for the Soviet Union and much more for popular social programs, middle-income tax relief and reduction of the deficit.
Expect the debate to last all next year. It will be a framework for the 1992 campaign.
