HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Bush Makes Aid to Israel Subject to Conditions

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR an issue charged with so much deep passion, the debate over housing loan guarantees for Israel ended last week in a remarkable hush -- but not because there was no clear winner. Indeed, it was precisely because the Bush Administration had trounced Israel and its Congressional supporters that neither side had an interest in ballyhooing the outcome. Israel and its supporters did not want to advertise their defeat. And the Administration did not want to publicly relish its victory, because it expects that it will have to fight this issue again four months down the road and there would be no point in antagonizing its opponents any more than it already has.
Last week Senators Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, and Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, announced that they were acceding to President Bush's request to delay until February their legislation offering $10 billion in loan guarantees to help Israel resettle Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union. While the Senators said they had 70 co-sponsors for this legislation -- enough to override a Presidential veto -- what they didn't say was that many had signed on only on the understanding that the bill would be delayed as the President asked. 
 That the loan-guarantee issue was put to rest this way was both revealing and pregnant with longer-term implications. The first thing to understand is that virtually nobody in Washington is challenging Israel's need for the loan guarantees, which would enable it to raise money from private banks on preferential terms. For the first time ever, though, the United States is trying to link the granting of such economic assistance to a change in behavior by Israel. President Bush let Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, know that he would grant Israel the housing loan guarantees only if Israel accepted unprecedented conditions -- severe restrictions on settlement activity in the occupied territories -- to insure that the loans would not be indirectly helping Israel consolidate territorial claims on the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Mr. Bush said he sought the four-month delay because he knew how inflammatory a debate with Israel on such conditions would be. He wanted the issue to arise after the beginning of a peace conference planned for this month, in hopes that the United States could get a settlements freeze not by using its own economic stick against Israel, but rather as part of a deal: Israel halts settlements in return for the Arabs suspending their economic boycott and the Palestinians suspending their uprising.
In spurning Mr. Bush's appeal for a delay, the Israelis seriously miscalculated the mood in America. The overwhelming sentiment in Congress is that Israel should not continue its de facto annexation of the West Bank, and when Mr. Bush was prepared to take the flak for finally making an issue of that point, he got the lawmakers' quiet support. Even more interestingly, he got the quiet support of many average Israelis and American Jews, who largely kept to the sidelines at the peak of the debate. Many American Jews remain deeply troubled by the threatening language Mr. Bush used in opposing Israeli wishes. Nevertheless, on the substance of the case an advertisement placed in major newspapers last week by Americans for Peace Now, a liberal Jewish group, seemed to speak for many. It said: "If Israel continues to build and expand settlements in the occupied territories, it will undermine the possibility for a Middle East peace. A recent poll showed 67 percent of Israelis favor a freeze on settlements for the sake of peace talks."
Rep. David R. Obey of Wisconsin, an influential Democrat who supported a delay, put the argument this way: "I think we have an obligation to help resettle Soviet Jews. But Shamir has a concurrent obligation to settle those Jews in a way that does not block a peace settlement." Mr. Obey recalled the Israel exemplified by its first Prime Minister, David Ben-Gurion, as "an inspiring example of wise conduct and long-sighted sensitivities" and added, "I have a full commitment to that Israel, but I do not feel that that translates into a commitment for bull-headed expansionism at the cost of Israel's long-term welfare and America's long-term welfare."
If there is one principle that Administration officials say they think they established by defeating Israel on the question of a delay, it is the right to attach political conditions to Israeli aid. That notion, heretofore virtually unthinkable, has now become legitimate and will almost certainly be reflected in the future. The relative quiet among American Jews in the wake of the housing loan imbroglio masks an intense, private debate on this very point.
"I believe that this is one of the most important results of the whole controversy," said Stephen P. Cohen, head of the Montreal-based Center for Middle East Peace, "because it is making American Jews and Israelis ask the question: 'What is the relationship between American Jewish political activism for Israel and the wisdom of Israeli policies?' That is a linkage that people have not wanted to investigate in the past."
But all of this comes at a price. The intense struggle between Washington and Israel during the last month could leave the impressions that the only big problems with a peace conference are Israeli settlements, and that all Arabs are ready to attend and offer Israel real reconciliation and security in return for Israeli concessions. This is not at all clear. There is still much work for the Administration to do on the Arab side of the table.
In some ways, the tough line Washington has taken with Israel should make the Arabs more willing to talk. But it may also be that the Administration's tough approach to Israel has raised unrealistic Arab expectations, especially with Syria, that Washington will deliver Israel, and that all that the Arabs will have to do is negotiate with the White House, rather than with Mr. Shamir.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For the Democrats, The Trick Is to Change Concerns Into Votes

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
EVERYONE knows what America's problems are. For Maryland state troopers, it's government layoffs. For Colorado real estate developers, it's savings and loan losses. For New Yorkers trying to bring civil suits in Manhattan it's logjammed courts.
Of course, it would be difficult to build a Presidential campaign on such narrow issues. But the five Democrats now running for the Presidential nomination might face the same problem with other issues as well, including education, racial tension, poverty and homelessness. 
 The problem is that many of the things that worry people -- even those that worry a great many people -- cannot easily be turned into the kind of political cause that gets politicians elected. The existence of a dissatisfied electorate, which should be good news for Democratic challengers and a catalyst for political change, becomes an increasing frustration to Democrats unable to translate that dissatisfaction into votes that can be marshalled against Republicans.
Although voters seem to think Democrats fare better coping with domestic concerns than Republicans, polls show that few seem to hold the Republican White House responsible. And Democrats have yet to figure out how to turn the nation's concerns into campaign issues.
The 1988 Presidential election provided a textbook case. Although Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts presented a universal health care plan and talked often of other core issues, his campaign will always be remembered for becoming mired in Republican-made images of flags and convicts.
The fault does not all lie with the Democrats. In survey after survey, poll takers have discovered a vital disconnect between concerns and campaign issues among voters. The Gallup poll, which since 1951 has been asking Americans to name the political party identified most closely with national prosperity, recently reported that the majority of those who had an opinion named the Republicans. The outcome was unusual, the Gallup polltakers said, because the party holding the White House tends to suffer the public's wrath in economic downturns like the current one.
Some political experts say that one reason the Democrats have trouble capitalizing on core issues is that Republicans have used their last 11 years in the White House pitting traditionally Democratic interest groups against one another. Hence, civil rights legislation is cast as an entitlement program, and the move to extend unemployment benefits is portrayed as a budget-busting maneuver on behalf of labor unions rather than the general public.
In the end, every Democratic issue winds up looking like a game where no one benefits, least of all the reliable middle class voters both parties are competing for. This leaves the campaign landscape clear, as in 1988, for shallow games about who is more patriotic.
Campaign strategists for both parties have hammered home to candidates that they should speak only of the salient issues that determine how Americans vote, not of the vague concerns that crop up in polls but do not affect the way ballots are cast.
"Frequently the pollsters are telling candidates that they are better off talking about what one would call consensus issues rather than contentious issues," said John Deardourff, a Republican consultant. "You've got to find issues about which some kind of working majority of people feel the same way or it isn't vote-productive." As a result, issues that disproportionately affect the poor and the disenfranchised generally hold little exploitable political benefit for Presidential candidates.
Homelessness, for instance, was cited as the nation's second most important problem in a January 1990 New York Times/CBS News poll. But by the following August, the issue had practically dropped off the screen. The problem, it seemed, was considered intractable even by those who had led the call for a solution.
Curtis Gans, the director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, said Democrats have abdicated their role of defining a focused party message that could help them mount an effective Presidential challenge, although the Democrats might have an outside chance of making a dent on the electorate if the recession continues. "But it is also true that if the economy recovers at all, it is likely that the Democrats will still be at a severe disadvantage," he said. "Because they have not figured out who they are."
There is also some debate about whether the Republicans have figured out who they are. But for the White House, there is less to lose on that front, because it is relatively easy for a President to maintain a positive image. White House finesse in this area was on display last week as Mr. Bush and Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander turned a visit to a Washington, D.C., elementary school into a campaign preview.
The visit, in which the President talked to schoolchildren who had been advised to wear soft-soled shoes that would not make distracting noise, was taped by a private production firm that was paid with $26,750 in Federal funds. The visit was broadcast live by Cable News Network and Public Broadcasting Service stations and the tape was made available to other networks.
The Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the event was not electioneering. But he also said the White House would not hesitate to use the footage for political purposes if it was deemed effective.
The President has lately grown annoyed at the Democrats' consistent refrain about what they describe as his lack of concern on domestic matters. But for his opponents, White House irritation is the best they can hope for as an immediate strategy to get their message heard above the din. President Bush, well aware that the public generally thinks far less of Congress that it does of the White House, has already demonstrated how quickly he can take the offensive.
"The President, I think, can rightly say, 'George Mitchell and the Congress have prevented me from helping to get this economy moving again,' " said Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and the Administration's domestic issues czar. "It's no secret I would like to see him do more of that."
But Mr. Kemp, who encountered problems of his own distinguishing himself in the primary crowd when he sought the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988, warned of the problems inherent in failing to address the issues that most trouble the electorate. And his words serve as warning to candidates of both parties.
"The economic pie is in contraction; it's shrinking," he said. "It pits people against people and class against class and race against race. We become uncivilized when we have a shrinking pie."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Haiti Democracy, Such as It Was, Is Ended by A Chaotic Coup

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
AN indignant world endowed with newly activist reflexes almost immediately began to organize a strong reaction last week after a mutiny by Haitian soldiers turned into a bloody rout of supporters of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. The mutiny quickly forced the elected priest-turned-president into exile on Monday.
While statements of condemnation rained down from all over the hemisphere and as far away as Moscow, the Organization of American States and other international bodies began to seek a strategy for quickly returning the deposed President to power. 
 By Friday, a delegation of foreign ministers from the Americas flew to Port-au-Prince to deliver a demand that Haiti be returned to constitutional rule. Argentina's Foreign Minister, Guido di Tella, portrayed the mission as "a test of the new international order" and what he called the "newly democratic O.A.S."
But for many Haitians, whose country has long been torn by violence and wrenched by serious class- and race-based tensions, the coup is rife with murky complexities.
President Aristide, though still wildly popular among the desperately poor masses of this country who elected him in the expectation that he would improve their lot, has generated almost equally passionate fears and suspicions among many in the tiny and prosperous educated elite; these people say that after his election to the presidency last December, Father Aristide showed scant regard for the country's newborn democratic institutions and on several occasions openly legitimized the use of violence to settle scores.
To be sure, almost nobody in Haiti is showing any sympathy for the armed, undisciplined thugs who now roam the streets shooting randomly at pedestrians, and virtually everyone is crying out for a return to constitutional rule; those who are familiar with the Constitution, however, make the point that once he is returned to office, Father Aristide himself will have to work much harder at enforcing the rule of law. Even among those who detest the military and denounce the coup, many now fear that the supporters of a returning President Aristide might soon unleash a cycle of deep purges and violent retribution.
 
Quiet Appeals
 For months before the coup, foreign diplomats here say, they were quietly urging President Aristide to condemn the scattered roadside executions of supposed partisans of past dictatorships with burning tires by his supporters, as well as the intimidation of magistrates who were to judge the President's enemies.
While publicly proclaiming strong support for Father Aristide, the diplomats have also privately counselled him to work with the legislature, which they say he has rarely shown more than contempt for. His Government has repeatedly declined or ignored legislative appeals for it to submit nominations for important positions from judgeships to commander in chief of the armed forces, as called for by the Constitution.
In August, Father Aristide's angry supporters surrounded the Parliament, roughing up legislators and threatening to burn them alive. To date, the President has issued no explicit apologies for the incident or repudiations of it.
Now, after weeks of mounting tensions, the army, a force that itself has no history of respecting the law or human rights, has seized upon the executive's many perceived constitutional breaches to justify a takeover of the country.
While few here take the army's statements at face value, the pressing international demands that Mr. Aristide be returned to power are rapidly being supplemented by much stickier requests by legislators, businessmen and political leaders that the international community help arbitrate Haitian institutional tensions and somehow constrain a free-wheeling President to stay within the law.
"Aristide has been told in Washington that he cannot simply return to the status quo ante," said one diplomat privy to last week's discussions between the deposed President and the O.A.S., referring to the President's provocative and legally questionable behavior. "He just looks blankly at you when those kinds of things are said, though. It is like the message does not register."
 
A Lack of Tools
 Other diplomats here spoke with exasperation about the lack of tools for making such a message stick once the President is returned to power, which remains the goal of all the foreign organizations addressing the crisis. Diplomats and knowledgeable Haitians say the means available to outside countries for enforcing conformity with the internal laws of a sovereign nation, always a matter of interpretation, are new and untested. Moreover, each has obvious drawbacks.
First there is the sensitive question of how another country can set guidelines for the behavior of a democratically elected leader. Then there is the separate matter of enforcement. Last week, before the international community decided to cut off Haiti from economic aid, President Bush himself expressed distaste for imposing economic sanctions on a country that is among the world's poorest.
Stronger support for the Haitian legislature, which has the constitutional authority to impeach the President if he breaks the law, could also backfire. With no tradition of parliamentary democracy, Haitians have so far shown little sympathy for the methodical legalisms of the legislature and would likely rally to a popular president's cause in the case of a showdown, throwing the country once again into crisis.
"The O.A.S. cannot sustain itself here indefinitely, but neither can the country go forward and survive if Aristide comes back without making some serious changes," said one Western diplomat. "What this is all about is a constitutional equilibrium between the institutions and restoring some balance to the society."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Leaders Come and Go, But the Japanese Boom Seems to Last Forever

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
TOSHIKI KAIFU became Japan's Prime Minister two years ago, riding a wave of public disgust over the ruling party's scandal-tainted ways. Yet there seemed little sense of outrage last week when the same sort of political kabuki he promised to reform was played out in public once again, forcing him to abandon his campaign to cleanse Japanese politics and announce that he would not run for re-election. The reason for the subdued reaction, at least in part, was contained in an equally important but little noticed event during the week: Japan set a record for its longest post-war economic boom.
The Japanese seem to have taken prosperity for granted, assuming that the politicians can maneuver as viciously as they like with little impact on their steadily humming economic machine. It is not hard to understand this feeling: At a time when the American economy is struggling with recession, the Japanese economy has just completed its 58th month of uninterrupted growth. It topped the 57-month Izanagi boom -- named for one of the mythical beings who created Japan -- that lasted from October 1965 to July 1970. 
 Setting the new record may not have been an occasion for parades or speeches, but economists are calling this one of the greatest booms in recent history, a period that has not only fundamentally altered the Japanese economy but sown the seeds of even greater friction with the United States. Some have taken to calling this period Japan's second economic miracle, as important as the one that turned a war-devastated nation into an industrial powerhouse.
"Japan is a different country today than it was five years ago," said Kenneth Courtis, senior economist with Deutsche Bank in Tokyo. "It will become even more evident in the 1990's. The Japanese economy has so much momentum that, competitively speaking, the 1990's will be over in 1995. The West won't be able to catch them after that." As Mr. Courtis put it, Japan has grown economically by the equivalent of one France since 1985, or by one South Korea each year. Its manufacturers invest more every year in new plants, equipment and research than American companies, though the American economy is some 40 percent larger than Japan's.
But the real import of the boom, economists emphasize, is not just the high growth rates. "The Japanese economy has improved not just quantitatively, but qualitively," said Yoshio Suzuki, chief counselor at the Nomura Research Institute and a former central banker. "Our companies have changed the composition of their products; they have shifted some of their production abroad, and are building higher technology products."
This is the change that is likely to make Japan an even more threatening competitor for American companies, many of which used the immense wealth created in the 1980's to benefit their investment bankers rather than investing aggressively in the future. Japanese companies are expected to increase their capital investment budgets this year -- a time when the economy is starting to cool -- by slightly less than 10 percent. But in previous years capital investment grew at a double-digit clip, roughly twice the rate of their American counterparts. Mr. Courtis estimated that Japanese companies spent about $625 billion on such investments over the last five years, a sum it will take American companies nearly 10 years to spend.
Toyota Motor, for instance, entered the 1980's as a tough competitor in the low end of the American auto market, and ended the decade having held on to its solid position selling less expensive autos while carving out a place at the luxury end, using a technologically advanced, $40,000 car to duel with Mercedes Benz. Toyota produced 3.7 percent of its vehicles abroad in 1985. Last year the figure stood at 16.1 percent.
The problems this improvement could generate were also evident last week: Japan announced Friday that its trade surplus more than doubled in August from the year before, to $8.25 billion. After tumbling for the last four years, the surplus could rise to more than $70 billion this year as companies wrest ever larger shares of foreign markets.
As has often been the case with Japan, this boom grew out of an immense challenge. In September 1985, Japan agreed to reduce its yawning trade surpluses and America's growing deficits by doubling the value of the yen against the dollar. Suddenly, the exports on which Japanese industry relied soared in price for Americans holding weaker dollars. "We thought that no economy could withstand a doubling in the value of its currency," said Mr. Suzuki. "We began reducing interest rates rapidly just to avoid a depression."
In 1986 the growth rate of Japan's economy was halved from the previous year and it slipped into a deep lull. The central bank slashed its official discount rate, a benchmark that affects what banks charge for loans, to 2.5 percent from 5 percent. The move sent a strong signal to Japanese industry: they were being given access to almost free capital to increase their productivity.
Companies poured immense sums into new technologies, more modern plants and, to avoid currency problems, new plants in the markets where they sold their goods. This flood of investment began to make up for the shortfall in exports. Corporate profits began to pick up, workers' incomes rose, and consumer buying was lifted. . The stronger yen also slashed Japan's fuel import bills, since oil is paid for in dollars.
In 1987 the Japanese economy had built up so much speed that it barely reacted to the crash on Wall Street. The value of the shares traded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange stood at 91.9 trillion yen in 1981, but rose to a peak of 611 trillion yen in 1989. At current exchange rates, that means almost $4 trillion of new wealth was created. Some of this has trickled down to the average Japanese, who is enjoying a huge improvement in lifestyle. Japanese, for instance, began venturing abroad in huge numbers. The country's travel deficit -- the difference between what foreigners spend traveling in Japan and what Japanese spend when traveling overseas -- rocketed to $21.4 billion last year from $3.7 billion in 1985.
There was, however, a dark side. Worried that the soaring prices of stocks and real estate would trigger broader inflation, the central bank began to hit the brakes in late 1989 and lift interest rates. The result was a stock market crash last year, sharply reduced lending to property speculators, and a wave of bankruptcies.
The financial industry has been hit with several scandals as stories of excesses become public. Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Finance Minister, announced last week that he was planning to resign to take responsibility for a damaging series of disclosures of unethical practices.
How much this turbulence in the financial markets has affected the industrial economy remains to be seen. Mr. Suzuki said he fears the economy is at a crossroads and he predicted there is a 60 percent chance of its slipping into a recession -- in Japanese terms that means less than 3 percent growth, an enviable rate in the United States. What is being called the Heisei boom, which means peaceful boom, would be over at last.
"They've steered to a new course, and so you have to look at things in a different way today," said Mr. Courtis. "The lesson was that they didn't roll over when they took a punch. They faced reality."

HEADLINE: A BUMPIER RIDE FOR NEW YORK TAXIS: Rarities;
One Job Women Don't Want

BYLINE: By By Ian Fisher

 BODY:
Why are there so few women among New York City's 40,000 yellow cab drivers? And why is the number dropping so quickly?
The Taxi and Limousine Commission says the number driving medallion cabs fell from 708 in 1989 to 520 in 1991 -- or 1.3 percent of all drivers. And fewer are on the way. In 1984, nearly 3 percent of all applicants to the Taxi Drivers Institute were women. This year, the number may not even hit 1 percent. 
 Experts disagree as to why women, who were probably never more than 5 percent of the drivers, are becoming as rare as Checker cabs.
"Why don't women come in?" asked Willy Bly, director of the League of Mutual Taxi Owners, which represents 4,500 taxi owners. "There is only one reason: the crime chases them away."
Several experts mentioned worry about robbery, and said fewer women drive at night. But others noted that the job market had changed too. In the 1980's, there was an increase in office temporary and data-entry jobs, which offer flexible schedules, little danger and no need to get a license.
"A lot of jobs -- whether you work hard or you don't work hard -- you get paid X number of dollars a day," said Karen Hartson, 37, a driver for seven years. "Especially in the last year, we've had bad economic times and it's been very difficult. There just aren't the passengers out there anymore."
Others said women from the countries whose men are rapidly entering the business -- Haiti, Pakistan, India and Egypt -- were probably less likely to drive.
And some blame a general decline in the perception of cab driving as a job. Sophie Bakelman, 70, who has driven for 25 years, said driving has become more stressful and competitive during the recession.
"The business isn't like it was," Mrs. Bakelman said. "They're crazy drivers now. If there is a fare on the right and they are on the left, they cut you off."
Anne Syntaski, a lively, gravelly voiced 72-year-old who works for the Taxi Drivers and Allied Workers Union and chats with many drivers, but said that fear of crime hasn't driven everyone she knows off.
"We had a woman come in here last week," she said. "She said, 'Hell, I'm 75 and I'm still driving.' Well, God bless her. That took a lot of moxie."
Mrs. Syntaski, who started driving in 1963 after her husband and son both died, only quit herself four years ago.
"It wasn't always so dangerous," she said. "I only got shot once."
About 15 years ago, she said, she was on the FDR Drive near Houston Street when she heard a shot. It came from somewhere off the highway.
"I guess I jumped a little in the front seat," she said. "The passenger said, 'Are you hurt?' And I said, 'I'm not looking down,' because I knew that I'd been shot in the arm. It was a surface wound, thank God."

HEADLINE: A Bumpier Ride for New York Taxis

BYLINE: By By Ian Fisher

 BODY:
In the overheated 1980's, New York City's taxi business reflected the decade. As the economy soared, so did hands on every streetcorner, making it nearly impossible to flag a ride. Medallion prices jumped, other kinds of cabs burgeoned and calls for reform rose. Now cabbies say there are fewer passengers, more inspectors and more unregulated competition. And the subways are cleaner. But are the cabs better? Who's the man -- it's probably not a woman -- behind the wheel? What's the story with those yellow-bumpered cabs? And why are they yellow anyway?
It might not be noticeable, but when you hail a taxi or call a car service these days, the cabs should be safer, cleaner and operated by more qualified drivers than ever before -- in theory at least.
The reason is that over the last five years, the Taxi and Limousine Commission has grown vastly, enacting scores of new rules intended to improve service and bring order to a chaotic industry. 
 There is, for instance, a dress code, and a new yellow cab safety inspection center in Queens. Most significantly, the commission in 1987 quadrupled the number of cars it regulates by licensing the 30,000 livery cars and "black cars," the dark sedans usually servicing corporate accounts -- both of which can legally take passengers only by phone.
The commission has also doubled the number of school hours for new cab drivers and mandated English tests, and has more enforcement agents prowling the streets, making sure drivers are licensed and do not refuse to pick up minorities or balk at trips outside Manhattan.
Inspectors wrote 42,240 summonses to yellow cab owners in fiscal 1991, 17,000 more than in 1989. Most were for safety defects like bald tires or severe dents, or for dirty cabs.
But those numbers -- and many new rules -- infuriate people like Ronald Stoppelman, president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, which represents 18 fleet owners. "We in the industry can't move, sneeze or stub our toes without breaking some regulation," he said. "It's just simply an over-regulated business."
Many drivers agree. "The T.L.C. inspector is crazy because he fines you for everything," said one 32-year-old driver.
Industry leaders and cabbies say the rules hurt drivers, most of whom earn $21,000 to $30,000 a year, the commission estimates. And they say the commission does little to stop their biggest problem: illegal street pickups by licensed livery or black cars or by gypsy cabs, unlicensed and often uninsured cars cruising for passengers. (Licensed livery cabs have a diamond-shaped T.L.C. sticker on the windshield.) Just last year, inspectors began seizing gypsy cabs -- sometimes by hailing them and impounding them if they offer a ride. They have seized 979 since May 1990, plus 35 yellow cars with meters that weren't New York taxis at all.
But with the new rules, the question remains: Is riding a cab better now? The commission says complaints have dropped from 12,578 to 8,927 in the last five years. But most riders can still tell stories about cabbies who speak little English, drive with a leaden foot and don't know Broadway from Broad Street from East Broadway.
All attempts to increase the number of medallions, frozen at 11,787 in 1937, have been beaten back by the industry. And New York is still often compared unfavorably to London, where cabbies get two years of tests and training, and spend weeks on bicycles, learning even the most obscure byways of the city.
Elizabeth Roistacher, a Queens College economics professor and consultant to a taxi panel under the Koch administration, said many changes look promising, especially a new rule that requires new owners of individual medallions to drive their own cabs the equivalent of 36 hours a week. "They are doing a lot of the right things in terms of trying to improve the standards," she said.
And some riders say cars seem cleaner and that, at least since the recession began, it has been easier to find a cab.
But for William Lugo, theater worker, hailing a taxi remains the same frustration it always has been.
One night this summer, Mr. Lugo, a dark-skinned Hispanic 28-year-old, tried to catch a ride from Times Square to Chelsea. He watched for 25 minutes as empty cabs streamed by him. And nowadays he doesn't even bother to try to hail a cab home to the South Bronx.
"Never -- they will not go," he said. "They just look at me and laugh."

HEADLINE: In 7 TV Appearances, Wealth of Exposure for Bush

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
President Bush provides a special introduction tonight in an ABC television movie called "Heroes of Desert Storm," which mixes news coverage of the Persian Gulf war with dramatic re-creations of events.
Mr. Bush's videotaped appearance will mark the seventh time in 10 days that he has been on national television in an extraordinary streak, even for a President. Those appearances have come on the major networks as well as on the Public Broadcasting Service and cable television, although the forums have been extremely varied: 
 On the night of Sept. 27, he addressed the nation on all networks about his plans to reduce nuclear arms. The next two afternoons he opened NBC's coverage of the Ryder Cup golf tournament with a brief taped message rooting for the American team.
 
Children and Country Music
 On Tuesday afternoon he delivered a message of encouragement to the nation's schoolchildren on PBS and the Cable News Network. On Wednesday night he appeared on stage to salute the winners of the Country Music Association Awards show, televised by CBS.
On Friday he held a news conference that was televised by all networks except ABC, which decided that the session would not generate any real news and did not need to be broadcast live.
These television appearances came over a period when events were dealing a number of blows to Mr. Bush: Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas made well-publicized announcements of their candidacies for the Democratic Presidential nomination and included attacks on him; Mr. Bush's nominee for Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates, was the subject of damaging testimony before a Senate panel; attacks continued by lawmakers opposing confirmation of Mr. Bush's Supreme Court nominee, Judge Clarence Thomas, and Democrats, spurred by the President's plans to veto bills that would extend unemployment benefits and guarantee unpaid leave for workers with family emergencies, stepped up their complaints that his Administration lacked a domestic agenda.
Dorrance Smith, the director of media affairs for the White House, said Mr. Bush's television appearances were not part of "any organized political effort" at a public-relations counteroffensive.
"It's fair to say we are going to find different ways for the President to do television," but the participation in the golf tournament coverage, the country music awards show and the movie tonight were not conceived of as parts of an overall plan, Mr. Smith said. Mr. Bush's participation in "Heroes of Desert Storm" was requested long ago, he said, and was in no way related to his other appearances.
 
Celebrating 'Our Neighbors'
 The movie is a dramatized account of the experiences of American troops in the war. The President will open it with a 30-second statement, saying that Americans have always believed there are causes to fight for and that the real heroes of war are not just the leaders but also "our neighbors" who commit themselves to the cause.
Mr. Smith said he had been asked by Don Ohlmeyer, executive producer and director of the movie, about the possibility of such an introduction. Mr. Ohlmeyer and Mr. Smith, a former news producer at ABC, once worked together at the network, very briefly.
The White House asked for and received a copy of the movie's script, Mr. Smith said, and "it seemed editorially consistent with what we wanted to say: that the troops were the heroes." He also pointed out that the movie had been made with the full cooperation of the Defense Department. "So it was a completely friendly project in that regard," Mr. Smith said.
Mr. Ohlmeyer emphasized that the movie incorporated extensive videotape from the war, including some shot by the Defense Department. He said that among the reasons he had used videotape is that it helped make the overall look of the movie consistent, with no discernible seams between the news coverage of the war and the movie's re-creations of it. The movie will be preceded by a disclaimer that says this technique was used "to achieve realism."
Television movies have sometimes been criticized for blurring the line between reality and re-creations. But Mr. Ohlmeyer said he regarded such arguments as "specious."
The writer of any news account brings a personal perspective to the story, he said, just as he and his scriptwriter did in this TV movie.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the last 10 days, President Bush has appeared on national television seven times, including Wednesday when he saluted winners of Country Music Association Awards along with the hostess, Reba McEntire. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Diplomats Press Haitian's Return

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 5

 BODY:
International efforts to restore the presidency of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide continued today amid indications that the army, which deposed him and forced him into exile on Monday, continued to rule out his return to Haiti.
According to reports filtering out of the closed-door meetings Friday evening between a high-level delegation of the Organization of American States and Haitian officers led by Brig. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the military said instead that it would be willing to relinquish power to an interim administration headed by the chief justice of the Haitian Supreme Court, Andre G. Cherilus. 
 New elections were reportedly promised within 90 days under the proposal.
General Cedras's position seemed to shift, however, before his third session with the O.A.S. delegation tonight. He suggested that Father Aristide could return to the country only "after a consensus is realized through all the sectors in the country."
As this conciliatory-sounding statement was being made, the Government television began broadcasting an unsigned 20-point petition against the deposed Government, urging among other things that Father Aristide and his Prime Minister, Rene Preval, be tried for treason.
General Cedras's qualified statement about the President's return seemed based upon the calculation that few sectors of the elite, from leaders of political parties to legislators and business executives, look forward to Father Aristide's return after a traumatizing eight months in office.
 
Talks With Parliament
 The eight-member O.A.S. delegation was to return tonight to Kingston, Jamaica, where it had spent Friday night for reasons of security. Officials of the delegation gave no indication of whether they would halt or continue their efforts here on Sunday. One member of the O.A.S. delegation, Foreign Minister Guido di Tella of Argentina, told reporters traveling with the mission that the organization had strongly expressed its commitment to the return to power of Father Aristide during its two hours of discussions on Friday with General Cedras.
"He is an intelligent man," Mr. di Tella said. "He has tremendous problems. Now he is aware of the seriousness of our actions."
 
Issue of Rights Abuses
 Asked about concerns over the deposed President's perceived abuse of authority and encouragement of violence, themes General Cedras is said to have discussed with the delegation, Mr. di Tella said, "These allegations of human rights abuses are part of the picture."
Early this afternoon, leaders of eight Haitian political parties, none of them linked to the President, arrived to meet with the O.A.S. delegation, and reportedly expressed strong reservations about Father Aristide.
"Most of the people in the delegation don't want him to return," said Marc L. Bazin, the only serious rival to Father Aristide in the December elections, which he won with 67 percent of the vote.
At a brief afternoon news conference that followed discussions with members of the Aristide Government, the Bolivian Foreign Minister, Carlos Hurralde, called the Haitian crisis a "complex, sensitive problem," indicating that diplomatic efforts would continue for some time.
 
Promoting Aristide's Return
 "We need the return to the constitutional process," Mr. Hurralde said. "We are promoting the return of President Aristide." Asked what might be done should the military refuse to relent, Mr. Hurralde said, "Other measures can be taken" after further consultations at O.A.S. headquarters in Washington next week.
As the talks went on, limited economic activity resumed in the capital today after six days of a near-total freeze on commerce that resulted from fears of violence and popular consternation over the military coup. Although public transportation was nowhere to be seen, large crowds of people milled through streets heavily littered with the debris of a powerful nighttime storm.
Women selling eggs, fruits, rice and other goods and shoppers uncertain when their next opportunity to purchase food lent renewed animation to the central city.
 
Roads Are Barricaded
 Reports from the countryside, however, indicated that roads in some areas remained barricaded by Aristide supporters, who rained rocks down on anyone who tried to pass.
Diplomats said low stocks of many goods, including oil and gasoline, and the bureaucracy's continuing refusal to collaborate with the military administration could soon place additional pressure on the military to reach a negotiated settlement of the crisis.
Some observers who believe that General Cedras did not order the coup and is not in full command of his soldiers, however, question whether he can reach an agreement that achieves the return of the President over the objection of his soldiers.
"Aristide's status is not something that Cedras or the General Staff can simply decide by themselves," said an official who is close to the O.A.S. talks.

HEADLINE: Rebel Front Says It Can Fix War-Battered Angola

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, Sept. 30

 BODY:
As Angola emerges exhausted from 16 years of civil war, most people think that their lives can only improve. They may be disillusioned.
"During the war I suffered a lot," said Emiliano Chitunda, a baker, "but now my life is becoming more normal." Mr. Chitunda called President Jose Eduardo dos Santos "a good man" because he signed the peace agreement concluded with the Government last May. But Mr. Chitunda put his faith in Jonas Savimbi, the guerrilla leader of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. 
 Mr. Savimbi, who returned here Sunday after 16 years spent fighting from the bush, is already campaigning to win the national elections schedule in a year. He contends that his rebel movement, popularly known by its Portuguese acronym Unita, can direct its battlefield resolve toward a peaceful struggle for prosperity.
"Enough of Mediocrity -- We Deserve a Better Life," read a banner hung by Unita backers on a street in Luanda.
 
Will Seek U.S. Intercession
 "We will cooperate with the Government in peace, but we are an opposition movement," said Mr. Savimbi, who is scheduled to meet with President Bush on Monday in Washington.
"I'm going to ask the Americans to put pressure on the process," Mr. Savimbi told reporters. The visit is also calculated to increase Mr. Savimbi's electoral chances by implying that the United States, which supported his movement, will do more for Angolans than the Soviet Union and Cuba, which backed Mr. dos Santos's Government.
Unita, which blames the Marxist ideology now scrapped by the Government for Angola's ills, lacks an economic track record of its own. The areas under its control operate by barter at subsistence level. Mr. Savimbi's group says that it has plans for reconstruction but has yet to disclose them.
But some people in this capital, who blame Unita for wartime atrocities, nonetheless think that the insurgents can do no worse than the Government run by the rival Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.
Angel Feijo, a student, said Mr. Savimbi "has the power to put right the conditions in this country," adding: "The Government hasn't the power to put it right. They don't know how to lead the way."
 
Regaining 1975 Levels
 Some economic analysts predict that it will take as long as a decade to bring Angola back to the level of 1975, when Portugal gave up its African colony. The Angolan economy, said Alfred S. Fawundo, the deputy representative of the United Nations Development Program here, "really defies conventional description."
The civil war was devastating, causing the deaths of more than 500,000 Angolans, two-thirds of them children. Up to a million people were displaced. Basic installations and services have suffered more than $30 billion in material damage since 1980, according to a United Nations estimate.
Angola has one of the world's worst child mortality rates; 1988 figures showed that 29 of every 100 children died before reaching the age of 5.
Before the war, Angola had rich potential. It still ranks second in Africa, after Nigeria, in oil production. Petroleum and its products generate 95 percent of foreign earnings, much of which has been spent on Soviet weapons.
Once, Angola was the world's fourth-largest producer of coffee and the fifth-largest of diamonds. It also prospered on cotton and fishing, and supported itself in agriculture. Now, many basic food items must be imported.
The country's deterioration is conspicuous in Luanda, which has tottered for years on the brink of urban apocalypse. Stately houses have decayed and many office buildings, reduced to derelict slums. Squatters from a refugee influx that quadrupled the population of Luanda camp in the decrepit buildings, hanging laundry from the balconies, cooking or sleeping in the foyers. The stench of uncollected garbage fills the humid air.
Disabled people, some wearing remnants of army uniforms, hobble or crawl along the streets begging for food. More than 40,000 Angolans, including civilians, have been maimed, and live land mines are still found throughout the country.
Yet Luanda throbs with an informal, though hardly productive economy. Women balance on their heads cases of imported beer and soda acquired from restricted state stores. They are bound for Roque Santeiro, a sprawling black market nicknamed from a Brazilian television soap opera.
Francisco, a clerk in Luanda, said he uses the monthly hard-currency allowance from his European employers to invest in imported beer. At Roque Santeiro, he resells the beer at seven and a half times what he paid for it -- $176 a case at the official exchange rate. Francisco said the Government made speculation a necessity.
"We have a very corrupt society," complained a young teacher named Manuel, who also asked that his full name not be used, "and the civil servants earn a lot, not through their salaries but through their privileges at the Government stores."
 
2 Adjacent Tiers of Commerce
 Near the waterfront, a "people's store" displays rice, cooking oil, vinegar and other staples subsidized by the Government. They must be purchased with ration cards issued to state employees, which excludes many Angolans. Outside, women sitting on the cracked sidewalk beg emerging shoppers to sell them anything. On the black market, a can of cooking oil can fetch 25 times the state price of 12 kwanzas.
After the black market rate for a dollar soared to 2,000 kwanzas last year, the Government devalued the currency -- from 30 kwanzas to the dollar to 60. Last October, it recalled the old money to exchange for new kwanzas. Angolans received one-twentieth of what they handed in, and promises that the Government would hold the rest. Outside the main bank, men stand scanning posted lists of those whose applications to get money back are under consideration.
Though the Government has repudiated Marxist policies and moved to start deregulating the constricted economy as early as 1987, it seems unwilling to undertake sweeping free-market reforms with an election a year away. A law forbids even unprofitable companies from laying off employees.
And the central bank refused to give foreign currency to some companies to import machinery and spare parts, grinding some factories to a halt.
"To privatize is one thing, but the most important thing is shifting responsibility from the Government," an African economic analyst said. "There will still be a tendency to resist through regulations, or hold out strategic enterprises" from deregulation.
"I think Unita might not have that kind of restrictive mind," the analyst said.
 
The New Colonialists
 Some Angolans express nostalgia for Portugese colonial rule, when they say they were oppressed and exploited but had stable homes and enough to eat. But many also take for granted the welfare policies of socialism.
"There is a will on the part of the people of Angola to change, but I don't think there is a will to make more sacrifices," Mr. Fawundo said.
The immediate threat to peace is posed by war-weary soldiers on both sides who have no prospect of jobs or even food for tomorrow.
Peace plans call for 70,000 Government soldiers and 50,000 guerrillas to gather at 50 assembly points and be disarmed. From each side, 20,000 will be selected for a new professional army and the rest demobilized. A target of Aug. 1 was missed because mined roads and blown bridges made travel hazardous. With food shortages at the assembly points, concern has grown that some soldiers may resort to banditry.
 
Unicef Role
 "We are afraid that they are not all going to the assembly points," said Valentin Neto, a Luanda resident. "We want them to stop being soldiers so that we are safe from them."
The United Nations Children's Emergency Fund, or Unicef, has been active in Angola. It has found that to feed malnourished children and their mothers, it may have to help the soldiers too.
"The issue is what do you do to make sure that the peace process doesn't grind to a halt, to make sure that the peace process isn't threatened?" said Ibrahim Fall, the fund's representative in Angola. His relief program, designed for 1.9 million Angolans in nine provinces, now contemplates feeding up to three million in all 18 provinces.
"The war cost a lot of money, but peace has its price," Mr. Fall said.

HEADLINE: Shooting Puts Focus on Korean-Black Frictions in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The grainy videotape, in pantomime, shows an angry tussle over a $1.79 bottle of orange juice at the counter of a Korean grocery. It shows the customer, a 15-year-old black girl, turning as if to walk away, then it shows a woman raising a pistol and firing a single, fatal shot into the back of the girl's head.
The videotaped shooting, which has been shown repeatedly on television, has become the focus of rising tensions between Koreans and blacks in this city, where increasing ethnic diversity is bringing with it increasing frictions. 
 On Monday a jury is scheduled to begin deliberations in the trial of Soon Ja Du, 49, the Korean woman who faces a charge of second-degree murder in the death of Latasha Harlins, whom she had accused of trying to steal the bottle of juice.
"This incident embodies all of the problem areas," said Larry Aubry, a member of the Los Angeles County Human Relations Commission. "It has come to symbolize what is wrong in the situation."
He added: "You look at all the economic indices like income and housing, and blacks remain at the bottom. Then the Koreans come in and try to make their mark. It's kind of a worst-case scenario."
In crumbling South Central Los Angeles, with its vacant lots and closed storefronts, the only economically successful enterprises in some places seem to be Korean groceries, service stations and liquor stores.
It is a situation that has led to frequent violence. In the last six months, two Korean shop owners have been shot and killed in holdups, and another has been gravely wounded. In the same period, Koreans have killed three black people, but charges were filed only in the Harlins case.
With a boycott similar to the yearlong action in Brooklyn that ended last February, a black group, the Brotherhood Crusade, succeeded this week in closing a Korean market where a black man was killed in June in what the police called justifiable self-defense.
At her trial this week Mrs. Du tearfully denied intending to shoot the girl after they argued over the bottle of orange juice that was protruding from the girl's backpack.
 
Poverty and Discrimination
 Two witnesses, a 9-year-old boy and a 13-year-old girl who were in the store to buy hair gel for their mother, testified that Mrs. Du and Miss Harlins engaged in a slapping, shouting, stool-throwing argument before the fatal shot was fired on March 16.
Outside the courtroom some blacks said the killing points up the poverty and racial discimination with which black people live as a wave of energetic immigrants jostles them aside.
They said the Koreans, who now own about 3,000 small businesses in Southern California, are preying economically on their people.
"There is consistent and persistent rude treatment," said John W. Mack, president of the Los Angeles chapter of the Urban League.
Chull Huh, secretary general of the Korean Chamber of Commerce of Los Angeles, said of the boycotters: "They're not willing to listen to the Korean community's opinions. They try to provoke, to exaggerate the issue."
Leaders of the Korean immigrant community talk urgently of the need to understand the ways of black Americans, and suggest that racial stereotyping may be involved on both sides.
 
The First Third-World City
 Cultural sensitivity has become an urgent issue in recent years as Los Angeles has developed into what some people have begun to call the nation's first third-world city.
In the last 20 years the Korean population of Los Angeles has increased to 250,000 from 9,000 as part of an influx of Asians, who now make up 9 percent of the city's population of 3.5 million.
At the same time, the black population has declined, to 13 percent from 17 percent in the last decade. Black neighborhoods like Watts have been flooded with members of other minorities, while blacks have remained at the bottom of the economic ladder.
In South Central Los Angeles some Korean markets have become the targets of vandalism and firebombings, as well as a series of boycotts organized by Danny Bakewell, the leader of the Brotherhood Crusade.
He has targeted the Empire Liquor Market, where Miss Harlins was killed, the 7 Days Food Store, where a Korean grocer waved a pistol in a dispute with two men who were delivering eggs, and the Jr. Liquor Market, which was closed in the agreement Friday.
In the final days of the 110-day picket of that market, a half-dozen picketers were protesting the death of Arthur Lee Mitchell, a former amateur boxer, who was shot in an attempted holdup on June 14 by the shop's owner.
The scene was emblematic of the deep fissures of mistrust and misunderstanding that often divide the city's many ethnic groups.
Inside the quiet, empty store, its owner, Tae Sam Park, 47, patted his heart and said, "I'm scared -- all the time." Every day, he said, he and his wife, Kum Ock Park, walk past picketers shouting, "Go back to Korea!" and "Murderer!"
Mr. Bakewell has said he hoped to form a flying force of picketers who would make Korean businesses change their ways or close down altogether. The agreement ending the boycott would offer Mr. Park's grocery for sale to a black buyer, if one comes forward.
This approach seemed only to underline the economic realities behind the black-Korean tensions.
Outside Mr. Park's store, the picketers said that when shoppers approached them they sent them down the street to King's Market, the only other nearby grocery.
King's Market is owned by a Korean.

HEADLINE: REPORT IS CRITICAL OF MENTAL CLINICS

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Nearly half of the community mental health centers that are required to provide basic services under Federal contracts have failed to do so, a Government report asserts.
Officials of the National Institute of Mental Health, the agency in charge of the community mental health program, disputed the figure issued Thursday in the report by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services. But they acknowledged that 10 to 15 percent of the community mental health centers under contract with the Government were failing to provide basic services. 
 The failure of this and other programs to provide service is one of the reasons for the growing number of homeless, mentally ill people now wandering the streets of American cities untreated, experts say.
About 600 community mental health centers have received a total of several hundred million dollars in Federal construction money in the past 25 years. In return, they agreed to provide, for at least 20 years, five basic mental health services, including emergency treatment and outpatient clinics.
 
249 Failures Are Cited
 The Inspector General's report estimated that 249 of the 600 have failed to give the basic services to the community and many have failed to provide service at all to the poor, as required. The report was released at a hearing of the Human Resources Subcommittee of the House Government Operations Committee.
But officials of the mental health institute estimate that about 60 of the centers have failed to provide basic care. The agency said it was working to get them to do so in most cases. In a few cases, the agency is seeking to have the mental health centers return the original Federal investment.
But both the Inspector General and the mental health institute agreed that the community mental health center program had been substantially altered over the years.
The program was begun in 1963 in the belief that the hundreds of thousands of patients being released from mental institutions under new laws and court rulings could go home and receive mental health care at the centers in their communities.
 
Construction on Promises
 The Federal Government provided construction money to build the centers, often as part of existing hospitals, and in return the centers agreed to provide five basic services: emergency mental treatment, in-patient care for the severely ill, day treatment for those who could live at home but needed intense care, outpatient services for those who needed periodic treatment, and education services to schools, hospitals and other institutions.
Further, these centers were required to provide a small amount of free or very low-cost care to those who could not afford regular rates for 20 years. The amount required in the 1963 law was 10 percent of the original construction grant in services each year, an amount that now amounts to very little after almost three decades of inflation.
Today Dr. Alan Leshner, acting director of the National Institute of Mental Health, said that in the intervening years it had become apparent that community mental health centers had been unable to provide adequate service to those who were released from institutions or were most seriously ill.
In addition, it has become clear that few centers provide free care. Some provide reduced-price care, but for people without insurance, the amount can still be high. In one example cited, a 45-minute counseling period cost $18.
Among the institutions cited in the report as failing to provide basic services were are such well-known clinics as McLean Hospital near Boston and the Thalians Community Mental Health Center at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.
Other institutes cited as failing to provide basic care were the University of Arkansas Medical Center; Carondelet Health Services in Tucson, Ariz.; Buffalo General Hospital in New York State; Touro Infirmary in New Orleans; Battle Creek Adventist Hospital in Michigan, and Youth Consultation Services of the Episcopal Church in Newark.
 
'A Toughter Attitude'
 A report 18 months ago by Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group, working with a former consultant for the institute, Howard Fishman, found serious deficiencies in the way mental health services were provided by many of the centers.
Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of Manhattan, the chairmen of the subcommittee holding the hearing, said that since the report was issued, "N.I.M.H. was supposed to require the centers to refund the Federal grants they had received, or to make up for their past mistakes by providing the required services for additional years."
"Today, we hear that in most cases, N.I.M.H. failed to do either," he said.
Dr. Leshner said he believed that many of the centers cited as deficient were not seriously deficient and that their violations could be corrected. In several cases, the institute asked the centers to keep offering services several years beyond their 20-year requirement to make up for their years of failure. But the institute asked for only about one-third of the number of additional years that the Inspector General's report said could be extracted from the centers.

HEADLINE: Lured by Zlotys, Ivan Plays The Model Migrant Worker

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRZEMYSL, Poland, Sept. 29

 BODY:
In the factories and on the construction sites of eastern Poland, there is a new model employee these days. Trustworthy, tireless, and willing to accept half the prevailing wages, these highly prized workers speak broken Polish and are likely to answer to names like Nikolai, Mikhail or Ivan.
They are Russians, Lithuanians and Ukrainians. Like the Poles who have for years streamed west to work without permits in America and Western Europe, they are flocking to Poland, eager to earn sums equivalent to eight months Soviet pay in a month. Some enter legally, while many more come on tourist visas and then melt into the cities and countryside, wherever there is work. 
 The result is a paradox of Eastern Europe's uneven transition to capitalism. While state enterprises in the Soviet Union have earned a reputation for inefficiency and indolence, Polish employers in this border region speak of Soviet workers in awe-struck tones -- even as Poles continue to supply the West with cheap, illegal labor.
"They work for much less money; they don't need vodka, and they work without supervision," said Michal Rabski, who owns two cosmetic stores and is putting the final touches on his three-story home. His construction crew consists of two Nikolais and a Pyotr, all from Sambor, a Ukrainian city about 35 miles from the border.
"Look at the way they work -- everything is neatly put away," Mr. Rabski said with evident delight. "If they were Poles, half of the village would be up here having drinks."
 
A Yen for Zlotys
 To the visiting Soviet workers, the most important feature of Poland's economic program is the internal convertibility of the Polish currency, the zloty. While foreigners are officially barred from trading zlotys for American dollars or other foreign currency, the exchange counters in various Polish cities in fact serve all comers. Soviet visitors can also use their zlotys to buy goods that are scarce in the Soviet Union -- from cars to children's clothing -- and resell them back home at a large profit.
The two Nikolais and Pyotr are typical. They entered the country legally, sponsored by a Polish construction company, and work in their spare time for Mr. Rabski, earning 10,000 zlotys an hour, a bit less than $1 and about half of what Poles make for comparable labor. Their total monthly pay, 1.4 million zloty, turns into $128, which in turn can be traded for at least 4,000 rubles at the current black-market exchange rate -- eight months pay for the average Soviet factory worker, whose monthly salary is about 500 rubles, although workers in private, cooperative and other enterprises can earn much more.
A year ago, officials throughout Eastern Europe feared the imminent arrival of hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions, of refugees from a collapsing Soviet Union. That threat has not materialized, but Polish officials worry that the loosening of travel restrictions in the Soviet Union presages a flood of migrant workers who will take jobs from Poles or force local wages lower.
The phenomenon reflects the differing pace of economic change in the two countries. Poland is in the second year of a far-reaching program that filled once empty shops with goods; the Soviet Union is still debating the first steps towards dismantling its command economy. Further, Soviet workers have little or no incentive to work.
 
Four Million Soviet Visitors
 Local officials say they have no solid estimate on how many Soviet citizens are working in Poland, but they acknowledge that the number is growing, with most of them taking jobs primarily in construction and in private factories. More than four million Soviet citizens have already visited Poland this year, and tens of thousands are known to be legally in the country now.
"Things in Poland are in good order," said the younger Nikolai at the door of the workers' hotel where he temporarily lives. "This is the kind of work and conditions we'd like to have in the future in free Ukraine." He and his colleagues said they intend to stay in Poland through the rest of this year, but said they have no plans to settle in the country.
Local employers -- cities or other entities -- may hire the Soviet citizens if they establish that no Poles are available for the work in question and that the wages are appropriate in the labor market. In Rzeszow, when the local orchestra expanded, it chose to hire 14 violinists from the Ukrainian city of Lvov at a salary of 1.4 million zloty, or $128, a month; an orchestra official said no Polish musicians were available at this salary.
From the Soviet side, a prospective worker needs only a written invitation from a Polish citizen -- which must be approved by local police -- and a valid Soviet passport.
Lodging is a problem for some of the migrant laborers. Local officials say that visiting Soviets have been seen sleeping in sheds Poles keep on their state-provided garden plots, leaving behind a bottle of Russian vodka as payment.
 
'Longing for Work'
 Zdzislaw Besz, a journalist from Przymysl who operates a store and brick factory, said he hired two Ukrainians earlier this year with the help of a cousin from Kiev. Mr. Besz said he paid them the same salary as his Polish employees.
"These are excellent specialists," Mr. Besz said. "They never gave me any problems. I'd like to hire even more Russians. These people were motivated. I didn't have to keep my eye on them."
Jacek Pasternak, head of the labor office in Rzeszow, about 60 miles from the Soviet border, said he has heard reports of labor markets, where Polish employers can place orders for craftsmen from the Soviet Union. But he said most appeared to be finding work through informal channels.
The story told by Kazimierz, a 68-year-old retired carpenter in Rzeszow, was echoed by many employers. Kazimierz, who spoke on condition that he not to be identified further, said he hired a Soviet citizen who simply walked up to his construction site and asked for work.
"He was a guy with a university education, and the goal he set himself was to add some money to the family budget and buy a car," Kazimierz said. "You could set your watch by him. He came at 7 A.M. ready for work, in his work clothes. As far as alcohol, well, he didn't drink."
 
Taking Jobs Poles Don't Want
 Poland's eastern regions have unemployment rates at or above the national average of 10 percent but local officials insist that the immigrants are taking jobs Poles have already turned down.
"Generally, Poles do not want to undertake these jobs," said Mieczyslaw Janowski, the mayor of Rzeszow. "Russians and Ukrainians do this kind of work for relatively low wages."
The Polish Government's response thus far has been characterized more by slight nervousness than by panic, and there is no systematic attempt to prevent these people from working here. If Rzeszow faces a larger influx of Russian or Ukrainian workers, Mr. Janowski said, the authorities would have no choice but to vigorously enforce immigration laws.
Still, Mr. Janowski acknowledged, his city has little ability to make the rules stick because of enforcement difficulties. "The United States hasn't resolved this problem either," he said."
The Polish tradition of working illegally in the West is particularly strong in this region. Many of the Poles working illegally in Chicago or New York come from here, and Mr. Janowski was well aware of the comparisons.
"If we felt upset because the borders of Western Europe were closed to us, so similarly the Ukrainians and Russians will feel resentment if we try to put up some very strict, inpenetrable barriers at the border," he said. "Besides, this would not resolve any of problems."
So, the two Nikolais and Pyotr toil away, saying they plan to take their earnings back home. One said he would buy a car on the open market, instead of waiting up to 20 years to order one from the state factory. Another said he planned to build a house.
And all three acknowledged that they were considerably less industrious back home. "We work as we are paid," said the younger Nikolai.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Signs an Accord For Limited Role in I.M.F.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Opening the way for the Soviet Union to receive large-scale Western technical aid to help its transition to a market economy, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed an agreement today that grants this country special association status with the International Monetary Fund.
Under the agreement, the I.M.F. will advise the Soviet Union on combating its high inflation, setting up a Western-style banking system, gathering accurate economic statistics, and establishing a social safety net for those hurt most by economic reform. 
 The accord, which goes into effect immediately, contains no explicit Soviet commitment beyond supplying economic statistics to the I.M.F. But implicit in the negotiations has been an understanding that the Soviet Government will continue to push for market principles as it negotiates to transform itself into a loose economic confederation of sovereign republics.
"This agreement paves the way for the U.S.S.R. and the republics to take their rightful places in the world economic system," the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, said after meeting with Mr. Gorbachev.
"None of us here believes that this agreement will create miracles overnight," Mr. Camdessus said. "On the contrary, this agreement represents the beginning of a difficult and challenging course of economic reform that is unique in our history."
Under Communist rule, the Soviet Union repeatedly denounced the Washington-based I.M.F. as an instrument of capitalist exploitation.
Today's agreement states that the fund will also provide technical assistance to the republics if they request it. I.M.F. officials said they were waiting for the central Government and the republics to clarify their political and economic relationship before the agency determines what aid to give to Moscow and what to the republics.
Mr. Camdessus said individual republics might be able to become full I.M.F. members if they wish to and if they achieve diplomatic recognition as independent countries.
In London in July, the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial democracies agreed to offer the Soviet Union special association status with the I.M.F., but a week later the Kremlin applied for full membership. Such membership would enable Moscow -- with a crumbling economy and almost $70 billion in foreign debt -- to borrow money from the I.M.F., which was set up in 1945 to promote exchange-rate stability and economic growth among nations.
 
Surer Organization Wanted
 At a news conference today, Mr. Camdessus said full Soviet membership was inappropriate, at least for now, while Moscow and the republics had not yet hammered out their relationship. He added that it was now impossible to accurately assess the Soviet Union's economic output and determine how much money it would be required to contribute to join the I.M.F.
Mr. Camdessus said special association was preferable for now because it enabled the fund to begin providing immediate technical assistance.
The Bush Administration has opposed granting the Soviet Union full membership because it worries that any loans Moscow took out might be squandered until substantial economic changes were in place. But Germany, whose banks are major creditors of the Soviet Union, has supported membership. German commercial banks are eager for the I.M.F. to lend money to the Soviet Union to help keep it solvent.
The I.M.F. director said teams from his group would begin working in Moscow on Monday to discuss the range of aid to be provided, analyze and discuss tax policy, and assess the nation's process of collecting statistics.
 
Vast Soviet Resources
 "This country has incomparable human resources, well-trained people," Mr. Camdessus said. "What is necessary is to give them the savoir-faire, the know-how accumulated in our institution over 45 years."
President Gorbachev and republic officials seemed eager to move forward with economic change, he said, adding that I.M.F. experience shows that when people and their government back reforms, "progress can be made rapidly."
Under today's agrement, the fund will open a permanent office in Moscow and conduct periodic assessments of the nation's economic policies and performance, as it does with full members. It will also invite Soviet banking officials to Washington to take I.M.F. Institute courses on subjects like regulating the money supply and foreign exchange operations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, right, after signing an agreeement that granted the Soviet Union special status with the International Monetary Fund. Also signing the agreement yesterday in Moscow was Michel Camdessus, executive director of the I.M.F. (Agence France-Presse)
