HEADLINE: Dying Town Considers Salvation in a Landfill

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WELCH, W.Va., Oct. 2

 BODY:
The corrugated Appalachian terrain of McDowell County is as pretty as America gets this time of year, with the leaves starting to turn along the banks of the shimmering Tug Fork River. But it is as sad as America gets, too, with the hills that are dressed in foliage ravaged by coal mining, and the river fouled by raw sewage because the county seat, Welch, has never had the money to build a sewer system.
Now some hope has dawned, but it is hope tinged with despair and a sense of ignominy. A developer is proposing to set up a vast landfill in a remote 6,000-acre hollow three miles from town to treat and store sewage sludge, household garbage and incinerator ash from other states, brought in by 150 to 200 railroad cars a day. It would be the nation's largest repository for non-toxic out-of-state refuse. 
 In return, the developer, Capel Resources Inc., would build Welch a sewer system that would clean up the river, which has the state's highest levels of fecal bacteria and which flows through Welch. The county would get tax revenue from the landfill and long-term jobs for to 300 workers, many of them former miners who have been displaced by automation.
However demeaning the notion of building an economy upon the refuse of other economies, most community leaders here say the only alternative is McDowell County's extinction as an economic entity.
"We're for it for the economic benefits," said Tony Johnson, a former state trooper who publishes the little Welch Daily News. "It's a damn shame a county has to look at doing something like that. In my heart I'm mad about it. But I don't see anything else. It's a cornerstone to build off of."
 
Legislature Considers Action
 But to others, including Gov. Gaston Caperton, the landfill would be an environmental disaster. "The people of West Virginia are crying out for protection from out-of-state garbage," the Governor, a Democrat, told a special session of the Legislature this week. He is proposing an overall limit on landfills that, by setting a maximum monthly tonnage for each landfill, would severely restrict the acceptance of other states' waste.
Environmentalists warn of poisons leaching into creeks and water tables and of mob-controlled waste haulers lacing their exports to West Virginia with prohibited toxic materials.
But Jack Fugett, president of Capel Resources, said the company was taking all precautions to prevent the contamination that others fear and that the hollow was situated beyond any roads or sight of the community.
Governor Caperton expects the issue to be resolved in the special session, within two weeks.
Under Federal deadlines to close overloaded and leaky landfills, many states have turned to incineration and recycling. But incineration is often expensive and can foul the air, and a lot of waste is not recyclable. Capel Resources, an affiliate of the Berwind Corporation of Philadelphia, a big owner of coal mines in McDowell County, calculates that rather than engage in the political brawls of opening new landfills, states would readily dispatch their wastes to West Virginia.
 
A Town Divided
 The question is how readily West Virginia would receive it. In McDowell County, there are strong feelings on both sides.
"I don't like sitting on somebody else's garbage," said an aged widow on the porch of her home in a fashionable neighborhood of Welch, population about 3,200. She refused to give her name because she said she was afraid of recrimination.
Paitsel Lockhart, a retired teacher and school administrator, lives in a poorer part of town on Route 16, closer to the site of the proposed landfill. "Kick the dump in the rump," reads the sign propped in front of her house.
Ms. Lockhart is an officer of Tears-WV, which stands for Team Effort Against Ruining Southern West Virginia. "I think the mountains are too beautiful for out-of-state garbage," she said. "Good for the economy? Maybe it's good for their economy," the economy of Berwind in Philadelphia.
But Welch's Mayor, Martha Moore has endorsed the landfill.
 
Mine Union's Views
 The United Mine Workers, still a powerful institution in the state, has seen its membership plunge in southern West Virginia. While the landfill would bring jobs, the union doubts that those hired would be anywhere near 300 and that they would earn little more than the minimum wage because the jobs would require little expertise.
The union wants the landfill limited to waste produced by West Virginians. But Mr. Fugett says that would be too little to justify the project.
Most people in McDowell County seem to think the local economy is in such a state that any new business, however humiliating, is worth trying, and supporters of the landfill are urging the Governor to exempt the county from his proposed dumping cap of 50,000 tons a month and let McDowell residents decide for themselves.
 
Living Off the Government
 McDowell County's population is 35,000, a third the level of the 1950's. Most months, it has the highest unemployment of the state's 55 counties, currently exceeding 20 percent, or more than twice the state average. Government checks -- for Social Security, unemployment compensation, coal miners' disability, welfare -- are the principal source of income.
A study this year by the state Task Force on Children, Youth and Families found that 37 percent of McDowell County's residents fall below the Federal poverty line, which was $13,360 for a family of four last year; that percentage is about twice the average for the state.
In the view of many people here, the sole options are moving away and thereby accelerating the county's decline or installing the landfill. Most sources of jobs do not come to McDowell County. Companies that would build factories are repelled by a terrain too hilly to accommodate them and by roads, all tortuous and only two lanes, that put the nearest sizeable city, Beckley, up to an hour and a half away.
"I'm concerned about environmental control," said Don Goodson, a grocer here. "If that can be achieved, then, yes, we should have the dump."

HEADLINE: House Battles to Make Parental Leave Veto Proof

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
House supporters of a bill that would grant many workers unpaid leaves for family emergencies say the Senate's overwhelming approval of the measure this week will strengthen their cause. But they still foresee an uphill struggle to pass a veto-proof version of their own.
The House proponents say they are sure they can improve on the 237-to-187 vote that passed a similar bill last year, a margin that fell far short of the two-thirds approval necessary to override a veto. To attract more votes, they say, they will adopt compromises reached in the Senate that decreased the number of part-time workers and senior-level employees covered by the leave benefit. 
 The bill would require employers of more than 50 workers to grant their employees up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave a year for the adoption or birth of a child or for a serious illness suffered by the employee or an immediate family member. Workers would be guaranteed their jobs back upon returning to work.
The legislation, which would cover 46 million people and is vigorously opposed by business groups, is to come before the full House in two or three weeks. The Senate passed the compromise measure on Wednesday, 65 to 32, with three Democratic supporters absent, but President Bush has said he planned to veto the measure, just as he vetoed last year's bill.
House Democrats have been savoring the uncomfortable position that their Republican colleagues were left in by the President's promise of a veto. They said that while Mr. Bush might be able to withstand political damage caused by opposing abortion rights, increased unemployment benefits and family leaves, Republican members would be forced to take the brunt of their constituents' ire if they continued to back the President.
"The President is losing some of his soldiers on this one," said Representative Pat Williams, a Montana Democrat who is chairman of the House Education and Labor Subcommittee on Labor-Management Relations. Still, he expressed doubt that the House could pass the Senate version by a veto-proof margin.
 
Seeking White House Approval
 Mr. Williams said he and other supporters of the legislation would try to work with the White House and Republican lawmakers "to determine whether or not we can pass a bill and get a Presidential signature."
Representative Marge Roukema of New Jersey, the most active House Republican supporter of the legislation, said the margin of the Senate victory would "send a powerful message to the rank and file here." But she added that while her rough estimate of the current House vote spread was more favorable than last year's tally, "it's not good enough."
"We still have to do an education job on why the business community has no legitimate complaint and why you can't keep saying no to American working families," she added.
Ms. Roukema suggested that Mr. Bush still might eventually drop his opposition to the family-leave bill without major modifications, but Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, put a damper on such hopes by insisting that businesses should not be forced by law to provide the benefits.
Mr. Fitzwater dismissed the bill as a partisan Democratic effort to make Mr. Bush look insensitive to the needs of families, although 15 Republican Senators voted to pass it. "This bill points up very dramatically the kind of political season that is upon us here," he said.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who is the principal sponsor of the legislation in the Senate, is seeking a compromise with the White House despite Mr. Fitzwater's comments, according to a Senate aide.

HEADLINE: Japan Focuses on Takeshita for Premier

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
A bruising contest for the political leadership of Japan got off the ground today with all eyes focused on former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, a wily and secretive leader of the governing party's biggest faction with the power to make or destroy any candidate's chances.
Mr. Takeshita and his ally, Shin Kanemaru, were the ones who at the last minute withdrew their support from Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Friday, forcing him to drop his efforts to win another term in office. Until this week, they were Mr. Kaifu's biggest benefactors. 
 The Kaifu withdrawal paved the way for a race that will culminate on Oct. 27, when 394 members of Parliament in the governing Liberal Democratic Party choose their next leader. The struggle was expected to provide an important glimpse into the way power relationships work behind the scenes in Japan.
Today, for instance, Mr. Takeshita and Mr. Kanemaru were beseeched by three would-be successors to Mr. Kaifu. The meetings were the subject of endless speculation, including whether Mr. Takeshita would eventually decide, or be asked by his colleagues, to try to return to the job.
 
Power Behind the Scenes
 Mr. Takeshita resigned as Prime Minister in April 1989 to take responsibility for a spreading bribery and corruption scandal that had caused his approval ratings to skid to single digits in the polls. But he has continued to wield power behind the scenes.
Announcing their candidacies were Kiichi Miyazawa, a former Deputy Prime Minister; Michio Watanabe, a former Finance Minister, and Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, a former Foreign Minister. All are considered shrewd and experienced professionals but linked to various scandals in the past.
Mr. Miyazawa, an urbane former government bureacrat, and Mr. Watanabe, a gruff-voiced political operative, were initial front-runners. Both pledged today to continue the cause of political reform, economic expansion and close ties to the United States.
In another development today, Mr. Kaifu held a news conference but declined to explain his decision this week to threaten a dissolution of Parliament, then to withdraw the threat, and then to make the threat again -- a sequence that was said to have led to his downfall.
 
Failure of Reform Plans
 "Many things have happened," he said with a grim face, his hands folded tightly before him. "Now I have put everything in my heart and I have nothing more to say."
The Prime Minister, who will remain in office until Oct. 30, said he had only one regret, the failure of his package of bills overhauling Japanese politics, including curbs on fundraising, government subsidies of campaigns, and a sweeping redistricting of parliamentary districts.
Those changes were all aimed at reducing the flow of money into the political system, but they were torpedoed by an alliance of party barons. Mr. Kaifu said he nonetheless hoped that the next Prime Minister would pursue the agenda of political reform.
 
Biggest and Richest Faction
 The contest for Prime Minister is certain to be less the result of issues than the product of alliances of the governing party's five factions, cemented as always by promises of jobs and patronage.
The Takeshita faction is not only the biggest in number, with 108 members, it is also the richest, tapping hundreds of millions of dollars in funds from the securities, automobile, construction, electronics and appliance industries, all of which have been helped by the Government.
Under normal circumstances, the Takeshita faction might have been expected to turn to two of its younger and more promising leaders. But one, Ichiro Ozawa, a former party secretary general, has taken himself out of the running, partly because he suffered a heart attack last summer.
The other, Ryutaro Hashimoto, is tainted because this week he resigned as Finance Minister in Mr. Kaifu's Government to take responsibility for the huge securities scandal, in which the ministry's surveillance of the industry was widely criticized as lax.

HEADLINE: Gambling's Spread: Gold Rush or Fool's Gold?

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DEADWOOD, S.D.

 BODY:
Hoping to breathe some life into this colorful but withering Old West town in its storied gulch, South Dakota voters approved casino gambling in Deadwood two years ago. The promoters said they expected betting of $4 million a year.
They were way off. In the first two years, gamblers have bet $400 million on Deadwood's slot machines and blackjack and poker tables. 
 "Nobody," said Bill Walsh, a former Roman Catholic priest who runs a hotel and casino here, "could have expected anything like this."
Deadwood may be the most successful recent venture in legal gambling, but it is not alone. Around the nation, and especially in the West, gambling fever has reached a gold-rush pitch. Gambling experts predict that one day in the not-too-distant future, casinos will be operating within an easy day's drive of everyone in the nation.
The experts warn that gambling is no economic savior; some call it nothing more than a tax disguised as a slot machine. But such warnings have been ignored in the face of the magical appeal of chance.
Already, gamblers in Iowa and Illinois can wager on riverboats in the Mississippi River, and Louisiana and Mississippi have approved similar plans. The slot machines started whirring in three Colorado mountain towns last Tuesday. Card games are legal in California, Montana and Oregon. Slots are permitted in the oceanside counties of Maryland. Vermont is considering legalizing video poker.
 
Indians Look to Gambling
 And Indian reservations are investing heavily in gambling. In Minnesota, reservations operate 11 casinos with profits last year of $500 million, though they hardly threaten Los Vegas, which gathered a take of $4.3 billion last year. There are casinos on reservations in Michigan and South Dakota, and tribes in at least 10 other states plan to open gaming halls.
Under Federal law, tribes can offer any games already legal in their state. And Indians are not subject to the same betting limits. One casino in Minnesota, for example, has gambling of up to $1,000 a hand.
Between 1982 and 1990, gross gambling revenues roseto $25.9 billion from $10 billion, not accounting for inflation. And the nation's aging populace augurs more growth. Older people tend to have more disposable income, and more time to dispose of it.
 
A National Pastime

"Like any industry, there is a saturation point for gambling," said Paul Dworin, publisher of Gaming & Wagering Business Magazine. "But we're not anywhere near reaching it yet."
Once viewed as a bit tawdry, even sinful, by a large segment of society, gambling has become a national pastime, now regarded as American as, say, the lottery, which is sanctioned in 36 states.
"The nation's inhibitions toward gambling have been completely broken down, and why not?" said Bill Thompson, a professor at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas who has written books about the gambling industry. He said people tend to take this attitude: "If your own state approves of gambling, in the form of the lottery, then it must be all right."
 
Benefits Called Overstated
 In rural regions, gambling has been embraced as an economic tool to generate jobs. And as a means of raising money for government treasuries, politicians have found that gambling is often considerably more palatable among voters than, say, increases in the sales tax.
But Mr. Thompson, who predicted that someday no one will live very far from a casino, contends that the economic benefits of gambling have been vastly overstated. To be sure, some towns and regions reap economic returns. But it does not help the economy as a whole, he said. Gambled money simply plays a sort of musical chairs, jumping from the pocket of an unlucky player to a luckier one.
Atlantic City's struggling neighborhoods, for example, are testimony that gambling's high tide does not lift all boats. "There is this notion that gambling creates all this new, free money," he said. "That's nonsense, of course. Money doesn't grow on trees. A job that's created by gambling in one place usually just means the loss of a job somewhere else. For the most part, gambling only amounts to a tax. And it's a very inefficient, unfair tax."
 
Powerful Supporters
 In referendums on gambling, those campaigning in favor usually outspend opponents by 20 times or more. There was scant popular opposition when gambling in the Colorado towns of Central City, Blackhawk and Cripple Creek was approved in a statewide vote.
Indeed, three council members in Cripple Creek who voiced opposition to gambling were recalled by the voters. One of them, June Sylvain, said some people snubbed her after she predicted that gambling would ruin Cripple Creek. She has since moved away.
Bets in Colorado and South Dakota are limited to $5, with gambling halls offering slots, blackjack and poker. Riverboat gamblers in Iowa cannot lose more than $200 on a trip, at least in theory, because players are limited to buying that amount in chips.
 Stakes are kept smaller, in part, to avoid attracting organized crime. And promoters say the limits on bets insure that no player can get hurt too badly. But at $5 a throw, or even less, a paycheck can disappear in an afternoon, as many unlucky gamblers know.
 
A Compulsive Quest
 And for every gambler who strikes it rich, many more fall victim to a compulsive quest for the big jackpot. For these gamblers, who account for an estimated 5 percent of all bettors, the expansion of gambling could put temptation nearly everywhere.
"I'm sure Colorado already has some Gamblers Anonymous meetings," said Arnie Wexler, the executive director of the Council of Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey. "But just wait and see how many more there are going to be now."
Since casinos opened in Deadwood, the biggest winner has clearly been the town treasury, which has collected more than $11 million. Much of the windfall is being used to refurbish Victorian buildings and preserve a town made famous by Calamity Jane and Wild Bill Hickok, who was shot to death as he played cards here. Deadwood is perhaps the nation's only town of 3,000 with a full-time archeologist.
Some longtime residents here, however, wonder if gambling has not succeded too well. Traffic is heavy, the sidewalks are crowded and the quaint, small-town feeling has disappeared, along with most of the retail stores.
 
No Drug Store, But Lots of Slots
 The Deadwood Trading Post has become the Golddiggers casino. The New York clothing store has become the Midnight Sun casino, which is owned by Dan Costner and his brother, Kevin, the actor. The town's car lots are gone, and so is the drug store. The famous Goldberg's grocery store remains, but it is jammed with slot machines.
"It's exciting now, like a constant carnival," said Bob Harlan, a Deadwood resident who works for the Homestake Mine Co. in nearby Lead. "But it's completely changed the face of the town. A lot of the older people feel badly about it. We have a lot of good restaurants now. But you have to go out of town to buy clothes, or just about anything else. And we don't recognize the faces in town anymore."
But proponents of gambling note that Deadwood had been sliding toward oblivion for years, and they say gambling offered the only realistic hope for survival.
"You had a town that was experiencing decades of slow decline," said Jody Severson, a tourism consultant here. "Maintenance on the infrastructure had been deferred. The tourism was drying up. And this is a state that's near the bottom of per capita income. It's desperate for jobs."
 
Gambling Jobs at Home
 Indeed, the gaming growth has allowed many young people to find jobs at home, curtailing the traditional exodus to bigger cities.
 For owners of businesses in new gambling centers, the increase in prices for commercial real estate has made many rich. Most of these retailers have happily sold buildings for 10 times or more what they had been worth.
But Rosie Hennings, who runs an antique shop amid the gaming halls in Central City, has been one of the few holdouts. She had declined offers of up to $1.3 million for her establishment.
In fact, she has posted a hand-lettered sign in her window:
"We approve of gambling," it reads. "However, this shop will stay as is -- we are not going out of business. Merchandise is not 50 percent off."

HEADLINE: Multiculturalism Divides More Than It Unites

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Mosaic and the Melting Pot" (Op-Ed, Sept. 23), Hugh B. Price trots out the favorite evidence of the multiculturalists for alleged Eurocentric bias in today's classrooms: textbook enormities from the 1950's. (New York State's Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, is particularly fond of the long-defunct "Columbus discovered America" idea when arguing for textbook reform.) Never have outdated textbooks had so long and useful a life -- their pedagogical value long since exhausted, they are recycled as ideological weaponry for a war that has already been won. 
 One would never know from the alarmist rhetoric that textbooks have been revised in accordance with the multiculturalist agenda for well over a decade. A study by Nathan Glazer and Reed Ueda in 1983 of six major high school American history books found that European immigrant groups received a quarter or less of the coverage accorded blacks and Hispanics, and that the achievements of minority culture and individuals were disproportionately stressed (with the exception of Asians, whose successes do not sit well with the multiculturalists).
The textbooks presented American history as a morality play whose primary theme is the oppression of virtuous ethnic minorities by a monolithic evil white majority.
It is most unlikely that in the eight years since the Glazer-Ueda study, textbooks have become less sensitive to minority demands. But since the multiculturalists' power is directly proportional to the stridency of their demands, they cannot acknowledge their own success.
Mr. Price seeks to turn the tables on the proponents of a common American civic tradition by arguing that the multiculturalists are its only true defenders. He appropriates the rhetoric of his opponents, invoking the political and economic freedom that "defines our society and bonds us together." This is a clever rhetorical ploy, but wholly specious.
The proponents of multiculturalism have little interest in the elements in American ideology that bond us together. They typically express nothing but disdain for the American experiment, seeing it as a thinly veiled project of imperialism and racism. But their emphasis on race and ethnicity as the most important elements of a person's identity augurs a new apartheid, in which one's racial and ethnic qualifications are scrutinized carefully to determine fitness for a job or inclusion in the curriculum. Contrary to Mr. Price's claims, multiculturalism leads not in the direction of "inclusiveness," but toward fragmentation and exclusivity.
The concept of an inclusive, tolerant society is the legacy of the European Enlightenment, and of it alone. We can realize that ideal not by trashing the Western tradition, but by understanding it through the study of its history.
 
HEATHER MACDONALD
New York, Sept. 24, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: DESIGN;
DOWN TO EARTH

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
EVERYONE SEEMS TO BE FEELING THE RESTRAINED MOOD of the 1990's -- including the folks at the International Home Furnishings Market in High Point, N.C. At this mecca of mainstream furniture design, the kind of opulent features that flourished in the 80's -- gilt and velvet, shiny lacquers and trompe l'oeil surfaces -- are no longer politically correct. When the nation's largest wholesale furniture fair opens on Oct. 17, for nine days, the look will be low-key, the feeling earthy.
"There's no question that manufacturers are taking into account a very different set of values than they were a decade ago," says Robert Sonneman, a lighting designer who will introduce his first collection of furniture and fabrics this fall. "People want solid pieces with intrinsic value, furniture you can put your feet up on." 
 Which also means modern isn't really modern anymore. "There's a softer, more romantic approach to contemporary styling," reports John Mascheroni, a designer for Swaim and for Jeffco. "The hard edge is disappearing." So are slick pieces fashioned from plastics, steel and polished chrome. The new look, to borrow a computer cliche, is user-friendly. Brushed metals, weathered patinas and natural finishes prevail, along with organic motifs. The most environmentally conscious manufacturers are even using recycled wood and nontoxic paint.
As always at High Point, the offerings are geared to the thousands of store buyers and merchandise managers who will shop the showrooms. Naturally, then, the economy will influence style. With sales down in both the furniture and housing markets, manufacturers fear taking chances on bold new looks and flights of creative fancy. Designs are more cautious, and so are purchases.
"Homeowners are no longer buying seating by the mile," Mascheroni says. "They are more interested in acquiring one piece at a time -- a love seat one year, a reading chair the next." In an effort to spur sales, showrooms will be carrying fewer complete sets of furniture and more individual pieces -- ones with a softer, friendlier, more casual look. For the time being, it seems, furniture makers and merchants are keeping their feet firmly on the ground.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A chair designed by John Mascheroni for Swaim has the new softer, romantic look. Its rounded shape is reminiscent of 1930's designs. This fall's modern pieces, like the oak and brushed-metal table by Robert Sonneman for Stanley Furniture, make use of more natural materials. Earthy elements, like the twig base of this glass table by John Mascheroni for Jeffco, characterize the new look. An ebony and burl bed, from the Pace Collection's new Boca series created by Leon Rosen, has simple, conservative lines.

HEADLINE: Manhattan for Under $100 a Night

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO; TERRY TRUCCO, who lives in New York, writes a column of design for The Home Section of The Times.

 BODY:
MANHATTAN has hundreds of hotels, but they tend to be expensive. Even hotels that say they are economically priced can easily cost $150 a night for a double room. And that's before little extras like room service, tips and taxes, which are currently 16 1/4 percent for rooms under $100 and 21 1/4 percent for rooms over $100, plus $2 a room.
But Manhattan is a big place, and it's still possible to get a room for two for less than $100 without checking into a youth hostel. You shouldn't set your sights too high, of course. Expect an elevator, a private bathroom and sturdy locks. Expect fresh sheets, clean towels and daily maid service. Room service is usually too much to ask for, though there should be vending machines and perhaps coin-operated washing machines. And if your room has recently been renovated, there may even be a bit of style. 
 I recently spent a night at four hotels aimed squarely at budget-minded visitors. Three were chosen because they are either new or recently renovated. And the fourth was selected because it's a legend. In each instance, I reserved a room several days in advance and never mentioned that I was writing an article.
 
Broadway American Hotel
 The new Broadway American Hotel, which opened in January, is a welcome arrival on the Upper West Side. The place is a study in budget chic. Headboards have oval cutouts displaying postcards of King Kong on the Empire State Building. (Visitors can keep the cards.) The lobby's sleek new ceiling also has big oval cutouts, with the original crenelated ceiling, nicely restored, peeking through.
These touches are particularly striking as the hotel, originally designed as a 1919 apartment building, was a dingy single room occupancy hotel for years. One caveat: 173 of its residents still live here, in rooms sprinkled among the hotel's 200 guest rooms. All doors are identical, though I assumed a room on my floor with two extra locks belonged to a permanent guest. Ear-splitting music emanated from that door as I carried up my bag; luckily, though, things got quieter when I was ready to go to sleep.
My sixth-floor $89 room was large, with simple gray speckle-paint walls, two big closets, new blue-gray carpeting and two narrow twin beds with pale blue spreads. The television stood on a cupboard that hid a mini-refrigerator. It was the perfect atmosphere for "I Love Lucy" reruns. There was an oval-topped bedside table but no desk, and two armless wooden chairs, not very comfortable. The simple, white-and-gray bathroom was spacious. Only 50 rooms have private baths. The rest share what range from baths with tiny stall showers to larger bathrooms with tubs, with one bathroom to three guest rooms, or 13 bathrooms to a floor.
The tired-looking kitchens on each floor -- no pots and pans are supplied -- seem the domain of the permanent residents (one refrigerator door was padlocked). Drinks and snacks cost $1 in vending machines throughout the building.
Broadway American Hotel, 2178 Broadway (at 77th Street), New York, N.Y. 10024; (800) 446-4556 or (212) 362-1100. Rates: double rooms with private bath, $89; $65 with shared bath. All guests must present a credit card on checking in.
 
Herald Square Hotel
 Not far from the Empire State Building (and Macy's) is the Herald Square Hotel, a neat, clean few-frills hotel, with a glamorous past. Built in 1893, this pink brick and limestone building was the original home of Life Magazine -- there's a century-old carving of Winged Life, a fetching little cupid, gazing down at the entryway. It's worth taking a minute to admire the handsome exterior, because once you're inside, historic details are few. The well-lighted lobby is functional and nothing more, with no place to sit (vending machines and lockers fill a room off to the side). But early Life photographs and covers, including illustrations by Charles Dana Gibson, a onetime resident, adorn the walls. And the atmosphere, with lots of talkative Europeans and South Americans, can be lively and fun.
Like its sister hotel, the modestly priced Washington Square Hotel, the 114-room Herald Square, renovated two years ago, is cleverly designed, with no wasted space. My compact sixth-floor room, $65 for one person, was long and extremely narrow, with pale pink walls and gray moldings. A cheery strip of classically patterned wallpaper lined the ceiling. The double bed, with a pastel patterned spread, stood beside a built-in bedside table. A cabinet holding the television was at the bed's foot. By it was a drawerless desk with a cane-back chair. The long, narrow bathroom had a fairly new tub with a sliding glass shower door. There were no free-standing lamps; instead, rather annoying fluorescent lights were built into the walls.
My tiny window looked onto another building, though much of the view was obliterated by the air-conditioner. But larger rooms, all identically furnished, are almost spacious. All have vintage Life covers on the walls.
Herald Square Hotel, 19 West 31st Street (between Broadway and Fifth Avenue), New York, N.Y. 10001; (800) 767-1888 or (212) 279-4017. Rates: double rooms with private baths, $55 (showers only), $70, $75 and $85.
 
Journey's End
 Journey's End Hotels is the slightly ominous name for a chain of Canadian-owned economy hotels found mainly in small towns throughout Canada and the United States. But in July 1990 the company opened a 189-room hotel, just off Fifth Avenue, in a new high-rise near the main branch of the New York Public Library. There are no notably New Yorkish details about the Journey's End hotel, which typifies the high end of the budget league. The big white lobby looks like an airline check-in area. The narrow mezzanine lounge, where complimentary coffee and muffins are served on weekends, is clean and comfortable and has lots of tropical-print sofas and chairs. But the place is clean and well-run, if a little preachy. A printed notice on my bathroom mirror requested that guests refrain from stealing the towels.
My 14th-floor room in the back, at a summer weekend rate of $115, looked straight onto several brick buildings. It was spacious but dark; I had to keep the lights on during the day. The queen-size bed had a green floral spread, a blond wood headboard and one bedside table. A lamp hung over a table with two upholstered chairs. The large, cream-colored bathroom had a molded plastic tub.
When I checked in I was handed a stack of take-out menus from nearby delis and Chinese restaurants. So I ordered a corned beef sandwich from Reubens.
Journey's End, 3 East 40th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016; (800) 668-4200 or (212) 447-1500. Rates: double rooms, $135.88, $88.88 on weekends.
 
Hotel Chelsea
 In its own way, the Hotel Chelsea is as famous as the Plaza. The roster of illustrious past residents at this downtown red-brick temple of bohemia includes the writers Thomas Wolfe, Dylan Thomas, Arthur Miller and Brendan Behan. Punk rocker Sid Vicious died here. And Edie Sedgwick, girl of the year in 1965, almost burned the place down. The Chelsea, which seems little changed since Edie's day, still has an intriguing atmosphere, if you like things a little scruffy and don't mind seriously outdated plumbing. It's about as far as you can get from spit and polish, but that's probably the point.
The highlight of my brief stay was a morning spent in the lobby, sipping coffee from a nearby deli. The much-painted walls are lined with an impressive collection of contemporary art, all painted or sculptured by onetime residents, including the painter Larry Rivers. And the parade of passing residents was enjoyable and varied, from old ladies in shorts and straw hats to slim young artists and actors. Everyone stopped to pet a big white dog gnawing a bone by a battered coffee table.
The elevator wasn't working very well, so I walked the four flights to my $85 room. It was roomy but very old, with painted white stucco walls and stained mouse-gray carpeting. An orange wool chair stood in a corner, next to a beat-up desk. The double bed, which didn't have a blanket, had pilly sheets and a pink floral spread that matched the curtains. An old black-and-white television stood on a pedestal. And a weary kitchenette, with gas stove, fridge and sink, was by the door. But the room got plenty of light and was oddly cheerful.
The old yellow tile bathroom, however, was ghastly. The vintage shower dripped continuously. And the toilet was a slow flush. The porter will pick up take-out orders from nearby restaurants.
Hotel Chelsea, 222 West 23d Street (at Seventh Avenue), New York, N.Y. 10011; (212) 243-3700. Rates: double rooms with private bath cost $85 to $145.

HEADLINE: DANCE;
The Graham Company Faces Life Without Martha

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
For the first time in its 65-year history, the Martha Graham Dance Company will open a New York season without Graham, though the founder's imprint remains strong. She helped plan the two-week run that begins on Tuesday at the City Center, and even left an unfinished dance, "The Eye of the Goddess," from which an excerpt will be presented.
Graham also laid plans further into the future. She chose two longtime associates, Ron Protas and Linda Hodes, to run the company, and suggested directions they might take over the next few years. Work by other choreographers was to be introduced into the all-Graham repertory, and new choreographers were to be developed in the choreographers' workshop offered at the school she founded in 1927. 
 "Martha laid down an artistic and financial structure which is pretty clean for at least three to four years," said Mr. Protas, who is 46 years old. "We'll be feeling our way through the framework she left us."
To date, Ms. Hodes added, there have been few surprises. "This is not so different from what we were doing before. It's only that there's no Martha to go to and say, 'What will I do?' "
With no more new works to come from Graham, the company is reaching out to choreographers like Jerome Robbins and Paul Taylor. Graham also drew up a list of about 10 pieces long absent from the repertory for possible revival, and there was even talk of reviving Ted Shawn's tigerish "Xochitl," one of Graham's first major vehicles in 1920, for Suzanne Farrell.
Spurred by economic difficulties of the sort facing most arts groups today, the company is also considering requests from troupes around the world to stage Graham's work. So far, only Mikhail Baryshnikov's White Oak Project has acquired a piece, "El Penitente," which Mr. Baryshnikov will dance at the opening-night gala on Tuesday and in four other performances at City Center. Mr. Protas described this signature Graham work as "Martha's gift to Misha."
Graham had considerable personal magnetism off the stage as well as on. Mr. Protas came under her spell in 1969, when he approached her as a young amateur photographer of theater stars. A Brooklynite who had abandoned his law studies at Columbia University, Mr. Protas had no experience in running a dance company. But a few years later, Graham -- sick and feeling abandoned by some of her dancers, Mr. Protas said -- asked his help in reshaping the company. By the end of her life she had come to depend on him and he on her.
"She was a fantastic, wild, wonderful being," he said, "real, honest, strange, private, and a wise and caring woman. I don't think anyone really knew her." The two often talked about Mr. Protas's growing reputation in dance circles as a monster upstart. "That's the role of anyone close to me," he quoted Graham as having said. "They don't like me either, but it's easier to attack you."
Difficult as it is to run a company, Mr. Protas said that life has become easier in some ways now. "I don't have the responsibility I had. Every day, I had one goal -- to make life as comfortable and interesting and challenging as I could for Martha. Yes, I'm upset we have a layoff coming up. But if Martha were alive, I'd be hysterical. There'd be so much less time for her to work."
For Ms. Hodes, a former Graham dancer and an administrator at the Martha Graham Center, Graham was first a teacher and later a friend. "I came to Martha young," said Ms. Hodes, who declined to give her present age. "I was 7 and had my heart set on being an ice skater." Dancing, she had heard, was good for skaters. And since her family lived around the corner from the Graham studio in Manhattan, Ms. Hodes attended Saturday children's classes taught by Graham.
"They were extraordinary," she recalled. "There were maybe five of us. She didn't treat us as if we were little kids. She taught us technique with dramatic images. She'd tell us these great stories from dances she was working on, like Medea putting the poison crown on the princess's head. The bloodier the better."
Ms. Hodes danced with the company from 1953 to 1964, when Graham asked her to stage some of her dances for the new Batsheva Dance Company of Israel, which Ms. Hodes went on to direct. Fifteen years later, Graham called her back to New York to run her school and serve as a coach and rehearsal director.
The third key figure in the new management, appointed associate artistic director by Mr. Protas and Ms. Hodes in one of their first official actions, is Yuriko Kikuchi, a noted interpreter of Graham's dance roles, who is known professionally as Yuriko. The American-born dancer made her way to the Graham studio in 1943, armed with a permit to leave the Japanese relocation camp where she had been interned, a one-way ticket to New York and $100. She began as a seamstress, and joined the company in 1944, eventually taking on many of Graham's dance roles. She later became director of the Martha Graham School Ensemble.
"Martha was a loner, really," said Yuriko, who is 71. "She never confided anything to her dancers. We were like her different colors, for her to use as a painter." But watching Graham choreograph and perform over the years, Yuriko said, she was able to steal a lot of things.
"I talk about all those dramatic and dynamic moments to the dancers," she explained. "My job is to work with them on the artistic development of the characters, how to bring the true character of the piece out of them. I would like every one of them to get close to the performance pitch of Martha Graham. Not everyone can get there, but they can understand the dynamics and how they approach the role."
Change, all three of the managers agree, is natural and inevitable. And the world of dance has changed enormously since Yuriko's and Ms. Hodes's days as Graham dancers. "The company needs to change because the business is changing," Ms. Hodes said, "not only because of Martha's death."
Tours have been booked well into 1993, with negotiations in progress for an Australian tour in 1994. The company has reduced its deficit to $1.1 million and has acquired some eager and influential new board members. Russ Alley, the director of development, said that four planned European tours and a national tour next year are being supported by a new financial partner, Chase Manhattan Bank, which is also sponsoring the City Center season.
But the company's greatest treasure is the Graham dances. "The body of Martha's work is still so wonderful, so brilliant, so contemporary, there's no way we'll ever run out of interest in it," Ms. Hodes said. "If we do in time, then there's no reason to have a Graham company. Of course, there's an insatiable need for the new. As a businesswoman, I understand that. But I'm hoping the changes will be gradual.
"It may not be everybody's view that we are doing the right thing. But Martha chose people she trusted. She gave us her blessing to continue in a way she saw fit. This hasn't happened 10 times before. We don't have examples. We'll have to see how it goes. It's a very tenuous time, but it's also exciting. There has always been this question about what happens to a ballet or modern dance company when its creator dies. And this question has not been answered yet."

HEADLINE: Bulgaria: The Old World at Ancient Prices

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER; KEITH BRADSHER is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
IMAGINE walking into a government tourism office in Manhattan, paying a little less than $5 and receiving not only the directions but also the key to a stranger's private apartment in one of the better parts of town.
Or imagine walking into one of the finest restaurants in Manhattan, consuming a five-course meal with wine, with live piano music in the background -- all for less than $10. 
 Such were my experiences last April in Sofia, the capital of Bulgaria, a country that offers the rich history of Europe for a fraction of the cost of a visit to Britain or France.
Indeed, traveling alone with a small knapsack in Bulgaria for 10 days cost me just $830 -- including round-trip air fare from New York. From the 80-cent fare for a two-hour intercity bus or train trip to the 50-cent hearty meals in village cafes, travel in Bulgaria is almost ridiculously cheap, a throwback to the postwar days when the United States dollar was still mighty.
Bulgaria is so little known in the United States that about as many Americans visited it in all of 1991 as went to Britain on a single average day last year. Most of the 8,000 or so American visitors to Bulgaria last year were diplomats, businessmen and consultants who stayed in Sofia, so that Bulgarians in smaller towns have met few if any Americans and are eager to chat.
And while Bulgaria's historic sites are not as famous as Notre Dame or the Tower of London, they give up nothing in beauty: the immense Rila monastery, with its painted colonnades of wood set in a wooded Balkan valley beneath snowy peaks; the walled city of Veliko Tirnovo, an elaborately restored 14th-century fortress to match Carcassonne in southern France in a more spectacular setting, and Koprivshtitsa (pronounced Ko-PREEV-cheet-sa), a small community of 19th-century homes, narrow cobblestone streets and rushing brooks spanned by stone foot bridges.
Seeing these splendors without spending a lot of money requires a certain willingness to endure some discomfort. The four Bulgarian budget hotels that I stayed in cost nearly as much as a Motel 6 in the United States but offered smaller rooms, intermittent hot water, very short beds, burned-out light bulbs and poor service. The Bulgarians have been so insulated from Western tourism that even the taxi drivers in Sofia do not understand the phrase "how much" and cannot give a price in English. Memorizing a few Bulgarian phrases is easy, however, and learning to count in Bulgarian does not take long. French companies built the Bulgarian rail system in the 1930's and French terms and signs are still used there extensively. Traveling to Sofia and back for less than $1,000 also requires a willingness to book a ticket long in advance or do business with a discount travel agent. However, Americans no longer need a visa.
Authorized with four days' notice to take a vacation, I paid just $580 to a ticket consolidator, a friend of my brother, for a ticket aboard Yugoslav Airlines.
The carrier canceled the return leg of my ticket while I was in Bulgaria -- a kindly reservations agent in Sofia fixed the problem -- and then stranded me for an extra day in Belgrade on the return because of a strike. But Yugoslav Airlines, which never knew that I was a reporter, very generously transfered me to a Pan American World Airways flight the following day. Given the civil disorder in Yugoslavia now and the difficulty with my ticket, I would not try to fly the same way again. A new, privately owned Bulgarian carrier, Jes Air, has just begun offering weekly flights from New York to Sofia with round-trip tickets as low as $678 this autumn and $568 this winter.
The true budget traveler begins saving money in Bulgaria as soon as he steps off the plane at Sofia airport. A coven of raffish-looking taxi drivers and black market money-changers haunts the exit. It is not a good idea to use them. The lucky traveler who does so will pay the official rate of about $2.20 in Bulgarian leva for the ride into town and will be able to change money at close to the official rate.
The unlucky traveler may pay considerably more for the taxi ride and lose his shirt to the money changer. One black marketeer eager to practice his English explained the tricks used to defraud tourists. These include lying about the exchange rate or handing over either a fistful of out-of-date Yugoslav currency or a few Bulgarian notes wrapped around a wad of newspaper.
The most aggressive ploy is to point suddenly at an imaginary secret police agent, grab the startled tourist's dollars or marks and bolt into the crowd.
A good strategy at the airport is simply to change money at the state bank there, pick up a map at the tourist bureau and walk outside to catch the municipal bus into town. It only costs a nickel.
After a little sightseeing, head for the downtown tourist bureau, where you will be offered a selection of hotels or, if you prefer, assigned to inexpensive lodgings with a family. Except in the summer there is no need to reserve ahead.
Repeated devaluations of the Bulgarian leva and a profusion of exchange rates for different transactions have confused even the bureau officials. A room for the night in a local apartment cost $10 in dollars during my visit. But it cost only $4.90 if I changed dollars and then paid the same official at the tourist bureau in Bulgarian leva.
My first encounter with Bulgarian hospitality came a few minutes after I had left the tourist bureau. When I mistakenly knocked on the wrong door in the apartment building, the tenant did not just walk me to the right apartment. When it became clear that no one was home, she insisted on using the key from the tourism office to open the carved wooden door and let me in.
I insisted that I could not enter someone else's apartment if no one was home, and would have to go for dinner first. So she not only walked me to a nearby restaurant but also asked whether I had enough money to pay the bill.
When I returned late that evening, the apartment proved to be very comfortable and well furnished, but occupied, like many such apartments, by an elderly woman who talked unceasingly in rapid-fire Bulgarian. I later encountered the same problem in the Black Sea port of Nesebar and, for this reason, I ended up dividing my nights equally during the trip between private homes and budget hotels.
Sofia is the best place in Bulgaria for fine dining and shopping. The Pyongyang Restaurant, forbiddingly named for the capital of North Korea, turned out to be a series of well-appointed dining rooms. I had a savory spiced mushroom dish, wild rice with beef stew, fresh bread and fruit salad over sherbet along with wine and delicious apricot brandy -- for just $8 including tip.
Good meals are hard to find in smaller towns, where the only meat served is usually poor-quality pork and fresh vegetables are almost never available. I never found it necessary to wait for a table in a Bulgarian restaurant, however, because the collapsing economy has left few people with the money to eat out.
Widespread desperation combined with the lifting of more than 40 years of Communist controls has brought a flood of privately owned religious paintings and icons onto the black market at very low prices. But shoppers should be aware that fakes are also sold and that the Bulgarian Government bars the export of any artwork deemed a national treasure.
After visiting the Alexander Nevski Memorial Cathedral, I headed for the Sofia tourist bureau. An employee there told me incorrectly that most of the intercity buses had been canceled because of a fuel shortage, and prevailed on me to pay $40 for a 50-mile taxi ride to the Rila Monastery. The taxi driver waited there for an hour, and then drove me 10 miles back to a $9 budget hotel in the village of Rila. The following day I took a municipal bus up to the monastery, took more pictures, then hitched a free ride aboard a school bus to Rila and caught an intercity bus back to Sofia for 80 cents.
Bulgarian buses and trains cost almost nothing by American standards and are clean and pleasant but very slow, having scarcely been modernized in the last half century. So to cross the breadth of the country to the Black Sea, I then paid $45 for a ticket aboard one of Bulgarian Airlines' two-propeller Antonov-4's, of ancient Soviet manufacture. We sailed low during the 90-minute flight over snow-capped mountains and hills lacerated with trails and dotted with small villages, the tile roofs of cottages forming collages of red squares below.
Burgas, the second largest Bulgarian city on the Black Sea after Varna and the region's transportation hub, has rows of huge apartment buildings facing the sea. In an Orwellian touch, each building bears a one- or two-digit number six feet high instead of a street address. The local taxi driver told me that they were mainly occupied by elderly people.
The village of Nesebar, a $7, 20-mile taxi ride from Burgas, stands on a small islet at the end of a causeway. The village contains the ruins of more than a dozen churches dating back as early as the ninth century. Because the island is fairly flat, it lacks some of the visual impact of Mont-St.-Michel in France. But the hospitality of the residents more than compensates. While the merchants in Mont-St.-Michel charge extortionate prices even for basics like food, a Nesebar resident closed her shop early and invited me to her home to feed me a light lunch and give me advice on what to see.
From Nesebar I rode a bus for nearly three hours north to Varna, visited the city's extensive Roman ruins and took a two-hour train ride inland to Shumen, the site of a well-preserved mosque built during the five centuries of Turkish occupation of Bulgaria, which ended in 1878. The following day I took another two-hour train ride farther inland to Veliko Tirnovo, Bulgaria's magnificent medieval capital. The last several days of my trip, in which I traveled by train back to Sofia with overnight stops in the market town of Kazanluk and the museum village of Koprivshtitsa, were very relaxing, but never matched the history and hospitality that I found in Veliko Tirnovo.
The site is spectacular, the Yantra River having cut itself a gorge several hundred feet deep in the soft limestone rock and wriggled through no fewer than six hairpin turns in the course of several miles. From the surrounding hills the river resembles the confluence of three, twisting through steep canyon walls. The old walled city on a hill is ringed on three sides by water, while on the fourth side, across a causeway spanning a deep gully, lies the present-day, more sprawling town.
The old town was razed to the ground by the Turkish army after its capture at the end of a five-year siege in the 14th century. Today the foundations of many houses and churches are visible, the king's palace is being rebuilt and a fairly modern church has been raised. The walls have been fully rebuilt on the two sides facing the new town.
The friendliness of the residents was remarkable. A taxi driver of Turkish ancestry took me without charge to the local mosque to show me how the government had allowed it to fall into disrepair, then invited me home to meet his father, wife and children over coffee.
A woman who had grown up in Veliko Tirnovo and just returned insisted on my joining her family for a guided tour down a historic cobblestone street. And a group of students in torn T-shirts and leather jackets gathered round at a cafe to talk about music and soccer in the West.
After touring both the old and modern cities by day, the best way to spend the evening is on the balcony of the Hotel Yantra in the new town, which looks across a gorge to the old town. There you can watch an extravagant sound-and-light show, its lasers and colored floodlights illuminating the fortress walls. Even travelers completely jaded with such shows will be impressed.
And the budget traveler can still save money. The hotel charges Western tourists as much as $100 for a lavish meal in the restaurant, after which the waiters herd everybody onto the balcony for the show. But for hardier travelers who eat at tables on the balcony, the price is a few dollars for the same meal and a seat for the show is ensured.
 
 
 
LIVING LIKE THE LEADERSHIP
 Every fan of spy novels and movies can picture the scene. High above an impoverished and bitter town stands the villa, surrounded by a high fence and at the end of a winding road through immaculate gardens. The conference room is hung with expensive tapestries, the bedrooms offer perfect views across a manicured lawn to the medieval fortress in the valley below.
And through the post-modern mansion's long hallways once stalked the absolute ruler of nine million people, the master of one of the world's most feared secret police forces.
Todor Zhivkov, the Communist ruler of Bulgaria for 35 years and the original builder and master of the Arbanasi villa overlooking Veliko Tirnovo, is now under house arrest in Sofia. His more democratic heirs to the financially crippled country have turned his estate and other country retreats of the Communist party into luxury hotels in a desperate bid to attract foreign currency.
For $70 to $90 a night, you can stay in the bedrooms where foreign dignitaries and Bulgarian party bosses once slept. Or, for just $120, you can stay in the presidential suite and imagine yourself a despotic Balkan leader. The suite includes a large anteroom with its own washroom; a spacious corner office with a massive desk and several overstuffed and uncomfortable chairs; an austerely elegant bedroom, and a bathroom the size of a Manhattan living room.
A small cafe downstairs serves delicious pastries and coffee to a clientele of foreign hotel guests and Bulgarian visitors curious to see a once-forbidden sanctuary of their leadership.
Yet the villa's exclusive ambiance is beginning to erode. Armed guards are nowhere to be seen, and the hotel staff is very friendly and willing to give tours to casual visitors. A peasant woman from the nearby village tended a small flock of rather dirty sheep on one side of the lawn. And, to my surprise, the taxi driver contemptuously urinated on a neatly trimmed hedge in the front lawn before we left.
For the budget traveler, the Etar hotel in Veliko Tirnovo charges just $10 for a single room with a less impressive view of the fortress. The beds are very short, the sheets are threadbare and the faucets drip, but there is hot water and a rollicking bar and restaurant downstairs. -- K. B.

HEADLINE: Life Without Intourist

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON; ALLEN R. MYERSON is an editor of the business section of The Times.

 BODY:
I knew that a trip to Moscow and Leningrad promised no luxury. I was ready for mass-produced meals drowned in gelatinous gravy, and gloomy hotels patrolled by personnel as friendly as wardens at the state pen. What I could not take was the price in the Intourist brochure: an off-season minimum of $1,375, or $2,179 with the flight from New York, for an advertised 10-day tour of Moscow and Leningrad, now St. Petersburg, that amounted to only eight nights in the Soviet Union.
And so, last fall, I decided to test the Soviet Union's new openness by trying to circumvent Intourist. 
 True, many guidebooks and articles warned that Intourist was the only way to go. I feared that any effort to beat the Soviet system might tempt the system to strike back.
Some foreign guidebooks mentioned that tours could be less expensive through Britain than the United States. With a few letters, telexes and phone calls, I discovered British agencies that offer inexpensive tours through Intourbureau, the Soviet Central Council of Tourism and Excursions. Set up to handle trade union exchange programs, it has tiptoed onto Intourist's turf in the past few years by taking paying customers -- an estimated 200,000 a year -- at hotels it operates in at least 25 Soviet cities.
The greatest difference between bourgeois and proletarian travel appeared to be price. I sacrificed little else by going with the Central Council instead of Intourist. For an eight-night Central Council trip from Sept. 29 to Oct. 7, Goodwill Holidays, which sells the organization's programs, asked 425 from London, or 260 for land costs alone. The exchange rate had turned sharply unfavorable, almost $2 to the pound, but the land cost was still just $1,038 for both my wife and me -- less than half the Intourist rate.
The other attraction was a chance to do more than see the sights. The Goodwill brochure was titled "Meet the Russians." It said the agency was founded by Quakers wanting to pursue "people's detente." Like many Goodwill tours, ours was organized around a special interest or group: we were offered the opportunity to join about 30 students from Notre Dame University who had been studying in London. Rather than meeting the group in London, we checked the travel advertisements and found $650 round-trip tickets on Yugoslav Airlines to Moscow, plus $30 on Aeroflot from Moscow to Leningrad, where the tour began. There was a change of planes in Belgrade, then a second red-eye flight dumping us in Moscow at 4 A.M. For us, the switch was an advantage, since we planned to visit Eastern Europe and return from Belgrade on the connecting flight.
Then the problems began. Two weeks before departure, Goodwill called to say the flight from London to Leningrad had been canceled, so the group would leave the day after. I had to change my return flight anyway since I planned to go from Eastern Europe back to Moscow; the change penalty was only $100.
Our Belgrade layover included a hotel nap and dinner at no extra cost. We returned to the airport an hour before the daily 11 P.M. flight. Bad news: The flight was bumped to 10:30 P.M., it was already filled, and we were bumped off. We came back the next night almost three hours early.
In Moscow, we were left with Leningrad tickets dated the day before, and the knowledge that Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, was invariably overbooked. We felt like stranded orphans. This was no time, we decided, to remain aloof from Intourist. In need of a foster parent, we asked an English-speaking Intourist guide for aid in getting on the Leningrad plane with her group.
The guide agreed to help. Later, we cautiously asked her about Intourbureau. "The Intourist hotels are much better," she sniffed, saying our hotel would be jammed with Russian tourists all crowding into our shared bathroom.
Our flight to Leningrad, scheduled for 7:35 A.M., left four hours late. We hitched a ride on the Intourist bus, then took a cab to our hotel, the Gavan, an Intourbureau property about five miles from downtown.
We were not impressed. The dreary lobby was roiling in cigarette smoke and sharp Slavic accents. The reception desk wanted us to wait. And wait. Fortunately, we spotted a group whose Reeboks and camping parkas were patently American. It turned out to be our group, which had arrived the day before, and our Intourbureau guide, Valera Bason, known as Val, persuaded the desk to let us into our room.
The room looked like it had been fixed up as well as possible after a brawl or two. It was clean, but narrow, with two tight single beds, end to end, along one wall, blistered wallpaper, a black-and-white television -- and our own bathroom, no matter what the Intourist guide said.
Val planned a trip to a history museum. Having missed the city tour that morning, we decided to do it ourselves. Val gave us a disapproving glare. "Thomas, I'm not responsible for these people," he loudly warned the professor who led the group.
We returned in time for a supper little different from any others we had in Leningrad or Moscow: meat, probably beef, slathered in gravy, with boiled potatoes and a vegetable puree. We usually had soups and salads for appetizers, with cabbage prominent in both. The filling offerings at breakfast included yogurt, cheese, creamy Russian farina and sausages similar to hot dogs. The meals were never unpalatable, and there was always some hearty, brown Russian bread, but everything was so bland that it seemed to fade into the plates.
That first night, we chose an evening of people's detente arranged by Goodwill at a trade union recreational center over another meeting set up by Intourbureau. Our hosts, English-speaking, more or less, were curious about the United States, and many were ready to pack up and go. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had no admirers.
Val was usually unwilling to reveal his plans more than a few minutes in advance. Leading us the next morning on a 45-minute bus trip to Pavlovsk, a sumptuous summer palace, he rushed us around with perfunctory remarks. Rolling through the nearby town of Pushkin on the way back, my wife and I asked to jump off the bus and explore, enduring more of his warnings and passing up the group's lunch.
The adventure was worth it. We looked over Catherine the Great's immense Italianate palace. At a farmer's market, we scooped up fruit far more luscious than anything in Soviet stores. We rode wooden benches on a train back to Leningrad, where we met the group at the Hermitage.
Val soon told us that, because of our late arrival in Leningrad, my wife and I had been crossed off the reservation list for the late train. The only alternative was an earlier train that would get us to Moscow before dawn.
Our train cabin had four bunks with plenty of mattresses and blankets. The car had a samovar for tea. We shared a bottle of wine with the two women in our cabin, who offered their bread, candy and cheese. The older one examined the mineral water we had bought in a hard currency shop. She coveted the plastic bottle, we realized, and we handed it over when we arrived.
Nobody met us at the Moscow station, contrary to Val's promise, so we spent five packs of Marlboros on a cab to our hotel. It was called the Central Tourist House, despite its location a 25-minute drive or 35-minute subway and bus ride from Red Square.
As Intourbureau's 35-story flagship, it was a great improvement over the Gavan. The lobby boasted travertine floors, and the sunny dining room had alcoves separated by curving wooden partitions. Our room was larger, the beds wider than in Leningrad, and the dark wainscotting handsomely matched the furniture.
The hotel's distant neighborhood did give us a glimpse of ordinary Moscow life. The subway stop was set among modern, blank-faced high-rises. The barren grocery stores, the weed-grown courtyards, the swarms of commuters packed into wheezing buses -- for most Muscovites, these were more familiar sights than the Pushkin Museum.
Many Russians were sharing the hotel, as the Goodwill brochure had promised. We had little contact. Our group was seated together at meals, and usually lounged around together, sometimes at a comfortable bar on the 34th floor. By the time we reached Moscow, my fears of being surrounded by raucous, vodka-swilling students had turned to appreciation of their observations. They were, after all, braving the Soviet Union on their break instead of lolling on some Mediterranean beach.
The several M.B.A. students were especially attentive at the Paris Commune shoe factory -- with 5,000 employees, the nation's largest. Some students were surprised by the factory's tidiness, while others wondered whether it was a showplace section of a showplace plant. We doubted that most Soviet plants had American and Japanese computers for advanced design.
The plant managers were confident of profiting in the emerging free market by keeping up to the minute with fashions. Then one said they planned new shoe designs three years in advance. The shoes in a display room looked stylish enough, if not trend-setting, but these were solely for export. They bore little resemblance to the dowdy footwear in Soviet stores.
To save the trip back to our hotel for lunch, our group ate three days of four at downtown hotels owned by the City of Moscow and often used by Intourist. The Ukrainia, a Stalinist monstrosity, featured a high-ceilinged dining room with murals, and waitresses in some ministry's conception of peasant garb. The meat was more fatty, the service more brusque than at our hotel. "Can we have one meal without cabbage or potatoes?" one woman on the tour asked.
As for our second dose of detente, what was billed as a round-table discussion at a downtown technical school featured two English-speaking economists seated at a couple of rectangular tables, with our group in rows of seats facing them. "After so many years of silence, we are glad to be able to express ourselves," one said. He was also a pollster, who had found that Mr. Gorbachev's approval rating had fallen in three years from 85 percent to 28 percent.
Otherwise, our chats with the Russians were impromptu, and sometimes easier to start than break off. Many knew some English. We were startled by their openness, irreverence and despair. We listened to the owners of a private art gallery complain of official harassment, and heard several versions of the Cab Driver Plan for economic reform.
Our guide, Vladimir, or Vlad, Khachaturian, was as much of an improvement as our hotel. He posted schedules and always had backups if plans fell through. Arriving at the Pushkin Museum one afternoon to find locked gates and a sign citing "technical reasons," he pointed the bus toward the Tretyakov Gallery, with Gorky Park across the street.
He also had an understated, contemporary wit. When we passed Gosplan in our bus, he announced, "Here is where all the five-year plans are worked out. But not very efficiently, as you can judge by our economy."
Would I travel with Intourbureau again? Assuming that price continues be an object, yes -- especially after sampling Intourist's own accommodations. A couple of weeks later, I returned to Moscow for business, staying at Intourist's prerevolutionary National Hotel shortly before its scheduled closing for renovation. A few of the most expensive rooms had Russian antiques and Kremlin views. Mine had towels and curtains with the texture of dishrags and a view of the neighboring Intourist Hotel. The dining rooms dazzled with immense chandeliers and moldings that seemed applied by French pastry chefs. But waiters, like the rest of staff, floated in a haze of indifference. The food was only somewhat better than on my tour; at one dinner, red caviar was a welcome luxury but the chicken Kiev seemed to have been cooked in Vaseline. Being down the hall from a room where Lenin himself once stayed was poor compensation for paying $160 a night. Except for the location and the whiff of Czarist grandeur, the National was no better than the Central Tourist House.
But when I return to Russia, I might join a tour in London instead of flying over myself. When things start going wrong -- and in Soviet travel, they always do -- it's more comforting to be in a group.
 
 
 
ALTERNATIVES TO INTOURIST
 In touring the Soviet Union, it pays to check the exchange rates and shop around: prices and schedules, in many cases, are as changeable as Soviet politics. Some agencies say the nation's turmoil has caused them to trim their schedules and avoid certain republics.
With the pound running at about $1.73, Britain usually offers the cheapest alternatives to Intourist. There, several agencies deal with the Central Council of Tourism and Excursions, or Intourbureau, and with some of the new entrepreneurs, partnerships and local travel services that have sprung up. Progressive Tours (12 Porchester Place, Marble Arch, London W2 2BS; telephone 262-1676) plans dozens of trips next year. An eight-day, seven-night tour of Moscow and St. Petersburg will be about $700 from London through March, about $50 more during warmer seasons. Without flights, the prices will be about $350 less. Total costs from the United States are likely to be less than half of what Intourist charges. Goodwill Holidays (Manor Chambers, School Lane, Welwyn, Hertfordshire AL6 9EB; 871-6421) also will have at least 20 tours next year.
Progressive and Goodwill are among the agencies also offering to arrange reasonably priced travel for individuals, until recently the exclusive and expensive province of Intourist. Cheapest of all are their accommodations in Russian homes -- few comforts, but they say that Russian hosts with hard currency can assemble meals much better than most hotels, and there is no better way to learn about Soviet life.
You can join British tours in the Soviet Union, but a London rendezvous is simpler, the cost difference minimal. The joint Pan Am-Aeroflot flight to Moscow from New York can add $1,100; searching for a discount flight to London or Moscow can save several hundred dollars.
A drawback of going with a British agency is applying for a visa on your own. If the Soviet embassy in Washington loses your materials or you apply with less than a month to spare, an expediting service, like Express Visa Service in Washington, (202) 337-2442, is worth the extra charges.
An Intourbureau trip through an American agency might be more convenient, and the extra cost could nearly vanish, depending on exchange rates. Try Ideal Tours, 56 West 45th Street, Suite 601, New York, N.Y. 10036, telephone (212) 764-8000, or Mir Corporation, 85 South Washington Street, Suite 210, Seattle, Wash. 98104, (206) 624-7289.
Although Intourist's prices during the warmer months remain stubbornly high, the agency has stepped in with its own special deals, including some trips under $1,000, for visitors willing to brave a Russian winter. Call General Tours, 245 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016; telephone (212) 685-1800 or (800) 221-2216.
Keep in mind that changes are in store at both Intourbureau and Intourist. Both are building new hotels: Intourbureau, a badly needed alternative to the Gavan in St. Petersburg; Intourist, several throughout the nation. And other ways to skirt Intourist are emerging all the time, as Soviet entrepreneurs, local and republic governments and foreign agencies jump into the business. -- A. R. M.
