HEADLINE: Rx for a System in Crisis

BYLINE: BY BARRY MEIER; Barry Meier is a consumer reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
For half an hour, Edward Dillon has been watching television in a small basement room at the V.A. Medical Center in White River Junction, Vt., where he is an outpatient. It's not a talk show or movie that holds his attention, but a video in which patients and physicians speak in stark terms about prostate surgery. Dillon, a 74-year-old retired building inspector, has an enlarged prostate, a condition affecting more than 300,000 American men over age 50 each year. It is not life threatening, but causes such unpleasant symptoms as abdominal pain and difficulty urinating. Dillon's doctor asked him to watch the video to get a broad range of opinions about the benefits and drawbacks of the operation.
Some patients in the video say they are glad they had the surgery because they no longer experience pain and frustration trying to urinate. But others plainly regret it. Prostate surgery can damage the sphincter muscle, causing retrograde ejaculation, or dry orgasms. One man said that he was stunned at the effect the operation had on his sex life. 
 Dillon has been disinclined to have the surgery because his symptoms are mild and his doctor has not urged him to have it. Hearing this patient's story reinforces his opinion. Dillon is not alone in choosing to avoid a surgeon's scalpel. Of some 700 prostate patients who have seen the video, more than 70 percent have opted to delay surgery, including men with extremely severe symptoms.
Score a small victory for sexuality and the medical outcomes movement, a new kind of research being undertaken by a growing group of doctors who believe they've found a way to help solve America's snowballing health care woes. Outcomes researchers are attempting nothing less daunting than to find out which medical procedures work and which don't. The goal is not only to identify the treatments that can relieve symptoms or cure a disease, but also to determine whether patients are satisfied with the long-term results. These researchers argue that such information has two important benefits: it can empower patients to make informed choices about their treatment options -- with the help of educational devices such as the video on prostate surgery -- and it can help the Government and private insurers keep a rein on health care costs, which have increased an average of about 10 percent annually since 1980 to more than $604 billion in 1989.
Spurred by society's growing concern over the high cost of health care, outcomes researchers have seized on one of the most disturbing contradictions in medicine. Doctors may see their craft as a science, but more often than not they have little evidence to determine which treatments work best. Some studies suggest that tens of billions of dollars are wasted each year on diagnostic tests, drugs and surgery that are unnecessary, ineffective or possibly even detrimental.
Consider some hospital data from Iowa City and Tallahassee, Fla. A baby in Tallahassee is more than twice as likely to be born by Caesarean section as a baby in Iowa City. But as an adult, that Tallahassee baby is more likely to undergo back or neck surgery than its Iowa City counterpart. The difference appears to be the result of nothing more scientific than local medical customs. "For many conditions in medicine there are many options, and doctors often don't know which works best or which the patient would prefer," says Dr. John Wennberg, a leading outcomes researcher and a professor of epidemiology at Dartmouth Medical Center who helped develop the prostate video.
In a bid to put more science and accountability into the craft of practicing medicine, outcomes researchers have begun studies involving hundreds of hospitals across the country on the long-term benefits as well as side effects of various medical procedures. This year, the Federal Government is spending more than $62 million on such studies. They rely in part on such traditional sources of data as published scientific reports, insurance claims and hospital records. But they also include an element not often found in scientific research -- interviews with patients about their satisfaction with their treatment and its effects on their well-being. "We are really asking the question, what value are we getting for our health care?" says Dr. John E. Ware, director of the International Resource Center for Health Care Assessment at the New England Medical Center in Boston.
The answers are expected to have a powerful effect on the future of health care. Over the next few years, the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, a unit of the Public Health Service, will use outcomes research to issue guidelines to doctors, nurses and other health care workers on how to treat dozens of conditions, such as diabetes, knee and hip problems, and gall bladder disease. In time, such guidelines will probably influence which procedures both Government and private health insurers choose to cover.
Many hospitals, insurers and large corporations such as General Motors and Procter & Gamble are also participating in outcomes research. Corporations, motivated by the desire to trim their health insurance costs, hope these studies will help them get the greatest medical value for their money. With evidence in hand that certain procedures are better than others, companies are aiming to play a role in selecting which diagnostic tools and treatments will be used when employees require medical care. "There is a growing appreciation that a lot of medical care is being provided to patients without anyone knowing what the impact is," says Dr. Howard Bailit, vice president for medical policy and programs at the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in Hartford.
Though still in its infancy, the outcomes movement is already sparking conflicts. Some advocates see it as a populist effort to empower patients, others as a means to control costs. But critics fear that the research will ultimately limit patients' choices, producing a "cookbook" style of medicine that addresses the needs of an average patient, without taking individuals into account. A number of experts simply dismiss outcomes research as a "soft" science, because it relies heavily on patients' feelings.
Much of the foundation for today's interest in outcomes research was laid by studies done by Dr. Wennberg of Dartmouth almost 20 years ago. In the mid-1970's, as director of a Federally funded program in Vermont that analyzed the use of services in the state's hospitals, he found that the rate of such common procedures as tonsillectomies, hysterectomies and prostatectomies varied widely from one town to the next. In Middlebury, for instance, about 7 percent of children under the age of 16 had had a tonsillectomy. But in Morrisville, only about 70 miles away, the rate for that age group was a whopping 63 percent.
Dr. Wennberg traced the mystery to five physicians in Morrisville who had been operating in a medical time warp. These physicians still believed that tonsillectomies were necessary to prevent upper-respiratory infections in children. But most doctors throughout the country had found that antibiotics could cure the majority of these infections, and they would remove a child's tonsils only if drugs didn't work. When told why most other physicians performed comparatively few tonsillectomies, the Morrisville doctors agreed to change their practice.
In another study, Dr. Wennberg found that the prostatectomy rate at one Maine hospital was four times higher than the rate at a hospital just a few miles away. Such variations can be driven by economic forces: residents of wealthy communities are more likely to have certain kinds of elective surgery, such as back and neck operations, than residents of poor areas, who may lack insurance or disposable income. But in this case, the two hospitals were in demographically similar places, and Dr. Wennberg surmised that the variations were the result of doctors' vastly differing beliefs about how to treat an ailment. Their beliefs, he reasoned, had been shaped by the schools and teaching hospitals where they had trained. Different schools subscribe to different medical theories, some lacking a strong scientific base.
In 1983, Dr. Wennberg and his colleagues undertook a landmark outcomes study of patients with benignly enlarged prostates. Many doctors believed that surgery could forestall potentially fatal complications like kidney and urinary tract disease. Other doctors thought surgery would provide only symptomatic relief and counseled patients to avoid the operation for as long as possible because of its unpleasant side effects.
After studying the Medicare and insurance records of several hundred prostate patients, the researchers reported in 1988 that men who underwent prostate surgery had a slightly decreased life expectancy. The study also found that some men were far more willing than others to tolerate the ailment's troubling symptoms, such as difficulty urinating. Some men with severe symptoms were less inclined to have surgery than patients whose condition was milder. The research indicated that one reason for avoiding the operation was that it can diminish sexual enjoyment -- an attitude that might surprise doctors who assume that elderly men are not interested in sex.
British researchers soon raised yet another question about the value of prostatectomies. While they eliminated symptoms in 80 percent of those treated, the symptoms subsided in 20 percent of the patients without any medical intervention.
In the late 1980's, the Rand Corporation, a research group in Santa Monica, Calif., assembled a team of physicians to review patients' hospital records to determine whether various procedures had been used appropriately. Among their findings: only 56 percent of coronary bypass operations appeared justified. Rand raised similar doubts about several other expensive procedures, including coronary angiography, an X-ray technique for diagnosing heart disease.
The dozens of Government-funded outcomes studies under way aim to identify other medical practices of questionable value. One study is looking at the diagnosis and treatment of lower-back pain, one of the leading causes of absenteeism in the United States. "This project is a monumental task because physicians are dealing with a wealth of uncertainties in treating back problems," says Dr. Richard A. Deyo, associate professor of medicine at the University of Washington School of Public Health and Community Medicine and director of the five-year effort, which involves 22 specialists and tens of thousands of patients.
The researchers will assess the appropriateness of diagnostic techniques such as computerized tomography, which costs about $400, and magnetic resonance imaging, which can run as high as $1,000. They will also look at the effectiveness of different kinds of surgery intended to strengthen the spine and prevent future back problems.
Dr. Deyo says his group has already found enough data to question whether spinal fusion, an operation to stabilize the vertebrae, prevents further back trouble. "Those patients who had fusions were just as likely to require added hospitalization as patients who didn't undergo the operation," he says.
Though it will be years before doctors and policy makers have enough outcomes data to change the way medicine is practiced, there is considerable debate over how influential the information can -- and should -- be. The American Medical Association supports the concept of Government guidelines based on outcomes studies, but argues that they should be used only to educate doctors, not to determine reimbursement for health care. "We think that every case should be reviewed to determine what is most appropriate for the individual patient," says Dr. John T. Kelly, director of the association's office of quality assurance.
Insurers are eager to use outcomes studies to shape their coverage. "Depending on the quality of the data," says Dr. Howard Bailit of Aetna, "these studies could have a profound impact on how both public and private groups pay for services." But even outcomes pioneers such as Dr. Wennberg question whether the research will save cost-conscious insurers any money. For one thing, it is possible that some rarely used but extremely expensive procedures will prove most effective. And, unless researchers can work quickly enough to keep pace with medical advances, their work could soon become outdated.
Until more of the studies are completed, health care experts can only speculate on whether they will meet the lofty expectations that many people have for them. In the meantime, one thing is clear, says Dr. Wennberg: "There is going to be constant warfare over how to use this research."

HEADLINE: When the Market Sags Under a Big Developer

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
TO all of the ex's in Jerome Kretchmer's busy life -- ex-assemblyman, ex-city commissioner, ex-political hot-shot -- he can now add one more: ex-developer, at least for the time being.
After building more than 1,400 apartments in New York City and Westchester County, Mr. Kretchmer has hit the same housing slump that has stymied a lot of other builders and made them contemplate the meaning of life with no new projects to pursue. 
 The end came for Mr. Ketchmer when the last of the 59 condos in his artfully designed project on West 90th Street, Columbus Commons, was recently sold at a loss. Most of the others had been auctioned for far less than the three and four hundred thousand dollar prices so hopefully expressed in the offering plan. He lost a lot of money, he said, and so did his lenders, but he has retained his cheer.
"It's over, it's built, it's good for the community, a lot of good people are living there, it's behind us," he said. "I got everything I wanted except money."
Mr. Kretchmer grew up in New York, graduated from New York University's former Bronx campus and took a law degree from Columbia. He and his wife, Dorothy, reared two daughters and a son who went through the city public school system. For a while Mrs. Kretchmer operated her own string of women's apparel stores, The Holding Company, while Mr. Kretchmer climbed the political ladder.
He served as a Democratic state assemblyman from the old Chelsea/Hell's Kitchen Third District from 1963 to 1970, as Mayor John V.Lindsay's head of the Environmental Protection Administration from 1970 to 1973, and as minority counsel to the State Senate from 1975 to 1977. In between he ran local campaigns for John F. Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy and Mayor Lindsay, and worked to protect Democratic interests in the 1980 reapportionment.
But after that, he moved into his long stretch as a housing developer.
"In my opinion, politics is something you either have to be all the way in or out," he said.
Mr. Kretchmer still has his two successful restaurants, the Gotham Bar and Grill on 12th Street west of Fifth Avenue, and the Mesa Grill on Fifth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets. He has occasionally taken a consulting job with other developers and with lenders, principally to help work out problems arising from the soft residential market. He recently addressed a group of savings bank executives to argue the wisdom of staying with the developers of troubled projects, rather than assuming that taking a project back and assigning it to someone else will necessarily produce a better result.
And he still has his years of thoughtful concern about the city to keep him busy.
Mr. Kretchmer said he got his first troubling whiff of a slump in the city's economy two years ago, when he won a franchise to build a restaurant in the restored Bryant Park, but could not find any backers. A key component of any recovery in housing development, he believes, is a renewal of the expired 421 and J-51 tax breaks for new and rehabilitated housing projects.
"What I really want to do again is build housing for the same people who come to my restaurants, people who want to live in New York and raise their children in New York and who earn what is by New York standards a reasonable living," he said. "That is what has become so hard to do."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Interest on Advance Rent
 
Question: After taking early retirement I sold a home and moved to Manhattan. I rented an apartment in a co-op building before I had a new job. Because I was not employed when I signed the lease, the only way I could get the apartment was to pay the entire year's rent of $21,000, in advance. Does the management owe me interest earned on the lump-sum payment? . . . Shirley Granahan, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. Theodore L. Marks, a lawyer specializing in real estate, said Sec. 7103 of the New York State General Obligations law requires that money given as security or advance rent, if it is in excess of one month, be kept for the benefit of the tenant. It also requires that in rental properties of six or more units, security or advance rent must be put in interest-bearing accounts. The tenant has the right to the interest, less 1 percent for administrative costs.
 
Replacing Appliances
 
Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a building converted to a co-op. I had an old, leaking refrigerator, an oven with a split door and an unrepairable dishwasher. The landlord was indifferent to my requests for replacement. I arranged with the superintendent to install replacements at my expense. Do I have a right to recover my expenses in exchange for a rental increase? . . .Patricia Goodman, Manhatttan
 
Answer: No. Your landlord is under no obligation to reimburse you. The laws that cover rent-regulated tenants give them the right to working kitchen appliances. But landlords can repair appliances or replace them with used ones. If landlords supply new appliances, however, they may add 1/40th of the cost to the rent and the rent increase becomes permanent.
The leverage that tenants have when faced with owners who will not replace broken appliances is to file complaints with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which can order rent reductions in cases where owners do not provide full services.
You may be able to get your landlord to pay for the appliances if you can show that raising your rent would give him a financial advantage. The division's rent administration office is at Gertz Plaza, 93-31 Union Hall St., Jamaica, N.Y. 11433
 
Liability for Lease
 
Question: Four years ago my husband put his mother into a studio apartment closer to us. She was able to live alone and pay all her own expenses, but the owner would not rent to her because of her age, 84 years. My husband signed the lease. Recently she became ill and had to be moved to a nursing home. She will not return to the apartment. We feel his mother may have been the victim of age discrimination in not being able to sign the lease herself. Will my husband be responsible for the lease? . . Judith Lavanga, Randolph, N.J.
 
Answer As a general rule of law, the person who signs a lease is legally bound by its terms. But according to Richard Kahn, a Hackensack, N.J., lawyer specializing in real estate, under New Jersey law, if rent is not paid the landlord has the duty to mitigate damages by making a good-faith attempt to find a new tenant who would pay comparable rent. If a new tenant's rent is lower than what the current lease calls for, or if it takes several months to find a new tenant, the owner may make a claim for the losses.
Mr. Kahn said the age-discrimination claim would be problematic. New Jersey statutes do not specifically address age discrimination with regard to public accommodations or real property.
"While clearly the mother-in-law is a member of a protected class," Mr. Kahn said, "it would be very difficult for her to prove that she was denied the privilege or benefit since she was, in fact, not refused the opportunity to reside in the apartment."
Other factors may have included her financial circumstances at the time. Moreover, because she lived in the apartment for four years, a claim would be too late. The New Jersey Division of Civil Rights requires that discrimination claims be brought within 300 days of a claimant's notice of a discriminatory act.

HEADLINE: New Lines and New Life For Furniture Maker

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
ETHAN ALLEN Inc. -- the 60-year-old Connecticut company that is one of the nation's best-known furniture producers -- is being propelled into new product diversity and marketing clout by an unusual chief executive who arrived in the United States in 1965 as a political refugee. The executive, Farooq Kathwari, a native of Kashmir, is showing American business leaders how to take a tired company and give it a completely new spin.
In 1989 Mr. Kathwari, now 46 years old, led a group of company managers, dealers and other investors in a $385 million leveraged buyout of Ethan Allen from Interco Inc., a St. Louis conglomerate. Since then, by applying new disciplines, motivating efforts and marketing skills, he has imbued the company, based in Danbury, with new life. 
 "Sixty percent of our individual items were created in the last two years," said the soft-spoken executive with evident pride. "We started that process six years ago, when our research showed us that consumers no longer were buying early-American furniture as their predominant style. Our sales were not growing, and we decided to diversify into other furniture styles and accessory products."
 
Attention to Quality
 In addition to its traditional line, the company's diversified offerings now include modern American and country French furniture and a new kitchen collection. The effort to expand the Ethan Allen line required massive internal changes and new attitudes among dealers.
Two plants were closed, and others were retooled for the new styles. Factories were added to produce bedspreads, pillows, mirrors and clocks. Quality control, which Mr. Kathwari said was long a "culture" at Ethan Allen, was further improved, he said, and the old 300-truck delivery fleet was replaced by larger more fuel-efficient vehicles. Company executives who believed that big changes were vital stayed, including Clint Walker, the former president, who has remained as the head of quality control for wood furniture.
The biggest transformation was among the several hundred Ethan Allen dealers, who had been prone to add products not made by the company. Mr. Kathwari put his foot down on that practice, and while there was "some noise" from the dealers, he said, none left the fold.
The company also set up a school at its headquarters for all the sales personnel, who are now called designers, in the 300-some dealerships. As many as 1,000 troop in annually for four and a half days of seminars and briefings at Ethan Allen College. They also compete for trophies in a design and sales contest.
"In this way, the people closer to the consumer are motivated by what we are doing and can go back and further motivate the consumer," Mr. Kathwari said. The groups gather in the Danbury headquarters and in the adjacent flagship store and stay at the nearby Ethan Allen Inn, which is also owned by the company.
Although Ethan Allen's chief may have rattled his dealers with his all-or-nothing dictum, he nevertheless endeared himself to them by removing their need to stock backup inventory and to deliver goods to their customers. Ethan Allen sells only through its dealers, who need only have samples on the floor. The company takes the furniture directly to the customers, delivering wood furniture in 3 weeks and upholstered goods in 8 to 10 weeks.
 
Running for His Life
 Mr. Kathwari's connection to Ethan Allen began in 1973, when he and Nathan Ancell, then the company's chairman, agreed to start a joint venture, KEA International, to develop non-furniture products, like floor coverings, lighting and decorative accessories.
But only eight years earlier Mr. Kathwari was running for his life. As a 20-year-old political science graduate of Kashmir University, he was arrested when his political activities offended the Kashmiri Government. He escaped from his captors, finding his way to the United States. He lived in Brooklyn, N.Y., and one of his first jobs was with a printing company.
"I printed envelopes," he recalled. "Six months later I was running the place."
Soon after, Mr. Kathwari was surprised, when his grandfather in Kashmir sent him a collection of candlesticks and other household accessories worth $15,000. Scrambling for space to put the items, Mr. Kathwari offered them to any dealers on consignment. He had to do his own auditing of inventory, he recalled, because not all dealers liked to tell him what was sold.
By that time, he had a job at Bear Stearns, the stock brokerage, and he was working toward a master's degree in business at New York University as well as starting his own upholstery fabric importing company. In 1968 he moved to New Court Securities Corporation, now known as Rothschild Incorporated, where he became a vice president involved in administration and in the company's bond portfolio.
When he left New Court in 1973, Mr. Kathwari made his deal with Mr. Ancell, a founder of Ethan Allen. Their venture, KEA International, was merged into Ethan Allen in 1980, and Mr. Kathwari moved up in quick steps: vice president that year, senior vice president in 1981, executive vice president in 1983, president in 1985 and chairman and chief executive in 1988.
Mr. Kathwari's rapid advancement was "probably due to my national background," he said. "In Kashmir there's a saying that nature is your teacher. With only a four million population, rugged natural environment and political turmoil, there is a tight family structure in the country, and you have to be responsible for your family. I think that upbringing has given me my motivation and my endurance."
And Ethan Allen will probably never be the same again. Sales are expected to reach about $650 million this year, Mr. Kathwari said, and profits are up, too, despite the recession.
An appropriate homily is posted prominently in Ethan Allen's headquarters. It reads, "What man altereth not for the better, time altereth for the worse."

HEADLINE: Barns, Symbols of the Past, Are Preserved for the Future

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S barns have been put on the endangered-species list. As fewer people in the state operate farms, the barns that have long dotted the landscape are being torn down. Some just fall down.
The barns are "symbols of what we used to be," said Mary Neustadter, director of real estate services for the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation, which recently called the state's barns "threatened sites." 
 Some barns have been rescued for continued farm use or for new lives as homes, businesses or museums. The Connecticut Trust urges people to get involved in saving barns, and a preservationist in Bethel has suggested a zoning change to help preserve the structures.
 
Keeping Their Jobs and Looks
 Yesterday's barns were not built for today's farming equipment and methods, said John Bartok, a professor of natural resources at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. "Old barns don't fit in with new technology," he said.
But some old barns receive treatment that lets them hold onto their jobs -- and their looks.
David Rathbun keeps sheep, horses and hay in the barn that has stood on his family's farm in Stonington since before the Civil War. Recently Mr. Rathbun replaced the barn's wing that was lost in a 1938 hurricane and made numerous repairs, searching out old windows and timbers to maintain the period appearance.
"When you build a barn, you don't want to spend a tremendous amount," he said. "I like using second-hand."
David Stiles's barn in Southbury, built in 1672 by his ancestor Francis Stiles, still houses the family's farm tools and equipment. A few years ago Mr. Stiles hired Richard Babcock -- a craftsman known as "Mr. Barn" -- to replace the rotting timbers and weakened roof.
"He went out to our woodlot and hand hewed replacement timbers," said Mr. Stiles. Now, he said, "the barn looks exactly as it originally looked."
A national program to preserve historic farm buildings -- called Barn Again! -- encourages farming uses for old barns. The program, which provides advice and gives awards for successful projects, is run by the National Trust for Historic Preservation and Successful Farming magazine.
For some people, home is where the barn is. The Norwich home of Anne and Richard Sharpe had features like cow stanchions and a manure shoot when the couple acquired it in 1956. Mr. Sharpe, who had then just begun his career as an architect, got practical experience as he turned the century-old barn into a contemporary house. "It was his first hands-on project," recalled Mrs. Sharpe.
Mr. Babcock, who heads Babcock Barns in Williamstown, Mass., and Edward Cady, who operates East Coast Barns in Roxbury, have turned many barns into homes. They frequently dismantle a barn, board by board, and re-erect it as a house in another spot. They aim to keep the barn's appearance and respect its past, they said.
"I try to not just move a barn but to preserve its history and send that along with it," said Mr. Babcock, who researches and records the history of each barn he works with.
Some preservationists object to putting old barns or materials from them into new uses and locations, saying that such practices destroy or distort the past. Others favor what they call a more realistic approach.
"Would people rather see the barns bulldozed?" Mr. Cady asked. "I save them and put them back up."
Professor Bartok noted that some unwanted barns have usable timbers of chestnut, now rare. "You're not going to preserve or rebuild all barns," he said. "You're better off using the lumber. It's recycling."
 
A Community's Symbol
 Mr. Babcock said that he began working with barns because, "I saw something that was dying that was really important." He said he understood that some people wanted barns to stay barns and stay put. But, he said, "with that thinking, nothing would get done, and nothing would get saved."
Southbury residents cheered the recent moving of a landmark barn once slated for demolition. "The barn was quite a figurehead, a symbol of the rural atmosphere here," said Richard Perry, president of the Southbury Historical Society.
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints bought the land where the barn stood, planning to demolish it to build a chapel. Local residents were greatly distressed until the appearance of what Mr. Perry called "an imaginative solution." The church donated money for Robert Parker Jr. to move the barn, piece by piece, to nearby land owned by Carol and Edward Winship. Mr. Parker had planned to build his new woodworking shop on the Winships' land. Instead he will work in the rebuilt barn.
"The barn will still be highly visible and close by," said Mr. Perry.
A plan to allow more uses of barns -- and thus improve the economics of preservation -- comes from Timothy Beeble, president of the Bethel Historical Society. He observed that Bethel and other communities have old barns in residential areas, where zoning regulations let people run a business in their houses, but only "allow you to keep your car and lawn mower in the barn," he said.
Mr. Beeble has proposed to the Bethel Planning and Zoning Commission that any use allowed in a house also be allowed in its barn, after a public hearing. "All we're asking is, Let us do it in the barn," said Mr. Beeble.
Sometimes effort and money can turn old barns into museums. But a circa-1880 barn in Fairfield, recently spared from razing, will not be housing exhibits on onion farming (once a big local business) "until the financial situation improves," said Chris Nevins, curator for the Fairfield Historical Society.
 
New Museum in Old Structure
 Roxbury is moving a 200-year-old barn about 100 feet to a new foundation on town property, where it will become the Roxbury Historical Society's museum. Having raised $20,000 for the foundation, the society now seeks $80,000 for repairs and exhibits. "It's quite an undertaking," said Robert Hodges, president of the society.
Some barns simply succumb. "Most of them deteriorate," said Professor Bartok. "I drive by them every time I go down the road."
In Monroe a town-owned, early 20th-century barn was recently demolished for parking space. The town offered the barn to anyone who would take it away, but all who expressed interest -- even someone who flew in from Chicago -- eventually turned it down.
Ms. Neustadter of the Connecticut Trust said she hoped people could be educated to see barns as important, threatened resources. Concerned local groups can accomplish a lot, she said.
Mr. Babcock said more people are recognizing the need to save barns. "This is good," he said. "It's like waking up the giant."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Rathbun near barn that has stood on his family's Stonington farm since before the Civil War. State's Trust for Historic Preservation has called barns "threatened sites." (Bruce Johnson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Connecticut Taxes;
Has Some of the Allure Faded? The Jury Is Still Out

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
"CONNECTICUT is still appealing for New York companies because of its lack of a personal income tax. It's surprising how powerful that is."
That was the word in March 1990 from the Commissioner of Economic Development for the state of Connecticut, Stephen B. Heintz.
Today, Connecticut has an income tax. Mr. Heintz is gone. And, understandably, the state's economic development officials are stressing a different perspective. 
 "In over 20 years in economic development, I've never seen a company come to Connecticut or leave Connecticut because taxes were the No. 1 thing," said Ralph F. Hedenberg, senior development agent in the economic development agency. "Certainly, in the overall decision-making, that's a factor. But it's never been a deciding factor. There are such things as geographic location, livability, education facilities, labor force availability -- those are the factors that companies are looking for."
It is always tricky to sort out why a company chooses to move. But even if taxes are not high on the official corporate agenda, they are surely on the minds of executives.
"The income tax does bring Connecticut and New York closer than they've ever been," said Steven Vitoff, spokesman for the New York State Office of Economic Development, "and to some extent, it levels the playing field. But tax considerations are not by any means the single deteminant in keeping companies within the state."
"People who were middle management moved to Connecticut because there was no income tax," said Richard Gretsch Jr., senior vice president of the Albert B. Ashforth commercial brokerage in Stamford. "Eventually, they became the decision makers. And when they had the chance to move the company, they moved it near their homes."
The absence of a tax "used to be touted as one of the big reasons why corporations moved their headquarters here," said Michael H. Siegel, executive managing director of the northeast region for the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage. "The leaders of those companies said, 'What I can keep in my pocket is a big number.' Today, that number has shrunk considerably."
"Anytime we impact one of our states," he said, "whether by raising tolls or doing something like an income tax, the perception is: 'Oh, no. Another additional tax we didn't have before. Why are we in this region?' We really do affect this decision to relocate out of New York not to a surrounding municipality, but taking a leap like W. R. Grace took -- after looking very hard at Connecticut -- and winding up in Boca Raton."
Many eyes are on the Morgan Stanley financial services concern, which may remain in mid-Manhattan or move to Stamford, where it has an option on an 11-acre site.
In February, the director of asset management for the Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund, Geoffrey Donoghue, said: "We see Stamford as an economic advantage for the firm and for its employees in real estate and personal income taxes."
And what does Morgan Stanley think now that Connecticut has a personal income tax?
Several telephone messages were left for Mr. Donoghue in the last two weeks that he never returned. Finally, on Monday, a spokeswoman for the firm said "there is a problem with him talking" to a reporter.
Of course, Morgan Stanley is not alone among New York companies that are thinking seriously about relocating to Connecticut.
"We're not hearing -- from companies or brokers or developers -- of any huge backlash or reaction to the income tax," said Joseph M. Ercolano, vice president for economic development at the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, based in Stamford. "The number of calls we have received from companies interested in coming to Connecticut has not slacked off. It's increased in the past two months."
AS an example, he cited a holding company with about 50 employees that is now in mid-Manhattan and is weighing a move to Stamford next year. Because the company has yet to sign a lease, Mr. Ercolano said, he does not want to identify it further.
During a recent presentation to company representatives who were visiting Stamford, he said, the subject of the new income tax came up, but did not seem to excite concern.
"There were a couple of technical questions about the tax," Mr. Ercolano said, "but there wasn't a lot of complaining and wringing of hands. There was no indication from the higher echelon of the company that they would not move out here because of the tax."
Even with the new income tax, Mr. Gretsch said, Connecticut "still has a slight edge" regionally. He pointed to a study by the KPMG Peat Marwick accountancy, which compared the tax bills for a married couple with two dependents filing joint returns.
Take a couple with $85,000 in income -- $75,000 from wages, $5,000 from dividends or interest, $5,000 from capital gains.
If they lived and worked in Connecticut, their total tax bill would be $12,400 -- with the Federal Government taking $9,000 and the state taking $3,400. That is slightly higher than New Jersey, where the taxes would come to $11,700 and slightly lower than Westchester County, where they would have to pay $12,700. It is considerably lower than New York City, where the same incomes would be liable to a $14,100 tax bite.
"Connecticut and Westchester and Jersey are looking very similar tax-wise," Mr. Ercolano said. "Between Connecticut and New York City, there is still a large difference."
AMONG the changes that may be welcomed by executives is the reduction in the rate at which capital gains, interest and dividends are taxed. "To the extent that we're attracting companies that have a lot of individuals with income from those sources," Mr. Ercolano said, "there's no question that the tax change is a plus.'
There is also a rollback of the surcharge on the corporate tax, which will effectively reduce the rate from 13.8 to 11.5 percent.
"I liked two things in the package," said Alain Lebleu, president of Auguste-Thouard U.S.A., an affiliate based in Greenwich of the giant French real-estate concern. "No. 1 was reducing the sales tax, which was ridiculous at 8 percent. And secondly, having to pay the highest state corporate tax in the United States was another way to discourage people from doing business in Connecticut. Reducing the corporate tax was a must."
There is a hitch to the sales-tax reduction. Although it is coming down to 6 percent, it is being spread to cover more goods and services. "When we go out and hire a vendor to perform a service through us, that would be taxed," said Mr. Siegel of Cushman & Wakefield, which manages about 35 propeties in Connecticut. Subject to the tax, he said, were cleaning, maintenance, elevator repair, window washing and security services.
On the other hand, said Mr. Ercolano: "There will be a pass-through to users, but right now, operating costs are 30 to 50 percent less than New York City. If you add another 6 percent, they're still going to be far below the rates charged in New York."
One major corporate relocation has already been announced: the Richardson-Vicks health care and cosmetics concern is to move its offices out of Shelton by the end of 1992, joining its parent, the Procter & Gamble Company, in Cincinnati.
But taxes bear no blame, the company insisted. "The decision to move is strictly a business decision," said a spokesman, Mike Riess. "We've been in Connecticut since 1974 and in this facility since 1982. There is no dissatisfaction with the state or the community. The whole need is to bring our people together in one facility."

HEADLINE: Service Charges By Banks Scrutinized

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AMID growing concern that the state's banks need to be more responsive to consumers' needs, state legislators are considering several proposals that would make banking services more straightforward and accessible to a wider range of residents.
After recently enacting legislation that requires banks to offer low-cost "no frills" checking accounts to customers, lawmakers are now examining measures that would require banks to disclose all fees and account requirements in writing, provide free cashing of government checks and create basic savings accounts carrying minimal fees and opening deposit requirements. 
 The intensified interest in banking practices is underscored by a recent survey showing that consumers are paying significantly more in bank service charges despite the deregulation of the banking industry in the last decade. Consumer advocates said the deregulation had held out the promise of better services at lower costs. The report shows that over the last five years many banks have raised rates for regular monthly fees, increased service charges for bounced checks and returned deposits, set higher minimum balances to earn interest on checking account deposits and more than doubled fees for automated teller machine withdrawals -- despite the fact that the machines cost banks less for each transaction than a teller does.
The survey also concludes that only a small percentage of banks offer government-check cashing for non-account holders and that fewer than half of the banks surveyed provide complete listings of fees and account requirements in writing.
Though the actual dollar amounts involved are relatively small, consumer advocates say the survey illustrates the reality that some banks are making up for losses on bad loans and real-estate investments by increasing charges to banking consumers.
 
'A Necessity in Our Society'
 "A checking account has become a necessity in our society," said Jennifer Kohn, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, the New Brunswick-based advocacy organization that conducted the study. "People are paying a lot for these accounts, and they deserve better services."
The survey, which was based on a sampling of 76 banks throughout the state, indicated sharp percentage increases in the monthly fees charged for regular checking accounts that fall below set minimum balances. Since 1986, Ms. Kohn said, such fees have risen by about 50 percent -- to an average of $5.84 a month from $3.96. While some banks provide such accounts free to customers, others charge as much as $8 a month.
Charges for bounced checks and returned deposits also rose sharply. The average charge to a customer for bouncing a check in 1986 was $16.37. The current average charge is $20.51, with some banks charging as much as $30. And charges for deposits of checks that subsequently bounce have risen by about 90 percent, to an average of $6.93 from $3.64 in 1986.
 
Not Even the 'Consumer's Fault'
 "That's ridiculous," Ms. Kohn said. "A bounced deposit check isn't even the consumer's fault."
The highest percentage increase in fees was for transactions at automated teller machines, Ms. Kohn said. In a 1989 survey conducted by the advocacy organization, the average fee for a withdrawal at a cash machine, including free withdrawals at machines at one's "home" bank branch, was 43 cents. In 1991, the average fee had risen 102 percent, to 87 cents.
"It actually costs a bank less when a customer uses an ATM," Ms. Kohn said, referring to a report prepared by the Trans Data Corporation, a company based in Salisbury, Md., that provides economic analyses for the banking industry. That report, Ms. Kohn said, indicates that it costs an average of $1.05 for a teller-assisted transaction as opposed to 56 cents for a withdrawal at a machine.
"You would think that the customer would get the benefit of this advanced technology," Ms. Kohn said.
She added that while only three banks in the survey charged customers for using their home branch machines, nearly all banks charged for use of machines at different banks or branches.
"Banking has become big business," Ms. Kohn said. "Even local banks have been more interested in investing across the country than in investing across the street. Now the banks are in a mess, and they've been making up for their losses on the backs of consumers."
Some experts agree that consumers may now be underwriting some of the excesses of the 1980's.
"During the expansion years, a lot of sloppy habits emerged," said James W. Hughes, professor of urban planning and policy development at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
But now, he said, increased competition, bad loans and expensive overstaffing have all contributed to making banks more concerned with trimming costs, cutting losses and beefing up the bottom line.
 
'A Substantial Retreat'
 "The banking industry is in a substantial retreat," Mr. Hughes said. "Foreclosures have virtually doubled in the past year. And consumers are paying a part of the price."
Bank officers, however, say the increase in fees accurately reflects increased expenses.
"Expenses go up, and those expenses include things that are beyond the control of the individual banks themselves," said Ben Schaffer, vice president of the Covenant Bank in Haddonfield.
In the 1970's, Mr. Schaffer said, banks were extremely competitive and offered free checking just to attract customers. "All businesses have 'loss leaders,' " he said, referring to the retailing practice of offering certain products below cost to bolster business on more profitable items.
But with checking accounts' having become nearly a necessity, Mr. Schaffer said, check processing has become increasingly more time-consuming, complicated and expensive.
"Everything costs more these days," he said. "And with costs climbing, convenience costs money."
 
Charge of $30 a Month
 The Covenant Bank is listed in the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group study as charging the highest fee -- $30 a month -- when an interest-bearing checking account dips below the bank's required minimum balance of $1,000.
"Everybody's pricing schedule is somewhat different," Mr. Schaffer said. "We had to set a fee, so we estimated what we thought would be our cost to handle the account. It was felt to be the fairest way to do it."
About six months ago, Mr. Schaffer said, in anticipation of recently adopted legislation requiring "no frills" checking accounts, the Covenant Bank established a basic checking account that requires no minimum balance and costs $2.50 a month and 25 cents a check. "That cost is not much more than it was in the 60's," Mr. Schaffer said.
Nearly all the banks surveyed have service charges on interest-bearing and non-interest-bearing accounts that fall below set minimum balances. Some banks, however, are able to provide virtually free checking regardless of the account balance and despite increasing costs and an ailing economy.
 
'Totally Free Checking Account'
 "If you walk in our bank and open an account and keep a positive balance, you will have a totally free checking account," said Marc Reitzes, president of the Equity National Bank in Waterford Township, in Camden County. "We feel that if we can keep our advertising budget trimmed and lend out the money that other banks spend on advertising, we can afford to offer free checking."
But the Equity National Bank imposes one of the highest charges for a bounced check. "We charge $30 on an overdrawn check," Mr. Reitzes said. "But we're not inhumane about it. A customer gets the first overdrawn check free. We give them a warning."
That, however, underscores another point made in the advocacy group's survey. Fewer than 40 percent of the banks surveyed provided complete listings of fees and account requirements in writing upon request. According to the survey, the Equity National Bank did not provide a written explanation of its bounced-check policy.
"We'd like to see a fees disclosure law that requires all banks to put their fees and balance requirements in writing," Ms. Kohn said. She added that 30 percent of the banks that eventually sent complete information did so only after a second request. "That's a pretty inexcusable way to conduct business," she said.
 
Bill Would Require Disclosure
 State Assemblyman John J. Roberts Jr., Democrat of Camden, agreed that banks should provide fees and account requirements to customers in writing and has sponsored legislation, now in committee, that would require such disclosure.
"We've found that many banks offer basic no-frills checking accounts," said Mr. Roberts, who is chairman of the Assembly's Financial Institutions Committee. He added, however, that such accounts "aren't an item that they are terribly interested in selling to their customers, so they don't provide information about it."
Mr. Roberts also sponsored legislation, recently signed into law by Gov. Jim Florio, requiring all banks that offer checking services to provide low-cost "consumer checking accounts," or "no frills" accounts.
 
'A Lot of Strings Attached'
 "In essence, 'free checking' is not free at all," Mr. Roberts said. "There are usually a lot of strings attached, like significant dollars on deposit or a lot of money needed to open an account."
The State Banking Commissioner, Geoffrey M. Connor, whose office is developing regulations for the consumer checking accounts, agreed that banks should be required to disclose account information but emphasized that the state should not be in the business of setting fees.
"Banks are for-profit businesses; they're not utilities," he said. "Their fees are not regulated and shouldn't be regulated. The answer really is disclosure, so customers can compare one institution with another and choose the institution they want to go to."
The Commissioner said the regulations for the consumer checking account would set the amount of the deposit required to open the account, the minimum balance below which a bank could charge a fee and a minimum number of free checks per month. He said that under the "best- case scenario," banks would be required to provide such accounts by by next April.
 
Low-Cost Savings Accounts
 Another banking bill now before the Legislature would require banks to establish low-cost savings accounts. Such accounts would provide for low initial deposits and low or no minimum balance requirements or monthly fees.
Yet another bill would require all banks doing business in the state to offer free cashing of government checks regardless of whether a person has an account in the bank. Residents without bank accounts, consumer advocates say, typically have to pay commercial check-cashing establishments to cash government checks.
Only four banks out of the 76 surveyed, the advocacy group study said, offer government check cashing for non-account holders.
Neal Fogarty, president of the Consumers League of New Jersey in Montclair, a consumer group that supports efforts to lower bank fees, set disclosure requirements and provide free government check cashing, said that the banking system was essentially a government-insured industry and should be more responsive to consumers' needs.
"We're simply asking for the old-time good-neighbor bank practices that were nearly universal before 1980," Mr. Fogarty said. "But there's been a sea change in the way some banks view their customers. Before 1980, customers were viewed as friends. Now they're viewed as profit centers."

LENGTH: 1184 words

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

FANTASY IN CROTON FALLS
"Prelude to a Kiss," Craig Lucas's fantasy about love transcending gender, will open the season at the Schoolhouse in Croton Falls with nine performances beginning Friday and ending Oct. 27. 
 The play opened at the Circle Repertory in Manhattan in March last year and moved to Broadway shortly afterward, where it played for more than a year, closing last May. It won an Obie and an Outer Critics Circle Award as best play and received several Tony and Drama Desk nominations.
The kiss in the title is given by a mysterious old man to a young bride just before her wedding, and the two exchange souls -- to the confusion of the husband.
The Schoolhouse production was staged by an Ossining company called Logodaedaly, which means playing with words. Albi Gorn was the director and Robert Dean the designer. Performances are scheduled for Fridays and Saturdays at 8 P.M. and Sundays at 4 P.M. Tickets are $10, $12.50 and $15. The Schoolhouse is on Route 22N and Owens Road. Take Exit 8 west off Route 684 and bear right toward Croton Falls. Call 277-8477 for reservations.
 
ABSTRACT OILS
 Drawing on the theme of "Prelude to a Kiss" is a new exhibition at the Schoolhouse Galleries in Croton Falls, on view through Nov. 17. Susan Bush's abstract oils evoke relationships between people, both lasting and passing ones, and the interlocking elements of nature.
Leonid Hushvahtov, a newly arrived artist from Tadzhikistan in the Soviet Union, is showing a series of paintings of musicians and artists and their need to establish communication with others through their work.
The gallery, in the Schoolhouse, is open free of charge Thursdays and Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. and Fridays and Saturdays from 1 to 8 P.M.
 
PUPPET SHOW AT SUNY
 Dinosaurs are the stars of "The Mammoth Follies," an entertainment for children from 5 to 11 years old devised by the Hudson Vagabond Puppets in the Japanese Bunraku tradition. A performance is scheduled for today at 3 P.M. in the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York at Purchase.
The puppeteers, dressed in black, are visible but unobtrusive behind the puppets, manipulating them across the stage. Managing a 12-foot-tall tyrannosaurus rex and a 22-foot-long brontosaurus is no mean feat. There are also baby trilobites, trees called vegettes and other singing and dancing creatures from prehistoric times.
Lois Bohovesky, founder and director of the company, is a former member of Henson Associates, for whom she built puppets for "Sesame Street" and other productions. Her puppets are on exhibition at the World Trade Center each year at Christmas time.
Tickets for today's show are $13. Call the box office at 251-6200.
 
A FERRARO VISIT
 Geraldine A. Ferraro, former Democratic candidate for Vice President, will be the keynote speaker at the College of New Rochelle during a Conference on Public Policy and Nursing. The event, scheduled on Wednesday from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. and mainly of interest to health-care professionals, costs $65, including lunch.
Workshops throughout the day will focus on the need and the techniques for approaching legislators on issues relating to nurses and nursing care. Ms. Ferraro will discuss government policy and concerns of health care in the United States. Call 654-5436 to register or obtain more information.
 
HISPANIC WOMEN
 "Hispanic Women: 500 Years of Leadership and Dedication" is the theme of the Yonkers Library's Hispanic Heritage Month celebration Saturday from 2:30 to 4 P.M. in the Getty Square Branch at 7 Main Street. About 41,000 of the city's 188,000 residents are Hispanic.
Argentina Palacios will tell folk tales in Spanish and English, and 25 members of the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club of Manhattan will perform Hispanic songs and dances.
Among the women honored for their contributions to Hispanic culture and welfare since 1492 are Capiliana, a 16th-century Peruvian botanist; Victoria Magana de Fortin, founder of El Salvador's first vocational school, and Matilde Hidalgo Narro de Porcell, the first woman to receive a medical degree in Ecuador.
Sobeida Cruz, community relations manager for the New York Power Authority, and Edward E. Velez, a lawyer and administrator for the State Department of Economic Development Small Business Division, are co-chairmen of the event. Admission and refreshments are free.
 
AT HUDSON RIVER MUSEUM
 A quartet of new exhibitions is opening this weekend at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. At the entrance to the Glenview Galleries a new permanent orientation exhibition sets the stage for anyone visiting the museum with a scale model of the 1877 mansion. Samples of the building's carvings, upholstery fabrics, dining utensils and Victorian book bindings may be handled, and recordings explain it all.
To place the building in context with its history, a 20-foot wall bears a time line of notable events that took place between 1865 and 1925 here and abroad.
A three-part children's exhibition in the Glenview Galleries addresses the role of children in Victorian times, when adults believed that they should be seen but not heard, through photographs and other ephemera. A second part consists of a re-created nursery with furniture, toys and clothing that increased in variety and quantity during the Industrial Revolution. The third section deals with the introduction of mandatory education in the state in 1874, through books, photographs and documents. In all, more than 100 objects are displayed.
"Experiencing Sculpture: The Figure in American Art, 1850-1990" traces changing styles and techniques with works by Robert Arneson, Louise Bourgeios, Nancy Graves, Red Grooms, Seymour Lipton, Elie Nadelman, George Segal, David Smith and others. It will remain on view through Jan. 19 in the main gallery.
Recent welded steel sculptures by Helene Brandt and a selection of her large charcoal drawings tracing the development of the sculpture can be seen in the Voter Gallery through Jan. 12.
The museum, at 511 Warburton Avenue, is open Wednesdays through Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Thursdays from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. and Sundays from noon to 5 P.M. Admission is $3, $1.50 for the elderly and children. Call 963-4550 for more information.
 
JOBS WORKSHOP
 Those in midlife, which can be any age over 50, who are looking for new or different jobs may want to check into an American Association of Retired Persons program at Mutual of New York in Purchase. A free information session will be held Tuesday from 10 A.M. to noon, for which reservations can be made by calling 381-2048.
Workshop sessions, which cost $35, will take place Oct. 14, 17, 21, 18 and 31 and Nov. 7 and 14 from 9 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. Each session is limited to 20 people. Topics include matching up jobs with individual needs and abilities; understanding employment planning, the changing business world and attitudes toward aging; defining skills, interests and work experience as flexibly as possible, and learning how to apply job search skills. MONY is at 4 Manhattanville Road.

HEADLINE: Stamps

BYLINE: By Barth Healey

 BODY:

A New Americas Stamp
This year's Americas issue from the United States Postal Service serves as a sharp reminder that, despite the hoopla building up over the 500th anniversary of the first voyage by Columbus to the Western Hemisphere, he did not "discover" America.
The stamp, a 50-cent commemorative airmail, is part of an annual joint issue by the 25 nations of the Postal Union of the Americas, Spain and Portugal. The stamp is to be released on Saturday in Anchorage. 
 The design shows an Asian scanning the horizon in a re-creation of the first passage across what was then a land bridge connecting what is now Siberia and Alaska, a migration that probably took place 15,000 to 30,000 years ago. The land bridge is now submerged under the Bering Strait.
The legend around the top and right of the stamp reads "The First Americans Crossed Over From Asia." Although this theory has been generally accepted by archeologists, it has been contested by others.
Collectors who want first-day cancellations should buy the new stamps when they become available throughout the United States on Oct. 15, place them on self-addressed envelopes and send them in a larger envelope to America Airmail Stamp, Postmaster, 344 West Third Avenue, Anchorage, Alaska 99510-9991. There is no charge; the deadline is Nov. 12.
 
Philatelic Literature
 In connection with the Columbus quincentenary next year, the Collectors Club and the Philatelic Foundation are sponsoring what they describe as the first international exhibition of philatelic literature in North America.
Prizes will be awarded for reference books and special studies, stamp and auction catalogues, periodicals, columns, and audio-visual and computer programs.
The entries will be on display Nov. 4-14, 1992, at the Collectors Club, 22 East 35th Street in Manhattan.
Applications for exhibits must be submitted by Jan. 31. They are available from Philitex 92, c/o Philatelic Foundation, 21 East 40th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016. Most of the exhibits themselves are due Aug. 14.
 
Just for Fun
 The marketers of stamps from smaller nations, some of which derive foreign exchange from the export of offbeat philatelic material, help to create some odd juxtapositions of national culture and stamp design.
To wit: The Caribbean island nation of St. Vincent has just issued two miniature sheets of nine stamps, each a different design.
One might expect tropical fauna or some such. But the first sheet honors John Lennon, the Beatle. The second features an American singer and actress by the name of Ciccone from Bay City, Mich.; on stage she uses only her first name, Madonna.
And the neighboring nation of Antigua and Barbuda, perhaps because of the initials A and B, has issued eight stamps and two souvenir sheets featuring Archie and Betty, and of course Veronica and Jughead and all the gang, for the 50th anniversary of Archie Comic Publications.
Archie is depicted in various sports situations, and there is a tiny logo at the bottom of each stamp with the Olympic rings and "Barcelona '92," which may or may not lure hobbyists interested in the Olympics.
It is easy to be snide about such stamps, but as a bit of sauce, and especially as a way to entice young collectors, they have their place.
The marketer for the stamps in the United States is the Inter-Governmental Philatelic Corporation, 460 West 34th Street, New York, N.Y. 10001.
 
Under New Management
 The management of Stamps for the Wounded, which distributes stamps to veteran's hospitals and convalescent centers, has been taken over by the Lions International Stamp Club.
Stamps for the Wounded had been run for nearly 50 years by Herman L. Neugass, who died in Washington on Aug. 31 at the age of 76. Mr. Neugass, who was an economic consultant to the District of Columbia, died of leukemia, his family said.
Collectors who wish to contribute stamps or philatelic material of any kind should first send a description of the material to Stamps for the Wounded, c/o Lions International Stamp Club, P.O. Box 1125, Falls Church, Va. 22041. Contributions are tax-deductible.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Starting to Count On Castro's Fall

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
Talk about planning ahead. It seems that half the world -- certainly half of Southern Florida -- is frantically preparing for the day when Fidel Castro, one of the world's last military dictators, falls or otherwise surrenders power.
Some Cuban-Americans are reserving boats they can use to ship desperately needed supplies to Havana. Others are selling their homes to raise cash they can use to start businesses there, or are negotiating with American companies to sell their products in Cuba once the market opens up. 
 Wall Street is also joining in the odds-making. Just as there are traders willing to bet on the outcome of takeover contests and the recent Soviet coup, so there are people dreaming up various "Cuban plays."
"There's a lot of rumbling that makes this thing look imminent," said Richard Lehmann, editor of the Defaulted Bonds Newsletter in Miami Lakes, Fla., who has heard from lots of interested investors on the subject. "There's a lot of receptivity to the idea that Castro is going to go."
Much of the investor enthusiasm stems from the economic miracle in Mexico, which saw its busted Government bonds rise from 30 cents on the dollar to 57 cents once it agreed to swap its old securities for new ones. "It's kind of a showcase," said Arthur Byrnes, director of Deltec Panamerica, which invests in out-of-favor securities. "So everyone looks around and asks where's the next big play, and clearly it's Cuba. Everyone thinks it's just a matter of time before Cuba has a phenomenal resurgence."
President Castro's political undoing is far from certain. Nonetheless, recent events in Cuba seem to have emboldened the theory. Last month, the Soviet Government decided to withdraw its troops from Cuba and end longstanding economic subsidies. That remarkable piece of news was followed by reports that Spain may have offered the Cuban president asylum in the Spanish town where his ancestors once lived.
Now come the speculators, and their bets are taking several forms. Some are scooping up long-forgotten Cuban stocks and bonds that haven't paid interest or dividends in years, reasoning that any new Government would mop up old debts or return seized property to attract money from the West.
Others are looking at hotel and casino companies that might want to help awaken Cuba's tourism industry from a 31-year slumber. "I think it's farfetched, but it shows how people are thinking," said Mr. Byrnes.
The best "bargains" seem to be the loans that several commercial banks in Canada, Germany, Japan and Spain made to various Cuban Government entities after Castro's rise to power. That paper, which is in default, was selling at 5 cents on the dollar earlier this year in the secondary market. Speculators have since driven it closer to 10.
Should a new Government agree to swap those old loans for new ones in a deal modeled on Mexico, those claims could rise as much as five- or sixfold, according to traders who specialize in Latin American securities. But United States citizens are prohibited from buying that paper under laws aimed at strangling the Cuban regime. That means only nonresidents using offshore companies can take advantage of the potential spreads.
Americans have to stick to stocks or bonds that were issued by companies before the revolution or pre-existing Government debt that Castro repudiated once he came to power. The pre-1960 Government debt is one popular play, and there is even one 1937 Republic of Cuba bond issue that is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Last year, 722 of the bonds -- nearly 2 percent of all those outstanding -- were traded. Another 1,068 bonds traded through September of this year alone. In yet another sign of investor confidence, prices have doubled from 20 cents on the dollar early this year to the high 40's.
One problem with that strategy is that pre-1960 Government merchandise may be getting pricey, according to Mr. Byrnes, whose firm has some pre-1960 Cuban paper in "the far reaches of the vault."
That is because the price of that debt is already trading close to what it might be if Cuba were restructured as successfully as Mexico. He argued that investors who are not in danger of breaking the law might be wiser to buy more recent securities, issued after Castro's rise.
"If you're only going to buy one, buy the cheap one," he said. "On the other hand, if you're an American, the only one you can buy is the dear one."
There are also a handful of pre-1960 corporate securities to choose from, mostly sugar companies and railroads that have long since ceased paying interest or dividends. Rarely traded, many of them have been stashed in attics or drawers more for their value as wall-hangings than for their financial worth.
Such strategies are not for the faint-hearted. Like that of any illiquid security, prices will fluctuate sharply, especially since there are so few comparable trades.
"The pricing is very much an art, not a science," said John E. Herzog, whose firm, Herzog, Heine, Geduld Inc., makes markets in some Cuban securities. For instance, his firm is currently offering 5 cents to 8 cents on the dollar for any Cuba Railroad Company, 4 percent bonds due in 1977 "depending on how enthusiastic the trader is when he is making the bid," said Mr. Herzog. His firm will also pay 25 cents for any shares of Cuban Electric Company that someone wants to sell.
Nor are there any guarantees that Cuba will ever repay its old debts. Mexico took care of its old debts because it wanted to borrow even more money. British investors received roughly 10 cents to 20 cents on the dollar in 1987 for their pre-1917 Czarist bonds and for their pre-1949 Chinese claims. American investors are still holding the bag.
Likewise, some hapless investors have been waiting for more than 150 years for Missisippi to pay off fewer than $10 million in bonds it issued in the 1830's, mostly in Europe, and later repudiated -- twice.

HEADLINE: In Southern India, a Glimpse of Asia's High-Tech Future

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA

DATELINE: BANGALORE, India

 BODY:
Most people here still travel by bicycle, bus, motor scooter or on foot, and power outages are frequent. But with a growth rate surpassing any other major Indian city, Bangalore has achieved a reputation as the Silicon Valley of India -- turning what was once a sleepy community into a bustling center of high-tech commerce, replete with traffic jams and honking Mercedes-Benz automobiles.
Several top American computer companies, including Hewlett-Packard, 3M, Texas Instruments and the Digital Equipment Corporation, have set up operations here, vying to supply hardware and software to a technology-hungry Asia. The companies hope to exploit vast markets in India, which has middle class estimated at more than 120 million people, and in other nations where affluence is growing. 
 Many have already entered smaller, more prosperous nations like Singapore, but are now setting more ambitious courses for the coming decades. "India is part of a strategic presence," said Bob Watson, the managing director of Texas Instruments in India. "In the long-term, we are interested in the larger markets of South and Southeast Asia as well as the Pacific."
That interest focuses especially on this pleasant city in southern India, whose temperate climate, outdoorsy style of life and leading scientific institutes make it India's answer to the San Francisco area. Tree-lined avenues, a golf course, health clubs, fine restaurants, pubs and hotels contribute to a cosmopolitan ambiance that helps draw many of India's best scientific minds.
Their talents and relatively low salaries are luring more and more Indian and multinational computer companies. "Bangalore is still a place where you can attract people to settle with their families, it's still a livable city," said Prakash Mutalik, general manager at Hewlett-Packard's software project here.
Senior Indian software and computer engineers, especially in the private sector, earn 10,000 to 15,000 rupees, about $400 to $600 a month -- less than the minimum wage in the United States. Senior academics earn about half as much.
And despite complaints about the painful plodding of a vast Government bureaucracy that demands innumerable forms filled out in duplicate and triplicate, executives are excited about their companies' progress.
"I think many corporations also understand that with a market of this size, it's better to establish a major presence early on in the game," said Shiv Nadar, the chairman of Hinditron Computers Ltd., the country's top domestic firm, which now has a joint venture with Hewlett-Packard.
This partnership, formed after Hewlett-Packard invested $23 million in H.C.L. stock, will make top-of-the-line computer work stations for Indian customers beginning this winter.
India has long been a difficult nation for Western companies to do business in. Wages are low, but so is productivity. It wants foreign investment and technology, but on its own terms.
In recent months, Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao has liberalized investment rules to give foreigners automatic approval for buying as much as 51 percent of a company, with an accelerated process for considering higher stakes.
The International Business Machines Corporation left the Indian market in 1977 after foreign ownership was limited to 40 percent. India's Commerce Minister announced in late September approval for I.B.M. to return in a joint venture with an Indian conglomerate, Tata Industries, to produce I.B.M.'s Personal System 2 computers and computer programs.
The influx of foreign and domestic computer companies has helped transform what was once a sleepy haven for pensioners into a traffic-clogged city of four million. Sleek Mercedes cars sweep past the swarms of bicyclists along streets full of potholes dug out by monsoons. Elegant, colonial-style bungalows are being demolished to make way for glittering new high-rise apartments and offices.
The gleaming white Digital building, with its broad satellite dish and a small, gentle Japanese garden in front (complete with a tiny wooden bridge and stream), exemplifies the city's abrupt modernization.
"When we came here a couple of years back, this place used to be partly a warehouse and partly a garbage dump and look at what we have now," said Mike Shah, chief operating officer of Digital Equipment (India) Ltd. Mr. Shah, a cheerful 46-year-old Indian, worked with Digital in the United States and elsewhere for 19 years before taking on the Indian project. His engineers and technicians assemble minicomputers and mainframes.
In Bombay and Bangalore, programmers aided by satellite communications write diagnostic software for the entire company. "The satellite link connects me instantly to 65 Digital subsidiaries across the world and the parent corporation," Mr. Shah said.
Business, although a fraction of Digital's output worldwide, is good. Sales rose to $350 million for the year ended March 1990 from $280 million for the year before.
The company payroll has grown to about 800 now from 335 in 1989, and Mr. Shah expects an additional 40 percent increase by next March. The Indian subsidiary began production after absorbing staff from H.C.L., which once represented Digital here.
Computer services are a key element of Digital's India operations. Besides handling customer requests and complaints, the company has set up five computer literacy centers in the country's five most populous cities: New Delhi, Bombay, Madras, Calcutta and Bangalore. Some 40 full-time faculty members, all Digital India employees, offer instruction, and not just to the company's customers.
Digital India supplies hardware to some of India's major public and private organizations. Its software side put together a package that helped computerize and speed up reservations on the sprawling railroad network that carries about four million passengers every day.
The work at Texas Instruments India focuses on computer-aided-design programs that the company uses around the world to design semiconductors. Texas Instruments has been here since India began liberalizing its economy under Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in the mid-1980's. The company, the first multinational to ask the Indian Government to arrange a dedicated satellite communications link, had 1990 revenues of about $2.4 million.
Not that the American companies and their Indian hosts are always in harmony. Mr. Watson, a native of Dallas, said easier regulations have not removed all frustrations for foreign companies.
Repairing a work-station circuit board outside the country was an ordeal. "It took seven months to get it out and bring it back because of customs rules," he remarked.
The Indians have some complaints about the Americans as well. The head of Bangalore's premier computer science center says that he is disappointed by the failure of these companies to invest in research and development at the the Indian institutions.
"There is nothing in terms of inter-action, we are basically providing them manpower," said N. Viswanadam, the chairman of the department of computer science and automation at the Indian Institute of Science. "In that way, the multinationals are not behaving differently from Indian companies."
Most of these companies still prefer to do their most sophisticated research back home. Professor Viswanadam had hoped they would provide scholarships or equip labs. "But their mandate is different," he said. "They seem to be here just to manufacture their product."
