HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 29-October 4

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
The Family Leave Feud, Part 2 

No one can say President Bush shies away from a fight, especially if it looks as if he will win. So last week when the Senate passed its second parental leave bill Mr. Bush said he would veto it, just as he vetoed the first. The measure is opposed by conservatives and many small businesses. "It is portrayed as flexible. But 'flexible' and 'mandate' don't go hand in hand," said Tracy Wurzel of the National Federation of Independent Businesses in Washington. But many in the Senate say the United States is the only industrial country whose citizens can face dismissal for tending to ailing children. The measure would "insure that workers will not have to chose job over family in times of emergency," said Senator Wendell Ford, Democrat of Kentucky. The bill exempts the nation's highest-paid workers, as well as part-time employees. But it still covers about 46 million workers. That's too many, says Mr. Bush.
 
Cars Move Gently Out of Neutral
 
Finally, the consumer is putting a little gas in Detroit's tank. Sales of 1992 models and leftover 1991's (there are still a lot of those around) increased by 5.8 percent in late September compared with the same period last year. But these sales were not all high-test. Most of the increase came from a jump in fleet sales and from cash-back incentives. Both move metal off the lot, but return only slim profits to the auto makers. Still, an increase is an increase and suggests the car companies are starting to see some growth. September's showing is "consistent with the gradual recovery thesis," said Harvey Heinbach, an automobile analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
 
Can the Recovery Recover?
 
Rather than consulting the stars, the Commerce Department relies on its index of leading economic indicators to foretell the future. The Government must be scratching its head right now. According to the department, the index, which is supposed to show how the economy will do in the next six to nine months, had been showing steady increases over the last six months. But August showed no increase over July. That was perplexing. The index, which comprises 11 other indexes, saw only four of its key indicators rise. Taken together, the indicators say the recovery could use a little more adrenaline. "The economy seems to have lost some momentum over the summer," said Robert T. McGee, of the Tokai Bank Ltd., in New York.
 
Housing Does the Right Thing
 
At least the housing sector of the economy is beginning to behave. According to the Commerce Department, sales of new homes, which are highly sensitive to changes in interest rates, jumped 6.7 percent in July.

Home Buyers in the Catbird Seat
 
Why are houses starting to sell? Economists say the market is beginning to work. But you don't need a Ph.D. to understand what that means. Loads of desperate sellers have dropped their asking prices. The result, according to the National Association of Realtors, is that housing is more affordable now than at any other time this year. The way they figure it, the average family, which earns about $36,533 a year, has about 112.5 percent of the income needed to qualify for a mortgage covering 80 percent of the value of an average home. A year ago, the index was just 107.4. But the typical family in the Northeast had only 93.5 percent of the purchasing power needed to buy a median-priced home there. For the market to continue to work its magic, prices in the Northeast may have to fall even farther.
 
Grimmer News from Factories
 
The recovery may not have toppled over (yet), but it certainly has stubbed its toe. According to the Commerce Department, factory orders fell by 1.9 percent in July. That was not supposed to happen. Factory orders had been the economy's one engine of growth. The culprit in the latest report is orders for durable goods like refrigerators and washing machines. These big-ticket items fell by 3.9 percent in August. Since durables account for half of all factory orders, declines there signal trouble throughout the economy.

'Crummy' Employment Numbers
 
It's eerie. Unemployment fell by 0.1 percent in September, according to the Labor Depart ment, but the economists are not smiling. The reason they are so grim is that the unemployment numbers were uneven. "There was a drop in manufacturing employment and that's our strong suit," said Alan Sinai, of the Boston Company. "Let's just say it's a crummy recovery," he said.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Kerkorian Climbs Into Chrysler
 
Now that the Chrysler Corporation has slipped into the junk category (its bonds, that is, not its cars), the company must pay a premium to borrow. So it was no surprise last week when the company issued 35 million new shares of stock to raise money. Those shares were quickly gobbled up by optimistic investors eyeing Chrysler's new products and hungry for a bargain. The stock sold for $10.125 a share. The hungriest investor of all was Kirk Kerkorian. The reclusive financier bought $60.75 million worth of stock through his Tracinda Corporation, increasing his stake in the auto maker to 9.8 percent -- an eyelash under the 10 percent level where Chrysler's anti-takeover measures kick in.
 
Time's Wounds All Healed?
 
Time Warner Inc., one of the nation's biggest media companies, has been looking for a foreign suitor with deep pockets for almost a year to help cut its $8.5 billion in debt. Last week rumors were circulating that Japan's Toshiba Corporation and C. Itoh & Company would together invest as much as $1 billion in Time Warner. When those rumors hit the streets, Time Warner stock jumped $2.125. It finished the week at $83.875.
 
GTE Hangs Up on Sylvania
 
These days investors prefer big companies to be narrowly focused. The theory says narrower businesses are easier to manage (at least outside Japan). Following this notion, the GTE Corporation, which had $21.4 billion in sales last year, said it would shed itself of its $2.3 billion electrical products group. "When people invest in phone companies they want to invest in phone companies," said Jack B. Grubman, of Paine Webber.
 
Shoe Drops for I.B.M. and Apple
 
They have been letting tantalizing details escape for months. Even so, last week's announcement of a pact between Apple Computer and the International Business Machines Corporation still generated excitement. John Sculley, Apple's chairman and Jack D. Kuehler, I.B.M.'s president, said they will share chips, software and designs for a new generation of PC's and work stations. They also said they would set up two new companies. One -- Taligent -- will develop advanced operating systems using state-of-the-art object-oriented programming. The other -- Kaleida -- will develop hardware and software to put pictures, sound and video into PC's and work stations. But the companies' first products won't exactly be rushed into production. "It's pretty clear today that a lot of this stuff is years away," said Michele Preston, an analyst with Cowen & Company.
 
No Halcyon Days for Upjohn
 
It was a highly unusual move. Britain's slow-moving Ministry of Health, which usually follows its American counterparts on regulatory issues, took the lead last week and banned the sale of the prescription drug Halcion. The United States Food and Drug Administration, somewhat perplexed, said it has no plans to do the same. Halcion is made by the Upjohn Company of Kalamazoo, Mich. According to British drug officials, new information suggests that Halcion can cause some terrible side effects, including loss of memory, depression and, most worrisome, episodes of violence. More than seven million Americans take Halcion, contributing to the drug's projected 1991 sales of $260 million.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Kaifu's October Surprise
 
The Japanese are quick to point out that the word "wa" means harmony. It is a concept, they say, that is supposed to permeate the society. Don't tell that to the politicians. Japan's lawmakers are a bareknuckled bunch. Though popular with the voters, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told his colleagues last week that he would not seek another two-year term when his expires later this month. That makes him the third Prime Minister in as many years. (The other two, Noburo Takeshita and Sosuke Uno, lost their jobs in scandals). Mr. Kaifu faced a scandal of his own in the financial markets. It was enough to cause his Finance Minister -- and rival -- Ryutaro Hashimoto also to announce his resignation last week. But Mr. Kaifu's problems went deeper. He went afoul of the leadership of the Liberal Democratic Party by threatening on his own to call an election. It will take some time before wa permeates the Parliament.

A Publisher's Soviet Coup
 
Moscow may not have come up with a way to create a market economy, but Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has found out how to make money in the West. Rather than talk about the failed coup for free (Barbara Walters beware) he sold his story to HarperCollins for about $500,000. The book will be rushed to stores by month's end. The only decision left is who gets the movie rights.
 
In the Soviet Union, the means of production may have fallen into disarray, but there was one thing outsiders were sure of: Moscow was swimming in gold. Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the author of Moscow's latest economic reform plan, sees it differently. He says Moscow only has $3 billion in gold, not the $15 billion previously estimated. Others in the Government have disputed that claim. If Mr. Yavlinksy is right, Moscow's credit-worthiness may fall still lower.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Mr. Guccione Cleans House at General Media

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
As recently as a year ago, Robert Guccione was on a growth binge. His closely held publishing company, General Media International, seemed to be branching out in all directions. Building on his flagship properties, Penthouse and Omni, Mr. Guccione launched Longevity, a health magazine, in 1988. Last year, General Media acquired Compute as well as three car magazines.
But late last month, the binge came to an end, at least for now, when General Media announced that 120 people companywide -- about 18 percent of the 650-member staff -- were being let go. The company also said that it was merging the staffs of Compute and Omni, a science magazine, by moving Omni's editorial operation from New York to Greensboro, N.C., where Compute is based. 
 General Media is just the latest in a long line of publishing companies to announce cutbacks as the recession lingers on. Time Inc., for instance, also announced layoffs last month.
"Like everyone else, we were overstaffed as a result of the bounteous 80's," Mr. Guccione said last week.
But unlike most in the business, the flashy Mr. Guccione seems resolutely upbeat. He insists that the layoffs at his company were ordered for reasons of prudence and not out of desperation. While Mr. Guccione declined to disclose sales and earnings figures, some industry numbers seem to bear him out: Penthouse was up 18 percent in ad pages through the first eight months of the year and Omni was up 12 percent, compared with an average magazine decline of 10 percent, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.
Not all the numbers are positive, however. During the first half of the year, Penthouse circulation fell 10.3 percent, to 1.5 million, while Omni dropped 18.4 percent, to 755,000.
In any event, no one expects the 60-year-old Mr. Guccione to cut back any time soon on his opulent style of life. The townhouse he shares with his wife, Kathy Keeton, on Manhattan's East Side comes complete with a swimming pool and museum-class art collection. Ms. Keeton is vice chairman of General Media.
As for the future, Mr. Guccione sees new growth coming from the Soviet Union, of all places. In 1989, Omni became the first American magazine to be sold in the Soviet Union for rubles. As part of the deal, 20,000 copies of the official magazine of the Soviet Academy of Sciences are distributed to Omni readers here.
Mr. Guccione has been opening the door wider ever since. General Media now has 200 employees in the Soviet Union and is busy publishing a rash of Soviet scientific journals and technical papers, translating them into a variety of languages and selling them to scientific groups all over the world.
"There's enormous profit in publishing their scientific journals," said Mr. Guccione.
For their part, the Soviets apparently see no contradiction in a company that publishes both a sex magazine and serious scientific journals. Penthouse and the Soviet Academy? Strange bedfellows, indeed.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
What's Happening With Windsor?

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
One of the largest stock funds in the United States has announced a plan to bring in new managers for part of its portfolio, and in light of the fund's excellent record, it is worth asking whether holders should be worried about the changes.
The $3.2 billion Vanguard Windsor II Fund -- the 15th largest of the nation's 1,000-plus stock funds -- has been managed by Barrow, Hanley, Mewhinney & Strauss, a firm that handles roughly three-quarters of the fund's assets, and Invesco Capital Management. 
 But Invesco recently acquired the Financial Funds Group in Denver, which competes with Vanguard, and is now marketing the funds under its own name. Because of that, John C. Bogle, Vanguard's chairman, and Invesco have agreed to part ways to avoid conflicts of interest. Windsor II shareholders will vote on a proposal to replace Invesco at a meeting set for Oct. 22; if approved, the new management will take over on Nov. 1.
The upheaval at Windsor II "makes me a little wary," said Dan Wiener, editor of The Vanguard Adviser, an independent investment newsletter based in Brooklyn.
Vanguard began Windsor II in June 1985 after it closed Windsor to new investors because cash was flowing into the fund more quickly than it could be carefully invested. Windsor, the industry's second-largest fund, is managed by John B. Neff, one of the most prominent of all mutual-fund managers. Yet Windsor II has outpaced its big brother.
Both are "value" funds, which buy out-of-favor stocks with low price-earnings ratios. But Windsor II is more diversified than Mr. Neff's fund. Mr. Neff makes big bets with his $7.9 billion fund, which holds an average of only 70 to 80 stocks. Windsor II, whose assets are much smaller, holds roughly the same number of stocks, but its holdings are distributed over more industries.
Too much diversity can backfire in stock funds. When a fund owns too many stocks, its performance tracks the average of the market as a whole. So Mr. Bogle could be expected to be wary of overdiversifying Windsor II. Yet Vanguard wants to replace one manager -- Invesco -- with three, and it seems reasonable to ask whether more managers mean even more diversity.
Mr. Bogle insists that Windsor II investors will see "no change in the nature or direction" of the fund's portfolio. He says Invesco's share is being divided among three managers, selected from 20, to position the fund for future growth.
Two companies will each handle about $270 million, roughly 9 percent of the fund's portfolio. Equinox Capital Management uses a blend of quantitative and fundamental analysis to identify medium- and large-capitalization stocks. Tukman Capital Management specializes in concentrated portfolios of well-managed companies in growing businesses.
The remaining $200 million or so will be handled by Vanguard's Core Management Group, a unit of the company that manages the $5.1 billion in Vanguard's seven index funds. Its Windsor II stake will be entirely managed on a quantitative basis, meaning that stocks are selected from a group of 250 stocks with below-average price-earnings ratios, above-average yields and other criteria.
Right now, Invesco manages about half of Windsor II's 80 stocks. Of the new managers, Tukman will manage 10 or 15 stocks, and Equinox will manage 25 or so. Mr. Bogle said the Core Management Group would select an additional 40 or so, for a total of roughly 80 stocks. After accounting for overlap with the Barrow, Hanley portfolio, the new management arrangement is expected to add roughly 20 stocks to the fund's total portfolio.
As for performance, Mr. Bogle says that the Invesco portion of Windsor II returned an annual average of 17.6 percent and that Barrow, Hanley's performance was "substantially identical."
Right now, Windsor II has about 50 cents of "unrealized capital gains" per share. Unrealized gains are created when securities owned by a fund increase in value. The gains are realized -- and taxes are owed -- when the securities are sold. Assuming that Invesco may have realized some of those gains by year-end anyway, Mr. Bogle estimates that Windsor II shareholders may receive an additional 35 to 40 cents a share of capital gains in 1991, rather than several years down the road, as the new managers replace some of Invesco's holdings.
What's an investor to do? John Reken thaler of Morningstar Inc., a mutual-fund rating concern, says that because Windsor II "is not extremely idiosyncratic, it's easier to pull out one manager and plug in another." He calls it a "good fund with competitive returns and below-average risk."
Mr. Wiener of The Vanguard Adviser newsletter recommends that investors hold their shares of Windsor II, but he is worried about the possibility that the number of issues held by the fund may increase sharply. If the number of shares approaches 125, he said, "I would start to get nervous."
For investors who can handle more risk, Mr. Wiener prefers Windsor. Through August, Windsor had gained 25.8 percent this year, compared with 21.5 percent for Windsor II. "The difference is likely to rise as the economy pulls up because John Neff favors the unloved cyclicals that do well in the early stages of economic recovery," he said.

HEADLINE: And Not a Personal Computer in Sight

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
It is the office of the future that looks like a relic from the past: people working with note pads, blackboards and Post-it Notes, and not a personal computer in sight. It's a place where nerdy-looking shirt badges are de rigueur.
What makes this scene state-of-the-art-to-be is that the pads, boards, Post-its and badges are all "talking" to each other via tiny infrared light-emitting diodes or radio transmitters. 
 The badges keep track of where, when and with whom the wearer is spending time and receive messages on liquid crystal displays. The pads and other writing surfaces serve as the tabula rasa for a powerful -- but hidden -- network of computer machinery that surrounds workers like a cocoon. Information or instructions can be entered on the pads and boards in plain English, to be sent to similar surfaces in other offices or used to retrieve and store data from computers. The destination points could be down the hall or across the world.
This vision of a stripped-down high-tech office where the computers have disappeared into the woodwork is still years away from being turned into a reality.
But it has already signaled the revival of the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center, where the vision is being developed. The legendary birthplace of many of the ideas that resulted in the modern computer industry, PARC is attracting new interest after a decade languishing in relative obscurity.
"The magic has returned to PARC," said David Patterson, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley and a leading computer designer.
If the magic pays off -- and many think it will -- the implications are far-reaching. It would give Xerox, which mishandled PARC's earlier efforts by botching product development and marketing, a rare second chance to become a dominant player in information systems by building on its still-strong foundation in the copying business. And it would help to keep the United States competitive in high technology during the 1990's.
An increasing number of experts say that the PARC office's all-encompassing high-tech environment -- based on an approach called ubiquitous computing -- could not only revolutionize the way personal computers are used but also radically change the way work is done.
As powerful as desktop computers are now, to many people they are still off-putting and awkward to use. In some cases, they have even become dangerous to use, giving rise to so-called repetitive stress injuries. Office productivity has actually remained flat for the past decade despite the widespread introduction of PC's.
 
Dumping the Keyboards
 The solution, PARC says, is to pull out the keyboards and make the technology as accessible as a pad and pencil, albeit a pad and pencil imbedded with electronics. With everyone tied together wherever they are by familiar office instruments, efficiency can only soar, particularly when it comes to group projects, researchers say.
"You want to use technology inside to keep the outside simple," said John Seeley Brown, PARC's director. "Technology is getting sophisticated enough to get out of the way."
To be sure, a pervasive technology that surrounds people with radio waves and hidden computers is not everyone's vision of an ideal workplace. The PARC office has already raised concerns about personal privacy and office safety, concerns that Xerox says it is addressing.
Ideal or not, PARC's project could not have been better timed. The computer industry is in chaos as such major players as I.B.M., Apple, Microsoft and Compaq cast around for a new model to replace today's desktop computer and jump-start flagging sales.
"We're approaching the end of the PC era and we haven't established the metaphor for the next phase of the information revolution," said Paul Saffo, a consultant who is a computer industry analyst at the Institute for the Future, a market research firm in Menlo Park, Calif. "Everything is up for grabs and the industry is just waiting for a new idea. Xerox is the only place that consistently comes up with new ideas."
 
Early Promise
 The situation is rich with irony. Many industry leaders are placing their bets for the next PC era on smaller and smaller portable computers inspired by an early PARC vision: the Dynabook, a tiny wonder machine that would function as an intelligent electronic companion. But while others are still feeding off of PARC's early ideas, PARC itself is striking out in new directions, hoping that this time Xerox will know how to capitalize on what it finds there.
Located in the foothills behind Stanford University, the Palo Alto Research Center was founded in 1970. In its early years, a small group of scientists and engineers designed the first personal computers and created a variety of technologies that continue to define the direction of advanced computing. Office networks, graphical computer displays with windows, laser printers and distributed computing systems, not to mention PC's themselves, were all the fruit of a fundamental rethinking of the modern office that went on here during the 70's.
But PARC's parent, based across the country in Stamford, Conn., was a risk-averse maker of photocopying equipment. In their book "Fumbling the Future: How Xerox Invented, Then Ignored, the First Personal Computer," Douglas K. Smith and Robert C. Alexander recounted how Xerox executives refused to market PARC's personal computer, the Alto. Xerox's management never fully grasped the implications of personal computing and the company was quickly relegated to the sidelines when the International Business Machines Corporation introduced its PC in 1981.
Because their inventions languished, PARC's best researchers departed for such companies as Apple, Microsoft and Digital Equipment. It was those companies that produced commercial versions of innovations that PARC had pioneered.
In recent years, though, PARC has been attracting new talent and percolating new ideas, with much of the credit going to the 51-year-old Dr. Brown, who took over as director last year after serving as co-director for four years.
"John Seeley Brown is one of the creative outlaws, and the outlaws are running the shop now at PARC," said Mr. Saffo.
 
Closer Contacts
 Xerox also seems to have learned its lesson and is no longer isolating basic research from product development.
"The situation has changed a lot at PARC," said William Spencer, a former director of PARC who now heads Sematech, the chip-making consortium. "You have marketing people living there these days. With Paul Allaire as chief executive, contacts between Xerox's marketing and research sides are much closer."
One piece of evidence: Directly down the hill from the research center, construction workers are putting the finishing touches on Xerox's System Development Laboratory, where all of the company's software product development is to be consolidated. The software is now developed at a number of sites around the country.
Moreover, technological change may now be working in Xerox's favor. The gulf is rapidly narrowing between Xerox's paper-based copying machine business and digital computing systems that permit images and text to be stored, copied and manipulated electronically. Because of the shift, PARC's work has become central to Xerox's view of its future.
"In the 70's, PARC was started to diversify Xerox," said Michael Schrage, a high-tech consultant and writer. "In the 90's, PARC is being used to reintegrate the company."
Last year, Xerox introduced a high-end publishing system that represented the first step in its attempt to break down the wall that has separated paper documents from electronic documents. The Docutech Publishing System first scans a paper document and stores a digital image. It is then able rapidly to apply a range of computer technologies to the image, including image enhancement and optical character recognition.
The company says less costly versions of the Docutech system will be a component of Xerox's re-entry into the computing business.
 
Can It Sell?
 But if PARC has once again proven prescient in understanding and charting the evolution of personal computer technology, its parent has yet to show that it can do more than sell regular office equipment.
William Lowe, who led I.B.M.'s personal computer business before becoming head of product development at Xerox in 1989, says it is still unclear whether Xerox can market its digital innovations. Earlier this year, Mr. Lowe left Xerox to become president of the Gulfstream Corporation, a maker of business jets.
"An integration has taken place that will allow Xerox to get PARC's technology into products," he said. "The real issue is from a marketing and sales perspective. How do you sell systems to customers instead of copiers?"
The answer may well turn on how captivating Dr. Brown's "outlaw" creations turn out to be. And that will turn on the lure of ubiquitous computing, a system that Dr. Brown views as the new paradox of modern computing: As hardware and software systems become more powerful and shrink in size, they will surround us and disappear at the same time.
The driving force behind ubiquitous computing is the rapidly falling cost of even the most powerful microprocessors, the chips that are the heart of computing. That makes it economically feasible, Xerox researchers say, to imbue common office tools -- like note pads, blackboards and Post-its -- with computer "intelligence" and the capacity to create and transmit electronic documents.
In PARC's view, it is these writing surfaces -- and not computer screens -- that make the best "interfaces" between people and machines.
Information generated by PARC badges could in turn be used to add tremendous depth to future computerized storage systems. Because the badges monitor the wearer's every move and encounter, they should prove extremely useful in retrieving and sharing documents. For example, many people now remember documents not just by their content, but by where they were last used or the meetings at which they were generated. The badges would broadcast a nonstop stream of such minutiae to an unseen web of computers, which would then "wrap" each document in a coat of identifying information.
That would allow the PARC office to "keep track of the information that I call 'intrinsic,' " said Robert Spinrad, Xerox's director of corporate technology.
Collectively these intelligent office tools would push traditional computing tasks far into the background.
PARC is now thinking of computers "in terms of inches, feet and yards," said Mark Weiser, director of PARC's computer science laboratory, referring to the process of trying to package the technology seamlessly into badges, note pads and blackboards. Such an approach is the exact opposite of the current industry infatuation with virtual reality, in which the user puts on electronic goggles and a special glove to control a computer-generated environment. In virtual reality, the outside world disappears. At PARC, it is the computers that seem to vanish.
With the machinery gone, people take more of the spotlight, which may explain why Dr. Brown says research on new work practices is as important as research on new products.
Indeed, one of the things that has traditionally distinguished PARC from such other major American research centers as I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Laboratory or A.T.& T.'s Bell Labs has been a willingness to make sociological as well as technological experiments. For example, during the 70's PARC gave hundreds of researchers personal computers, which then cost $30,000 each to build. In doing so, it proved the value of office networks that permitted researchers to share information.
Now the company is conducting similar experiments with ubiquitous computing technologies.
 
A Willingness to Spend
 "Xerox has always been willing to spend the dollars and invest the human capital," said David Liddle, a former Xerox executive and the president of Metaphor Computer Systems, one of the Silicon Valley companies that commercialized technology that originated at PARC and which was recently acquired by I.B.M. "It's one of the reasons I have a good feeling about their work in ubiquitous computing."
But Dr. Brown's single-minded devotion to studying the sociology of the workplace in addition to its technology has occasionally left some of his researchers perplexed. "After listening to John, I sometimes wonder why he doesn't fire us and hire a laboratory of anthropologists," said Bernardo Huberman, a PARC physicist.
Others worry that some of PARC's new technologies -- like the identity badges -- may be too invasive and threaten personal privacy.
"The amount of negative reaction is large enough that we have to deal with it," said Marvin Theimer, a PARC computer scientist. Some researchers are now exploring ways to permit people to work anonymously in ubiquitous computer networks.
But much basic work remains to be done before the first PARC office can open for business. The new style of computing is requiring a massive overhaul of traditional software systems, which have been designed to serve a stable structure of computers wired to fixed locations. In PARC's new world, the mandate is for motion. The software will have to be sophisticated enough to keep up with office workers as they move about and take their computerized badges and pads with them.
"Understanding, designing and building ensembles of computers is emerging as the intellectual centerpoint of computing and computer science," said David Gelernter, a Yale University computer scientist.
Yet with ubiquitous computing still in its infancy, PARC and Dr. Brown are already poking around for new projects that promise big breakthroughs.
Dr. Brown recently assigned one researcher, Ralph Merkle, to work full time on an even more radical approach known as nanotechnology, a speculative discipline based on building computer systems by controlling individual atoms. A few scientists now believe that nanotechnology will make it possible in the next two decades to build computers capable of performing thousands of times faster than today's supercomputers.
"This is the manufacturing technology of the 21st century," Mr. Merkle said. "I'd call this long-range applied research."
 
 
WORKING IN THE SHADOW OF HISTORY
 Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center occupies a special place in the history and culture of the computer industry.
In the early 1970's, it served as the base for a small group of researchers, led by Alan Kay, who literally re-invented computing. Until then, computers were refrigerator-sized monsters that sat in air-cooled glass rooms and were shared by dozens of users. By the mid-70's, the Kay group had made it possible to give each researcher a personal computer small enough to fit under a desk.
But in the 80's, Xerox mishandled PARC's research, turning the lab into a symbol of America's inability to capitalize on innovation. Said one scientist who joined the exodus of talented researchers who quit PARC: "I left because I wanted to see the results of my work under a Christmas tree."
Today, PARC is home to about 300 researchers working in areas as diverse as ubiquitous computing and natural language. The center is small by the standards of many of the nation's corporate research facilities.
There are five related labs on PARC's California campus: electronics and imaging, computer science, electronic documents, system sciences and electronic materials. A sixth lab, EuroPARC, was founded in Cambridge, England, in 1988 to study human-computer interaction and serve as a link to major European universities.
The research emphasis at PARC has shifted in the last decade from physics, basic science and electromechanical and integrated circuits to such current interests as digital systems, anthropology, linguistics and the use of color.
PARC is one of three Xerox research centers. A second center in Webster, N.Y., serves as a base for research in copying and color printing technology. The Xerox Research Center of Canada, in Mississauga, Ontario, focuses on materials research.
 
A ZEAL FOR CONNECTIONS
 Xerox is widely believed to have fumbled its opportunity in the computer industry because its Palo Alto Research Center remained isolated from the giant copier company during the 1970's.
Today, PARC's new director, John Seeley Brown, has a passion for making certain there is no separation between the laboratory and its parent.
Earlier this year, Dr. Brown wrote a widely read and controversial article in the Harvard Business Review titled "Research That Reinvents the Corporation."
In his article, Dr. Brown argues that the role of a corporate research laboratory is not just to invent new products and technologies; it must fundamentally transform the way the corporation functions as well.
"We have to marinate in the real problems of the corporation," he said. That means that it is crucial for laboratory managers to be grounded in the practical concerns of the corporation as well as to be on the cutting edge of technology.
Trained as a computer scientist and a mathematician at Brown and the University of Michigan, Dr. Brown came to PARC in 1978 from Bolt, Baranek & Newman, a Cambridge, Mass., think tank where he worked on artificial intelligence and learning systems.
His background in artificial intelligence led to a new interest at PARC in what researchers there refer to as "collaborative" technologies: computer systems that support and amplify the activities of small groups of office workers. To understand those dynamics better, Dr. Brown hired the first anthropologists at PARC.
This approach has led researchers to view writing surfaces that produce electronic documents -- and not personal computers -- as the heart of the modern office.

HEADLINE: All About/Musical Instruments;
In Search of the High-Tech Chord

BYLINE: By DAVID BERREBY

 BODY:
Horns and other big-band instruments were the hottest sellers when Manny Goldrich opened his music store in 1933 on West 48th Street in Manhattan, conveniently near Broadway and a still-thriving Tin Pan Alley. In the 1960's, the public's taste for Elvis Presley and the Beatles drove the shining saxophones into a single corner of the cavernous store, cramming the rest with guitars and amplifiers.
In the 80's, though, Mr. Goldrich's son Henry and grandsons Ian and Judd have had to change even more radically. Digital recording technology has revolutionized music-making, so that today's customers are as likely to be interested in ROM -- a computer's read-only memory -- as in reeds for clarinets. 
 With the retail music business getting more high tech, retailers have to do more than just make room upstairs for computers and software. They need well-trained people to explain how all the equipment works. "In 1982, we had 25 salespeople," Ian Goldrich said. "Today we have 81. Things are more technical and we need those skills."
Manny's Music, though larger than the average music store, is typical of the music retailing business, which is dominated by thousands of "mom and pop" operations.

 
 
An Adaptable Industry
The Cacophony Of Segments
 The country's 5,000 to 6,000 retailers of musical instruments are used to adapting to the shifting waves of fashion and technology. According to Brian Majeski, editor of Music Trades, an industry trade magazine, retail music stores sell about $3.5 billion a year worth of instruments and "sound reinforcement" equipment -- microphones, mixers and the like -- to an enthusiastic public with somewhat fickle tastes.
"The business is really an agglomeration of small markets that are pretty discrete," Mr. Majeski said. "There's the piano segment, which is overwhelmingly parents buying an instrument so a kid can take lessons. Then there are band instruments like clarinets and horns, which are bought for kids in school bands on lease-buy programs. The third segment is guitars and synthesizers, which is overwhelmingly young men between the ages of 13 and 25. Then there are the electronics, which are bought by hobbyists."
There are even smaller splinters, Mr. Majeski said. Percussion instruments, for example, are 3 percent of the market, and "some people are still buying accordions," he said.
The piano and band segments, which together account for about 27 percent of the market, have been held back in the last three years by slack consumer spending and by reductions in school music programs. The electric guitar and electronic markets, about 25 percent of the business, have also had lackluster sales. With consumers wary about the economy, overall instrument sales have been flat in the last three years, Mr. Majeski said. The one bright spot is acoustical guitars, whose sales have been climbing because of renewed interest in traditional instruments.
In many industries, such flatness might prompt mergers and liquidations at the margins, but most musical instrument makers, like retailers, are small family businesses and are reluctant to abandon a craft spanning several generations.
 
The Midi Revolution
Putting a Studio Into the Software
 Selling these instruments requires sophistication. David Rovin is typical of the generations of musicians who have supported their pursuits by working in a music store. But Mr. Rovin, a salesman at Manny's Music, sells software, not guitars.
Mr. Rovin works beside a wall crammed with computer screens and displays of programs aimed at making the musician's life easier. To demonstrate one big seller, he taps a few instructions into an Atari personal computer. The Atari is a favorite with music software makers, he said, because alone among PC's, it has a built-in musical instrument digital interface device, or Midi. As Mr. Rovin plays on a keyboard synthesizer next to the computer, the Midi translates the sequence of keystrokes into computer code.
On half of Mr. Rovin's computer screen is an image of a typical sound engineer's mixing device, its meters rising and falling with his playing, as a real mixer's would. Below this image, on the other half of the screen, is a musical staff. As Mr. Rovin plays each note, it appears, correctly notated, on the computer's screen. Once he's satisfied with this first track, a click of the PC's mouse allows Mr. Rovin to create a second track, and so on up to 18. The computer mixer allows him to blend musical tracks as if he were in a studio; the notater will allow him to print out the score.
The software, made by C-Lab, a company in Hamburg, Germany, sells for $479. In the three years it's been out, 50,000 programs have been sold, according to the manufacturer. Similar programs for I.B.M. and Macintosh computers are also available.
Music software makers are bullish on the potential market for musicians and for musical training, but Mr. Majeski, the trade magazine editor, is not so sure there are enough potential composers and mixers out there to make it a significant market. "The whole business was only about $15 million last year," he said.
Software advances have also drawn the interest of the Yamaha Corporation of Japan, the $2.7 billion instrument maker that was the first to market synthesizers and electronic keyboards in the 70's. For the last three years, the company has offered an acoustic piano with the modern version of a piano roll -- software that reproduces a great performance on the instrument. Of special interest to the company is that 70 percent of people who have bought grand pianos equipped with the device don't play themselves.
 
An Acoustic Backlash
The Revenge Of the Quiet
 As president of Washburn International Inc., Rudy Schlacher has to be a trend-watcher. The Buffalo Grove, Ill., company, which had sales of $40 million last year, is one of the largest guitar makers in the country. The prime market for Washburn's guitars is young men who want to be like the hot artist of the moment.
"MTV dictates what our industry will be for years to come," Mr. Schlacher said. MTV is now featuring an all-acoustic show called "MTV Unplugged."
Sales figures reflect the new interest in traditional instruments. Acoustic guitar sales, which plummeted from 2.5 million a year in 1972 to a low of 875,000 in 1983, have climbed back up to 1.5 million last year, according to the Guitar and Accessories Music Marketing Association.
Washburn is scrambling to produce enough acoustic guitars to meet the growing demand. The company's basic model, made in South Korea, sells for less than $200. Other models cost more than $1,000, and are made in the United States. The new acoustic trend has inspired a new form of high-tech instrument: the electric acoustic guitar.
"If you amplify a regular acoustic guitar and you don't do it right, it sounds like an electric guitar," Mr. Schlacher said. The answer, he said, is to build in devices that detect the vibrations of the guitar's body -- the inspiration was a motion-detection sensor used on jet-fighter wings -- and then amplify those vibrations, which are what give the instrument its distinctive sound.
Mr. Schlacher concedes that many buyers probably will never have an audience big enough to require its special features. But to the eager musician, he said, "it's not what you need, it's what you can afford. The music business is a dream business."
 
 
 
MUSIC'S ROCK AND HARD PLACE
LAST March, a concert at Carnegie Hall featuring Sting and Antonio Carlos Jobim brought to light a problem in the musical instrument business. The concert was dedicated to preserving the Brazilian rain forest with the proceeds going to the Rainforest Foundation International.
But many musical instruments are at least partly made from rain forest woods. For example, mahogany, which is a very hard rain forest wood and whose destruction is being protested by a number of environmental groups, is an ideal wood for guitar necks and backs. Mahogany is also used in some pianos and clarinets.
Then there is rosewood. Rosewood, which also comes from the Brazilian rain forest, is used for the sides and fronts of guitars.
Customers who discover they have been singing songs against deforestation accompanied by a product made of mahogany are not happy customers, acknowledges Rudy Schlacher of Washburn International Inc. "We get letters all the time," he said.
Washburn now gets its tropical woods from Indonesia. "We don't go to the Brazilian areas anymore, partly for publicity reasons, but also because of scarcity. And we're trying to work only with people who have a reforestation program," Mr. Schlacher said.
Still, he said, the supply of raw materials is "a massive problem." For example, "a good-quality piece of maple for a guitar body might have cost us $10 about ten years ago. Now it costs $60," he said.
Supplies are also an anxiety for the Yamaha Corporation. A piano, for example, has some 8,000 moving parts, many of them wood, said Ron Raup, a company vice president. "Solid spruce is the best material for sounding boards," he said. But Yamaha long ago abandoned ivory for its keys. "We developed a synthetic that feels just like ivory," he said.

HEADLINE: Toughest Fight Yet For Hydro-Quebec

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
Hydro-Quebec, the $50 billion utility that is wholly owned by the Quebec government, has powered a vast industrial expansion in the province. And the company is committed to further development that would almost double its output of inexpensive hydropower. But getting there might be a problem. For the first time, the company is encountering fierce resistance.
Hydro-Quebec's chief executive, Richard Drouin, has faced tough fights before. He took office three years ago amid a labor battle in which unionized workers ransacked some of the company's executive offices. He has since brought a measure of labor calm and improved the reliability of the company's electrical service. 
 But he may have more difficulty carrying out the company's ambitious growth plans. Hydro-Quebec is now in the center of a storm over a proposed project that would spend 12.6 billion Canadian dollars to tap hydropower on the Great Whale River, which flows into Hudson Bay. The project is intensely opposed by the Cree Indians who live in the area and by environmentalists.
The dispute has spread to the United States, where opponents are pressing New York and Vermont to restrain purchases of power from Quebec even as growth in power demand is slowing. New York, which currently gets only a tiny percentage of its power from Quebec, has delayed until late next year a final decision on proceeding with a contract to pay 14.5 billion American dollars over 21 years for power from Quebec.
In this atmosphere of uncertainty about demand for its hydropower, the company's heavy use of debt to finance construction is causing some analysts to wonder if it will have sufficient revenue to pay off its bonds.
Mr. Drouin, however, expresses no doubts about the worthiness of the project. Still, he acknowledges with a diffident grin that the company's profile "is a little higher these days than we would like."
The 59-year-old Mr. Drouin went to school with the current Premier of Quebec, Robert Bourassa, at the College Jean-de-Brebeuf in Montreal, then took a law degree at Laval University in Quebec City. That early friendship, combined with Mr. Drouin's expertise in labor relations, won him the job that some say is equivalent to economics minister of the province. As a source of big construction projects as well as of hydropower, the company has long been an important engine of growth for Quebec.
The urbane, square-jawed, silver-haired executive, who as a sailor in the Gulf of Saint Lawrence often braves inhospitable seas, came aboard Hydro-Quebec three years ago, when the utility faced severe labor problems.
The rancor stemmed from the company's insistence on contracting out work instead of hiring additional workers or paying more overtime. Mr. Drouin reached an agreement with the unions under which company workers perform operating and maintenance work, while subcontractors handle new construction. Nonetheless, relations with the company's 25,000 workers are still touchy.
As chief executive, Mr. Drouin has tried not only to get a better handle on labor relations but also to improve the company's reliability. In the last decade Hydro-Quebec has been plagued by power blackouts and brownouts. But failures have already been sharply reduced, and Mr. Drouin's goal is to make Hydro-Quebec one of Canada's most dependable utilities by the mid-1990's.
The Great Whale construction project had already been set in motion by the time Mr. Drouin arrived on the scene. He has pursued it vigorously, saying expansion is essential for the well-being of the province, where the company's operating and construction activities in 1990 injected more that $7.5 billion into the economy, equivalent to 4.5 percent of Quebec's gross domestic product.
The entire province is believed to have a hydroelectric potential of about 50,000 megawatts, equivalent to the output of about 60 traditional power plants. The company has already developed about 25,000 megawatts, with plans for 20,000 more.
Noting that hydropower is "cheaper to develop and bring to major load centers than any other generating option," Mr. Drouin said he expects to be able to sell power in the northeast United States for 40 percent below other electricity producers.
But to continue tapping Quebec's hydro resources, the giant utility, which generates revenues of $6 billion a year and borrows about $4 billion a year, needs environmental approval to go forward with the 3,100 megawatt Great Whale project.
The project entails building dikes and dams, roads and airports, diverting four rivers and flooding an area slightly larger than Lake Champlain, in a region where 10,000 Cree and 5,000 Inuit make their home. Mr. Drouin insists that his company can carry out the construction work while preserving the environment and raising living standards of the native peoples.
The Cree and their lawyers in Montreal dispute this. They argue that the project will take a severe toll on the environment. They are fighting the project every inch of the way and now have help from North American conservationist groups, including the Sierra Club and the National Audubon Society. Entertainers are also getting involved; three rock concerts are scheduled for this week at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan under the title "Ban the Dam Jam."
The coalition recently won a significant victory. Quebec's Environment Minister, Pierre Paradis, announced on Aug. 22 that no work would begin on the Great Whale project until after there has been a thorough environmental assessment by the province, which will take at least a year.
In addition, a federal judge in Ottawa last month ordered the Canadian Government to undertake its own environmental review, and Ottawa and Quebec are weighing a joint assessment. But it cannot begin until the indigenous people agree to participate.
Quebec's Energy Minister, Lise Bacon, said the province needs the power and faces a choice of using either hydropower or nuclear power. "Do you want a nuclear plant to be built in Quebec?" she asked at a news briefing last week. In fact, Hydro-Quebec already operates two small nuclear plants.
When Mr. Bourassa and Governor Cuomo signed a power contract in 1989 under which Hydro-Quebec would provide 1,000 megawatts of electricity to New York State for 21 years beginning in 1995, they gave each other until next Dec. 31 to back out without penalty. Now both parties have extended the deadline until Nov. 30, 1992.
Richard M. Flynn, chairman of the New York Power Authority, said the state would use the time to reassess its power needs in light of the reduced growth in electricity sales resulting from the recession and from greater conservation. The growth has fallen to six-tenths of 1 percent annually from 1.5 percent in the mid-80's. This could mean changes in the contract to adjust delivery schedules.
Mr. Flynn said in an interview that the contract offered "significant environmental benefits" for New York. He cited a report of the state's energy office that hydroelectric power cuts "millions of tons" of carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxide and sulfur dioxide pollutants that would otherwise pour out of from oil- and coal-fired power stations.
In addition, he calculates that Quebec power has saved the state's residents more than $600 million since 1978.
The Great Whale project is only the latest of a number of projects to open up the hydro resources of the north. A huge complex on La Grande River, a couple of hundred miles to the south of the Great Whale, was completed in 1985 and generates 10,300 megawatts of power. A second phase at La Grande is scheduled to add 4,500 megawatts in 1995.
In the next decade the company expects to spend some $64 billion not only on La Grande Phase 2 and the Great Whale but a vast new complex along the Nottaway, Broadback and Rupert Rivers, south of La Grande, which would generate 8,400 megawatts. It is also negotiating with Newfoundland to develop two big hydroelectric sites on the lower Churchill River in Labrador.
To get the funds for these tremendous capital-intensive ventures, the company has used retained earnings and borrowed heavily in local and foreign capital markets.
With long-term debt of $25.6 billion at the end of last year, including $7.5 billion in United States dollars, Hydro-Quebec already owes more money than all but a few other North American corporations, and some bankers have expressed uneasiness about future borrowing for the new ventures.
Robert Blohm, an American investment banker in Montreal, said the export contracts for New York and Vermont are intended to provide the bulk of the income needed to service the American indebtedness. If these contracts are annulled, he warned, the company could be "dangerously exposed to risk on the American portion of its debt."
But William Streeter, vice president of Moody's Investors Service, is less worried. He cites positive factors, including the company's "strong management," its "flexibility" in construction programs and its "very competitive" electricity prices.
There is no greater enthusiast of water power than Premier Bourassa himself, the 58-year-old leader of Quebec's Liberal Party, who has been provincial chief executive on and off since 1970.
In a book titled "Power From the North," published by Prentice-Hall Canada in 1985, Mr. Bourassa wrote: "Quebec is a vast hydroelectric plant in the bud, and every day millions of potential kilowatt-hours flow downhill and out to sea. What a waste!"
 
 
A BARGAIN FOR SMELTERS
 THE secret is finally out about how much big energy-hungry aluminum smelters and other metal refiners actually pay for the power they buy from Hydro-Quebec, the utility owned by Quebec's taxpayers.
The answer: precious little in bad times, more in good times. Under risk-sharing variable-rate contracts, prices are pegged to a combination of the inflation rate, the world price of the metal and the customer's profits.
For example, Norsk Hydro Canada Inc., operating a magnesium smelter at Becancour, Quebec, for its Norwegian parent, now pays 1.6 cents a kilowatt-hour. This is about half of what Hydro-Quebec charges other industrial users and a quarter of what the New York Power Authority pays.
Norsk Hydro is one of 13 heavy energy users that have invested billions of dollars in Quebec and have similar contracts. Of the 13, four are magnesium or aluminum smelters -- companies that use enormous amounts of electricity to separate and refine metals.
As times improve for Norsk Hydro, its payments for electricity would rise under the formula so that over the term of the contract Hydro-Quebec theoretically would fare as well as with its other industrial customers.
Still, there are questions about whether the smelters are being subsidized at the expense of other consumers, the taxpayers and competitors. The Utah-based Magnesium Corporation of America has brought a case before the United States International Trade Commission seeking duties to wipe out any competitive advantages Norsk Hydro may have gained from its contract with Hydro-Quebec.
Hydro-Quebec says no subsidy is involved. It calculates that it may lose as much as $125 million this year on the 13 agreements but that it can make a profit of twice that much if aluminum sales and profits recover.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Long-Term Bonds Are Out of Kilter

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The returns of funds holding United States Government bonds and investment-grade corporate bonds usually closely parallel each other. That is not true today.
The current returns of corporate bond funds reflect a traditional yield curve: the longer investors are willing to tie up their money, the greater the return. By contrast, investors in intermediate-term Government bond funds actually enjoy a greater return than holders of long-term bonds. 
 Eventually, Government bond funds' returns will move back into alignment. Because the United States economy is coming out of recession, the inverted yield curve -- where short-term performance exceeds the long-term -- is unlikely to last. For now, however, Government-bond-fund investors are not being rewarded for the extra risks inherent in long-term investing. The better choice today is to hold short- and intermediate-term Government-bond funds.

HEADLINE: Sunday Dining;
3 Places Where Brunchers Can Get a Taste of Dinner

 BODY:
The brisk breezes of fall inevitably bring the hungry brunchers, and this year, because of the slow economy, more restaurants than ever have decide to offer brunch. Some offer conventional fare like eggs Benedict and French toast, while others supplement that with items from the regular menu. Here are three spots worth trying, for brunch or Sunday dinner.
 
La Boheme
 24 Minetta Lane, near Avenue of the Americas, in Manhattan, (212) 473-6447 -- This popular Greenwich Village bistro has a country-setting feel with plank floors, wood-and-stucco walls and close tables the size of cutting boards that are draped with Provencal fabric and butcher paper. Prices are moderate and the kitchen turns out seductive roasts, lovely prepared seafood and thin-crusted pizzas. 
 Among starters are the zesty eggplant puree slathered over toasted French bread; braised endive with prosciutto; smoked trout with warm potato salad; and a mixture of goat cheese, sweet red pepper, onion and zucchini in puff pastry. The pizzas that come whizzing out of the brick oven have thin, deliciously blistered crusts and well-orchestrated toppings. Among those is a spiced chicken with tomato, onion and coriander.
For main courses there are a grilled half chicken served with caramelized shallots, garlic and mashed potatoes; lamb stew with curry accompanied with couscous; and pepper linguine pasta tossed with prosciutto, mushrooms and Marsala sauce. Desserts include a chocolate marquise with sabayon, and a warm thin-crusted apple tart.
Appetizers range from $4.50 to $6.50; entrees $12.50 to $16.50; desserts $4.50 to $6. Sunday hours are from noon to 11 P.M. (Review, Dec. 2, 1988).
 
 
Symphony Cafe
 950 Eighth Avenue, at 56th Street, in Manhattan, (212) 397-9595 -- On the ground level of the Symphony House apartment complex at 56th Street near Eighth Avenue, this grand expanse was designed by Jeffrey Beers, who also created China Grill in the CBS building on the Avenue of the Americas. Symphony Cafe is similarly colossal in scale, yet unlike the marmoreal and glacial China Grill, it extends warmth and a sense of neighborhood congeniality. The unpretentious menu and relatively moderate prices have made it a popular spot.
To begin there are braised snails with wild mushrooms; salad of greens with toasted goat cheese; duckling crepe with raisin sauce; and grilled shrimp with mustard sauce. Starting from the top on the main course selection is a knockout roast chicken with mashed potatoes; a New York strip steak with shoe-string potatoes; pan-seared salmon is garnished with golden globules of salmon roe and moistened with a basil butter sauce, and lamb chops come with a port wine sauce. Among desserts are warm apple tart with ice cream, and creme brulee.
Appetizers range from $4 to $9; main courses $14.50 to $25; desserts $4.50 to $5.50. Sunday dinner is 3 P.M. to 9 P.M.. A $15.95 prix-fixe brunch menu is served from noon to 3:30 P.M. (Review, April 7, 1989; Article, Oct. 19, 1990).
 
 
Voulez-Vous
 1462 First Avenue, at 76th Street, in Manhattan, (212) 249-1776 -- The glass-fronted contemporary dining room, at this moderately priced French bistro, gives scant hint of the rustic fare within. It is comfortable and mercifully muted by sound tile and has tinted-mirror walls, stout cushioned chairs and a sleek bar in the back. Jacques Rameckers, the genial owner, is a no-nonsense host who keeps tabs on his young, earnest staff.
Appetizers include the French staple, saucisson chaud, or garlicky country sausage; smoked herring with potato salad; brandade de morue, the garlicky codfish-potato puree; and French onion soup. For main courses there are cassoulet; a seafood choucroute with smoked salmon, trout, sturgeon, scallops and haddock; grilled salmon with a light lemony sauce and a concasse of tomato and cucumber, and coq-au-vin served with steamed potatoes and vegetables. Among desserts are profiterolles, and cappuccino frozen souffle.
Appetizers range from $4.75 to $6.75; entrees $14.50 to $18.95; desserts are $6.25 each. Sunday dinner service is from 4 P.M. to midnight. A $12.45 prix-fixe brunch menu is served from 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. (Review, Feb. 12, 1988; Article, Oct. 19, 1990).
This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

HEADLINE: Keeping the Government Out of Housing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The suggestion ("How to Revive Housing Starts," Forum, Sept. 22) that states assist home buyers by underwriting "low-interest loans" to people whose income falls below some figure is unwise. The Government already offers a sizable subsidy to homeowners who write off the interest expense of their mortgages. If the Government didn't allow this, the Internal Revenue Service would have collected more money to reduce the Federal budget deficit. And if state governments took the risk of exposing their finances to potential default and foreclosure costs, taxpayers would have to be called upon to provide a bailout. 
 It is about time politicians and consultants realize that the American taxpayer is tired of being called to pay the cost of "neat ideas" invented by those who think they know what is best for the country. The remark by the author, Charles Lockwood, that state-sponsored homeownership would prevent the American republic from becoming one that is "a two-class nation of homeowners and non-homeowners," is a classic example of socialist talk that appeals to the human heart without being analyzed by the head.
 
ABDUL RAHMAN ABDI
Greenbelt, Md., Sept. 22

HEADLINE: Yankees and Mets: The Forecast;
Harazin Aiming to Put A Stop to the Hurting

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Al Harazin, asked recently if he didn't feel he would be dealing from a hurting hand in the great baseball card game of off-season trades, smiled.
 "Probably," said Harazin, who will take over as general manager of the Mets on Monday. 
Asked his strategy, Harazin said, "Add more chips."
 Is this a bluff?
 The public gets to call Harazin on it as soon as the last out is made Sunday afternoon against the Phillies at Veterans Stadium and the curtain drops on the Mets' 1991 season. It began with the cynical premise that the Mets could lose Darryl Strawberry for nothing and be better off and ended with a front-office realignment, the firing of a manager and the rank residue of the club's first losing record since 1983.
 In comments that reflected a healthy break from the parsimony and personal ill will that colored Frank Cashen's sunset seasons, Harazin implied broadly that he disagreed with the former general manager's belief that the team possessed a competitively competent core of talent. And he hinted loudly that he would be more prepared to spend dollars to restructure and reoutfit the Mets.
 "Don't assume anything," he said. "Don't assume anything."
 Sorry, Al, it can't be resisted.
 What follows are a lot of assumptions -- first, about what the Mets, who lost yesterday to the Phillies, 1-0, can be expected to do before next season, and, second, about what the Mets should do to arrest a slide into even earlier summer irrelevance in 1992.
 
Look for This to Happen
 Dallas Green to Be Named Manager: The lock has become a long shot of late, with the prevailing theory being that Harazin would not want the threat Green may pose. Jeff Torborg may well bail out of Chicago and return to New York, but he has got as good a chance of landing with the Yankees as the Mets. The appointment of Mike Cubbage, the interim manager, would be a respectable and honorable decision, but it won't happen. Tom Trebelhorn, if removed in Milwaukee, would be likely to impress Harazin. But as a pure hunch, Green, without the job options he thought he would have, will become the intriguing option Harazin chooses.
 The Mets to Talk Seriously to Frank Viola: The negotiations -- and there is a chance they will be short and sour -- can be seen as absolutely vital to Harazin's entire poker game.
 The signing of Viola, which would on a practical level afford the Mets reliable innings pitched, could more importantly impress and maybe convince other interested free agents. A commodity like Bobby Bonilla will have clubs lining up as suitors, but after playing on a team that won consecutive NationalLeague East titles, he could interpret harshly an organization that allows Strawberry and Viola to walk without compensation in back-to-back off seasons.
Because of the uncertain physical future of Dwight Gooden and arguably because of Cashen's departure, the Mets appear more inclined to labor hard in negotiating with Viola. Gerry Hunsicker, the baseball brains alongside Harazin and not a charter member of the Viola fan club, has sounded conciliatory toward Viola of late and will no doubt try and sound convincing to Harazin when he underscores the indisputable value the left-hander represents.
 A failure to close a deal -- Viola's probable insistence on four years could scotch the talks quickly -- would make mandatory a major trade for a pitcher or the more economical but multiple signings of, say, Mike Morgan and Tom Candiotti.
 The Mets to Take a Real Run at Signing Bonilla: Bonilla, according to a source with the Pirates, has said he is genuinely intrigued by the idea of joining the Mets. He understands that the runaway assumption is that the Yankees want him more and will open their wallets wider, but he smiles at the kind of fit he might enjoy with the Mets and is perfectly agreeable to playing first base. The Mets, if reluctant to pay $5 million a year for a short-term deal, might lure Bonilla with added years at a lesser rate.
 The Mets to Find Out There Is No Market for Vince Coleman or Kevin McReynolds: The realization that the Mets overpaid at overextended terms a one-dimensional outfielder in Coleman and a left fielder in a multidimensional decline in McReynolds will have been made by others even if the Mets can't seem to come to it themselves. The burdensome contracts (three years at, $10 million for McReynolds; three years at roughly $9 million for Coleman) make a possible blockbuster trade less likely.
 Hang On to Gregg Jefferies: It will break the hearts of his detractors among Mets fans and the hearts of more than a handful of his teammates, but the team in all probability won't trade Jefferies. Harazin might be bold with the bucks in the free-agent market, but probably won't have the daring, in his rookie season as general manager, to trade the franchise's long promoted but slow to mature infielder.
 Howard Johnson Will Remain With the Mets and in Right Field, and Will Do a Good Impression of Hubie Brooks There: Asked who, if anyone was an untouchable on the Mets, Harazin said the names Gooden and Johnson. Enough said. Of course, enough can never be said to the Mets to convince them of the value of defense, and so there will be leads lost and games imperiled in 1992 by Johnson's miscues in right field, just as there were dark laughs galore in 1991 at the team's ghastly glovework.
 The Mets Will Make More Minor Moves Than Major Ones: Harazin, who is likely to be ill-equipped to be imaginatively shrewd, will be busy nonetheless. Mark Carreon could be traded, an able and veteran infielder like Oakland's free agent, Mike Gallego, might be signed, and a pitcher with health as his most glamorous aspect -- Kirk McCaskill? -- could be added.
 
Wish for This to Happen
 The Mets to Retain Viola: Keep him to three years and pay him what it takes. Credibility as much as cash is at question, and of course the two are linked when it comes to ticket sales for coming seasons. A rotation of David Cone, Sid Fernandez, Pete Schourek, Anthony Young and Wally Whitehurst for the start of 1992 won't have folks storming the turnstiles.
 The Mets to Sign Glenn Davis: A gamble of probably enormous proportions, but with the Orioles reportedly offering only a one-year deal for the first baseman who missed much of the season with a serious neck injury, the Mets might acquire him as a relative bargain if they were to offer him a multiyear package. If the Mets are convinced that Davis's physical liabilities are too considerable, then they should make every effort and pay every dollar to sign Wally Joyner of the Angels.
 The Mets to Sign Steve Buechele: Perhaps this would be falling victim to the sin of being seduced by a solid player having an extraordinary season as he campaigns for the contract to end his financial concerns forever. But it would be acquiring an unquestioned defensive plus -- not a silly notion if John Franco is going to be your closer -- with more pop in his bat that had been thought. It might allow the Mets to do the following.
 Trade Gregg Jefferies: One general manager has said teams would step on and over each other to snatch Jefferies and supposedly reap the benefits of a talent pent up because of the pressures of New York. Take all offers, take them seriously, exploit them by playing them off each other, enlarge them by offering to include Magadan in the mix. See if San Diego's catcher, Benito Santiago, can be obtained. The operating doctrine here is not to fret about what kind of player Jefferies becomes elsewhere. It's immaterial. The mistake would be in receiving too little value in return.
 The Mets Hire Cubbage as Manager: The fear that Cubbage, an organization man with no experience at the major league level, would suffer the fate of Harrelson is a fear founded in ignorance. Either Harazin can judge what Cubbage is as a man and manager or he can't. Either he is the next Harrelson or maybe, just maybe, the next Jim Leyland. Make up your mind and act without regard for a payoff in marquee value. Intelligence is the single greatest characteristic a manager can have in New York, and Cubbage's intellect is luminous.

HEADLINE: An Economic Forecast: Clouds but Some Sun

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
ONCE a year, the mountain comes to Mohammed. That is when well-known forecasters appear in Westchester to discuss the economy of the region at the yearly fall symposium sponsored by three of the county's leading business groups: the Westchester County Association, the Westchester County Bankers Association and the Westchester Business Partnership.
"We in Westchester are in danger of becoming too insular and talking only to one another," S. J. Schulman told an audience of 125 business and community leaders at the Rye Town Hilton at this year's meeting, on Sept. 27. "We need to hear other voices, like those of Richard Ravitch, former Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman and chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, and Rosemary Scanlon, the chief economist for the Port Authority, to tell us about the region's economy and what we can expect for Westchester." 
 The symposium's participants conceded that with few exceptions, the economic problems facing Westchester were not much different from those facing Manhattan, New Jersey and Connecticut. But government, Mr. Ravitch and Ms. Scanlon said, isn't doing its part to battle the recession.
The Federal jobs program and funds for public works projects that were successfully used to fight recessions in the mid-1970's, they said, are lacking in the current downturn. "We had the CETA jobs program then; we have nothing now," Ms. Scanlon said.
Public Works Are Urged
"We need a strong state fiscal policy to help local governments," said Mr. Ravitch. "The city and state are linked together like Siamese twins." Both Ms. Scanlon and Mr. Ravitch urged state and local governments to make funds available for public works projects.
"The existing infrastructure is our greatest anchor to windward," Mr. Ravitch said, "yet the maintenance of the infrastructure is the first thing officials cut back. Why? Because nobody sees it, and nobody complains. And that is a serious mistake. Funding for public works should be increased, not cut, during a recession. In that way we can build our way out of the current mess and in doing so, create jobs."
Saying that lower real estate prices will mean opportunities in the real estate market for new investors, Mr. Ravitch chided officials in New York City for not taking the current drop in real estate values into consideration in the city's own budget projections.
Most banks in Westchester, said James J. McDermott Jr., a symposium participant, are doing fairly well because they have the capital to ride out the storm.
 
Optimism on Westchester Banks
 "We're in pretty decent shape compared to those in Connecticut, where many are in deep trouble," said Mr. McDermott, who is the president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, an investment banking and brokerage firm.
Bank consolidation this year has brought with it signs of stabilization, he said. "By combining forces, the banks bought a ticket out of recession. Such high-expense items as duplicate software systems and overlapping branches are being eliminated with the beneficial cost savings."
And there is cause for future optimism in the banking community, Mr. McDermott said, because, unlike a year ago, capital markets today are showing interest in good banks.
The healthy savings and loans are prospering, he said. "Yet I don't want to raise expectations too high. The banks have the tools they need to get out of trouble, and while there are many fine community banks around, the thrift crisis is still episodic. Outbreaks will continue to occur."
 
Problems in Insurance Field
 In addressing the problems of the insurance industry, Robert H. Vatter, vice president and economist of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in Manhattan, said that excess investment in junk bonds and real estate, plus sloppy writing of investment contracts, has hurt the insurance industry, which was already troubled by cash-flow problems when new business dried up.
"Currently, our industry is under a microscope, suffering from cultural shock," Mr. Vatter said. "At present, there are 2,300 life insurance companies in the United States. Some won't survive; others will merge." Consolidation will benefit the consumer, Mr. Vatter said, adding that one negative factor is the strong possibility of foreign companies buying American insurance companies.
Insurance companies can also expect increased competition from banks and brokerage firms, Mr. Vatter said. "However, the more complex the product, the less likely the competition," he added.
 
Unemployment Is Up
 Ms. Scanlon said unemployment in New York City is running ahead of the national average for the first time, and unemployment in Westchester is also up, which signifies a change from the low unemployment rate the county has enjoyed in recent years. During the first six months of this year, Ms. Scanlon said, the 17-county region of northern New Jersey and the New York City area lost 165,000 jobs.
"And what is equally disturbing is the lack of office starts and residential starts in the region," she said. "There were only 20,000 residential building permits issued for the 17 counties this year, and zero office-building contracts."
Nor was there any significant investment made in the infrastructure of the region, she said, adding, "Retail sales were also off, reflecting the pain in this recession."
The good news?
It is the downward slide of interest rates, Ms. Scanlon said. "Mortgage rates are lower so housing sales are beginning to pick up," she said, "and low interest rates encourage new construction. We've gained back competitiveness with other regions."
Yet, Mr. Vatter said, insurance jobs are being phased out of Manhattan because of the high cost of doing business there.
 
High Costs Hobble the County
 When asked if Westchester might realize a gain in jobs from insurance companies that would be moving their back office operations to the county, Mr. Vatter said: "No. In Westchester, the cost of housing and labor is too high. And there is congestion on roads like Route 287 to contend with. The insurance companies are setting up their back offices in places like Rensselaer, N.Y., and Wichita, Kan."
Ms. Scanlon said she sees signs of a slow recovery.
"Although the national economy is at a very uneven, rocky and uncertain point," she said, "it is under way. As for the future of the region, encouraging signs are evidenced by a small pickup in employment on Wall Street this summer and international aspects on the region's economy are hopeful.
But Mr. Ravitch said the recession is so deep that it will take years, possibly as many as five, before the economy rights itself. "Sixty million square feet of office space stands vacant in Manhattan, and yet to this day the city of New York projects an increase in asset value when the tax base has actually been decreased. I am staggered by the failure of government to deal with declining revenues in a good way."
Mr. Ravitch said he has cause for optimism. "Judging from the steady flow of new immigrants into the city, New York still offers opportunities to people from all over the world," he said. "Hundreds of them are successfully running small businesses here. And in doing so, they are revitalizing the city and keeping employment as high as it has been. The value of property in Chinatown and parts of Brooklyn and Queens, where the new immigrants have settled, has gone up, generating additional revenues."
