SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1; Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1249 words

HEADLINE: State Officials Draw Fire For Delays On Housing

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
HOUSING advocates across Connecticut say they are dismayed by the dismantling of the state's housing programs. Millions of dollars have been cut from the budgets of programs to develop low-cost housing, effectively gutting them, and some programs have been eliminated entirely. And critics contend that state officials have largely ignored groups that, by statute, are supposed to provide recommendations on housing policy.
A spokeswoman for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Michele Sullivan, said the problem is timing. The Governor has been busy with a budget crisis, she said. But Lisl Standen of Kent, a member of the state's Central Housing Committee for more than 10 years and its chairwoman for 6 years, recently stepped down, saying that the board -- established to advise the State Housing Department, the legislature and the Governor -- has been ignored. 
 State officials "don't want anything to be done," Ms. Standen said. "They have no philosophy, no plan, and they are not interested in developing one." Ms. Standen and others cited not only severe cuts to housing programs but also an apparent lack of interest in housing matters. "If the committee is not being listened to, either by the Governor or the Department of Housing, what's the point?" asked Marvin Farbman, a committee member and head of the Connecticut Legal Services Statewide Housing Unit. "By statute it's supposed to be providing advice on policy matters. But if the thing isn't working for Lisl, there's a problem as far as I'm concerned.
"With her leaving, I'm going to have to see if it makes sense for me to stay."
Margaret P. Reich, executive director of the Windham Regional Planning Agency, said the Governor's office still has not appointed a chairman to the Windham Region Housing Council, despite repeated requests. But under state law, only the chairman, appointed by the Governor, can convene a meeting. The law allows the council to apply for money to cover its secretarial and postage costs, but the request for funds must be approved at a meeting. And without a chairman there can be no meeting.
"So here we sit, without a regional housing council, without the ability to get the money to help us with secretarial costs, and a lot of housing things are happening in the region," Ms. Reich said.
 
'When Things Begin to Settle Down'
 Ms. Sullivan said: "We are currently looking for qualified candidates to fill the positions as soon as possible. But there has been no one chosen yet." The Governor and Housing Commissioner Henry S. Scherer Jr. "are very committed to housing," she said. "But all of state government is in a state of change at this point, and it may be something we have to look at later, when things begin to settle down."
Mr. Scherer, through his spokesman, Christopher Cooper, released a statement that said Ms. Standen's resignation was "a loss to the housing community."
Mr. Cooper said that while the Commissioner did not directly address Ms. Standen's charges that the committee is being frustrated in efforts to advance a housing policy, "from my own perspective, any time there is a change in administration, there is a period of transition."
He continued, "Sometimes, as efforts are under way to make sure the structure and laws and regulations are in the best possible form to facilitate, things can appear to be not moving forward as ambitiously as some people might hope."
Ms. Sullivan said the recent loans approved by the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority for the Ninth Square development in New Haven, which will have a large housing component, is evidence of the Governor's backing for housing, particularly in areas where low-cost housing is a pressing need.
That project, though, seems not to have satisfied many critics of the administration.
"We're still waiting for the administration to define its housing policy," said Jeffrey Freiser, executive director of the Connecticut Housing Coalition, which has 250 members, primarily nonprofit housing-development agencies. "Housing has been dealt a severe blow right from the start of this Governor's term. Housing did not seem to be a priority of the new administration. We were very disappointed, for instance, to see severe budget cuts in the Governor's recommendations for bonding for affordable housing."
The state's allocation to build such housing dropped to $53 million in the current fiscal year from $94 million in the previous year. Another $580,000 for the administrative costs of nonprofit housing agencies was eliminated altogether, Mr. Freiser said.
 
Rent Aid Cut in Half
 "Those groups are the only ones building housing for low-income families right now, and the grants that helped them keep the lights on and the doors open are gone," he said. "I don't know of any that have closed yet. But most of them have cut staff, and are just barely holding on."
A state program to forestall evictions was cut to $550,000 from $1.2 million at a time when unemployment is growing, and more people will need it, Mr. Freiser said, and a program to pay the rent for people in a temporary crisis has been halved, to $1 million.
Ms. Standen said she stepped down from her post reluctantly and after long deliberation. She testified on more than 30 housing bills before the legislature this year, worked with the legislative committees and was active in establishing housing policy, she said, but the executive branch has been moving slowly.
Ms. Standen, appointed by Mr. Weicker's predecessor, William A. O'Neill, said she had agreed in April to stay on after the new Governor's election but resigned last month after months of frustration.
In recent years the commissioner of housing has attended Central Housing Committee meetings, Ms. Standen said. But since Mr. Scherer took over, he has sent his deputy to a couple of meetings, never coming himself.
"It helped the morale of the committee when the Commissioner attended," Ms. Standen said. "People wanted to work because they felt they were appreciated."
Ms. Standen said the Commissioner asked the committee to select a member for a task force on housing but ignored the recommendation and chose his own appointee. He also did not provide any staff to help coordinate the annual housing conference traditionally sponsored by the Department of Housing and planned by the committee, so the conference will not take place.
"I think this committee could really help to ameliorate the affordable-housing shortage in the state," Ms. Standen said. "But it needs the backing of the state. There ought to be public discussion about the policy of the department -- about where they ought to be going."
 
'I Can Still Serve'
 Nancy C. Brown, executive director of the Greenwich Community Development Agency and a 10-year member of the central committee, has also resigned from her seat.
"I'm not as close to the problem as Lisl is, but I certainly sense that the administration has not put things to do with housing at the forefront," Ms. Brown said. "But I can still serve the state, and its housing program, through my other positions. I'm on the board of the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority, for instance."
Mr. Freiser, meanwhile, said the coalition of housing agencies has recently been working with Mr. Scherer and is hopeful that there might be progress soon.
"At this point, nine months into the administration, we wish there was more good news to report," Mr. Freiser said. "But we're not ready to give up yet."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: DR. MARK R. CULLEN;
The Evolution of Occupational Health

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
DR. MARK R. CULLEN, director of the Center for Occupational and Environmental Medicine at Yale University, is also the author or co-author of more than 50 articles and editorials on the effects of job-related stress and exposure to asbestos, lead, oil and solvents.
These occupational diseases have received wider attention recently because of the publication of a study by the State Workers Compensation Commission that concluded that between 750 and 1,700 workers in Connecticut died of such diseases in 1988, the most recent year for which data could be compiled. In a recent interview at his office in New Haven, Dr. Cullen discussed occupational health. Here are some excerpts from the conversation. 
 Q. What are occupational diseases?
 A. It's important for people to realize when we talk about occupational diseases, we're not talking about a lot of diseases with strange names. We're talking about lung cancer, dermatitis, asthma, hepatitis, renal failure. We're talking about diseases that already have names, that don't sound occupational related. Lead poisoning sounds like an occupational disease. Asbestosis sounds like an occupational disease.
But most of them don't sound like occupational disease, and there's nothing about the name of the diagnosis that will separate a case of lung cancer in a retired 65-year-old chemical worker from a case in a grandmother who never worked outside the house.
Q. What are two or three of the most serious occupational hazards now in Connecticut?
A. The question is hard to answer, because there are a variety of diseases that are incredibly serious that aren't very common, thank God. We're starting to see the decline of asbestos diseases, or at least as many as we did 10 years ago. We don't see a lot of cases of lead poisoning from industry.
On the other hand, we're starting to see an enormous rise and a whole wave of occupational health problems that, from an economic point of view, may be incredibly important: for example, cumulative trauma disorder, problems caused by repetitive forceful motions at work, and disorders related to indoor air quality, so-called sick-building syndrome.
There's a tremendous risk of disease now in the health-care industry. As the classic industrial diseases start to wane a little bit, we're starting to see a whole new range of illnesses of technology. I think occupational health problems are no less prevalent than they were 10 years ago, but the spectrum of them is beginning to change.
Q. How responsive has the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration been to new trends in occupational medicine?
A. I think you have to understand the history of OSHA. In the late 1960's there were a couple of big mining disasters. You had some increases in the power of labor, and it finally got some national strategy for control of work-related disease. If doctors' textbooks said, in the 1960's, that there was no occupational disease, you couldn't tell that to an auto worker or a machinist or a chemical worker. It was no secret in occupational circles.
So Congress came up with a policing strategy that said, if you use chemical X, Y or Z, or machine X, Y or Z, you're going to have to follow certain rules. It was a tremendously effective strategy, in that over a decade many serious hazards came under control.
If high exposure to chemicals was reduced, you could bet that even though there were some violators, you'd have fewer problems, and you did, much as how, by having lower speed limits, you have fewer car accidents. But you don't get rid of all of it, and there are a lot of reasons for that. There are violators -- people still drink and drive, to use the analogy. Some had to do with the fact the rules were lousy and couldn't change fast enough. And some had to do with the fact the whole strategy was inherently limited, and some occupational health problems would not yield to that strategy.
OSHA has been very effective at doing what it was supposed to do. Could it have been better? Of course, if you tripled its budget and took out some of the political tampering. And without it we'd be dead in the water. But as a single strategy it was doomed to be limited, much as all the traffic rules in the world are not going to stop all fatalities. You need driver education and other strategies, the kind of things we're doing now in occupational health.
Q. Connecticut is moving rapidly toward a service economy. Do service-sector jobs have fewer occupational hazards?
A. Not fewer. Certainly, using the normal measures a public health person would use, morbidity and mortality, they are less serious. You can never meaningfully equate black lung with carpal-tunnel syndrome. Even though the rate of health problems might be comparable, the severity is obviously quite different. As we move to a service economy, the mortality will drop. But I feel like I will, unfortunately, be in business for a long, long time.
Q. How can we say which cancers, for instance, are job related, and not the result of life style, such as smoking?
A. The way we really answer those questions is wearing our public health hat. We don't ask, "Did Mr. Smith get his bladder cancer from his work in the dye manufacturing plant, or did he get it from smoking or from his alcohol consumption?" We know all three of those are risk factors.
What we do is look at the pattern of disease in a dye manufacturing plant and compare it with the incidence of disease in other industries. If people in that industry are dying at a rate three or five or eight times people in other jobs, who drink as much and smoke as much, we can say X percent of those bladder cancers are what we call "excess cases."
Q. With liability lawsuits being brought, is there more of an economic incentive to make the workplace safer?
A. Sure there is. With OSHA, it serves as a reminder to people that if they're making chemicals in 1991 that cause cancer, someday they may have to pay for that. To the extent that our legal system is designed to assign value to certain injuries, you bet it provides an incentive.
Unfortunately, the insurance industry, to some extent, blunts that. By collectivizing risk, insurance reduces the incentive of any individual to reduce their risk. If you didn't have car insurance, you'd drive real carefully.
Q. Is there a risk that some occupational disorders become popular and overdiagnosed?
A. Yes, there are certainly fads in environmental and occupational medicine, as there are in other areas of medicine. Part of it is catch-up from years of neglect. When we first started looking at the problems of repetitive trauma at the shipyard in Groton, the first observations were made by two area orthopedic surgeons who came to us, who had done hundreds of carpal-tunnel surgeries, and the men were not getting better. What was happening was people were going out and getting this surgery but not talking about it.
Now the pendulum swings too far. Now that we know carpal-tunnel strains are common among people who work at keyboards all day long, people are looking at themselves and their threshold for complaint is lower, and the incidence has quintupled in the last three years. There are a lot of people with relatively minor complaints who would never have sought medical treatment before who ask themselves, "Do I have the dreaded carpal-tunnel disorder?"
Relatively minor aches and pains of life are now being glamourized as cumulative-trauma disorders. But that, too, will find its norm. The most important consequence of the attention is people are paying more attention to work conditions, which is great, and people are stopping getting unnecessary surgery. Those two things alone will in the long run save society zillions of dollars.
Q. Speaking of the economics of occupational disorders, has anyone ever calculated what it is costing industry in lost productivity?
A. It's difficult to calculate. For many of these problems, such as chemical allergies or cumulative trauma disorder, there are no deaths to count. If you got the chief executive of a large company with a few drinks and honest, he'd say it's a cost of doing business, some people are going to be sick, and we're going to have an explosion or two. But this is a cost of doing business that may not have been counted on. We have a work force that is nonproductive, or underproductive, to some extent because of environmental factors that could be easily remedied. The usual way is to take the direct medical costs and the time lost from work. Those might be considerable underestimates if people in an office building are working at 30 percent below their potential productivity.
Q. Your clinic recently documented high levels of lead poisoning in workers who are scraping paint off bridges that were painted with lead paint. Given what we know about lead, how could that have happened?
A. There are vast segments of our professional society where you would expect there would be a high level of knowledge. For example, architects you would think would know about building materials and ventilation, but they have historically been taught nothing about the environment. Businessmen historically get no training in the environment. The people who are in decision-making capacities, such as contractors, have no specialized training. Where are they going to get this expertise?
And it is difficult to regulate. You can reduce lead levels in a factory, and draw blood samples to make sure the exposure limits are working. But if you have contractors working on a bridge, you've got guys working five days then go on to another contract, or you've got exposure conditions changing every 10 minutes. You can't have an inspector come in once a year to check on conditions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Mark R. Cullen is director of the Center for Occupational and Environmental Medicine at Yale University. (Bill Burkhart)

HEADLINE: Shore Communities Assess Implications Of L.I. Sound Study

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
UNTIL recently, 1991 looked as if it would be a good year for the Long Island Sound. In August, Hurricane Bob wreaked havoc on land but was seen as a blessing for the 1,300-square-mile estuary. The storm stirred up the normally stratified layers in the narrow body of water, infusing them with oxygen and preventing the algae blooms, fish kills and other problems of previous summers.
But now there are disturbing reports from divers who are discovering lobsters and blue crabs dying on the Sound's floor off the Westchester shoreline. Their findings have scientists wondering whether these recent marine-life deaths are yet another symptom of the severe degradation of water quality in the Sound, or merely a separate and less-serious problem, perhaps just the aftereffects of an unusually long period of warm weather. 
 While marine biologists try to track down the immediate cause of the crustaceans' deaths, national, state and local officials are looking at the long-range picture: trying to understand the implications of a Federally financed study, released in early September, on methods for improving the health of Sound.
 
Nitrogen From Sewage Plants Is Cited
 The report, published by the Long Island Sound Study, identifies five problem areas: low dissolved oxygen, toxic contamination, pathogens, floatable debris and the health of living marine resources.
Initial data from the six-year, $5 million project -- paid for by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency -- indicate that hypoxia, a condition resulting from low levels of dissolved oxygen, is the most pressing problem affecting the estuary and "warrants immediate management action."
The interim management report identifies nitrogen, which enters the Sound from sewage-treatment plants and other sources, as the primary contributor to the low oxygen levels.
Hypoxia, scientists say, occurs when excessive amounts of nitrogen act as fertilizer for algae blooms. As the algae die, sink to the bottom of the Sound and further decompose, oxygen in the lower layers of the water is depleted.
And because the layers of the Sound tend to stratify during the summer months, new oxygen is often unable to reach the colder waters on the bottom. During hypoxic events, free-swimming organisms flee oxygen-depleted waters, while slow-moving crustaceans that live along the floor are unable to migrate and often die.
Using 1990 as a reference point, the Long Island Sound Study's four-member policy committee voted unanimously on Sept. 6 to begin taking steps to cap the amount of nitrogen flowing into the Sound from what it called "point sources," namely sewage-treatment plants.
The policy committee members include Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, administrator of Environmental Protection Agency's New York Region; Julie Belaga, administrator for the Federal agency's New England office; Timothy Keeney, Commissioner of Connecticut's Department of Environmental Protection, and Robert Bendick, deputy commissioner for New York's Department of Environmental Conservation.
"We don't know yet how much nitrogen has to be removed to get the desired result," said Richard L. Caste, director of water management for the Environmental Protection Agency's New York office. "But for now, we've decided no more increases. Let's not allow the problem to get worse. We have to draw a line somewhere while we figure out how to solve the problem in the long run."
Implementing the recommendations of the Long Island Sound Study report for no net gain in nitrogen could prove costly. It may also mean a state-imposed building moratorium that representatives of the construction industry say will sound the death knell for businesses already debilitated by the current economy.
 
Upgrading to Cost $440 Million
 In Westchester, a nitrogen freeze would entail upgrading four waste-water treatment plants that feed into the Sound, at a cost of $440 million, said Adam J. Zabinsky, director of waste-water treatment for the county.
Of the four sewage plants, only one, the Blind Brook Waste Water Treatment Plant in Rye, is operating below capacity and could handle additional sewage. Although it is not now eliminating nitrogen, the Blind Brook plant could be retrofitted to do so at a cost of less than $200,000, Mr. Zabinsky said. The other plants -- in Mamaroneck, New Rochelle and Port Chester -- would require expensive construction to comply with the Sound study's no-net-gain policy.
"We're hoping for funding from the Federal Government," Mr. Zabinsky said. "But there may be no grant money. If there isn't, we're talking about a mind-boggling number."
If taxpayers in the four sewer districts, which serve Scarsdale, Rye, Larchmont, Mamaroneck, New Rochelle, Port Chester and parts of Harrison and White Plains, have to bear the costs of retrofitting and upgrading, it could mean a 300-fold increase in local sewer district taxes, Mr. Zabinski said.
While County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke agreed with the need to institute measures to clean up the Sound, he questioned why the policy committee did not pass restrictions on other sources of nitrogen entering the estuary, like water from storm drains illegally hooked up to sewer lines and runoff from golf courses that use herbicides.
Also, Mr. O'Rourke said he did not support a building ban, calling it a "Draconian measure."
If a building moratorium is imposed, the construction industry "would effectively be shut down," said Ross J. Pepe, president of the Construction Industry Council of Westchester and Hudson Valley.
"It couldn't come at a worse time," Mr. Pepe said. "The likelihood of our industry pulling out of its current slump is difficult to foresee with this action before us. We have a number of projects on the books ready to go. If a building moratorium goes into effect, we're dead."
 
Port Chester Mayor Opposes Ban
 In the village of Port Chester, Mayor Peter Iasillo predicted that a building ban would "virtually kill the city." Port Chester, he said, is in the process of developing a $250 million waterfront project.
"We need the ratables," Mr. Iasillo said. "A building moratorium isn't the answer. The problems with the Sound already exist. Meanwhile, we need to develop our shoreline."
A different note was sounded in Albany by Philip M. DeGaetano, director of water-quality management for the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
A building moratorium may not be imposed, he said. And the state may be able to provide some money for upgrading waste-water treatment plants through a Federal loan program.
Moreover, retrofitting and upgrading sewage plants may not be as expensive as some claim, Mr. DeGaetano said.
"There is a lot of overreacting going on," he added. "Necessity is the mother of invention. And when push comes to shove, people can get pretty ingenious and find cheaper ways of accomplishing things. We have to find the best mix of solutions."
 
'The Sound Is in a State of Collapse'
 From an environmentalist's point of view, however, a nitrogen freeze would not begin to solve the problems of Long Island Sound.
"These guys live in political la-la land asking for a no net increase when the Sound is in a state of collapse," said Long Island Soundkeeper Terry Backer.
"They're crazy," said Mr. Backer, who is employed by the Soundkeeper Fund, a 1,000-member activist organization based in Norwalk. "How I read it is that they're saying the current state of the Sound is O.K. But it isn't. We've added so many nutrients that we've driven the natural system completely out of balance."
"The symptoms of the Sound's pollution may have been less evident this year, but essentially nothing has changed," Mr. Backer said. "We're still getting cases of dead lobsters."
 
Seeking Cause of Lobsters' Deaths
 Marine biologists from New York's Department of Environmental Conservation and Connecticut's Department of Environmental Protection are coordinating efforts to find the cause of death of the lobsters in the western waters of the Sound off Westchester's shoreline.
Mark Blake, marine fisheries biologist for Connecticut, said the dead lobsters were being tested for an infection known as gaffkemia. The rod-shaped bacteria are always present in the water, but lobsters and crabs can become infected if their resistance is down, Mr. Blake said.
"We really don't know why this is happening," he said. "But we're not raising any alarm now because not all of the lobster population is infected."
 
Record Years for Lobster Fishing
 Since the hurricane, there have been no hypoxic events in the Sound, and it is unlikely that the deaths are related to the larger problems of the Sound, especially since 1990 and 1991 were record years for lobster fishing, Mr. Blake said.
"It could be that the Sound got warm very early this year and stayed warm later than usual," he said. "Maybe the lobsters' resistance was down because of the weather. And perhaps there's a more virulent strain of the gaffkemia bacteria out there. Frankly, at this point, we have more questions than answers."
While officials digest the first set of data from the Sound study's interim report, the final Long Island Sound Study report is being prepared and is to be released in November next year. It is expected to include a comprehensive conservation and management plan for the Sound, which has been designated an estuary of national significance under the Federal Clean Water Act.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A recent report on improving the Sound's water quality focused on low oxygen levels and nitrogen from sewage treatment plants. (Elsa Brenner)

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Getting Help for Cases For 'Telephonophobia'

BYLINE: by Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
After 25 years in the finance industry -- including a decade as senior vice president of a major bank -- a graying, distinguished-looking New Yorker recently found himself out of work, the victim of a corporate "downsizing." Now he spends his days reading trade periodicals, revising his resume and writing letters to potential employers. He doesn't mind such job-hunting activities, with one exception: making his daily round of phone calls.
"It's awkward to call somebody you've been out of touch with for a long time and explain your situation," said the banker, who asked that he not be identified. "You think, 'maybe I should have called three months ago, when this first happened.' You don't know how to talk about it with former colleagues; you want help, not sympathy." 
 The out-of-work banker is not alone in his reluctance to use the telephone. Career counselors, corporate psychologists and outplacement advisers report a growing epidemic of "telephonophobia," the fear of making tough phone calls in tough times. This particularly strikes executives accustomed to granting favors -- job offers, say, or informational interviews -- rather than asking for them.
"When these people had jobs, everyone returned their calls right away," said Kate Wendleton, director of the Career Center at the New School for Social Research in New York. "Now they may have to make 10 calls before somebody speaks to them. It can be quite discouraging if they don't manage their expectations properly."
Ann Marie Sabath, president of At Ease Inc., a Cincinnati-based executive consulting firm, notes a rising demand for "phonogenic" training. "Many executives haven't learned to handle themselves properly on the phone," she said. "They aren't aware of how to create a good impression, which can make networking calls more difficult."
Executives used to making multimillion-dollar decisions in a snap often contract the worst cases of telephone phobia.
"They can't stand calling their peers to ask for help," said Dick Beston, a senior vice president at Drake Beam Morin, the international outplacement firm based in New York. "They have the best contacts, but they aren't willing to use them. They're the ones who've been victimized as never before by this recession."
Thus, on a late September morning, the unemployed banker gathered with two dozen laid-off executives in Drake Beam Morin's mid-Manhattan offices for a seminar on phone phobia. The leader, Ted Fuller, chief operating officer of Communispond, a New York-based communications consulting firm whose clients include General Motors, American Express and Time-Warner, rattled off the three cures for telephone phobia: The afflicted had to become better speakers, develop a positive attitude and follow a disciplined routine. For high-level executives -- who often come equipped with good speaking skills -- the latter measures are key.
"Many executives can make presentations before hundreds of people, but they can't pick up the phone and ask for a simple favor," he said. "They're used to being in the driver's seat, not the passenger seat."
Indeed, his audience offered a variety of excuses for avoiding calls. One retail executive related a series of attempts to reach a former business associate. "I've left a stack of messages already," he said. "I'm afraid to seem like a pest."
Across the conference table, a marketing executive agreed. He noted that in his previous position, he rarely had time to offer advice to job hunters -- particularly unfamiliar individuals. "I know what it's like to have strangers demanding my time," he said. "I don't want to keep bothering a busy person, especially in this economic climate."
Nonsense, Mr. Fuller said. More and more, he believes, busy executives are making time for job-hunters' calls.
"People are curious about what it's like to be laid off, especially if they're in high-risk places like banks and advertising agencies. They don't want to hear, 'Hey, you could be next,' but they're probably thinking that," he said.
Mr. Fuller instructed the displaced executives to phone at least 10 sources each day, including three new prospects -- all of whom have been previously contacted by letter. Particularly nervous ones can use the "poker-chip strategy," stacking 10 poker chips on one side of the desk and moving them, one by one, to the other side as each new call is made. In advanced cases of phone phobia, executives might chat with a friend first, to relax on the phone.
For many, the biggest worry isn't what to say to a stranger on the phone; it's how to handle his or her secretary. Mr. Fuller suggests making calls from 8:30 to 9:30 A.M. and from 12:30 to 1:30 P.M. "That's when the secretaries aren't blocking their bosses' phones," he said. "There's a better chance you won't hit the screen."
Other communications experts advise different tactics. "Don't try to sneak around the secretary; make her your friend," said Ms. Wendleton. "If you keep calling, sooner or later she'll get her boss out of a meeting to talk to you."
That may be the only way, since Ms. Wendleton warns against leaving a return number. "Tell the secretary you'll be in and out all day, and you'll have to call back. That way you won't feel rejected," she said.
Of course, telephone phobia isn't a one-way street. John Connellan, president of the Executive Technique, a Chicago counseling firm, finds stress at both ends of the wire. "Out-of-work executives may be frustrated at making calls, but think about the people at the other end who receive them," he said. "They can be stuck on the phone for hours. It's hard on them, too."

HEADLINE: 71 Billionaires On Forbes List

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The recession hurt some of America's wealthiest people, but most kept getting richer.
A record 71 billionaires populate Forbes magazine's 10th-annual ranking of the richest, up from 66 last year and up from 13 in the magazine's first ranking in 1982. And the net worth of the 400 wealthiest Americans reached $288 billion -- the highest ever recorded by Forbes. The list, released yesterday, appears in the magazine's Oct. 21 issue. 
 Forbes said John Werner Kluge, the founder of the Metromedia Company, is worth more than any other American for the third straight year. At an estimated $5.9 billion, his worth is up $300 million from last year, the magazine said. But William H. Gates 3d, the founder of the Microsoft Corporation, moved up from 16th to second place and is closing the gap. His estimated worth is $4.8 billion, Forbes said.
The recession took its toll on some, mostly in real estate, including Peter S. Kalikow of New York, who filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, and Harold Brown of Boston, who restructured debt after a Chapter 11 filing.
"Since 1989 the economy has slowed -- for blacks, for whites, for rich, for poor," Forbes said in an essay. "The median net worth of the Forbes 400 has stagnated since 1989, not even keeping pace with inflation."
While the inflation rate may be important for a factory worker with a family of four, cost-of-living increases are not as essential for people with a net worth of $275 million -- the bottom on Forbes's list and $15 million more than the lowest ranking last year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Magazine Publishers Get Some Answers

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAPLES, Fla., Oct. 6

 BODY:
A new marketing survey of consumer attitudes may not solve the problems of dispirited magazine executives, but it will surely cause talk at the annual American Magazine Conference being held here amid the lush mangroves of the Ritz-Carlton hotel.
The report, which will be released on Wednesday, has some striking findings, among them: that readers are less preoccupied with health and fitness; that their idea of status has more to do with being in control of one's life than with having expensive possessions, and that their concern about the environment, which had been intensifying since the mid-1980's, has fallen off somewhat. 
 "People's needs and desires have changed," said Robert S. Shulman, president and chief executive of the marketing and social research firm Yankelovich Clancy Shulman, which conducted the study. "If marketers think all they have to do is turn up the dial on what they were doing in the 80's, they won't succeed."
 
A Profound Change in Attitude
 The report, commissioned by the Magazine Publishers of America, is a spinoff of the Yankelovich Monitor, an annual survey based on two-hour interviews with 2,500 people.
Mr. Shulman ascribes the end of the frenzy of the 1980's and the striking decline in consumer spending not to the recession but to a profound shift in people's values. His interviewers, he said, began to notice this change about five years ago, well before the economy began to decline
And everyone knows that much to their loudly proclaimed dismay, baby boomers are aging. Since they are the largest group in the population, whatever they do sets a trend.
"You naturally think more conservatively as you grow older and you are not in the mode of taking so many risks," said Paul Benjou, president of the media management firm Group One Communications.
Mr. Benjou said that in response to shifting priorities, marketers were becoming more involved in education and in special community projects.
 
Saying Is One Thing
 But as the Yankelovich report points out, what people say and what people do do not necessarily jibe. For instance, interviewees were given a list of "things that people have said worry them about their health and staying fit," and they were asked to say which ones bothered them. Answers seemed to indicate that the health and fitness craze was still in full flower.
The most worrisome concerns, according to the responses, were: maintaining the right weight, listed by 53 percent of the respondents; eating a balanced diet, 43 percent, and watching blood pressure, 30 percent.
When asked, however, whether in the last year they had actually kept to a healthier diet on a regular basis, only 26 percent of the men and 38 percent of the women said yes, down from 35 percent and 45 percent, respectively, for 1990. And asked if when they went out for dinner they ate what they wanted and did not worry about nutrition, 63 percent said yes, up from 59 percent last year.
 
'Tuckered Out' on Health
 "People were once very obsessed about their health, but they have gotten tuckered out," Mr. Shulman said.
As for the question about status, it should be instructive for magazine editors and advertisers alike. In recent years when asked what signaled status in their lives, consumers reported "traveling for pleasure" as the No. 1 status symbol. This year, travel came in fourth, with 52 percent of the respondents saying it was the best way to impress friends. Travel was topped by three new categories offered for the first time this year: "being satisfied with your life," which 63 percent said was the most important; "being able to afford the things that are important," 57 percent, and "being in control of your life," 57 percent.
As for the environment, concern had been found to have grown steadily since 1986, when 16 percent of the respondents expressed interest in it. By 1990, it had become of concern to 29 percent. This year, that figure dropped to 24 percent, its first decline in five years.
Researchers said that because of the intensive media focus on the issue and because so many environmental practices like recycling were actually occurring, people had been lulled into thinking they could relax. Nonetheless, a strong interest was expressed in choosing brands that make an effort to solve environmental problems.
 
Magazine Readers as a Group
 While the report drew on the general Yankelovich Monitor data, it also separated out magazine readers as a group and compared them with the overall respondents. Magazine readers were defined as people who read at least five magazines regularly. On the whole the reader group expressed more interest in shopping and in actively finding new products than the general respondents did, a finding the industry will certainly not fail to point out to its skittish advertisers.
The sample had a margin of error of 1.3 percent to 2.2 percent, depending on how many people answered the particular question.
At least one of the survey's findings should cheer magazine executives. Deep in the hearts of all publishers and advertisers is a yearning to view the world as a happy place where people leaf eagerly through magazines and rush out to buy the products they read about. Asked to describe their state of mind, only 9 percent of the regular magazine readers checked "not too happy," while 55 percent answered "pretty happy," and a whopping 36 percent "very happy."

(Source: Yankelovich Clancy Shulman)

HEADLINE: Lending When Bankers Won't

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Earlier this year, John Donovan, chairman of BMI Inc., a Summit, N.J., importer and distributor of door parts for buildings, needed to find a lender. Security Pacific Bank of Los Angeles, which had been his banker for six years, "made it clear that they did not want our business," he said, "not because of our creditworthiness but because they were cutting back on lots of companies our size."
Mr. Donovan, whose company has annual sales of about $10 million, tried the local New Jersey banks. But "they were so involved with the regulators," he said, "that they did not want to hear from me" unless he made a deposit equal to the credit line. 
 Snubbed by the banks, Mr. Donovan found the credit he wanted at MTB Banking Corporation, a New York-based financial company that makes loans but is not a traditional bank, since its deposits are not insured and it lacks direct access to a system for clearing checks and electronic money transfers.
 
Lower Rates Have Not Helped
 Stories like Mr. Donovan's are increasingly common, according to officials at commercial finance companies.
Although Washington policy makers are trying to encourage responsible lending to help stimulate the economy, the cutback in bank loans is widely cited as a cause of the recession and the anemic recovery. The Federal Reserve Board's moves to bring down interest rates have helped lower the prime lending rate to 8 percent, down from 10.5 percent at the beginning of 1990, but have not stimulated more lending by banks.
While bankers say they are not making loans because demand is low, commercial finance executives report unusually strong demand from business borrowers, despite the fact that the finance companies generally charge higher interest rates and fees than banks.
From the beginning of 1990 to the end of July this year, loans by finance companies to business increased by $41.2 billion, or 15.9 percent, to $300.2 billion. During the same period, business loans by American banks fell by $31.9 billion, or 6.2 percent, to $480.6 billion, according to Federal Reserve data.
The increase by finance companies "would have been even greater, except that some of the commercial finance firms owned by bank holding companies were instructed to keep volume down" said Leonard Machlis, executive director of the National Commercial Finance Association in New York.
Anthony K. Brown, a managing director of the Trading Alliance Corporation in New York, a commercial finance company, said, "There are lots of companies out there that have a solid business, but do not have the track record that satisfies banks." And, he added, "without financing, those companies have a hard time growing to a point where they will ever qualify for bank loans."
Mr. Brown, who founded Trading Alliance in 1988 along with two other former bankers from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said that many large banks "have not learned the new rules of commerce, where it is the buyers and sellers of products who need credit."
Manufacturing companies, with whom the banks traditionally were most familiar, are often located overseas these days or in another part of the country far removed from the bank's local market, Mr. Brown said. But banks, he said, still seem uncomfortable lending money to the middlemen who increasingly are becoming their potential customers for loans.
For example, David Engel, president of Trendsellers Ltd., of Stamford, Conn., obtained orders from major merchants including Wal-Mart Stores and Caldor for backpacks and bags he wanted to import from China. But Mr. Engel found that no bank would provide the letters of credit he needed to pay the Chinese manufacturer. And since the goods had not yet been shipped to the department store buyers, there was no account receivable to offer as collateral for a loan.
But Trading Alliance recognized that the purchase orders from major discount stores were valuable, and provided Trendsellers with the letter of credit needed to import the goods. To protect itself from loss, Trading Alliance is overseeing the shipment of the goods, which it would seize if Mr. Engel's deal fell apart.
For their part, bankers attribute the decline in loans to weak demand from borrowers. "Our credit standards have not changed, and I still want to make as many loans as possible," said Frank Lourenso, an executive vice president at Chemical Bank who is in charge of lending to small and medium-sized businesses.
 "What has changed from a few years ago," he said, "is the condition of our customers and the economy, not our lending standards." Stepping up the level of bank loans in a weak economy, Mr. Lourenso said, is difficult because businesses cut back on inventories and borrowing.
Because most of Chemical's loans to businesses are unsecured, which means that they are not backed by assets like inventory or accounts receivable, Mr. Lourenso noted that there is always room for commercial finance companies to gain business by making secured loans to companies whose financial condition has weakened, but that are willing to put up collateral and pay the high rates charged by nonbank lenders.
As lawmakers wonder why the economy is not recovering more speedily, they have not been satisfied by bankers' claims of weak loan demand. Instead, they have preferred to criticize banking regulators for imposing tougher capital standards and for encouraging bank examiners to be more zealous in identifying bad loans and forcing banks to recognize the losses that result from those loans.
 
Choosing to Be Smaller <HE
Regulators' demands that banks strengthen their financial condition have caused some banks to scale back on new lending in order to become smaller. In that way, a bank's capital cushion for absorbing unanticipated losses is a larger percentage of its remaining loans.
Fearing a major pullback in bank lending, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said in May that the time was not right for the Fed to push for increases in the minimum capital requirements imposed on banks. But his comments have not lessened the drive at many banks to improve their capital cushions. Even though all but a few of the nation's large banks already meet the minimum capital requirements set for the end of 1992, bankers know that they must have more than the minumum capital if they want permission to make acquisitions and enter new businesses.
 
Banks Under More Scrutiny
 Regulators say that examiners are merely following good business practice. Recognizing bad loans, even if doing so results in a loss to the bank, is a way of insuring that banks do not continue making unsound loans.
"The banks have a lot more people looking over their shoulder than commercial finance companies, so we can be more liberal in the type of transactions we do compared to the banks," said Howard Krollfeifer Jr., a senior vice president at the A.T.& T. Commercial Finance Corporation, a Morristown, N.J., unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
A recently published study by the New York Federal Reserve Bank concluded that the leading cause of the drop in bank lending to business last year was the heavy losses some banks suffered from their commercial real estate lending, followed by weak capital.
The sharpest declines in business lending, the study found, occurred at banks with the most exposure to bad real estate loans and with the weakest capital. Those two problems were especially powerful forces for cutting back lending in the Northeastern and Middle Atlantic states, where the economy has been weakest, the study said.
Frederic Tordella, president of MTB Banking, noted that as banks tried to improve profits by cutting expenses, they had helped newcomers to the lending business quickly gain expertise. In laying off experienced loan officers, banks have "made the job of finding quality people in the lending field a piece of cake," he said of his company, a dealer in precious metals and foreign currency, which became active in the finance business about three years ago.
Mr. Tordella said the availability of experienced lending officers is one reason, Mr. Tordella said, that MTB, which has $26 million of capital and can lend up to $2 million to a single borrower, is putting more emphasis on its corporate finance business and less on other activities like gold trading and electronic funds transfers overseas.

HEADLINE: A Split Over Machine Tool Imports

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
For decades, machine tools have been regarded as a mundane but crucial industry, often figuring in American military and trade politics. They are the behind-the-scenes workhorses of an industrial economy, used for cutting, grinding and boring all sorts of products, including armaments.
In both World Wars, machine tools were officially earmarked for hurry-up production, regarded as vital to wartime mobilization. And in the 1980's, the decline of the domestic machine tool industry was seen as a symbol of both the plight of American manufacturing and Japan's export offensive. 
 Today, the industry is once again at the center of a debate that touches on the larger issues of trade policy and national security. The Bush Administration must soon decide whether to push to extend a five-year-old program of restraints on imported machine tools. And it promises to be a tough choice this time because of the growing complexity of global trade patterns and the recent changes in the geopolitics of national security.
 
Renewal Is Uncertain
 The Commerce Department is expected to make a recommendation within days on whether to renew the five-year program of restraints, which expires at the end of this year. The department's recommendation -- expected to be a call for renewal -- will then be reviewed by the Administration after consulting with other agencies, including the Defense Department and the United States trade representative's office. The outcome of that review is by no means certain, according to Administration officials.
The advocates and opponents of import restrictions no longer line up in neat camps. A handful of America's most competitive machine tool makers, for example, want the protections for domestic producers dismantled because they have had the curious effect of protecting Japanese market share and driving up the costs for many American producers.
One problem with the complex system of import curbs, they note, is that it defines an American machine by how much of the rudimentary cast-iron components are American-made but ignores the computer controls, which represent more and more of the cost of a modern machine tool. The largest supplier of such controls is a Japanese company, Fanuc Ltd.
So the free-traders say that those who favor restraints are taking a backward-looking "Maginot Line" approach to international competition. "The people who want to maintain the restraints are trying to fight a war that is already over," said Brian McLaughlin, president of Hurco Companies, an Indianapolis machine tool producer. "Protectionism doesn't work. The only way to revive this industry is to focus on research and development, to develop leading-edge technology and to compete globally."
For their part, the Japanese, who were the main targets of the curbs, are officially silent on the matter but would be happy to see the restraints renewed. The so-called voluntary restraint agreement serves to freeze Japan's large share of the American market, while restricting the advance of up-and-coming rivals like Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore.
 
A Different World
 National security calculations today are also far different than when the Reagan Administration prodded Japan and Taiwan into the voluntary restraint agreement in 1986. Back then, the United States reasoned that it should not depend on foreigners for machine tools to make parts for missiles and bombs.
But those were still the "evil empire" days, when the Soviet military threat meant just that and before the Berlin wall had been torn down. "All these national security arguments have been deflated enormously because of recent events," said Gary C. Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Most companies in the machine-tool industry and 200 members of Congress eager to protect jobs back home insist that the national security argument still holds. "National security is pre-eminent to commerce," said James Mack, the vice president for government relations at the Association for Manufacturing Technology, the industry's trade group.
The pure free-traders, Mr. Mack said, "want this country to be the Blanche DuBois of international trade politics -- always dependent on the kindness of strangers," in a reference to the faded Southern belle of Tennessee Williams's "A Streetcar Named Desire."
The restraint agreement allowed the Japanese producers to hold more than 50 percent of crucial machine tool markets like computerized lathes and machining centers, while warning other countries that they would be slapped with penalties if they rushed to increase their sales in the United States. The Taiwanese were pressured to join the agreement, partly to make it seem that the Japanese alone were not being punished.
Opponents of renewal argue that the restraint pact has increased their costs by forcing them to buy more expensive domestic-made components, irritated overseas buyers and had the "perverse" effect of protecting the Japanese producers since their share of the market was calculated when the yen was cheap and imports at a peak.
Yet the experience at Hurco, based in Indianapolis, shows the costs of the voluntary restraint agreement on one high-technology machine-tool maker. With sales of about $100 million a year, Hurco is a company that revived in the late-1980's by investing in research on computer controls and software, increasing productivity and moving aggressively into foreign markets. More than half of its sales are now overseas, including East Asia.
At Hurco, Mr. McLaughlin estimated that the restraint agreement had forced his company to increase its cost of making a machine tool by more than 10 percent. He said the company it was forced to buy more expensive components domestically, like the cast-iron base and housings on machine tools, instead of buying less expensive ones from Taiwan, Singapore and South Korea. The additional cost in one of the cheaper $70,000 machines would be roughly $7,000, according to Mr. McLaughlin.
Hurco was also forced to invest $6 million in new patterns and in establishing new sources of supply for machined cast-iron parts so they could qualify as American machines under the restraint accord. That money, Mr. McLaughlin said, would have otherwise been invested in research on the computer controls and software that are Hurco's competitive forte.
The import restraints brand the United States as protectionist and thus can make selling overseas more difficult for American companies, according to Ray Blakeman, the chairman of the Met-Coil Systems Corporation, a Cedar Rapids, Iowa, company that has a joint venture in Japan and a sales office in Taiwan.
Mr. Blakeman, a former president of the machine tool trade association, wrote to its board in August to protest the group's support for an extension of the agreement. "We are riding a mule that is crippled and should be out to pasture," he wrote.
 
Plea for More Time
 Yet the proponents of continuing the import curbs say the agreement has safeguarded the domestic industry, allowing it to increase investment. An extension of three to five years, they add, would give the domestic industry the time it needs to regain competitiveness. The industry's revenues have increased slightly since 1986 to an estimated $2.9 billion this year, while employment has declined more than 8,000 people, to 60,150.
At K. T. Swasey, a machine tool maker in Milwaukee, Winthrop Cody says the import curbs helped give his company the breathing space it needed to invest heavily in computer-aided design equipment and training for engineers. He estimated that the productivity of his operations increased 25 percent in the last four years.
Without the import curbs, "countries like Japan and Taiwan would take even more of our market because they will cut prices to gain market share regardless of the cost," said Mr. Cody, president of Swasey, which is a subsidiary of the Cross & Trecker Corporation.
Economists and trade experts have generally scorned the use of voluntary restraint agreements in industries including autos, specialty steel, textiles and ball bearings as costly to consumers and of little genuine help to the protected industries. At best, the curbs may temporarily slow the shrinkage of a domestic industry and encourage foreign producers to set up factories in the protected country to sidestep the barriers. Indeed, the Japanese machine tool companies including Mazak, Okuma, Toyoda and Amada now have plants in the United States.
The real hope for the future of the American machine tool makers, some experts say, is to increase their competitiveness in their basic businesses and band together to develop new computer-controls technology to leapfrog the Japanese and other rivals.
A few such joint research efforts are under way. For example, a next-generation controller program, supported by $20 million from companies, the Air Force and the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences, a research consortium in Ann Arbor, Mich., was begun in 1988. "That effort could have a monumental impact on American manufacturing," said Ed Miller, president of the center. "But it's not going to have an effect today or tomorrow."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Protectionism doesn't work," says Brian McLaughlin, president of Hurco Companies, an Indianapolis machine tool producer. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New Focus On Decline Of Inflation

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
In fretful economic times, people often talk as if the only thing standing between the United States economy and permanent stagnation is the Federal Reserve's next move to trim short-term interest rates. But now, some economists contend, declines in inflation and long-term interest rates may be even more powerful stimulants for growth.
Lower long-term rates reduce the debt burdens of businesses and consumers, making it easier for families to buy homes and allowing companies to invest more in new technology. 
 "Nothing would be more helpful to the sub-par economic recovery than a sizable reduction in long rates," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns, the New York investment firm. And nothing, he might have added, would make a reduction in long-term rates more likely than solid prospects for lower inflation.
 
Expectations a Key
 Unlike short-term rates, over which the Fed exercises some control, long-term rates rise and fall with investors' expectations of future inflation and future demand for credit.
True, long-term rates can follow short-term rates lower when the Fed eases credit, if only because investors in short-term securities seek higher yields in longer-term maturities. But the extent to which long-term rates actually decline greatly depends on the confidence of savers in the soundness of their money. If people expect inflation to remain low, they are more likely to invest for the long term, helping to push down long-term rates.
The good news, reflected in the current bond rally, is that the United States, which used to have some of the highest long-term interest rates of any industrial country, is now on the low end of the spectrum.
 
Closing the Gap
 American rates on 10-year Government bonds -- the usual global yardstick, since many countries do not issue 30-year bonds -- have recently been just over 7 percent, compared with more than 8 percent in Germany and more than 9 percent in Britain.
Although Japan still has lower rates, at around 6 percent, the gap between Japanese and American rates has narrowed from more than 400 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, a few years ago.
This welcome decrease in the cost of capital mostly reflects the fact that the United States, once the most notable high-inflation country among the industrial powers, has joined the low-inflation crowd. So far in 1991, the Consumer Price Index has risen at a 2.5 percent annual rate, compared with 4 percent in Germany and around 3.5 percent in Japan.
Granted, a break from lower energy and food prices has pushed this year's actual inflation rate below the long-term trend. Nonetheless, a number of Fed officials, as well as many private forecasters, think the long-term rate is between 3 and 4 percent, compared with 4.5 percent in the five years leading up to the recession.
The Blue Chip consensus of 50 economists, compiled by Robert Eggert in Sedona, Ariz., which has been trimming its price forecast for a few months, sees 3.7 percent inflation in 1992. That, incidentally, is just about where the American public feels comfortable. According to a recent report by the Federal Reserve bank of San Francisco analyzing public attitudes toward inflation, Americans are intolerant of inflation when it exceeds 4 percent. New Zealanders, in contrast, grew disturbed when the rate reached 30 percent.
So far, there are plenty of signs, in addition to the slow money growth of the last four years, that suggest that inflation could remain subdued.
An index of leading inflation indicators from the Columbia University Center for International Business Cycle Research ticked up in September, but is running about 10 points below its level of two years ago.
 
Gains in Productivity
 And labor costs remain under control. The restructuring of some service industries, as well as the slow pace of overall hiring, suggest decent gains in productivity and muted pressure to raise wages.
In particular, points out Maury Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., government workers are no longer getting the higher-than-average pay raises typical of the last few years, because of state and local fiscal crises.
Actual price trends have also been encouraging. Inflation in services, far more persistent than in goods, has lately moderated in everything from rents and other housing costs to medical services.
And, as the bond rally itself suggests, inflation expectations seem on the whole to be improving. Commodity prices remain weak. And in a sign that executives do not see much inflation ahead, business appears to be determined to operate with ever-leaner inventories.
A drop in inflation in the first year or so of a recovery, it turns out, is the rule, not the exception. Even after the relatively short and shallow recession of 1969-70, which the recent downturn probably resembles most closely, inflation declined by about 1 percentage point during the recovery. Indeed, lower inflation, which reduces costs and lifts business profits and consumers' purchasing power, is one of the forces that help the economy to recover.
Should prices really stay well behaved, long-term rates could stay below 8 percent even if the economy is growing at, say, a rate of 2.5 to 3.5 percent next year. Mr. Harris said the spread between inflation and long-term rates was averaging about 400 basis points until the recession.
Besides, if investors gradually come to believe that the Fed really means what it has been saying about near-zero inflation, even that spread, which reflects the risk that inflation might be higher than expected, could narrow slowly.
In all, experts are beginning to conclude, America's improving track record on inflation may now be more important to future economic growth -- and to the bond rally -- than whether the Fed eases credit another quarter point this week.

HEADLINE: American Says Lebanon Captors Predict 'Good News'

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Terry A. Anderson, the American journalist held hostage in Lebanon since 1985, said yesterday in a videotaped interview broadcast by the Cable News Network that he had been told by his captors that "we can expect some very good news" soon.
Mr. Anderson, the Middle East bureau chief for The Associated Press, said his captors had not told him what the news would be. "I can only hope, of course, that it means some more people would be released on both sides," he said. 
 "We weren't told whether it would be me or Tom or Terry or someone else," he added, referring to the American Thomas M. Sutherland and the Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite, with whom he said he had been confined. "But I don't think that is terribly important at this moment, which one of us goes free."
Mr. Anderson, who is 43 years old, said he had no information on any of the other Western hostages in Lebanon.
CNN said said it had obtained the 12-minute videotape, made yesterday "in the Beirut area," from an independent Lebanese television production company, Al-Mashrek. The network said that it had submitted questions to be asked of Mr. Anderson, but that not all of them had been used and some had been reworded. CNN said it had not paid for the tape.
The network also showed what it said was a statement in Arabic signed by Islamic Holy War, one of the Shiite Muslim groups holding Western hostages in Lebanon. CNN said the statement characterized the tape as a continuation of the process that started with the release of John McCarthy of Britain in August. The statement said the tape was a way of "showing our hostages stating their opinions, which serves practical steps to bring an end to the hostage case," The AP reported.
Mr. Anderson, the longest-held Western hostage, called on all parties to hasten efforts to free the nine Western hostages in Lebanon in a wide release of prisoners held in the Middle East. All captives should be freed, he said, not just Westerners but also hundreds of Lebanese detainees held by Israel.
His captors may have allowed the tape to be made in part to increase pressure on Israel to release more of the prisoners it holds in southern Lebanon. Israel demands the return or an adequate accounting of Israeli servicemen missing in Lebanon.
 
U.N. Chief Praised
 Mr. Anderson, wearing a brown shirt and aviator glasses, said efforts by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations to secure the release of hostages in the Middle East "are enormously helpful."
"I can say," he added, "I think it is an absolute necessity that everyone involved in this process on both sides simply cooperate, that this is no longer the time for bargaining, that this is no longer the time for anyone to try to get some small advantage out of each step that might be coming to fruit here."
CNN delayed showing the full interview for several hours while it transcribed Mr. Anderson's words to provide subtitles across the bottom of the screen, since the audio track was poor.
 
Hears Daughter on Radio
 The network said Mr. Anderson told his unseen interviewer that he reads magazines -- he mentioned Time, Newsweek, U.S. News and World Report and The Economist -- and listens to radio broadcasts from the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation. With apparent pride, he said he had heard a radio interview with his daughter Sulome, who is now 6 and whom he has never seen.
Mr. Sutherland also heard his daughter Kit on a radio program, Mr. Anderson said. "He was amazed and impressed and didn't stop talking about it for a considerable amount of time," Mr. Anderson said.
"We have little bit of television," he added, "although most of it's inadequate. Of course, the English movies are rare."
He said his captors had treated him "with respect," adding, "We're treated as well as can be expected under these circumstances."
"Our guards do the best to make things easier on us," he said. "They give us the things we need. We get medicines when we need them."
He said he, Mr. Sutherland and Mr. Waite played chess every day.
"We talk about everything," he said. "Politics, religion. That's really been our saving, having people to talk to." He also said the food he is given was "not bad."
From parts of the interview that CNN carried early last night, it was not clear whether Mr. Anderson's captors watched from behind the camera as he was being questioned.
At one point he thanked his friends and family for "keeping the issue alive and not letting it come to a halt." Speaking to "friends and colleagues," he said: "We are grateful you haven't forgotten us. Keep up the good work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terry A. Anderson in a videotaped interview aired yesterday by the Cable News Network. (CNN via Agence France-Presse)
